SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 2; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 2155 words

HEADLINE: Debating How Best to Love Your Country;
Do You Fight Off Assaults on the System or Fight to Make the System Better?

 BODY:
Norman Podhoretz is the editor at large of Commentary magazine, a senior fellow of the Hudson Institute and the author of "My Love Affair With America," to be published on Tuesday. Victor Navasky is the publisher and editorial director of The Nation, the Delacorte professor of magazine journalism at Columbia University and the author of "Naming Names," a study of the Hollywood blacklist. For many years they have disagreed, often vehemently, about the issues that shape American life. For this Fourth of July weekend, The New York Times asked them to discuss patriotism. The moderator of the discussion was Barry Gewen, the editor of Arts & Ideas and an editor in the Book Review of The Times.
Q. Norman, you begin your new book, "My Love Affair With America," with the quotation from Samuel Johnson: "Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel." This is probably the single most famous quote about patriotism, and it prompts the question: Has patriotism gone out of style? 
 PODHORETZ. Well, I think Johnson was wrong and this was a most uncharacteristic remark for him, a fervent Tory, to have made, since conservatives, generally in Europe anyway, had been associated with patriotic sentiment and the nationalist sentiment.
Has patriotism gone out of style in America? The answer is certainly yes, as of very recently. But my own feeling is that it's slowly coming back. We see signs of this resurgence of patriotic sentiment in various sectors of the culture. The most salient, I suppose, would be the enormous success of Tom Brokaw's two books on the World War II generation. I think the success of a movie like "Saving Private Ryan" is another sign, a sign of a new respect for the kind of virtues that were traditionally associated with patriotism or love of country.
NAVASKY. Well, about Samuel Johnson: Ambrose Bierce had an amendment to Johnson. I think he said, "I beg to submit, sir, it is the first." In other words, patriotism is not the last refuge of scoundrels, it's the first.
I don't agree with that. But I think it depends what your definition of patriotism is. I would suggest that in the Vietnam era the people who were protesting the war included a large number of patriots. My definition of patriotism would involve fighting to make sure your country lives up to its highest ideals. And from that perspective even those who burn the flag -- not all of them but some of them -- may have been as patriotic as those who wrapped themselves in the flag.
So the word may be coming back in some way, but the struggles to make America the best it can be have been going on, it seems to me, since the Revolutionary War.
PODHORETZ. I would like to take issue with the definition that Victor is offering. To define American patriotism as struggling to make the country live up to its best ideals has in practice generally meant denigrating the country for not doing so. The ideal is very often the enemy of the real.
The conditions under which Americans have actually lived in one generation or another is the country that one either loves or does not love. One can be critical of the country while loving it, just as one can be critical of one's wife or husband or lover in personal life. But I would submit that the people who burned the flag during the Vietnam War or people who spelled the name of the country with a K to suggest an association with Nazi Germany or people who saw no difference between America and the Soviet Union during the cold war, morally or politically, were not patriots.
NAVASKY. I guess I don't pretend to know the motives of the folks who chose the burning of the flag as their way of protesting the Vietnam War, but I do know that going back to the beginning of our history, and right up through the abolitionist movement and the movement for labor rights in the 1920's and 30's and the movement for civil rights in the 60's, those people who fought to achieve the American dream of equal rights for all were scorned at the time as, in effect, unpatriotic and later on as Communists.
Q. Let me ask Victor a question about patriotism and liberals and the left. In the period around World War II, there was no embarrassment on the left about engaging in traditional patriotic activities -- flag waving, Fourth of July celebrations -- but these symbols of patriotism seem to have disappeared from the left. Do those symbols now totally belong to conservatives and the right, or does the left have some call to them also?
NAVASKY. Sure, there was a shared symbology that went across the ideological board. Irving Kristol has written an essay, which Norman cites in his book, where he said that there is a holy trinity associated with American patriotism and it includes the Constitution, the Declaration of Independence and the flag. I would say two out of three isn't bad. To me, the authentic symbols of our country start with the covenants, the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution. The flag is important only for the principles that it represents.
Q. Next question: is there a good patriotism and a bad patriotism?
PODHORETZ. Yes, though my own view is that patriotism has been so ridiculed and has been so out of fashion that spiritual and moral balance require an emphasis on patriotism as a good thing. I mean, most people would say that when patriotism becomes chauvinistic or jingoistic or even simply nationalistic, it becomes aggressive and dangerous. But the heritage that we fight for is not merely one of rectifying wrongs of the past, such as slavery or discrimination, and trying to create conditions that are more in consonance with what is promulgated, both in the Declaration and the Constitution; it's also to fight off assaults on the system of government that was designed by the Founding Fathers.
Q. Victor, is there a good patriotism and a bad patriotism?
NAVASKY. Stephen Decatur, who said, "Our country right or wrong," said first, "May she always be in the right." And that's a good part of patriotism -- to fight to have your country be in the right. A destructive part of patriotism is when it slips into a kind of nationalism which makes you hate other countries, put your country's interests first when you think it's behaving in an immoral and unjust way. So that confusing patriotism with unconditional support for a government policy, it seems to me, does damage, and core damage, to the meaning of citizenship in our democracy.
PODHORETZ. But to denigrate the country, to call it foul names, to desecrate its symbols, should not be given the name of patriotism. People who want to do that are free to do that in this country. But I don't think they ought to then wrap themselves in the flag that they've just burned.
NAVASKY. When Frederick Douglass made his famous speech where he said that freedom requires rain and thunder and lightning, what he was talking about was that you have to do a lot of nasty and uncomfortable things to bring the plight of folks who don't have freedom to the national attention. And that is a part of a patriotic America-loving act. It's not an America-hating act to try to bring the African-American community to its entitlement.
PODHORETZ. In the civil rights movement, the early civil rights movement in the late 50's and early 60's, the most effective means blacks employed happened to be not nasty, whatever, but nonviolent resistance. Which was perceived by everybody in this country as noble and admirable and which made the sheriffs who were attacking them with water hoses look ignoble and evil. So I don't agree that nasty things necessarily have to be done.
Q. A great deal of the historical scholarship of the last few decades has examined and brought to light the negative aspects of American history -- slavery, the treatment of American Indians, the detention of Japanese Americans during World War II. How do we fit these negative aspects of American history into education programs for our children?
PODHORETZ. Well, I think they have to be faced up to honestly. Children have to be taught that these things happened. They also have to be taught that many -- in fact, I think all of the ones you mentioned -- were acted upon, were corrected. And that they were corrected through the resources of the American constitutional and institutional structure.
It's very important to teach children that the history of this country is on the whole a glorious one, not an inglorious one. That this is a country to be proud of, including for the way it has dealt with what I would say are the inevitable blemishes and warts. I think that we as a socio-political-economic system rank with such great civilizations of the past as fifth-century Athens and Elizabethan England. Not, as I say in my book, in the production of artistic monuments, though we haven't done so badly in that department either, but in the provision of more liberty and more prosperity to more people than has existed anywhere else on earth, whether present or past. And this, too, has to be taught to our children and should be emphasized.
NAVASKY. I think the way you teach the abolitionists, for instance, is that you make clear that, in terms of your own values, the abolitionists were greater patriots than the plantation owners against whom they were fighting. That the folks who were organizing the workers, in my judgment, were greater patriots than the mine and mill owners who were exploiting them. That the real patriots during the Vietnam War were the folks who resisted it. And the patriots during the civil rights movement were indeed, as Norman said, the folks who adopted passive resistance. And it worked to a degree there.
PODHORETZ. I have nothing against the abolitionists, but I would say that my hero in the Civil War is not John Brown but Abraham Lincoln. They were very different and they were not on the same side. And it makes a big difference whether you think it's Abraham Lincoln who should be celebrated or John Brown.
NAVASKY. I think they both should be celebrated, as should Frederick Douglass.
PODHORETZ. Well, I agree with you about him.
Q. What impact, if any, has multiculturalism had on our idea of patriotism?
NAVASKY. I think it requires a revision to this classic notion of my country right or wrong, first of all, depending on when your own group became part of the tradition and entitled to the rights that other folks got.
Secondly, I think the real contribution of multiculturalism to our culture today is the right of people to establish their own identities and define their own identities.
And thirdly, multiculturalism suggests that we have a series of competing allegiances. One of them is love of family. A second is love of tribe or culture or whatever it is. A third is love of country. And a fourth is one's relationship to the international community. And it seems to me the most valuable kind of patriotism is one which honors the other relationships rather than competes against them.
PODHORETZ. Well, here we go again. I think multiculturalism is a perversion of the traditional American idea of pluralism. The ideal was that in the public sphere -- in the public schools -- the rule of assimilation prevailed. That is, if an immigrant came to this country, he was expected -- and, indeed, wished -- to learn English and to absorb the traditions of his new country, to become an American, to be Americanized. Nothing prevented that individual from remaining loyal, within the private sphere, to the tribe and the family. You were free as an individual to live in both worlds if you chose. But what you were not free to do was to refuse to assimilate to the culture of this country. Nobody was going to arrest you or anything of that sort, but you would certainly limit your opportunities for employment, for advancement and for participation, including civic participation.
I think that multiculturalism doesn't so much help to give people the power to define their own identities as it keeps them apart from the rest of the community. So I think it's a bad thing and I think it is not -- does not -- contribute to a healthy patriotism.
Q. Now each of you, if you want, can take a minute or two to say something in summary. Norman?
PODHORETZ. Yeah, why not. I'll take a crack at it.
I think intellectual honesty requires us to recognize that we have emerged from a period during which America-bashing, as some call it, or denigration of America, has prevailed, particularly among intellectuals, not so much among most people, but among the elites. I believe this has begun to change. I hope it has begun to change.
NAVASKY. I guess patriotism is best expressed in the struggle to make this a better place. And it is not best expressed in saluting the flag or in parades down Fifth Avenue but in writing, in marching, in suing, in voting, in going to court, whatever it takes to fulfill the promise of the Bill of Rights.

HEADLINE: Encyclopedia Raises Veil On Ancient Saudi Culture

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
In a culture of silence, words can be weapons. In perhaps no contemporary state has the written word proved more threatening than in Saudi Arabia, where sins, sources of shame and sometimes even accomplishments tend to be hidden away.
So it was with a determined lack of fanfare nearly a decade ago that Prince Khaled bin Sultan, the Saudi media baron and former co-commander of the military coalition against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, opened a front in the cultural war against silence in his country, even as he prepared to lead the multinational forces into battle to free Kuwait. 
 In September 1990, the prince quietly agreed to finance an ambitious project by a group of Saudi scholars to document the country's rich cultural heritage and traditions before they disappeared. Ten years and several million dollars later, the Encyclopedia of Folklore of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, a 12-volume, Arabic-language compendium of a vanishing way of life, has just been printed in Belgium. Its authors say that the series, which includes 5,000 drawings, illustrations and graphs, is the largest body of secular scholarship ever produced in Saudi Arabia. It includes separate volumes on topics like historical and archaeological sites, traditional medicine, geography, even children's games. And there is an entire volume devoted to the camel.
While Prince Khaled said he had contemplated such a project for two years before the gulf war, the conflict was the project's main catalyst. "The widespread ignorance of Saudi Arabia and its cultural heritage, not just among foreigners but among younger Saudis made me determined to try and document and preserve our traditions before it was too late," he said in a telephone interview.
Thanks to oil wealth, lifestyles have changed faster and more dramatically in Saudi Arabia than in almost any other country. Fifty-year-old Saudis can recall baked-mud hovels, with neither electricity nor running water, in which most of them were raised, but young Saudis today can barely imagine life without the Internet, cellular telephones, vacations abroad, air-conditioned suburban homes, sport utility vehicles and fancy shopping malls. Few have ever even ridden a camel.
Yet Saudi contributors to the volumes say that a work of this nature could probably not have been undertaken as long as tribal and regional divisions continued to plague the kingdom. Oil wealth has helped unify Saudis politically and culturally, said Sa'ad al-Sowayan, an anthropologist with a doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley and the encyclopedia's chief editor. Until Saudis spoke the same Arabic dialect and tribal and regional cultural differences diminished, a project examining the country's heritage would have been too contentious to be approved by the censors.
In addition, he observed, until recently many Saudi scholars viewed folk culture as academically dubious. They believed that attention to traditional ways of life emphasized backwardness. But after the gulf war, Mr. Sowayan said, "people realized that our old civilization was dying out, and that we had a limited window to capture what was being lost, mostly through memory. It gave us a renewed sense of urgency."
Some 75 leading Saudi scholars and writers contributed to the encyclopedia. Their texts were then vetted by older, often uneducated Saudis who still remembered many of the nearly extinct customs.
Consider the 547-page volume on the camel. The volume notes that it was the domestication of this amazingly adaptive, aggressive, often crotchety creature that made Bedouin nomadic life possible. Saudis rarely tired of extolling the camel's endurance, forbearance, fortitude and other virtues in chants, conversation, lore and song.
Bedouin poetry likens the swishing of the camel's tail to the swaying of the unbraided plaits of a beautiful young woman dancing on her wedding night. Without the camel, Mr. Sowayan said, nearly a third of the Arabic language would disappear.
Legend has it that the Arabs stole camels from the Jews. Because in Saudi lore the Jews are said to be still longing for their animals, the Bedouins describe any false hope by likening it to the hope of the Jews for the camels' return.
Ultimately, the volume asserts, the camel was superseded as the major symbol of Arabia by the palm tree, the emblem of the sedentary farmers, merchants and traders who were the Muslim prophet Muhammad's first and most enduring followers.
This community, which loathed and feared the warring Bedouins, imposed its written, settled culture on nomadic culture, said Abdulaziz Fahad, a lawyer and an early champion of the project. As a result, Saudi society remains deeply ambivalent about the desert and the traditional Bedouin life.
Some of that traditional culture has already vanished beyond memory and retrieval. The encyclopedia, for instance, includes no volumes on folk songs or traditional dancing because Mr. Sowayan could not find qualified authorities to write them. Nor is there a volume on Islam or any of Arabia's pre-Islamic religions. Religion is not folk culture, he asserted.
Still, the volumes may stir controversy among some of the kingdom's more rigid, literal-minded clerics.
As one contributor said, conservatives won't like the discussions of "un-Islamic" traditions and beliefs, or the books' many representational photographs and drawings, which they say are prohibited by Islam.
But so far, the encyclopedia has had no problem winning official blessing.
Because the Saudi government decided some two decades ago that any genuine encyclopedia would not be censored, the Ministry of Information, which routinely blacks out with felt-tipped pens magazine photographs considered too licentious, approved the encyclopedia with its pictures and drawings in less than 10 days.
"This work will not only help us preserve our vanishing past, but by examining the past, will emphasize our new cultural and political unity," Mr. Sowayan said. "In that sense, it is a truly nationalist project."

HEADLINE: Slight Rise In Spending By Consumers

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Americans, whose buying binges have powered economic growth, spent cautiously in May for the second consecutive month, another tentative sign that the robust economy might be slowing.
Consumer spending rose by just 0.2 percent in both April and May, the Commerce Department said today. Personal spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity. 
 The spending increase in May matched many analysts' expectations. The figure for April was revised down from an increase of 0.4 percent.
"It appears as if there really is some caution developing in the spending habits of consumers," said Joel Naroff, an economist at Naroff Economic Advisers.
The latest report also showed that Americans' spending on durable goods -- like cars and other costly manufactured goods expected to last at least three years -- fell 1 percent in May. That followed a drop of 0.7 percent the month before.
"Consumers are rediscovering the virtues of thrift, at least for a couple of months," said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Spending on nondurable goods, like food and fuel, rose a slim 0.2 percent after a decline of 0.2 percent in April.
Americans' incomes, which include wages, interest and government benefits, rose 0.4 percent in May, slightly faster than the gain of 0.3 percent that many analysts were forecasting.
In April, incomes rose 0.6 percent, a little slower than the government previously thought.
The personal savings rate -- savings as a percentage of after-tax income -- rose to 0.6 percent in May from 0.4 percent the month before. May's rate was the highest since 0.8 percent in January.
Other recent economic data suggests that the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases are working to slow the economy, economists said. The unemployment rate rose to 4.1 percent in May from a 30-year low of 3.9 percent in April. Economists said people might feel less inclined to spend if they were not working. And retail sales were lackluster in April and May.
But another report today offered a conflicting sign on where the economy is headed.
The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said its index of business activity in the Midwest rose to a higher-than-expected 56.8 in June, from 53.9 in May. A reading above 50 indicates expansion in the manufacturing sector. Analysts had expected a decline.
The Chicago report is considered a precursor of the closely watched national purchasing managers report, due out Monday.

HEADLINE: Downturn in Underwriting As Markets Show Volatility

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
On Wall Street, the second quarter roared in like a wildfire then fizzled to a campfire.
A sharp downturn in the Nasdaq stock market in April doused the market for new issues of stock that had been strong in the first quarter. By late June, dozens of companies had shelved plans to go public, and some that tested the market were sorely disappointed. And rising interest rates depressed the market for all sorts of new corporate bonds, especially junk bonds, which are issued by companies with poor credit ratings. 
 All told, the amount of money raised in the United States by investment banks -- $451 billion -- was down 24 percent from the second quarter of 1999. The total of stock and bond offerings in American markets fell to 3,823 in the second quarter from 5,047 in the second quarter of 1999. Measured by money raised in the United States capital markets, last quarter ranked eighth, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data in Newark.
The slump hit investment banks just as they were rushing to hire new bankers and were raising pay and improving benefits to keep their employees from leaving for Internet start-ups. Disclosed fees for underwriting new issues sank about 45 percent, to $2.64 billion, from $4.8 billion in the first quarter of 2000, and about 20 percent from $3.29 billion in the second quarter of 1999.
"The first quarter was as heady a market as we'd ever seen," said Jeff Edwards, co-head of stock capital markets at Merrill Lynch & Company. But after the stock market swooned in mid-April, he said, "there was a general pullback of all investors, retail and institutional."
Despite the newfound reluctance of investors to buy shares of untested companies, underwriters managed to float some landmark new issues. Most notable was the $10.6 billion spinoff of shares in AT&T Wireless, the biggest initial offering by an American company.
The $9 billion of that total raised in the United States accounted for more than one-third of the $24.5 billion raised through first-time stock offerings in the quarter and it accounted for the bulk of the initial offering proceeds raised by two of the biggest investment banks, Merrill Lynch and the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. Each of those firms was a lead manager, along with the Goldman Sachs Group, of the AT&T Wireless offering, and received credit for one-third of the United States proceeds, or about $3 billion.
Aside from that deal, Merrill raised about $900 million in initial offerings and Salomon raised about $750 million, according to Securities Data.
An initial offering is the most lucrative type of underwriting, leaving investment banks with as much as 7 percent of the money raised from investors.
Goldman Sachs again was the leading underwriter of initial offerings and all issues of common stock, commanding about 25 percent of the market so far this year.
Goldman managed several huge offerings during the rockiest period of the quarter in April, including the $4.6 billion initial offering of the insurer MetLife and the $3 billion spinoff of the T-Online subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom of Germany.
Looking back over the quarter, Mark Tercek, co-head of Goldman's stock underwriting business, said, "While market conditions were more difficult, we were still able to get a lot of deals done for companies of all stripes."
But, he added, investors are taking a more disciplined approach than they were during the I.P.O. frenzy that ran through much of last year and into the first quarter. "That was a very ebullient, extraordinary period of time and it largely is over," Mr. Tercek said.
After a weak May, the market for new stock started to recover in June and companies rushed back in to sell stock. Still, the market for new stocks was significantly stronger than the market for debt issued by corporations. As the Federal Reserve continued to raise short-term interest rates, investors were wary of buying bonds, especially those that mature in 10 to 30 years.
Investors showed a distinct aversion to risky bonds promising high yields. There were only 66 junk bond offerings in the quarter, down almost two-thirds from 178 in the second quarter of 1999. They raised just $7.5 billion, down from $32.2 billion a year earlier.
The virtual shutdown of the junk bond market came at the worst time for many young Internet companies that found that they could not finance their growth plans either by issuing stock or by borrowing in the public bond markets. That situation left some Internet retailers and other electronic-commerce companies no choice but to be acquired or go out of business.
For blue-chip companies, the borrowing was easier at the end of the quarter, after the Labor Department's report on employment in May eased fears of further rate increases by the Fed.
After that report hinted that the economy might be cooling, investors showed more interest in high-grade corporate bonds that mature in 10 years or more, said Randy Snook, head of corporate bond underwriting at Goldman Sachs.
"Much of the year has been unusual in that the amount of short-term issuance has been quite high," Mr. Snook said. "You can count the number of 30-year bonds issued from corporations on two hands."
Underwriters were encouraged by the reception for a $9.5 billion sale of bonds in the United States by Deutsche Telekom, which was split almost evenly among 5-year, 10-year and 30-year securities.
"We're not expecting an avalanche of activity," Mr. Snook said. But, he said, "We feel we have entered a period of much better market conditions than we've had in much of the first and second quarters."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rescue of Retail Chain May Threaten Recovery in Japan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 30

 BODY:
Japanese financial authorities bailed out a highly indebted department store company today, averting a major corporate bankruptcy but reigniting concerns about Japan's economic future just as it is showing signs of breaking out of a decade-long malaise.
The Financial Reconstruction Commission, the agency charged with overseeing reform in the banking system, said the government would spend 97 billion yen, or $924 million at current exchange rates, of taxpayer money to help rescue the store chain, the Sogo Company. 
 The agreement paved the way for Sogo's other banks to forgive more than 630 billion yen in loans, or roughly $6 billion. The banks had wavered for weeks on whether to grant Sogo's request for the debt forgiveness, one of the largest loan write-offs in Japanese bank history.
But the agreement may have created bigger problems for the government, which faces heightened scrutiny of its use of taxpayer money.
The decision to rescue the company -- and ease pressure on the banks to which Sogo owes a total of $16 billion -- raises questions about where the government will draw the line on the use of public money. The precedent set today could mean that thousands of companies will press for debt forgiveness.
More important, the government's decision casts doubt upon its commitment to a serious overhaul of the economy, which has yet to decisively rebound from a decade of decline. "It suggests that every time the Japanese government looks over the precipice and sees what it means to clean up this economy, it's just too scary," said Ronald Bevacqua, senior economist at Commerz Securities in Tokyo.
Japan is not the first country to aid a private company. The United States rescued the Chrysler Corporation 20 years ago, and South Korea used public money to prop up businesses during its economic crisis.
But Japan has taken the concept further. The government has spent a minimum of 7.7 trillion yen, or more than $80 billion at current exchange rates, to restore the banking system. The government has offered small and midsize businesses 30 trillion yen in loan guarantees to keep them afloat -- only to see a large number of them fail anyway.
At the height of the banking crisis in early 1998, the Bank of Japan bought corporate debt securities to keep companies from suffering a short-term cash crisis. The Japan Development Bank was permitted to extend emergency credit lines to struggling companies like the Nissan Motor Company.
But Sogo is not Nissan, never mind Chrysler. "I think it is sensible to forgive some debt as we go through the process of restructuring the economy here, but is this the right company?" asked James P. Fiorillo, senior banking analyst at ING Barings in Tokyo. "I think not."
Sogo's restructuring plan envisions a return to positive net worth more than a decade from now. And there is widespread doubt whether Sogo can entice shoppers back into its dowdy stores.
The government had hoped to avoid a very public bailout of a private company. But it was pushed into that position by Shinsei Bank, the former Long-Term Credit Bank, which the government sold last year to a private group led by an American investment firm, Ripplewood Holdings L.L.C. Under the terms, the government must buy back for the next three years any loans made by Long-Term Credit Bank whose book value falls by 20 percent or more.
Sogo's loans fell into that category, and on Wednesday, Shinsei asked the Deposit Insurance Corporation to buy back 97 billion yen of the 200 billion yen Sogo owes it. Shinsei had already set aside 103 billion yen in reserves against a potential default on the loans. Once it became clear that the government would be holding the loans, not Shinsei, Sogo's other large creditors threatened not to forgive Sogo debts unless the government did the same.
While the government was worried about destroying Sogo and putting its 9,900 employees out of work, it was more concerned about the impact of Sogo's failure on the banking system, according to officials: Many of Sogo's creditors had not adequately reserved against potential default.
The fact that the government must still worry about the stability and soundness of banks that have already received public assistance and are supposedly in the process of seriously revamping their business practices suggests that the financial crisis is not really over.
"We're still in crisis management mode in Japan," Mr. Fiorillo said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

AT&T Considers Spinoff Of Long-Distance Business
AT&T is considering spinning off its long-distance telephone operation, the largest in the nation, as a separately traded tracking stock, people close to the company said this week.
One reason AT&T may want to issue a new stock to track the long-distance unit is that its shares have languished recently. AT&T hit a new 52-week low during trading yesterday and closed at $31.8125, down 31.25 cents. Management is eager to bolster the stock price and believes that issuing a tracking stock might accomplish that if the shrinking consumer long-distance unit was separate. Page C14.
 
E-Signature Bill Is Signed Into Law
President Clinton signed legislation giving legal weight to electronic signatures. At a ceremony in Philadelphia, the president used both the traditional felt-tip pen signature and the more high-technology method of inserting a signature card into a computer. C3.
 
Oracle's President Steps Down
Oracle, the world's second-largest software publisher, said that Raymond Lane, its president and chief opperating officer, had abruptly resigned. Mr. Lane, at Oracle for eight years, had held the post of president since 1996. C3
 
Doctors Seek Antitrust Exemption
Elated with a victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues. But the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said he would stand in their way. A1.
 
Personal Spending and Income Rise
Consumer spending rose by 0.2 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported, matching expectations. Americans' incomes, which include wages, interest and government benefits, rose 0.4 percent in May, slightly more than expected. C3.
 
2nd-Quarter Slump for Underwriters
The amount raised in the United States by investment banks in stock and bond offerings -- $451 billion -- was down 24 percent from the second quarter of 1999. Fees for underwriting new issues sank about 20 percent from $3.29 billion in the period a year earlier. C14.
 
$765 Million Investment in Italtel
Cisco Systems and the private investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice agreed to acquire 80 percent of Telecom Italia's computer network equipment unit, Italtel, for $765 million. The two investors hope that by forging an alliance with Cisco and by making the company independent from its Italian parent, it will become more competitive. The investors said they hope to sell shares of the new company to the public soon. C4.
 
Russia Exerts Control Over Gazprom
Russia's government strengthened its influence over Gazprom, the natural gas giant. Shareholders voted in a new board, tipping the balance to favor the government, which controls 38.4 percent of the company. The vote greatly reduced the influence of Gazprom's chief executive, Rem Vyakhirev, who had wielded tremendous power. C2.
 
Japan Rescues a Department Store
Japan's Financial Reconstruction Commission, the agency charged with overseeing reform in the banking system, said the government would spend 97 billion yen, or $924 million, of taxpayer money to help rescue Sogo, a highly indebted department store. C2.
 
U.S. Markets to Close Early
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States will close at 1 p.m. Monday and be closed on Tuesday in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets, however, will be open both days. United States markets will reopen on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Weak 2nd Quarter Drags Stock Indexes Down for the Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged in the second quarter of the year, leaving all the major indexes down for the first half as the Federal Reserve continued to try to slow the economy.
The Nasdaq composite index lost 13.3 percent in the quarter, its first loss since the third quarter of 1998. The decline more than wiped out its January-March advance and left it down 2.5 percent for the first six months of the year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average declined 4.3 percent in the second quarter and is now down 9.1 percent so far this year.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped 2.9 percent in the quarter and closed out the first half down 1 percent.
Investors also decided that many high-technology and Internet shares were overpriced and that it was time to cash in some profits, sending many issues plummeting. Amazon.com, the cyberspace retailer, closed midyear at 36 5/16 after trading as high as 106 11/16 during the Christmas shopping season.
"We clearly did deflate a good portion of the speculative bubble called the Internet," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisers in Boston. "A number of investors finally recognized that there is risk in the risk-reward equation."
But investment money has to go somewhere and this time the beneficiaries tended to be drug and other health care companies, real estate investment trusts and utilities. Stocks of semiconductor companies also climbed.
And technology was not a one-way street. After hitting a record 5,048.62 late in the first quarter, March 10, the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite fell as low as 3,164.55 on May 23 before recovering to 4,064.01 on June 21 and then tailing off again. It closed yesterday at 3,966.11.
"The Federal Reserve's 50-basis-point tightening was a bit of a watershed," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager for the Dreyfus Corporation, referring to a May 16 increase of half a percentage point in the overnight lending rate.
"In mid-May, things suddenly reversed" in the stock market, he added. "Interest-rate sensitive stocks went out of favor and tech came back in."
Still, investors shied away from fledgling companies, many of them with no profits and scarcely any revenue. A flurry of 18 initial public offerings reached the market this week to lift the quarter's total to 104, but this was far short of the 141 companies that went public in the first three months of the year.
"The world changed," said Richard Peterson, market analyst at Thomson Financial Securities Data, which tracks initial public offerings, noting that 52 of the 104 deals were marketed at prices below the range projected in their original filings. In the first quarter 91 of these issues were priced above the filing range.
Nevertheless, the quarter's biggest Nasdaq stars were technology companies, led by the Ixys Corporation, a semiconductor company based in Santa Clara, Calif. With a 3 3/8-point surge yesterday. to 53 3/8, the stock nearly quadrupled from its March 31 price of 13 9/16. Adept Technology, up 6 11/16 yesterday, ended the quarter at 46 3/4, up from 12 on March 31. The biggest loser, excluding companies that filed for bankruptcy, was Fidelity Holdings of Kew Gardens, Queens, which lost 94 percent of its value, closing at 1 1/4.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Keithley Instruments, which makes electronic measuring equipments, soared 264 percent followed by Lilly Industries, up 142 percent.
Entrade, a Northfield, Ill., business-to-business Internet company, plunged 77 percent, to 7 1/16. The Chyron Corporation and Dynex Capital also lost more than 70 percent of their market value.
The average technology mutual fund fell about 13 percent during the quarter, according to Christopher Traulsen, an analyst for Morningstar. This contrasted with an 18 percent advance in the first three months of 2000. Last year, the average tech fund soared 135 percent.
"There was some flight to quality, into bigger, steadier companies" within the technology stock group, Mr. Traulsen said.

Share Prices Climb
By Bloomberg News
Stock prices rose as investors bet the decline in technology shares on Thursday was overdone.
Cisco Systems and Microsoft led the Nasdaq composite index higher, even as the gauge completed its first losing quarter since 1998.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 88.88 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,966.11, after dropping 1.6 percent Thursday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 12.21 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,454.60. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 49.85 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,447.89.
Treasury bond prices were mixed. The 10-year note rose 2/32, to 103 16/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.01 percent from 6.02 percent. The 30-year bond fell 9/32, to 105 1/32. Its yield rose to 5.89 percent from 5.87.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Are a Billion Chinese Grapefruit Compliant?;
U.S. Citrus Growers Are Early Winners In Two-Way Agricultural Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 30

 BODY:
At the Sidaokou wholesale market they have been snapped up, these strange golden orbs bedecked with American flag stickers and the name Ocean Spray.
Some people have driven two hours to purchase them. But most just regard these fruits with curiosity -- are they oversized oranges? -- and read the poster that explains: "Grapefruits from Florida . . . Famous Brand Name . . . Healthy and Tasty . . . Good for Your Blood and for Beauty." 
 "It's my first imported product, and sales are very very good," said Rong Zhifang, a saleswoman, hovering behind her cartons.
When China joins the World Trade Organization, probably later this year, it will be forced to allow a huge range of foreign goods greater access to its vast markets. But a few American agricultural items -- including citrus fruit and pork -- have already attained sharply improved entry in the last few months, under a recent United States-China agricultural agreement.
And, in Beijing, the fate of the invading oranges and grapefruits is seen as a glimpse of China's future, presaging the sudden new opportunities and problems that free trade will bring.
"The arrival of American agricultural products is just a start," said The Beijing Morning News, in one of many articles that have appeared recently about the American fruit. "Once China joins the W.T.O., the story about the boy crying wolf will soon become a reality."
Indeed, Western companies are drooling at the prospect of China's potentially huge market, aggressively promoting their products.
At the annual Food China 2000 Exhibition last week in Beijing, American producers of chicken, ice cream and fruit juice -- to name a few -- turned out in stands decorated with red, white and blue bunting to give buyers from Chinese restaurants, supermarkets and hotels a taste of the future. There was even a booth promoting American pork, to a country where a surplus of pigs has driven pork prices to near record lows this year.
But it was the citrus booth -- with its free fruit slices and drinks -- that commanded the longest lines. "This will certainly open up new business opportunities for me," said Ding Yong, a food distributor for cafeterias. "The juices are great."
Price, of course, is something of an issue. Imported oranges are about three times the price of Chinese products. Grapefruits here cost about $1.50 each, compared with about 10 cents for somewhat similar Chinese fruits, called youzi (pronounced yo-zuh) and huyou (pronounced hoo-yo).
These price differentials will narrow somewhat when China enters the W.T.O., since the fruits now carry an average import tariff of 40 percent. But even as tariffs are cut, imported fruit is likely to remain quite a bit more expensive.
And other hurdles are likely to remain for a long time, as China's slow-moving bureaucracy adjusts to the realities of more imports. The Florida grapefruits that arrived in China on April 20, for example, were stuck in quarantine for the next four weeks, their release blocked by a series of logistical problems.
First, the inspection documents provided by the Florida producers were considered invalid by Chinese customs authorities. Then the quarantine inspectors sealed the warehouse after noticing that some cases contained dead insects. The inspectors ultimately cleared the fruits, but not before Chinese distributors had paid them thousands of dollars in storage fees.
"I have met with so many troubles from these fruits, and I still have many grapefruits in the ports waiting to be inspected," said Zhang Zhimin, the sales manager for the China Cereal Import and Export Company, which is handling the citrus imports. "Although sales are good now and I am quite optimistic, there are still many problems."
The citrus fruits are coming in under the United States-China Agricultural Cooperation Agreement signed late last year. Under the accord, China said it would drop barriers that had previously prevented the import of some American agricultural products.
China agreed to recognize the American pork inspection system, for example, which it had called inadequate. It also dropped what had previously been a near-blanket ban on citrus imports, put in place to protect against infestation by the Mediterranean fruit fly, or medfly.
Under the new agreement, the United States promised not to send fruit to China from counties experiencing medfly infestations.
Since April 20, more than six huge shipments of fruit have arrived here, including 16 tons of Sunkist oranges in the northeastern part of Dalian and 60 tons of grapefruit in the coastal city of Tianjin. By the end of May, they could be found in upscale markets in Beijing, where the press has provided detailed analyses of their flavor, appearance, breeding and value.
In Shanghai, the 1,800 cartons of oranges that arrived on May 11 sold out within two hours. In Dalian, they lasted just three days. Tens of thousands of grapefruits have sold in Beijing since they arrived on May 20.
"Will the high prices affect sales in China?" asked The Beijing Morning News. "It seems not. The Chinese people have showed unexpected enthusiasm for these fine-quality oranges." Chinese experts urged their compatriots to carefully observe the invasion and learn from American farmers.
Of course, the initial burst of enthusiasm for the fruit may not be surprising in a country where consumers worship all things American. American fruit growers and distributors are determined to maintain the momentum.
Calling grapefruit the "No. 1 Fruit in the U.S.," material from the Beijing Shiyi Futai Trade Company says its grapefruits help "protect your heart, blood vessels and kidneys." The fruit "has the natural anticancer element of folic acid, and natural fruit colloid, which can lower cholesterol."
A series of flashy television ads, featuring a popular music TV host named Ke Lan, is planned to promote American oranges.
There is still much work to be done. At the China Food 2000 Exhibition, Sunny Chen, an executive chef from a hotel in Xian, declared that consumers there were "not ready" for the flavor of grapefruit, as he threw a rind into the trash can -- even though he personally liked the fruit and predicted success with the more worldly palates of Beijing.
But at the huge Xidan Market in the capital, six flag-festooned grapefruits sat forlornly on the shelves one recent day, more museum pieces than comestibles.
"Look! Fruit from America," said Gui Shufeng, a retiree who was strolling in the market with his wife.
"I like them -- a little tart and a little sweet," said Mr. Gui, who had tasted grapefruit while visiting his daughter in New York. "But I'm not sure if Chinese will buy them. They're expensive."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE GREEN CANDIDATE;
Unlike '96, Nader Runs Hard in '00

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., June 28

 BODY:
It was nearing 10 o'clock at night, but in the sweltering lecture hall that served as the stage for this political rally, the Green Party's nominee for president of the United States was still going strong.
He sharply criticized an "apartheid economy" that was benefiting only the rich, and he bemoaned the state of affairs in a country with "far more problems than it deserves and far more solutions than it applies." And he scoffed at the notion that he might be a spoiler, drawing enough votes away from Al Gore to tip the election to George W. Bush. 
 "You can't spoil a system," the candidate, Ralph Nader, said, "that's spoiled to the core."
The audience of 300 people or so loved it, repeatedly breaking into applause and giving the 66-year-old Mr. Nader a standing ovation coming in and heading out.
It is impossible to know whether, as current polls suggest, Nader's Raiders will have more impact on the race than the Buchanan Brigades of the likely Reform Party nominee, Patrick J. Buchanan. But one thing is clear on the campaign trail with Mr. Nader, the country's best-known consumer advocate: he is running an exceedingly more energetic race than he did four years ago, when he essentially stood in as a protest candidate, spending less than $5,000, speaking rarely and taking 1 percent of the vote.
"This is the difference between a person running and a person standing still," he said by way of comparison to his 1996 White House bid.
He has campaigned in every state this year -- flying commercial coach class, frequently using his senior-citizen's discount -- and appears well on his way to his goal of raising $5 million, with the help of the direct-mail network he has built over the years and plugs from several big Hollywood names.
He may wind up as a passing phenomenon in this campaign, like former Senator Bill Bradley or Senator John McCain. But for now, Mr. Nader is attracting a lot of attention -- among the news media, among left-leaning voters who see him as a more reliably liberal voice than Mr. Gore, and among leaders of organized labor, who agree with his stands on trade. Mr. Nader is a staunch critic of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization, both of which he depicts as evidence of a "corporate globalization" that harms worker rights and the environment.
Polls in recent weeks have put him at 5 percent to 10 percent of the vote.
It would be a stretch to call Mr. Nader a natural politician, and his one-and-three-quarter-hour nomination acceptance speech on Sunday in Denver may have been a tad long. But he seems highly animated, and has a lot of sound bites down. He even claims to be enjoying his life as a politician, though he chooses a rather grim analogy to explain why.
"Oh, I have programmed myself so that if something is important to do, it's enjoyable," he said in an interview on Monday, after speaking at a women's center in the Mission District of San Francisco.
"I mean, there are some professional people who do that, too," Mr. Nader continued. "A good doctor, if he believes it's important to treat people, he'll enjoy treating people, even though outsiders may say, 'Oh, my God, what horrible tragedies and near misses, what pain you're dealing with.' "
In Mr. Nader's depiction, most of the country is in pain.
"At no time in our history have the children of America been in such crisis," he said in San Francisco the other day. And most wage earners, he told the crowd here, are working harder and longer than ever but have less purchasing power than they had in 1968.
Mr. Nader sees the West Coast -- with its mix of liberals, radicals, environmentalists and others who lean to the left -- as a fertile ground for his campaign. And indeed in California, where Mr. Nader has been involved in tort initiatives and has campaigned for so-called "patient protection" and H.M.O.-reform initiatives, polls show his support in the 5 percent to 7 percent range.
Though the number is small, much of that support comes at the expense of Vice President Gore, who most analysts believe has to carry California to win in November. But even with Mr. Nader campaigning hard in the state, Democrats here profess to be little concerned about his impact.
Rather than reaching out to Mr. Nader and his backers, they have so far been dismissive.
"Ralph Nader is a 66-year-old Corvair in this race ready to be rear-ended," said Bob Mulholland, campaign adviser to the California Democratic Party. "This is the most serious vote of people's lives and they're not going to throw it away."
Mr. Mulholland said his party would not "waste one ad" campaigning against the Green candidate.
"Nader became famous because of the Corvair and he's been doing college campuses ever since," he said. "And now he wants to be president? It's a joke; it's ridiculous. Only in America can someone completely irrelevant run for president."
Politically, Mr. Nader's message is a bit complicated. He says that he hopes his candidacy will energize turnout for Democratic candidates in close races for the House of Representatives, and thus help turn power over to House Democratic leaders, and away from the Republicans in the House leadership whom he calls "beyond the pale."
But at the presidential level, Mr. Nader has nothing but venom for Mr. Gore and President Clinton, whom he accuses of offering "some of the most intensive demonstrations of political cowardliness in American history." He says the race offers voters two "Republicrat" candidates, barely distinguishable.
"The only distinction between Bush and Gore is the velocity with which their knees hit the floor when big corporations knock on the door," Mr. Nader said the other day in Los Angeles, campaigning outside a public housing project.
A seasoned political strategist might suggest that while Mr. Nader remains so hot, he should be barnstorming the country. He did follow up his nomination acceptance in Denver with the swing here, and he said he plans many such swings. But afterward, he headed back to Washington, D.C., where aides said he planned to spend the rest of the week.
Here in Oakland, speaking on Monday at a downtown school called the University of Creation Spirituality, Mr. Nader elicited hisses of agreement from the crowd when he blasted several big-name Democrats in California, including Gov. Gray Davis and Senator Dianne Feinstein.
Among the central planks of his campaign are pledges to enact universal health insurance, to change labor laws to make it easier for unions to organize and to eliminate corporate welfare.
If there was any good news for Mr. Gore out of the rally here, it would seem to be that Mr. Nader's crowd was, by and large, so left-leaning that many voters there were not even the vice president's to lose. Several people in the audience said they had voted for Green or Libertarian Party candidates in the past.
What seemed to resonate with them most was Mr. Nader's "honesty -- just the sense that nobody is going to own him," as Corine Thornton, a 77-year-old retired waitress, put it. She voted for Mr. Nader four years ago, Ms. Thornton said, because "I just was no longer satisfied with voting for the lesser of two evils."
Mateo Williford, a 28-year-old self-described "traveling activist," rejected the idea that a vote for Mr. Nader was a wasted vote. "If we're ever going to have the possibility of three, four, five political parties," he said, "we have to make the choice to start bringing those in."
Still, some people were not even sure about the whole electoral effort on Mr. Nader's behalf.
"I'm disappointed that all this energy is being put into the political system," said Jonah Zern, 22, a recent Cornell University graduate with a degree in environmental policy. "I mean, the idea that one person can represent 250 million people is absurd."
Mr. Nader is not without potential vulnerabilities. Eyebrows were raised recently when the financial disclosure statements of Mr. Nader, America's most famous corporation-basher, revealed that he was worth nearly $4 million, in large part because of some savvy stock investments in high-technology companies.
Mr. Nader scoffed at the notion that there was anything untoward about reaping such gains. He said that he lived on about $25,000 a year, giving away 80 percent of his after-tax income, and that any of his gains represented a "de facto philanthropic fund" for his favorite causes.
No one really expects it, but what if Mr. Nader wound up in "that corporate prison we used to call the White House," as he describes it, dealing with the lawmakers "who have turned Capitol Hill into Withering Heights"?
Would he find it all daunting? Mr. Nader thought about the question for a while, and replied no: "First of all, I've been in Washington too long, I've seen what kind of characters were in power, who should have been daunted but weren't."
So, no, 'daunting' was not the right word.
"I would find it challenging to be president," he said. " 'Daunting' has almost a stuck-in-the-headlights, taken-aback sense, that maybe you're surprised by what you find yourself having to cope with. I don't think that would be the case."

HEADLINE: Leading Candidates in Mexico As Close on Issues as in Polls

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 30

 BODY:
The race for the Mexican presidency has been a show such as Mexico has never seen. The leading candidates have slugged it out on television, calling each other names and wrangling fiercely over the merits of change in a country governed by the same party for 71 years.
But as the dust settled in the final days before Sunday's election, it was hard to find much difference on the major issues between the leading candidates, Francisco Labastida Ochoa of the governing party and Vicente Fox Quesada of the right-of-center opposition, who have been running neck and neck. 
 On economic issues, the most deeply felt by Mexicans, the two were so close that they used the same slogan: "An economy with a human face."
Both candidates played down the nationalism that used to be a campaign mainstay and favored good relations with the United States -- although they did not say it too loudly. They even agreed on what not to bring up, so the crucial national security issue of narcotics was largely absent.
The candidates reflected a consensus among Mexican voters, who have embraced the global economy but want a fairer share of it, and seek better government through peaceful, orderly reform. And with Mexico linked to the United States more firmly than ever, the room in which its politicians can maneuver has been reduced considerably.
A leftist contender, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, contrasted with his rivals, calling for a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement and more confrontation with the United States. But the latest polls show that although Mexicans admire his honest zeal, they will not elect Mr. Cardenas president.
Both Mr. Labastida and Mr. Fox were strong supporters of Nafta, which has transformed Mexico into an export powerhouse, creating millions of jobs in sectors that supply the booming United States market. Both criticized government policies that catered to the markets but did little to close the widening rift between rich and poor and between northern Mexico, where the export industries are based, and the south, where unemployment is rampant.
Mr. Labastida, the candidate of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, distanced himself from President Ernesto Zedillo, even though the government's tight fiscal policies generated a recovery and growth surge without which the PRI campaign would have been doomed. He criticized his party's president for neglecting the purchasing power of working class Mexicans. He proposed to double or triple current subsidies to farmers in regions hurt by American competition through Nafta.
Mr. Fox stood on his experience as a former Coca-Cola executive and his record of boosting Mexican entrepreneurs when he was governor of Guanajuato state. He said he would create a cabinet ministry, separate from the Finance Ministry, to create jobs through private investment, promote "aggressive policies" on behalf of small businesses and send "massive resources" to the poorest regions.
"No one among the analysts can make out whose proposals are better," said Damian Fraser, the head of Latin American research for UBS Warburg. "Labastida has more experience in government and represents continuity. Fox has a somewhat greater commitment to free market policies."
The final polls showed Mr. Labastida and Mr. Fox in a tie, with Mr. Cardenas well behind. Mr. Fox comes from the moderate conservative National Action Party, known as the PAN, but spearheaded a diverse group of Mexicans who want a change from the ruling system.
Despite the similarities, Mr. Labastida did score one propaganda coup against Mr. Fox. In a much-discussed television commercial, he showed a video clip of Mr. Fox speaking in English during a visit to the United States, describing a program he set up in Guanajuato to train gardeners for skilled jobs in the United States. Mr. Labastida comes in at the end to say that he planned to create jobs for Mexicans in Mexico.
Even though relations with the United States have never been closer, Mexicans retain a gut wariness of their neighbor. Nationalism was unusually dormant through much of the leading campaigns, but in the final days the PRI revived it with accusations that Mr. Fox received illegal donations from across the border. Mr. Fox denied the allegations.
The two candidates both promised a harder line in defense of Mexican immigrants. Mr. Fox stressed a proposal to make a free labor market in the hemisphere in the coming years to parallel the free trade market, opening the border to the millions of Mexican migrants who now risk their lives to cross it illegally.
Education was another hot-button issue, where Mr. Fox and Mr. Labastida diverged. Mr. Fox made a risky pitch to Catholics, who make up more than 90 percent of the population, suggesting that he would make more room for the Roman Catholic Church in public education. The idea drew a furious response from the PRI, whose anti-clericalism and commitment to nonreligious public schools date back to its founding. It was not clear how the overture played among the voters.
Mr. Labastida also gambled, with a nationally broadcast radio commercial saying he would bring English and computer courses to all public schools. The opposition ridiculed the proposal as impractical and elitist. But PRI media experts found that the advertisement was popular with working class voters, and they kept broadcasting it for an extra two weeks.
One issue too explosive for either candidate to dwell on was Mexico's No. 1 national security concern: the narcotics trade. One PRI state governor, Mario Villanueva, is wanted by the Mexican authorities on charges of laundering drug money. But Mr. Fox's party also had a bleak record on combating traffickers in Baja California and Chihuahua, two border states it governed in recent years.
Both candidates said they would fight crime and corruption by overhauling the justice system. Mr. Labastida said he would dissolve the attorney general's office, the central federal justice institution, and create a new justice system more like that of the United States, where the fight against drugs would be isolated in one agency, federal prosecutors in another and federal police in a third.
Many sparks in the campaign flew from the friction between two very different men. Mr. Labastida is an institutional man who served 37 years in government without making a big wave or a big mistake. Mr. Fox handily outperformed him in both debates because Mr. Labastida seemed noncommittal.
Mr. Fox's forcefulness and populist informality both helped and hurt him. In a survey by Consultores y Marketing Politico, a public opinion research company, more of those interviewed liked and trusted Mr. Fox, but thought Mr. Labastida had "the personality to be president."
The split that has made the contest so intense is over the record of the PRI, tarnished by corruption and repeated economic crises. Mr. Fox appealed to voters to abandon their deep-set risk aversion and throw off a system of rule that has dominated their entire lives.
From a podium high above a huge crowd in Mexico City's central square, Mr. Fox boomed out the slogan that summarized his crusade: "Don't stop now, Mexico!"

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Praises The 'Values And Virtues' Of Hispanics

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Mixing praise for Latin American culture with appeals to Hispanic "values and virtues," Vice President Al Gore asserted this evening that his approach to education, health care and the economy would "unleash the promise of every brave young Latino in this nation."
"The values and virtues that are at the heart of the Latino experience -- honor and responsibility, faith and family, caring and community -- are the same values that are most important in keeping America strong," Mr. Gore said in a speech before the League of United Latin American Citizens. "I want to give all hard-working Americans of all backgrounds the chance to live out their values and reach for their dreams." 
 In a 30-minute speech liberally salted with Spanish phrases, Mr. Gore made a handful of policy pledges specifically intended for Hispanic voters, including affirming his support for bilingual education.
"I say to you tonight, 'Todavia no han visto nada,' " Mr. Gore said. "You ain't seen nothing yet."
But he focused more heavily on the broad themes that are central to his candidacy and that he repeatedly suggested have special value for immigrants and their children: improving education, safeguarding the booming economy, extending health care to all children and strengthening the Social Security system.
"We can create a future where new Americans and all Americans can open the doors to their own homes and swing open the wrought-iron gates to education and opportunity and live out their lives in peace and plenty," he said.
Mr. Gore's speech came at the end of the organization's weeklong convention, which opened on Monday with a speech by the vice president's likely Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush. In a much shorter address, Mr. Bush called for splitting the Immigration and Naturalization Service into two agencies and for making it easier for relatives of permanent residents to enter the country.
The competition between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush for Hispanic voters has stepped up in recent days, when some recent polls have shown Mr. Bush cutting into the Democrats' historical domination among Hispanic voters.
In a poll from interviews with 2,721 likely Hispanic voters released today by The San Jose Mercury News, Mr. Gore was shown winning 50 percent of the Hispanic vote, compared with 34 percent for Mr. Bush. In 1996, President Clinton won more than 70 percent of the Hispanic vote.
Nationwide, Hispanics are projected to represent 5.4 percent of the electorate. But their numbers are significantly greater in the states with the most electoral votes: California, New York and Texas.
Douglas Hattaway, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, said polls showing Mr. Bush making inroads among Hispanic voters are meaningless so early in the campaign. "You can't compare poll numbers this far out from an election with results of previous elections," he said.
"Hispanic voters see that Al Gore is focused on issues they care deeply about, like education and health care," he continued. "And the more they learn about both candidates the wider this margin will grow."
Mr. Gore was accompanied tonight by several Hispanic members of the Administration, including Energy Secretary Bill Richardson and Aida Alvarez, the head of the Small Business Administration.
Mr. Gore did not mention Mr. Bush in his remarks. But he criticized Senate Republicans for holding up the nomination of Enrique Moreno to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
"I believe that it is time to call upon Congress to stop playing politics with judicial nominations and confirm Enrique Moreno," he said to loud applause.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
It Isn't Working

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The state of our political system the depressing state -- was illuminated by a report in The New York Times last week. The story, by Michael R. Gordon with Steven Lee Myers, showed how petty domestic politics had imposed heavy costs, financial and diplomatic, on plans for a U.S. missile shield.
The Clinton administration thought of building the antimissile system at Grand Forks, N.D., where an exception written into the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty allows a U.S. installation. But then computers showed that the single system would not cover the far western end of the Aleutian Islands, with a population of a few thousand. 
 That discovery killed the plan. Why? Because the Senate Appropriations Committee's defense subcommittee is headed by Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska. No one was willing even to ask him about the idea of leaving those few constituents of his unprotected.
So the plan now being considered by President Clinton would put a huge radar installation on a remote Aleutian Island and deploy 100 interceptors in central Alaska. The change will add $2 billion to the cost of the system -- and require problematic negotiation with Russia about amendment or abandonment of the ABM treaty.
That tale illustrates a curious aspect of contemporary American life. In business, we expect hard-nosed leaders to make decisions based on cost and comparative advantage -- and we thrive economically as a result. But in public policy, fewer and fewer decisions are made on the substantive merits.
The so-called missile shield is an example in another sense, even more profound. President Clinton is considering a "thin" system, designed to deal with the possibility of long-range nuclear missiles coming from such countries as North Korea. Republicans in general, and Gov. George W. Bush in particular, are arguing for a much bigger and more expensive system that would also cover American troops abroad and our allies.
The thin system is a halfway measure. It reminds one of what Winston Churchill said about the name of a fellow M.P., Sir Alfred Bossom: "It's neither one thing nor the other."
The purpose of the thin idea is plainly political. President Clinton wants to protect himself -- and Vice President Gore -- from Republican charges that they are weak on defense.
Ironically, it seems doubtful that the tactic will succeed. Despite enormous scientific doubts about the workability of antimissile devices, and extravagant cost, Americans have liked the dream of an invulnerable shield since President Reagan floated it. Governor Bush is likely to score with his call for an all-out system.
Nor would the limited plan now being considered by President Clinton obviate the diplomatic and security dangers of any antimissile system. Forty-five China scholars and diplomats, including President Reagan's ambassador to Beijing, have warned that an early decision to begin building any new system would provoke China into "negative steps that would undermine American security."
Politics also underlies another dangerous decision: the proposal, just approved by Congress, to send more than $1 billion in aid to Colombia to fight drugs. Here again President Clinton embraced an idea whose ramifications have hardly been thought through in order to protect himself from being called soft on drugs.
Drugs are a subject that has paralyzed American political leadership for a generation and more. The war on drugs fills our prisons without reducing drug use. But only a few politicians have been brave enough to say that the emperor has no clothes.
The other day the chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, Judith S. Kaye, ordered the courts to begin offering treatment instead of jail time to nonviolent criminals who are addicts. It took a judge to do what every study has shown is more effective and far less expensive.
Our sluggish democracy has always depended on courageous political leadership. It took a strong president and dedicated Congressional leaders, working together, to end American isolationism after World War II -- and to act on civil rights in the 1960's. When will we get the leadership to deal forthrightly with today's problems?

HEADLINE: Whitman Trims $21.4 Billion Budget Before Signing It

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a $21.4 billion state budget into law today after using her line-item veto to carve $50 million in spending proposed by the Legislature.
The budget, buoyed by windfall tax revenues generated by New Jersey's surging economy, represents a 10 percent increase over last year's spending, and includes a $45 million tax cut for 240,000 low-income families, and FamilyCare, the Governor's plan to use part of the tobacco settlement to help provide health insurance for 125,000 New Jerseyans. 
 The budget also includes increased spending for towns, preschools, public schools, colleges, nursing homes and charity care for indigent residents unable to pay hospital bills.
But the spending package still provides an $870 million surplus, the largest in state history.
"There's a lot of new policy initiatives in this budget," said Assemblyman Richard Bagger, a Republican from Westfield. "From health care and education to tax cuts. This is one of those years when there's something for almost everyone."
Governor Whitman and the State Senate have also agreed on two other huge spending programs not included in the budget: the $3.75 billion Transportation Trust Fund to finance road improvements and a $12 billion plan to rebuild the state's aging public schools. But both measures must still receive the approval of the Assembly, which is expected to pass them when it reconvenes for a special session on July 13.
Mrs. Whitman said she was grateful that she had the good fortune to govern during comfortable economic times, but said she felt obligated to make the $50 million in line-item-veto reductions.
"It's very difficult during flush times to say no," Mrs. Whitman said, "but we have a responsibility to spend tax dollars as if they were our own."
Among Mrs. Whitman's vetoes were $300,000 in spending cuts intended to send a blunt message to one of the governor's political adversaries, State Senator John A. Lynch, a Democrat from Middlesex County. Mr. Lynch was the lone dissenter in the Senate's 38-to-1 vote in favor of the budget, because, he said, the state should use its prosperity to reduce New Jersey's debt and offer more aid to its struggling cities.
Mrs. Whitman retaliated against Mr. Lynch by denying financing to three programs he had requested in his hometown, New Brunswick: a $100,000 community shuttle bus program, $100,000 for a housing rehabilitation program and $100,000 for street lighting. To make sure her reasoning for those vetoes was clear, the governor's written budget message, distributed to reporters, included this explanation: "The sponsor of this appropriation has indicated his lack of support for the fiscal 2001 budget. Therefore it would be inconsistent with the sponsor's intent to approve this appropriation."
When asked about those cuts, the governor flashed a smile. "He didn't think this budget was good," she said with a chuckle. "So if the budget isn't good, it isn't good in a lot of ways."
Mr. Lynch and Mrs. Whitman have clashed in the past, and Mr. Lynch was a prime political backer of a fellow Democrat, Jim McGreevey, who nearly defeated Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, for governor in 1997.
Mr. Lynch did not return calls for comment after the cuts were announced.
Other line-item cuts by the governor included spending reductions for several hospitals, a variety of road projects and $1.5 million intended to help New Jersey teachers pay for continuing education.
But Leonard Lance, chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee, said most legislators were able to secure money for projects in their districts. "The budget is 99.8 percent of what the Legislature delivered to the governor," said Mr. Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon. "The governor and the Legislature cooperated extremely well."
