HEADLINE: New Cinema And New Hope In Harlem

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
A milestone in what some people have called the miracle of 125th Street was reached yesterday when the long-awaited Magic Johnson Theaters opened, bringing Harlem its first multiplex, with amenities like stadium seating to rival any movie house in the city. For the first time in many years, local residents will no longer have to travel to the Bronx or the Upper West Side to take in a first-run movie.
But long before the first screening of "Shaft" yesterday afternoon, ripples from the nine-screen movie theater and the new $66 million Harlem U.S.A. shopping and entertainment complex of which it is a part were already spreading up and down the broad street that serves as Harlem's main thoroughfare. The six-level shopping center at 125th and Frederick Douglass Boulevard is home to several national chain stores, including an HMV record store, a Disney Store, an Old Navy store and a Modell's Sporting Goods store. 
 National chain stores, fearful of crime and skeptical of whether enough buying power existed in low-income and minority neighborhoods, have long shunned communities like Harlem. Now retailers across the country are closely watching Harlem U.S.A. to see if the ambitious project will succeed.
One regional retailer that has responded to the new shopping center is the aptly named Lazarus, a 40-year-old children's clothing store one block east of the new shopping center. Last year, the owners spent $500,000 to renovate the store, which has a new multicolored sign, a brightly lighted interior and a clean and up-to-date appearance. Harlem U.S.A. had a lot to do with the store's makeover, said George Adams, the general manager for 20 years.
"The street came back alive," he said. Mr. Adams said he was not worried about competition from Old Navy because his store had catered to the same families for three generations and emphasized personal service.
Signs of vitality are everywhere on 125th Street, from the recently added bright red paint on the KFC outlet across the street from Harlem U.S.A. to the new or spruced up clothing stores like Ashley Stewart, Scheme and Avenue. Pedestrians crowd the sidewalks, and there are long lines at the cash registers.
Some shoppers said they could scarcely believe the transformation. "I used to think, maybe it's all talk, talk, talk," said Julie Duncan, a retired telephone service clerk who has lived in Harlem all her 53 years, "but then it came to light."
Vacant spaces began disappearing and rents began climbing about three years ago when it became clear that the shopping center would actually be built, said Barbara Askins, the president of the 125th Street Business Improvement District. Annual rents in the area around the shopping center have doubled and now average $60 to $70 a square foot, she said.
But even with the new facades, no one would mistake 125th Street for the shopping corridor along Third Avenue in the 60's. Rhythm and blues and salsa music permeate the air and street vendors peddle a wide range of goods, from books and compact discs to hand-painted tiles and flavored ices.
There is much more to come. A complex with national retailers is planned for a site between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and a section of Lenox Avenue known as Malcolm X Boulevard, and excavation has begun for a building on Lexington Avenue that will house a Seaman's furniture store and a Duane Reade drug store. That site is cater-cornered to a Pathmark -- Harlem's first full-service supermarket in three decades -- which has flourished since it opened in April 1999.
The last large remaining unoccupied parcel on 125th Street recently changed hands for the unheard-of price of $5 million, said Geoffrey Canada, the chief executive of Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, a nonprofit agency whose board members include Stanley Druckenmiller, an associate of the financier George Soros. Mr. Canada said the Rheedlen Centers will move its headquarters to the new 26,000-square-foot site from 107th Street and Broadway.
Farther west, the food purveyor Citarella is planning a 100,000-square-foot warehouse on 124th Street and Amsterdam Avenue and a store in the old Tastee Cake factory at 126th Street and Amsterdam.
After years of disappointments, development in Harlem is proceeding with breathtaking speed, generating many hundreds of jobs and changing people's lives in small ways as well as large ones. For example, Ms. Askins said, Harlem residents previously had to leave the neighborhood to find the weight-lifting equipment that Modell's carries or a gym like the branch of the New York Sports Club that recently opened at Harlem U.S.A.
Not every recent development project in the neighborhood has succeeded. East River Plaza, an East Harlem shopping center that would be anchored by a Costco warehouse store and a Home Depot, has stalled because of a lack of financing for a $30 million parking garage.
A plan to build a 10-screen multiplex on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue was scrapped after United Artists backed out. The developer, Blumenfeld Development Group, was unable to find a replacement because the movie theater industry is retrenching after several years of rapid expansion. Loews Cineplex, which owns half of the Magic Johnson Theaters in Harlem, is closing theaters in other markets. But Marc J. Pascucci, a senior vice president of Loews, said that in contrast to the rest of the country, Manhattan remains underserved by movie theaters, based on population.
Tickets at the new multiplex will cost $9.50, the same price Loews charges at its other Manhattan theaters. "This is an expensive city to do business in," Mr. Pascucci said.
Randy Dillard, an unemployed brick mason who has five young children, said, "It's a little steep." But even though he does not expect to patronize the new theater very often, Mr. Dillard said he thought the changes in Harlem were "very good for the community."
Others were less restrained. Laurence Jennings, the development director for Harlem Congregations for Community Improvement, an interfaith organization representing 75 churches and mosques, said the new movie theater had vast symbolic importance to the neighborhood. "It sends a message of upliftedness and a sense of pride and well-being," he said. "I don't think you can encase it in a few words."

HEADLINE: Doctor's Antitrust Hopes Face a Roadblock From Lott

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Elated with a big victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign today to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues.
But the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, said he would stand in their way. 
 The House passed a bill to exempt doctors from major provisions of the antitrust laws early today. The final vote, at 2 a.m., was 276 to 136, with a two-thirds majority heeding the doctors' pleas for relief.
The chief sponsor of the bill, Representative Tom Campbell, Republican of California, and his allies at the American Medical Association said the lopsided vote in the House would give them momentum in the Senate.
But Mr. Lott expressed opposition, saying: "I don't think we need more lawsuits in America. And I don't think we need more, you know, labor unions in America. And that's basically what they're trying to do. So I certainly don't look on it favorably. And I won't be trying to find a way to pass it, I'll tell you that."
Mr. Lott's position reduces the chances that the bill will get through the Senate this year. No senator has introduced such legislation, though Mr. Campbell and the A.M.A. are trying to find a senator, preferably a Republican, to take up the cause.
Senate Republican leaders are in no hurry to help the association. Indeed, the Republican leaders are upset with the group because doctors have worked closely with President Clinton and Democrats in Congress to pass a Democratic bill defining patients' rights in a much more expansive way than Republicans want.
The Campbell bill would exempt health care professionals from provisions of the antitrust laws when they negotiate with health maintenance organizations and insurers over fees and contract terms.
In the last 20 years, doctors have often been accused of violating the seminal antitrust law, the Sherman Act of 1890, which prohibits contracts, combinations and conspiracies in restraint of trade. The law applies to doctors as it applies to vitamin manufacturers and road construction companies.
In a typical case, the Federal Trade Commission asserted that patients and employers had been forced to bear more than $1 million in increased costs because of a price-fixing conspiracy by surgeons in Austin, Tex., in 1998 and 1999.
Doctors who are employees -- at hospitals, for example -- can join labor unions and collectively negotiate with their employers under existing law. The House bill would grant similar immunity from the antitrust laws to independent doctors.
Doctors said they needed more leverage to negotiate on working conditions, the quality of care, the number of patients they must see in a day and similar issues.
"This bill helps doctors help their patients -- nothing more, nothing less," Mr. Campbell said. "Medical professionals should be allowed to provide care for their patients as they think best, and today Congress empowered them to do so."
House passage of the Campbell bill has set off a titanic battle of lobbyists that mirrors the struggle between doctors and insurance companies to control patient care.
The A.M.A. has a formidable team of lobbyists. Dr. Donald J. Palmisano, a trustee of the association, said he sent e-mail messages to hundreds of doctors in the course of the House debate, and they flooded Congressional offices with phone calls urging passage of the Campbell bill.
In an e-mail message sent to doctors at 3:15 a.m. today, Dr. Palmisano said: "Wow! We had an impressive win. Now on to the Senate and the president. We must continue to push hard and not accept the naysayers' view. They have been 100 percent wrong so far."
Insurance companies, H.M.O.'s and business groups like the United States Chamber of Commerce have waged an even bigger campaign against the bill. They said they would press their arguments next week in meetings with senators home for the Fourth of July recess.
The bill is opposed by groups representing nurses, nurse practitioners and midwives, who fear doctors would demand that health plans restrict the role of such nonphysicians.
Antitrust officials at the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department also opposed the Campbell bill, saying it would enable doctors to raise their fees. As a result, the officials said, employers and individual purchasers of health insurance would have to pay higher premiums, and spending for Medicare and Medicaid would increase.
The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department have filed numerous cases alleging that doctors boycotted H.M.O.'s, tried to fix prices or conspired to thwart the cost-control efforts of managed care organizations. Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the commission, said the Campbell bill would legalize such conduct.
The Consumer Federation of America opposed the bill. But dozens of liberal Democrats, who take pride in being consumer advocates, voted for it, saying the bill would correct the imbalance of power between doctors and insurance companies.
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, a staunch ally of organized labor, said the bill "reinforces the value of collective bargaining in our society."
Doctors said they needed the Campbell bill so they could serve more effectively as advocates for their patients in negotiations with insurance companies.
But Travis B. Plunkett, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, said, "When doctors express such concerns, it's often merely an attempt to improve their economic position in the guise of quality of care."
The Campbell bill does not give doctors any new right to strike, or to withhold services from patients. But Mr. Pitofsky said it would give doctors "coercive power" because they could back their demands for higher fees by collectively refusing to deal with certain health plans.
Mr. Campbell is running for the Senate against Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat. She has not taken a position on the bill, but has suggested that patients would be better served if Congress simply passed the patients' bill of rights.

HEADLINE: The No. 2 Executive at Oracle Resigns Abruptly

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30

 BODY:
The Oracle Corporation, the world's second-largest software publisher, said tonight that Raymond Lane, its president and chief operating officer, had abruptly resigned.
Mr. Lane, 53, had been at Oracle for eight years and had held the post of president since 1996. Though he was the second-ranking executive in one of Silicon Valley's most powerful companies, he has always been overshadowed by Oracle's flamboyant chief executive and co-founder, Lawrence J. Ellison. 
 Mr. Lane's departure came just days after the company admitted that it had orchestrated a surveillance campaign against its archrival, the Microsoft Corporation, in an effort to prove that Microsoft was secretly financing groups that were lobbying in its defense in the federal antitrust lawsuit against it.
The spying operation led to several exposes based on documents that were supplied to reporters at The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post.
In a short statement announcing Mr. Lane's departure, Oracle gave no indication why Mr. Lane had chosen to resign. Mr. Lane made no public statement today and could not be reached tonight.
Mr. Lane will continue to serve on Oracle's board of directors, the company said.
"I am grateful to Ray for all of his efforts," Mr. Ellison said in a statement. "He will be missed. We wish him nothing but the best."
An Oracle spokeswoman, Jennifer Glass, declined to comment on why Mr. Lane was leaving his post. But she said his departure was not due to the Microsoft controversy.
"It is absolutely unrelated," she said, to the events that exploded this week when Oracle executives admitted the company had hired the Washington detective firm of Investigative Group International in an effort to link Microsoft to public relations efforts in its behalf during the trial.
Mr. Lane's departure has been rumored for months. Tonight, several people familiar with the company's internal strategy said that Mr. Lane's role has decreased in the past year and that Mr. Ellison has increasingly guided the company in a direction different from the one advocated by Mr. Lane. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: July 7, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies of Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Raymond Lane, president of the Oracle Corporation, referred imprecisely to press reports that Oracle's software rival, Microsoft, had underwritten groups backing Microsoft's antitrust defense. The error was repeated on Sunday in the Economic View column in Money & Business, about the exchange of invective between Oracle and Microsoft. The accounts of Microsoft's financial support, in The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, focused on two groups that are now known to have been targets of an Oracle-sponsored investigation. But none of the newspapers have said the documents cited in their coverage came from the Oracle operation; they have not identified the sources of their information.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;
That Spit and Polish Can Come at a Cost

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Eight hours before a $1,000-a-person fundraiser for his nascent campaign for governor, Mayor Bret Schundler stood before reporters and posed a question that to him was simple: "Should police officers get overtime for shining their shoes, doing their laundry?" he asked. "I don't think so."
The question was by no means hypothetical. Indeed, it may be precisely what a federal judge ends up asking jurors if the mayor and 625 of this city' police officers -- two-thirds of the state's second-largest police department -- cannot come to terms in a labor dispute. 
 In what experts say could significantly expand the scope of what public employees -- and perhaps any employees -- are entitled to be paid for, the officers are suing the city under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, seeking overtime for hours spent, in part, shining shoes, buffing brass buttons and otherwise polishing their appearance before leaving home to protect and serve the public.
If the officers win the suit, which was filed in United States District Court in April 1999, it could cost Jersey City taxpayers up to $50 million, including $25 million in estimated overtime, plus another $25 million in penalties the officers would be entitled to under a provision of the 62-year-old labor law if they demonstrate that the city willfully defied its obligations.
The cost of sprucing up uniforms: an estimated $5 million of the total overtime bill, plus another $5 million in penalties. The claims date back three years before the suit was filed, the period allowed under the law, said Steve Hunter, the attorney for the officers.
The case is being closely watched because of its implications for public and private employers not only in New Jersey, but around the country.
"I think that this will, in fact, establish a very dangerous precedent for other municipalities," William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. "One thing we have learned in labor matters like this, it does not stop at one union's doorstep."
Beyond a potential liability that would amount to about 15 percent of Jersey City's $313 million annual budget, the issue has implications for the political future of Mr. Schundler, the 41-year-old mayor who became a darling of Republicans nationwide after his landslide victory in 1993 in this traditionally Democratic stonghold.
Mr. Schundler -- whose star has faded somewhat as he has stumbled while trying to deal with the political complexities of running an economically and socially diverse city of a quarter-million people -- plans to run for governor next year. One reason he summoned reporters to his office last Wednesday morning was to ridicule the suit as frivolous and to head off the city's two police unions from holding a demonstration outside a fund-raiser that night at the Liberty Science Center.
"The police are asking us to sell out the taxpayers for our political peace," he said.
Tom Bell, president of the city's 710-member Police Officers Benevolent Association, and Lt. Ron Bounocore, president of the Police Superior Officers Association, which has 160 members, made no secret of their strategy to pressure Mr. Schundler into settling the suit by demonstrating in front of his supporters.
"We are going to follow him throughout the state on the road to the governership," Officer Bell said.
The union officials said it was typical of Mr. Schundler to manipulate the situation by focusing on the shoe-shining element of the suit, even though it was only one of several issues. For example, they said, the department regularly denies compensatory pay to officers forced to skip lunch.
"You are eating a doughnut on the run because you can't sit down," Lieutenant Bounocore said.
The suit also claims that $4.5 million is owed to 125 police cadets because they were denied overtime despite working 18 days during six months of training. In addition, the suit seeks compensation for the time officers spent learning law-enforcement policies. Nor, the suit claims, have officers have been compensated for appearances on behalf of Drug Awareness Resistence Education (D.A.R.E.) for children.
In the past, officers had accepted that the time spent taking care of their uniforms was part of the job, and never sought compensation, the union officials said. It was only after the mayor had failed to address the other grievances, the officials said, that they filed the suit and included the spit-and-polish issue.
The suit comes after years of steadily eroding morale in the department -- almost from the start of Mr. Schundler's tenure -- stemming from such moves as the appointment of a civilian police director, Michael Moriarty, a former federal drug prosecutor, and an attempt to have civilians take over desk jobs in the department.
After the mayor's news conference, the union officials threw their own public relations counterpunch by welcoming reporters into the aging North District station house, where they were shown dingy bathrooms, cramped lockers, flickering light fixtures and collapsing ceilings.
In the end, however, it was the mayor who seemed to win the day's public relations battle. Reporters were clearly more interested in the shoe-shine story. After a conciliatory phone call from Mr. Schundler that afternoon, Lieutenant Bounocore called off the demonstration and agreed to meet with the mayor this week. "He's extending the olive branch," Lieutenant Bonoucore said, "so our sign of good faith was that we would not demonstrate."
But the lawsuit is still very much alive, and a hearing is scheduled for September before a federal magistrate in Newark.
Mr. Hunter said he was confident he would prevail -- even on the shoe-shine claim. He cited a ruling by Judge Alfred A. Wolin in Federal District Court in Newark last year in favor of officers in the Bergen County sheriff's K-9 unit who had sought overtime for the home care of their canine partners. He contended that Judge Wolin also suggested officers could put in for overtime related to other tasks, including the care and maintenance of their uniforms.
Nonetheless, the city's labor lawyer, Martin Pachman, was unfazed.
"We believe Judge Wolin was wrong," Mr. Pachman said, although he declined to cite legal precedent contradicting the judge.
Spokesmen for the state and federal Departments of Labor said they had never heard of an overtime claim for time spent spiffing up uniforms. Neither had William J. Kearns Jr., president of the International Municipal Lawyers Association. Mr. Kearns, a former mayor of Willingboro, who is also general counsel for the state League of Municipalities, said the Jersey City suit "is certainly pushing the envelope" for overtime claims, almost to the point of the absurd.
"Where are we going to draw the line?" Mr. Kearns said. "Are we going to pay them for taking their shower in the morning?"

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
A Madison Avenue Fantasy

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month.
E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE hit television show "Survivor" is credited with rejuvenating CBS, attracting loads of those coveted viewers between 18 and 49. That means the network, which mature Americans have long called their own, can now sell more ads at higher prices.
What remains difficult to understand is why Network Row and Madison Avenue think young eyeballs are worth more to them than older ones. 
 Consider these statistics:
* Seven baby boomers will turn 50 every minute until 2014, according to American Demographics magazine.
* People over 50 have half the nation's disposable income, and those over 65 enjoy twice the discretionary income of people 25 to 34, according to Theodore Roszak, the author of "America the Wise: The Longevity Revolution and the True Wealth of Nations."
* The net worth of households headed by people over 60 grew by 30 percent over the last decade, double the national average, according to a recent survey by the University of Michigan.
So what's going on? Why are advertisers acting like a bunch of anti-Willie Suttons, aiming where the money increasingly isn't?
Mr. Roszak suggests that corporate America and its media are at war with the Census Bureau. In a 1998 article in Civilization, the magazine of the Library of Congress, he put it succinctly: "The young are a vanishing breed. The future lies with the old."
While war may be too strong a metaphor, and the young aren't really about to vanish, there is little doubt that the advertising industry is generally well behind the curve of America's changing demographic landscape. And the reason may lie in the demographics of the advertising business, where many decisions are made by people in their 20's and 30's who have only the vaguest notion of, or interest in, life past 50.
Ann A. Fishman, 58, the president of the Generational-Targeted Marketing Corporation in New Orleans, recalls a meeting she once had at an ad agency in New York. "I was struck by the fact that every person I met except one was young," she said. "But you can't have one age group watching the store. You wind up not being sensitive to the various generational groups."
Nowhere is the disconnect between Madison Avenue and demographic reality more obvious than inside the covers of Modern Maturity, published every other month by AARP. The magazine has two versions, for working and retired subscribers, and a total circulation of 20.5 million, the largest of any magazine and almost double each of its two closest competitors, Reader's Digest and TV Guide, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. By further comparison, Ladies' Home Journal and Good Housekeeping have a circulation of 4.5 million each; Time magazine's is 4.1 million.
But you would never guess the circulation of Modern Maturity from its advertising volume. Publications aimed at younger people -- like women's fashion magazines, or Maxim for young men, or Fast Company or Red Herring, which focus on technology, business and the Internet -- attract so much advertising that they can be as fat as phone books. But not Modern Maturity.
Some of this youth-market myopia, however, is likely to fade as the 80 million baby boomers and their money decamp into the golden years.
Bill Novelli, associate executive director of public affairs for AARP, says Modern Maturity is trying to position itself to rise with the boomer tide. In 1998, the organization ditched its old name, the American Association of Retired Persons. Surveys and focus groups show that boomers hate words like "retired" that remind them of "old." And a lot of people in their 60's and 70's don't think of themselves as old, either.
"There are big changes coming in the magazine," he said. "It's going to become more of a lifestyle magazine, more vibrant and youthful in its aim. We think we have enough elasticity to appeal to both the 55-year-olds and the 75-year-olds." Recent covers, featuring celebrities like Paul Newman, Judge Judy and Cheryl Tiegs, are signals of the changes, he said.
He also said executives are considering a switch to monthly publication, the addition of newsstand sales and, perhaps, a change in name.
The repositioning will make the magazine more boomer-friendly just as the advertising industry is about to be jerked into reality by that aging group and its buying power.
"Media buyers and media planners are young," Mr. Novelli said. "A mind change has to take place. But they are awakening."
And yet: Modern Maturity, which already charges advertisers about one-third as much per subscriber as Time does, is considering cutting its ad rates.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 6; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 228 words

HEADLINE: AMERICAN SONG;
Emotion's Value

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Anthony Tommasini's article about the facile, pandering, pop-influenced, non-intellectually rigorous, sentimental new generation of American art song composers "A Sudden, Facile Flowering of American Song," June 11 has left my heart pounding in my chest.
Mr. Tommasini's compliments fall to composers whose work he describes as "abstract," "economical," "astringent," "complex," "knotty," "rigorous," "jagged," "pungent" and "lean and spiky." Ricky Ian Gordon is influenced by pop music. Horrors. Because his music is accessibly lyrical, he is seen as trying "to bridge popular and concert styles." Horrors again. Because Emily Dickinson's "Will There Really Be a Morning" is, as described by Mr. Tommasini, an "acute, unflinching poetic" reflection, it therefore suffers from the song's lack of knots, jags, spikes and astringencies. 
 "Will There Really Be a Morning" is set in a breathtaking sweep of sadness and longing by Mr. Gordon, written, undoubtedly, in a burst of emotion that disqualifies it from Mr. Tommasini's high regard. That Mr. Gordon's sophisticated and original songwriting is beautiful, and moving, and a product in part of its times is O.K. with this little pilgrim. A song need not be inaccessible, "knotty," "spiky" or "jagged" to be challenging -- or to be art.
 
LESLIE LIPTON
North Hollywood, Calif.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Kristina Putalik, Amos Klausner

 BODY:
Kristina Lee Putalik and Amos Joseph Klausner were married last evening in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner, the bridegroom's father, performed the ceremony at the Castle at Tarrytown.
The bride and bridegroom, both 28, have known each other since grade school and began dating at Byram Hills High School in Armonk, N.Y., where they grew up. They now live and work in California and are developing a Web site for entertainment and research for pre-teenage children. The bride teaches the third grade at the Park School in Mill Valley, and the bridegroom is the director of the San Francisco chapter of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, a professional organization. 
 The bride graduated from Connecticut College and received a master's degree in elementary education from the Bank Street College of Education. Her parents, Ann and Thomas L. Putalik, live in Armonk, where the bride's father is a management consultant and her mother is a broker for Vannier Real Estate.
The bridegroom graduated from Boston University. His mother, Judith Klausner, and father now live in Santa Fe, N.M. The bridegroom's mother is a sculptor in bronze. His father retired from Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers.
The couple became engaged last summer while hiking in the Dolomite Mountains in Italy. The bridegroom picked a bouquet of wildflowers and then presented the bride with a diamond ring that came into his father's hands at the end of World War II, when he was a United States Army chaplain in Europe.
"I was really skeptical about having an old ring, because I didn't know who had had it prior to me -- I was nervous that maybe it wasn't a happy marriage," Ms. Putalik said. "But when I heard the story of the ring, I felt so blessed, because the story to me means that two lovers were able to be together, and it brought a family back together."
The ring was originally given to Rabbi Klausner by a woman in Munich to be used in lieu of bail to obtain her husband's release from the Army Detainment Center. The rabbi secured the man's freedom without having to give up the ring, but before he could return it to the woman, the reunited couple had disappeared from Munich.
Rabbi Klausner later gave the ring to be used as a black-market payment in helping a survivor of the Holocaust find his daughter. Years later, in Israel, the man and his wife met the black marketeer who had accepted the ring as payment and bought it back from him.
In 1966, Rabbi and Mrs. Klausner, just married, traveled to Israel and visited the couple. Their hosts presented the ring to the new bride.
"It just seems that it fits," Ms. Putalik said. "This ring has survived, and our relationship has survived, and it makes sense."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Those Were The Days All Right. But No More.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
TIME flies when you're having fun. Zip-zap, and suddenly the year is halfway over.
Trouble is, for most investors the last six months have not been a lot of laughs. All three major market indexes are under water for the year. 
 The last time that happened was in 1994, according to Birinyi & Associates, a stock market research firm. And the midyear tally stands in sharp relief to the first six months of 1999, when the Dow Jones industrial average was up nearly 20 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500 was up almost 12 percent and the Nasdaq gained 22.5 percent.
But that's old news. The issue now is what happens from here to New Year's Eve.
Byron R. Wien, chief United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, took some time last week to revisit the recent past and to talk about the next six months. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Did the market pan out in the first half as you thought it might?
 
A. From the beginning of the year, I thought the market was going to have a rough time of it. The first six months haven't been as rough as I thought they would be, but it has been a difficult market. This is the first year in the last six that it has had a difficult time.
I also thought that people would begin to take a tougher look at technology stocks. And I anticipated that the price of oil would go up to $30 a barrel and stay there. I thought that would benefit energy and oil and service stocks, and it has, but not as much as I thought.
 
Q. Some people think the Fed is about done tightening, and that the market is poised to do better when it stops. Do you agree?
 
A. I think it is naive to think the economy will slow down enough for the Fed to indicate publicly that they are done.
The Fed might move to a neutral policy position. The economy is clearly slowing as it responds to a deceleration in money supply growth, and that will take some near-term pressure off interest rates.
I don't think a recession is anywhere in sight, but I do think we are going to have slower growth and a deceleration in profit growth. But inflation is going up. So I don't think the Fed will tell investors to relax.
 
Q. Does that mean the market will remain under pressure for the balance of the year?
 
A. Since the market's performance in the first half was a bit better than I had anticipated, it means the second half will be a little worse than I had hoped. By the end of the year, I expect the major averages will be within 10 percentage points of where they finished in 1999. Basically, this is not going to be a big money-making year.

Q. Do you expect more market volatility?
 
A. I don't know if conditions will be as volatile as they were, but I expect volatility to stay high.
The volatility we have seen is not due to the Fed, which is doing what is expected. It has to do with the fact that people are trying too hard. They are used to making a lot of money in the stock market, and they are impatient. They tend to migrate to where the action is, which is what creates the volatility. But there will not be a lot of discernible trends over the next six months.
 
Q. Has the correction we have seen in technology stocks made them attractive buys?
 
A. I own a lot of technology stocks, and I like a lot of technology stocks, but it is hard for me to say there are a lot of outstanding values here. Even the technology stocks I bought recently, JDS Uniphase and Brocade, are not cheap. Intel, another favorite of mine, is not cheap.
 
Q. Are there stocks you think should do well over the next six months or more?
 
A. I still think energy stocks will do well. I think there are some opportunities in old-economy stocks, including financials. Biotechnology and health care companies intrigue me. And hospital management companies are undervalued, even though they have come back a bit.
As far as individual names are concerned, in hospital management I like Columbia/ HCA HCA -- the Healthcare Company , Tenet Health Care and Health Management Associates. Immunex is a biotech company I like. And in energy I like Tosco, Exxon Mobil and BP Amoco.
 
Q. Will the results of the November election matter to the stock market?
 
A. The only way the election could have an impact is if the same party wins control of both the White House and Congress. If that happens it would be bad. The status quo has been fine for financial markets.
It would be bad because if Gore wins and the Democrats take the House, his spending programs will be negative for the market. And if Bush wins and the Republicans keep control in Congress, his tax program will go through. But it will be too stimulative and result in additional tightening.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE;
Off the Managed-Care Treadmill

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the first Sunday of each month.
E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
JOSEPH HADDAD, a pediatric ear, nose and throat doctor in Manhattan, said he realized how dropping out of managed care was paying off for him as he sat watching his son's preschool graduation. Dr. Haddad's workload has shrunk markedly -- 20 percent fewer surgical cases, a similar decline in office visits -- since he stopped abiding by the insurers' fee scales last year.
Now he is home for dinner most nights and can attend his older son's activities. "You realize how important that is when your kid keeps waving at you the whole time," he said, recalling the graduation ceremony. Ditching managed care, he said, "was really a quality-of-life issue." 
 A number of doctors around the country have taken the same calculated risk in the last few years, by deciding to stop settling for what insurance would pay. They cite low reimbursement rates that forced them to make up revenue in volume, crowding their waiting rooms with patients and rushing their care. The pace and the paperwork stole too much time from their personal lives, the doctors say. And frankly, some just disliked making less money.
Most of these rebel doctors practice in cities where there are plenty of affluent patients who can pay cash or who have access to old-fashioned indemnity insurance that simply reimburses the patient for most of the bill. Doctors in suburbs where managed care has all but cornered the health insurance market have less scope to drop out.
Barney Softness, a pediatrician on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, decided last year to tell his managed-care patients -- who made up about one-third of his busy practice -- that he would no longer accept their insurance. Half left immediately, and he finished the year on a sour financial note. But he was happy.
"A great benefit was, it was much quieter," Dr. Softness said. He and his partners were able to reduce the number of patients each saw in an hour to just four, from five or six under managed care. "We had time to do it right," he said.
Then something happened: The lost patients started coming back. "Some said, 'It is worth it to us,' " Dr. Softness said, "the implication being that they were getting mill-like treatment." Now, he said, "we are back to being as busy as we were." If it gets too busy, he said, he may have to stop accepting new patients.
As it happens, I have firsthand experience of the changes in Dr. Softness's practice: My own baby has been seen by his partners since shortly after they dropped the plans. Care was great, service speedy at first; lately, I've been kept waiting from 10 to 40 minutes, though once we get into an examination room, I still feel that my child is the only one the doctor is seeing that day. I'm a loyal fan.
And yet, my own primary-care doctor, who accepts many insurance plans, never makes me wait, and never rushes me either.
In fact, few patients feel that their doctors neglect their care as a result of insurance company pressures, according to a new survey by the Center for Studying Health System Change, an independent research organization in Washington. The study, based on interviews with 59,000 Americans, found that while 44 percent thought that the companies do influence doctors' care decisions, only 7 percent said they believed doctors put insurers' interests ahead of patients' needs. The center got similar results in 1997, before the backlash against managed care had gathered steam.
The response may mean that patients are simply not aware of how stressed-out their doctors are. Or it may signal that patients do not agree with their doctors' view that quality erodes as revenues rise. Even if they do agree, most patients have little choice: few earn enough to afford doctors' fees on their own, and doctors say they have had to turn away patients for financial reasons. "There are a lot of interesting cases that I might want to do, but can't, because the families are constrained by their choice of insurance," Dr. Haddad said.
JONATHAN SHELDON, a family doctor in Denver who opened a no-managed-care office after working for a managed-care company in Vermont, said he has found a way around the problem. He charges patients $4 a minute. If he sees them for 10 minutes, they pay $40, which, he said, is cheaper than an office visit at most nearby clinics. "It is a win-win," he said. "I have patients who are rich and poor, and they come because they love the service."
At a clinic, a patient might pay $60 for a 10-minute visit -- or the same for an hour, making it hard to say if Dr. Sheldon's approach really optimizes care and cost for patients.
Most doctors do not have the chance to test such theories. Peter Shutkin, an internist in New Canaan, Conn., recently decided that he had had enough of Aetna. But while he may fantasize about extending the take-a-hike message to the other four plans he accepts, he knows it's no use. "Practically, I don't think it would work," Dr. Shutkin said. "I wouldn't have any patients left."

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER; E-mail address: daschn@nytimes.com

 BODY:

Brazilians Shine
 
Q.: Is it true that most shoeshine men around town are Brazilian?
 
A.: Actually, yes. Though the study of employment patterns in immigrant communities is an imprecise science, a study by Maxine L. Margolis, a professor of anthropology at the University of Florida, estimates that 90 to 95 percent of the shoeshine men working in the city are Brazilian. 
 Many, in fact are from the same town: Governador Valadares, a city of 250,000 in Brazil's arid interior that since the 1960's has seen a large percentage of its population migrate to New York to escape that country's economic chaos and hyperinflation. Many work long days at menial jobs like washing dishes, cleaning houses or driving livery cabs, then return home after several years with what amounts to a small fortune.
In "An Invisible Minority: Brazilians in New York City" (Allyn & Bacon, 1998), Ms. Margolis writes that in the 1960's, two brothers left Governador Valadares and found jobs shining shoes in Midtown. "Word filtered back of the money to be made, and by the end of the decade a small contingent of Brazilians were shining shoes in the vicinity of Grand Central Station," she writes.
"Their numbers slowly increased as networks of friends and relatives found shoeshine jobs for new arrivals in the city, and by the early 1980's this job sector, once the domain of African-Americans, was monopolized by Brazilians."
 
Getting Rid of Grit
 
Q.: What goes on inside the low, 30's-style industrial building at 110th Street and the F.D.R. Drive? The words "Manhattan Grit Chamber" are carved above the door.
 
A.: In communities like New York City, where glass, sand and gravel wash into the sewer along with storm water, a grit chamber is sometimes used to allow heavy, abrasive materials to settle before they can damage pumps or clog pipes at a water treatment facility.
Geoffrey Ryan, spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said in the mid-30's, planners worried that grit would clog the deep underground tunnels linking sewers in Manhattan and the Bronx to the new water pollution control plant at Wards Island.
The city built two grit chambers, this one and a Beaux-Arts gem designed by McKim, Mead & White on Bruckner Boulevard in Mott Haven, the Bronx. The chambers are emptied every few days and their contents trucked to out-of-state landfill sites. They function today exactly as they did in the 1930's, Mr. Ryan said, but grit chambers were not deemed necessary for the city's 13 other water treatment plants.
 
Why Time Stands Still
 
Q.: What happened to the clock on the steeple of St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery? I used to consult it on my way to and from work, but it's been stuck at 6:05 for ages, and I wonder if it will be repaired before I retire.
 
A.: The clock was hit by lightning late last summer and hasn't ticked since, said Joan Coddington, administrator of the church. St. Mark's, built in 1799, is the city's second-oldest church building, after St. Paul's Chapel on lower Broadway (1766). The steeple wasn't added until 1828 and the carillon clock, which unlike the rest of the church is not a city landmark, dates from a renovation after a catastrophic 1978 fire.
The church still awaits an estimate of repair costs, and an insurance settlement has not been negotiated, Ms. Coddington said.
"We are a very poor church, with a congregation of about 60 people," she said. "We have no idea what it will cost. We might have to put together a public appeal."
The carillon still chimes on the quarter hour, she said, though one note sounds off key. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
A Plea for an 'Emerald Necklace,' But State Prefers Basic Blacktop

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY

 BODY:
A new waterfront esplanade along the East River?
Some residents see it as a possibility when the state renovates part of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive beginning next year and engineers build a temporary floating highway along the river from 53rd to 62nd Streets. 
 The state says that will not happen, but residents and politicians are demanding some kind of access on that stretch of river along with the highway project as part of the long-promised "emerald necklace" of parkland that is eventually supposed to encircle Manhattan.
Last month, Community Board 6 approved a resolution urging the State Department of Transportation, which will rebuild the deteriorated section of highway, to include "some form of waterfront esplanade that considers community concerns."
"We do badly need waterfront access in this area," said Carol Pieper, the board's district manager. She added that the City Planning Department and the New York City Economic Development Corporation had a long-stated-goal of ringing Manhattan with a seamless pedestrian and bicycle route along the waterfront. There are now many gaps along the East River, including the area in question.
The state will begin building two lanes of highway for northbound traffic on the river in 2001 so work can begin on the highway, which is capped by a overhanging structure that is leaking and needs repair, said Alex Dudley, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation. The floating highway will be used for northbound traffic, and the existing northbound lanes will be used for southbound traffic to permit repair of the current southbound lanes.
Some community leaders think that when it is time to remove the temporary highway, many people will ask why it cannot stay.
"Personally, I'd love to see an esplanade, but not everyone agrees," said Mary Clare Bergin, president of Sutton Area Committee. She said residents of the east side of Sutton Place, directly over the river, opposed an esplanade for privacy reasons.
Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis said he doubted that the temporary roadway would become permanent, "though it would be the best of all possible worlds."
"But you never know," he said. "Many so-called temporary things, like community gardens, have become permanent fixtures after turning into a cause celebre."
Mr. Dudley said the Coast Guard and other agencies would issue permits only under the condition that the roadway be temporary, adding that it would create environmental and navigation safety hazards.
"One day, we could possibly build an esplanade there," Mr. Dudley said. "But for now, it will have to be the clasp in the emerald necklace." DAVID KIRBY

LENGTH: 1143 words

HEADLINE: Don't Get Out Much? You'll Love This Store

BYLINE: By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
THE sight of the couple draped across the bed engaged in cozy pillow talk was more than a little disconcerting. Stumbling on the scene, one wasn't sure whether to eavesdrop, look the other way or join the lovebirds on the sheets.
Convincing as it was, this slice of life was in fact a performance, enacted by models and staged at a party last Wednesday night at the Apartment, a strenuously hip fashion and home furnishings store masquerading as a private residence. 
 A 3,000-square-foot duplex at 101 Crosby Street, where SoHo meets NoLIta, the Apartment is a showcase for furniture, cooking equipment and bathroom units by European design specialists like Boffi and Duravit. But it's also a site for vanguard fashions and accessories by the British label Not Tom Dick and Harry, and the French design team Marithe & Francois Girbaud.
The store, which feels like an animated version of Wallpaper, the British shelter magazine, represents the latest variation on retailing as theater, one in which the shop is a stage, the products props and the shopper both performer and spectator.
The concept of themed, interactive retailing was pioneered in the 90's when innovative retail operations like Niketown started staging multimedia happenings, and Recreational Equipment Inc., or R.E.I., in Seattle, offered a trail loop for bicycle test drives and a "rain room" to try out Gore-Tex slickers.
But the owners of the Apartment, Stefan Boublil and Gina Alvarez, who are married to each other, took the idea of consumer participation and refined it into an art form. Every item in the store, from the Phillipe Starck notepads on the desks and the Girbaud suede slippers at the foot of the bed to the bed itself, a walnut platform priced at $5,900, will be for sale July 1, when the store opens to the public.
At the preview party, visitors were encouraged to try things out on the spot, including the Boffi shower.
Even so, the wares seemed incidental, playing a supporting role to the action unfolding throughout the store. In the bathroom, some people removed their shoes, massaging their soles on the pebbled floor. In the kitchen, a chef from Le Gamin, a cafe in SoHo, flipped crepes in a pan. And across the room, a pair of actors staged an all-out brawl, hurling invective, along with papers and objects, to lend the evening, one supposed, a touch of gritty naturalism.
"Our idea," said Mr. Boublil, a Parisian who also maintains a career as an independent filmmaker, "was to introduce the idea of voyeurism right from the start."
The Apartment has a Web site where with a click of the mouse one can rearrange furniture on a small floor plan or look in on Chloe and Rebekka, fictional residents. But Mr. Boublil and Ms. Alvarez envisioned the store less as a partner of an Internet site and more as a variation on so-called reality entertainment. It was modeled, they said, on popular television shows like "Cops" and "The Real World," whose protagonists are ordinary people living their lives in front of the camera.
With its interactive, imitation-of-life approach to retailing, the store recalls -- and improves on -- the static model rooms of the 1970's created by Bloomingdale's and other stores to help customers envision products in a context. But in some ways the Apartment has more in common with theme parks and restaurants in exploiting consumers' fascination with simulated reality. Sniffing, tasting and touching the wares, chatting with staff and other customers, the shopper becomes an actor.
When you walk into such a store, "you take on a role in front of other individuals who are now watching you," said B. Joseph Pine II, the co-author with James H. Gilmore of "The Experience Economy" (Harvard Business School Press, 1999). The book, subtitled "Work Is Theater & Every Business a Stage," argues that in the future consumers will likely place greater value on the experience of shopping than on goods and services. "Creating an experience, by encouraging customers to act out their fantasies in a store, much as they would at a Renaissance fair, draws the customer right in," Mr. Pine said.
Some designers and merchants view the Apartment as altogether novel. But Lee Peterson, the creative director of retail strategies at Chute Gerdeman, a Columbus, Ohio, retail design company, explored the notion of store as stage a year ago, before Mr. Boublil and Ms. Alvarezdreamed up the Apartment.
At the time, Wolverine World Wide, the maker of Hush Puppies and other footwear brands, asked for a fresh concept for UP Footgear, its new mall-based stores. Chute Gerdeman responded with a Web concept called "I See Me." The idea, Mr. Peterson explained, is that you can watch yourself walk into the door of the store on the computer screen. "What's more," he said, "you can call up your friends, they can open the Web site at home, and there you'll be."
The strategy is evidently aimed at a generation for whom nothing is real until it is on television. The store's design serves to heighten the sense of reality. UP Footgear's prototype, at the new RiverTown Crossing mall in Grandville, Mich., is a loft-like setting complete with sofas, chairs, framed photos and a breakfast bar, a place that the cast of "Friends" or "Real People" might call home. "This setting goes beyond conventional lifestyle retailing," Mr. Peterson said. "It perfects the illusion that you are already living the life."
The experiment seems to be working. Blaine Jungers, the president of Hush Puppies' retail division, said, "At the Grandville mall, UP Footgear, one of eight shoe stores, ranks third in sales, just behind value-oriented retailers like Payless."
The store, he noted, "encourages people to congregate." At a second store, scheduled to open July 22 in Grand Rapids, the checkout area will be in the kitchen. "That's where people gravitate at parties," he said. "We want them to hang out, just the way they would at home."
Mr. Boublil and Ms. Alvarez would like customers to feel just as comfy at the Apartment. "We want this to be a meeting place absolutely," Mr. Boublil said, "where people lose track of the world outside."
During the Apartment party, people did just that. One couple became so absorbed in checking out the merchandise, watching other guests and being watched themselves, they seemed to forget they had left a stroller parked outside just beyond the plate-glass window. In it, their twins slumbered peacefully, attended by a security guard.
So inclined were guests to dream and loiter, one wondered how the store might shoo them out. "We're working on a strategy for that," Mr. Boublil said.
But until they have perfected it, the owners say they'll fall back on a time-honored ploy for disposing of guests. "I'll just tell them," Ms. Alvarez said brightly, "that I'm going to take a shower."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 814 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Toffs and Machiavels;
In Sports and On Screen, the British Don't Get No Respect

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN its understated way, Britain is the Edward I. Koch of nations, endlessly wondering "How'm I doing?" But unlike Mr. Koch, the self-congratulating former mayor of New York, Britain rarely expects a positive answer. And lately, a nation that is always sensitive about perceived slights to its international status has found more than usual to be upset about.
Not only did CBS News recently report that some crime in England is far worse than in the United States, but England's soccer team ignominiously lost to Romania (Romania!) in the Euro 2000 tournament. Then, the country's No. 2 tennis player, Greg Rusedski, was blown out of Wimbledon on opening day by Vincent Spadea, an American known to British newspapers as "the world's biggest loser" because he had lost 22 of his last 22 matches. 
 And now along comes "The Patriot," a film about the American Revolution that presents the English as effete war criminals with snobby accents who herd families of fledgling Americans into barns and set them on fire, just for fun. To Britons sick of being pushed around, this obnoxious affront to retrospective pride may be the last straw.
The film hasn't even opened here yet, but the newspapers have been full of outrage at what they see as wanton disregard for the historical record. Maybe the war was dirty and violent at times, they say, but their soldiers certainly never shot children or minced around in the creepy manner of Nazi generals. And it's no accident that Mel Gibson stars in the film, they say -- he's Australian.
"As every Hollywood casting agent knows, the devil speaks with an English accent," Neil Norman wrote in The Evening Standard, deploring how "to a man, the dastardly English are presented as heartless toffs and Machiavels, war criminals and child-killers."
Why do the British persist in casting everything in terms of national pride? Shouldn't they just lighten up?
"We have a significant pride in what we achieved in the past with regard to the British empire, and we don't like to see it unfairly traduced," explained the British historian Andrew Roberts. This puffed-up feeling about the past, he said, is inextricably linked to a sadly deflated view of the present.
"What is there to be proud of?" he asked, musing crossly about the European Union. "What are we doing now? We're getting sucked into some amorphous European superstate, largely against our will. As a nation we haven't achieved much since 1945, and the things that we are rightly proud of are being taken away from us by the distortions of a foreign entertainment industry."
"The Patriot," of course, is just one in a recent series of Hollywood slights perpetrated on the British -- and more specifically, the English. There were the Englishmen in "Titanic," who battened down the hatches to prevent the declasse, mostly Irish, lower-deck passengers from escaping. Then there was Anthony Hopkins, the repellant hissing villain in "The Silence of the Lambs." And don't forget Mr. Gibson's "Braveheart," in which the English are shown raping, slaughtering and pillaging their way through 13th-century Scotland.
More worryingly, Britons don't figure in "U-571," a recent film starring Matthew McConaughey as the leader of a band of Americans on a submarine who capture the German Enigma code-making machine in World War II. In real life, the Americans didn't capture the code -- the British did.
It wasn't always this way. Before the Communists, when the Nazis were still the worst villains, World War II movies regularly showed the British and Americans working together to repel the heinous Germans.
"Up until quite recently, films made in America were on the whole quite admiring of the British and British history," said Jeffrey Richards, a professor of cultural history at the University of Lancaster. Since then, he said, the British film market has virtually disappeared, and Hollywood no longer cares whether it alienates British viewers.
THE British are feeling alienated a lot these days. But no matter what other people say about them, it's not as bad as what they say about themselves -- particularly when they lose at sports.
"We have this absurd obsession with sport," Mr. Roberts said. "Even though, since 1967, we've been beaten at all the sports we invented, after 30 years we still get into great emotional upsets. The things we should be looking at seriously are things like Britain's great economy, but instead we get into a huge tussle about whether Greg Rusedski has a good day at Wimbledon."
When the unfortunate Rusedski lost to Spadea, the hapless American who had been touring the world losing one match after another for eight months, The Times of London just couldn't control itself.
"When you are on a 22 match, world-record losing streak," it wrote, "there is only one person capable of ending your misery: a British sports star."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
For a Brazilian Banker, The Highest Perch

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
THERE are the investment bankers who talk of things like deficit figures and inflation targets when discussing Brazil, Latin America's largest economy. Then there are the bankers, like Francisco Gros, who talk of Miss Piggy.
As a high-ranking executive at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Mr. Gros wrote in an online newsletter late last year that "we Brazilians suffer from what could be called 'Miss Piggy' syndrome -- we believe ourselves to be wonderful, while others, unfortunately, do not see us quite that way." 
 As one of Brazil's leading figures on Wall Street, Mr. Gros developed a reputation for talking tough. Now, however, he is toning down his approach after being named in February to one of the most coveted posts in Brazil's government, the presidency of the country's powerful development bank.
"I hope that stuff doesn't come back to haunt me," said Mr. Gros, who is 57.
He probably does not have much to worry about, given his reputation as a consummate insider among the coterie of Ivy League-educated economists, bankers and academics who have run Brazil for much of the past decade. But many other Brazilians question whether their interests are best served by a group of bankers bent on globalization.
Mr. Gros says he wants the bank to temper its worldly investing approach with a renewed emphasis on lending to small and medium-sized companies. But the bank still concentrates on supporting major companies in industries like steel and telecommunications.
Among Brazil's worldly group of financiers, perhaps no one is worldlier than Mr. Gros. The son of a French diplomat, he grew up on three continents, in Brazil, France and the United States, and attended Princeton as an undergraduate. After graduate school in economics at Columbia, he returned to Brazil and began a career in the high-flying financial circles of Rio de Janeiro.
Soon, he began playing the game of musical chairs that is familiar in Brazil, in which leading figures from the private sector accept high-profile jobs in government, then return to the private sector.
Between stints as an executive at Unibanco, one of Brazil's largest banks, and as president of Aracruz Celulose S.A., a large manufacturer of eucalyptus pulp used in paper products, Mr. Gros served twice as president of the country's central bank. He was also a partner in a small investment bank, Banco BFC S.A.
After his last term at the central bank, which ended in 1992, he returned to the private sector. He joined Morgan Stanley as its chairman for Latin America, helping to build the institution into a leading investment banking presence in the region.
Jetting between his homes in New York and Rio, Mr. Gros became a fixture on network television here, discussing the direction of the world's ninth-largest economy. His candid assessment of Brazil's challenges made him a favorite among journalists.
So few people were surprised by his appointment by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to head the National Bank for Economic and Social Development, a multilayered institution that rivals international lending organizations like the World Bank in its size. It is known as the B.N.D.E.S., its initials in Portuguese.
With the exception of Banco do Brasil S.A., another institution controlled by the government that focuses more on consumer banking, the development bank is probably the most powerful financial institution in Brazil.
"It is a banker's dream to run the B.N.D.E.S.," said Edmar Bacha, a former president of the development bank who now heads the New York office of Banco BBA-Creditanstalt. "It is the only domestic provider of long-term capital, and its size makes it one of the most powerful institutions, financial or otherwise, in the country."
The bank has the largest lending budget of any Brazilian bank, at nearly 24 billion reais, or $13.2 billion. During the Cardoso administration, which began in 1995, a fivefold increase in its government support transformed the bank from a financier of infrastructure projects into the main arm of economic policy.
As Brazil opened its economy to foreign investment and competition, the bank was there at every step. The bank guided the world's largest privatization program in the 1990's, selling some $90 billion of state assets. Often, this role put it in touch with the world's leading investment banks, which competed to handle the sales.
Under Mr. Gros's tutelage, Morgan Stanley won one such contract, serving as co-manager with Salomon Smith Barney for the $21 billion privatization of Brazil's telecommunications monopoly in 1998.
Through its investment banking unit, modeled on the International Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of the World Bank, the development bank financed many of these takeovers.
In fact, the freewheeling use of its funds, which it provided to companies regardless of their national origin, has been a major source of criticism by opponents of the government's privatization program. Last week in Brasilia, left-wing congressmen moved to limit the bank's financing capabilities in privatization deals.
"I don't see why a public institution in a poor country like Brazil is providing money to foreign companies that have cheap access to borrowing overseas," said Aloizio Mercadante, a Sao Paulo congressman from the Workers Party.
Because of the bank's big role in guiding policy, Mr. Gros will have to mitigate the tension resulting from a government seeking to rapidly modernize the economy and an opposition questioning whether Brazil is bending too far in its rush to globalization.
"Brazil is at a stage in which it needs something more than people who see the country as a balance sheet," said Clovis Rossi, a columnist for Folha de Sao Paulo, Brazil's most widely read newspaper. "It may be that neo-nationalists don't help the economy to grow further, but a collection of bankers does not seem to be the best alternative."
TO be sure, Mr. Gros is not alone among high-ranking officials in having a background in international finance. The central bank president, Arminio Fraga, a close friend, is a former hedge fund manager for George Soros. Another former banker, Development Minister Alcides Tapias, is Mr. Gros's immediate superior.
"We're a cosmopolitan bunch, but that alone is not enough," Mr. Gros said. "Accepting the inevitability of an open economy and preparing Brazil for a growing global role are the challenges ahead."
