PUB-DATE: July 2, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 3018 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Two American Anthems, in Two American Voices

BYLINE: By JODY ROSEN; Jody Rosen, a freelance writer in New York, is working on a book about Irving Berlin's "White Christmas."

 BODY:
IN October 1938, Irving Berlin came home to New York from the London premiere of his latest musical film, "Alexander's Ragtime Band," determined to write a "peace song" -- an anthem to soothe an American public weary from the Depression years and unnerved by the specter of Europe on the brink of war.
For over a quarter of a century, Berlin had been the country's leading songwriter, a pop poet laureate with an unwavering feel for the vagaries of mass taste. He had spent the better part of the 1930's at work in the Hollywood fairy-tale factory, feeding public desire for buoyant escapism with little masterpieces of tuneful, elegant insouciance: "Isn't This a Lovely Day?," "Top Hat, White Tie and Tails," "I've Got My Love to Keep Me Warm." But by the autumn of 1938, history had caught up with pop culture's bon vivants in evening clothes. Millions of Americans were still unemployed and destitute; Hitler was menacing Europe -- the Munich pact had just been signed -- Spain was rent by civil war, and suddenly, the spectacle of Fred Astaire twirling through a penthouse with a cocktail shaker felt decadent and unseemly. 
 Berlin set out to write a song that was the antithesis of 30's cosmopolitan cool -- an earnest, spirit-boosting anthem for troubled times. He made several unsuccessful passes at the project before he remembered a number he had abandoned two decades earlier: a bit of purplish patriotic verse, set to a rousing tune, originally written in 1918 for his World War I-themed revue, "Yip Yip Yaphank." Berlin dragged out the old song, tinkered with a few lines, adjusted a musical phrase and gave it to Kate Smith, the radio star whose wholesome image and fervent vocal style were a perfect match for the song's rostrum-pounding sentimentality.
Smith introduced "God Bless America" on her radio show on Armistice Day, Nov. 11, 1938. It was an instant sensation. Within weeks, the song was ubiquitous: crackling across radio airwaves, sung in churches, schools and ballparks, widely championed as a replacement for Francis Scott Key's ungainly "The Star-Spangled Banner." In a war-era pop culture filled with mawkish and bellicose patriotism, "God Bless America" stood out: more of a benediction than a rally-round-the-flag fight song, it both registered Americans' anxiety and provided a sense of reassurance and communal uplift. It was, in a hit-making career that spanned six decades, perhaps the greatest single example of Berlin's populist largesse. "A good song embodies the feelings of the mob," he once said. "And a songwriter is not much more than a mirror which reflects those feelings."
BUT not every American took solace in the skyward-striving strains of "God Bless America." In the winter of 1940, Woody Guthrie was bedeviled by the song: everywhere he went, Kate Smith's belting seemed to follow him; the more he heard the song, the angrier he got.
Guthrie may have been the only other major American songwriter as prolific as Berlin; in almost every other way, he was Berlin's opposite. While Berlin spent the Great Depression writing tunes for Broadway shows and Hollywood musicals, living in a plush Manhattan apartment and camping out in Beverly Hills hotel suites, Guthrie lived as a hobo, crisscrossing the West in railroad cars, working odd jobs, churning out wry, politically pointed folk songs on an acoustic guitar that bore the legend "This Machine Kills Fascists."
By 1940, Guthrie had landed in New York, where on Feb. 23, in a fleabag Midtown Manhattan hotel, he pulled out his guitar and, using a tune lifted from the Baptist hymn "Oh My Lovin' Brother," composed a six-verse song. Guthrie's Great Depresssion miseries had radicalized his politics, and in "God Bless America" he heard just the kind of uncritical jingoism he despised. This new song was Guthrie's answer: a patriotic epic, which, like Berlin's, used pastoral imagery to evoke an America of mystical grandeur.
"From the mountains/ To the prairies/To the oceans, white with foam," Berlin wrote. "God bless America, my home sweet home."
"When the sun come shining, then I was strolling/ In the wheat fields waving, and the dust clouds rolling/ The voice was chanting as the fog was lifting:/ God blessed America for me," went Guthrie's rejoinder.
Today, Guthrie's hand-written lyric sheet still bears its original title: "God Blessed America." But the world knows the song by the title Guthrie used when he recorded a revised version in 1945: "This Land Is Your Land."
This call and response between revered troubadours is one of the most piquant episodes in American pop music -- a tale whose mix of mid-century politics and national myth-making and whose turbulent backdrop of Depression and world war could fuel a semester's worth of American studies seminars.
But the story of "God Bless America" and "This Land Is Your Land" resonates most forcefully today not as a class battle between the Broadway millionaire and the Popular Front minstrel, not even as a clash of conflicting ideas about patriotism, but as a parable about musical populism. Pitting Tin Pan Alley's greatest dream-weaver against the archetypal renegade balladeer, pitting urban pop sophistication and music industry muscle against homespun folk, the Berlin-Guthrie skirmish is emblematic of a question that continues to roil a music culture obsessed with authenticity: who speaks in the true musical voice of the American people?
In the rock era, that question has been answered with an emphatic endorsement of Guthrie and the gritty tradition he represents. Berlin's Tin Pan Alley ethos -- that ardent dedication to "the mob" -- is regarded in the rock world as a false populism: lowest-common-denominator music that plies the people with the spun sugar they want. The theory of populism that prevails in American music culture today, dominating its iconography and mythologies, coloring its criticism and historiography, exalts Guthrie and his rock heirs for giving the people something more profound: a liberating blast of the truth that they need.
Though Guthrie's catalog remains a source of inspiration for innumerable songwriters, it is his image as a rogue cultural critic, armed with a guitar and his hard-won folk wisdom, which has most deeply marked rock culture. In Guthrie, rock recognizes a spiritual ancestor to its contrarians, misfits and provocateurs: a prototype not just for folkie protest singers, but for all musical rebels who refuse to compromise, from hip-swiveling Elvis Presley running roughshod over sexual proprieties to punk rock agitators to hard-boiled gangsta rappers.
Rock culture has also absorbed Guthrie's anti-pop animus. A self-declared singer of "peoples ballads," Guthrie loathed Tin Pan Alley music -- its grandiose production values, cloying sentiments and "sissy-voiced" crooners. His aversion to "God Bless America" was as much aesthetic as political: to Guthrie, Berlin's song was a supreme example of Tin Pan Alley's empty artifice and bloated emotionalism. In place of schmaltz, Guthrie offered grit and unflinching realism; at the bottom of the sheet on which he had scrawled the lyrics to "This Land Is Your Land," Guthrie noted: "All you can write is what you see."
That commitment to realism is alive in a rock culture that makes strenuous efforts to distinguish itself from the corrupting commercialism of pop; in the perennial hip-hop vow to "keep it real"; in the spectacle of rock bands like Nirvana and Pearl Jam bewailing their chart-topping success; in the purist politics that dominate music scenes like indie rock and techno, in which bands jockey for underground credibility amid recriminations about "selling out." Rock critics, in particular, have imbibed the anti-capitalist/social realist thrust of the Guthrie-led folk movement, often favoring even banal iconoclasm to well-made commercial pop, ignoring the fact the rebels they lionize are themselves professional musicians -- as Guthrie was before them.
This rock populism has, in many ways, served the music well. For almost 50 years, rock, in all its incarnations, has remained remarkably trenchant and politically potent music, reinvigorating itself, time and again, with fresh sounds and new voices from the cultural fringe.
But rock populism is problematic when projected back into musical history. The official history describes the genre's rise as a victory of rugged, rustic folk culture over Tin Pan Alley's high-toned treacle. It was, the story goes, a triumph of the heroic proletarians who are enshrined in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame: folk singers (Guthrie and Leadbelly), cowboy balladeers (Jimmie Rodgers and Hank Williams), blues legends (Robert Johnson, Bessie Smith and Ma Rainey). Though rock 'n' roll has traveled far from that musical promised land of dust bowls, deltas, Appalachian valleys and hilltop churches, it has preserved its indomitable spirit and broadcast its down-home verities to the world.
This is a lovely story, and there is truth in it; but like most polemical narratives, rock's myth of origins ignores inconvenient historical facts: the music's debts to Tin Pan Alley pop. Those debts exist, and not just in obvious places like the highly crafted music of the Brill Building and the Motown song-mills. Rock's power, which -- from Elvis to Bob Dylan to Lauryn Hill -- is so reliant on the magnetism of superstar performers, could not have existed were it not for the vaudevillians and crooners who pioneered that role: Al Jolson, Sophie Tucker, Bing Crosby, Frank Sinatra. And were it not for George M. Cohan, Jerome Kern, George Gershwin and, of course, Berlin, rock 'n' roll would simply not have had a pop-culture flag to capture in the first place. As the critic Gary Giddins has written: "To the extent that our lives are measured in song, we live in the Irving Berlin Era."
By rock's own criteria, Berlin's populist credentials would seem to be impeccable. A self-taught musician who never learned musical notation and could play piano only in the key of F sharp, Berlin registers with the rock mythology that glorifies ragged garage bands over slick professionals. There can hardly be a more genuine working-class hero than the dirt-poor Lower East Side street urchin who left home and school at 13 and plunged into the Bowery demimonde, sleeping in flophouses and tenement vestibules, scraping a living as a song plugger, sometime street busker and, eventually, singing waiter in a Chinatown brothel and opium den.
But if Berlin's low-born pedigree is unassailable, and his journey a picaresque that makes Guthrie's hard-knock rambling look genteel, his crowd-pleasing songs and unembarrassed aspirations unmask him as the bourgeois that rock culture abhors. Lushly melodic, unapologetically romantic, mixing slangy colloquialism and bursts of wit aimed at higher brows, classic Tin Pan Alley pop was music made for a broad middle-class mainstream of white adults -- an audience that turned to music not for unvarnished truth, but an enchanting reflection of its fondest desires and most cherished illusions.
If the song standards of that pre-civil rights, pre-feminist epoch strike us today as blithely ethnocentric, it should be remembered that they were the result of a social struggle in many ways as significant as those that have inflected rock's history. Tin Pan Alley was dominated in both its creative and business spheres by Jews, and the music it gave to the world was the music of assimilation, a distinctly New World concoction: the result of a people's terrific striving for social acceptance and a piece of the American pie. "God Bless America" -- that hymn of gratitude composed by the man born Israel Baline, who arrived at Ellis Island in 1893 as a 5-year-old refugee from the pogrom-scourged shtetl of Tyumen in Siberia -- is a milestone of Jewish-American acculturation matched perhaps only by another Berlin magnum opus, "White Christmas": a symbol of the way in which the Jews who wrote songs and founded movie studios reinvented American popular culture in their own image.
Rock culture wants no part of this story of middle-class arrivistes: it looks past Tin Pan Alley to other ancestors with more hard-bitten images and more colorful struggles. These days, those forebears aren't just haunting the pages of rock histories: they're hip. Spurred by the 1997 rerelease of the seminal "Anthology of American Folk Music" -- a collection of recordings from the 20's and 30's, compiled in 1958 by the musicologist Harry Smith -- "primitive" roots music is hotter than it has been in decades. This time it isn't just folk aficionados worshipping Smith's mountain string bands, Piedmont bluesmen and Bible chanters. The techno star Moby's hit album "Play" is filled with samples from old spirituals, blues and field hollers. At Other Music, the NoHo temple of record collector chic, shoppers who jostle to buy the latest drum 'n' bass imports and the new Belle and Sebastian album can take home "Prayers From Hell: White Gospel and Sinners Blues, 1927 to 1940" and "American Yodeling: 1911 To 1946," and have made the just-released fourth volume of Harry Smith's anthology one of the store's top sellers. The music's street credibility is mirrored by the mystique conferred upon it by rocks mandarins: the critic Greil Marcus has romanticized the anthology as "an occult document," the mysterious sound of "the old, weird America."
THERE is a parallel body of recordings in Tin Pan Alley pop -- musical artifacts of an America that is just as old and weird, yet today is all but forgotten. Those songs, preserved on cylinder recordings and 78-r.p.m. records, date from the period that preceded the heyday of the smooth Broadway and Hollywood song standard: the rambunctious heights of vaudeville, before, during and just after the First World War. They are the urban equivalent of the songs found on Harry Smith's anthology: long-lost songs by long-dead singers, dizzying in their variety and disorientingly bizarre.
Berlin's output from the period is representative of that music's eclecticism: a madcap mix of ethnic parody songs, dance numbers, syrupy "high-class" ballads, ersatz rags, rakish novelty tunes. The titles alone evoke the freewheeling optimism of an America being transformed by its big cities, loosening morals, new immigrants and new machines: "Keep Away From the Fellow Who Owns an Automobile," "Jake! Jake! The Yiddisher Ball-Player," "I Was Aviating Around," "My Wife's Gone to the Country (Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!)," "The Elevator Man Going Up, Going Up, Going Up, Going Up!"
In these oddball songs, we hear not only pop music being invented as a mass medium, but a new nation being born: it is melting-pot music, the sound of a polyglot America emerging from its Victorian past and striding jauntily into the century it would claim as its own. This clarion call of modernity was perceived, quite rightly, as a threat to the cultural dominion of the Anglo-American middle-class. Tin Pan Alley pop packed as much anti-establishment menace as the most outre rebel rock: with unabashed anti-immigrant bias, newspaper pundits thundered about the threat to public morality posed by the "suggestive" lyrics and manic ragtime-influenced rhythms emerging from New York's Jewish-run song factories. Some of the first folk music revivals date from this period, sponsored not by righteous lefties but by wealthy nativists seeking to bolster the indigenous culture imperiled by the toxic spread of "Hebrew Broadway jazz."
You won't find recordings of those vaudeville tunes at Other Music. No D.J.s have layered breakbeats over samples from Jolson 78's; no independent record label has released a smartly packaged compilation of "Primitive Pop." While a new generation of hipsters learn to treat the songs of Blind Willie Johnson and the Carter Family as holy writ, vaudeville-era pop, expunged from American music's official history, languishes in music libraries and on the shelves of obscure collectors, condemned to the most inglorious of pop culture oblivions: it is nostalgia music, the secret joy of a few crackpot old-timers.
The blame for this historiographical mess cannot be ascribed solely to rock culture: there has been plenty of provincialism to go around. In the 1950's, when rock 'n' roll dislodged Tin Pan Alley pop from cultural center stage, the shrillest rhetoric came from the older generation. In 1958, Frank Sinatra called rock 'n' roll "the most brutal, ugly, desperate, vicious form of expression it has been my misfortune to hear." Berlin, in a fit of petulance, tried to stop radio stations from playing Elvis Presley's recording of "White Christmas." There is more than a hint of tin-eared snobbery in today's champions of pop song standards: lurking behind their paeans to the "golden age of popular song" is the assumption that melodic sophistication and lyrical wit disappeared from pop music the day rock 'n' roll blazed in, riding a wave of African-American rhythm.
It is pleasant to think that, in the year 2000, we might get past all this -- that we'll leave the old resentments and misapprehensions behind with the old century, and hear that century's music afresh. It's time to pitch a musical big tent: time to scold the lover of a Gershwin tune who can't hear the beauty in James Brown, in the Notorious B.I.G., in Lucinda Williams; time to celebrate the common tradition that links "The Yankee Doodle Boy" and "Hellhound on My Trail" and "Stardust" and "Respect" and "Smells Like Teen Spirit" and "Nuthin' but a G Thang" and "God Bless America" and "This Land Is Your Land."
As we approach the first Independence Day of the new millennium, those two great national anthems of the American century are a reminder that, despite decades-long attempts to reduce it to genre myths and freight it with false politics, American pop music won't be tamed. It is, like our fondest hopes for the country that produced it, an improbably eclectic, wildly democratic thing: one grand, raffish, indivisible musical tradition, made for you and me.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 17; Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 600 words

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
In Defense of Luxury

BYLINE: By SCOTTY DUPREE; Scotty Dupree, who was editor of Luxe magazine, which covered the marketing of luxury products, lives in Briarcliff Manor.

 BODY:
I WAS disappointed by Hubert B. Herring's article "Coping with Luxury Fever" (June 25). His stilted view of current luxury trends offended me.
I was disturbed to see that he used only a few select points from Robert Frank's book "Luxury Fever" to illustrate his ire. The quotes he chose misrepresented the book, leaving me wondering if Herring has read it. Frank, an economist at Cornell, uses examples of the current luxury boom to win the reader to his economic view. What he proposes is a newer version of a system this country has spent nearly 100 years fighting: Communism. Our personal and economic freedoms allow me to make the choices I do, which often include dropping my teenage stepdaughter at her school in my sports utility truck. In the truck my family is safe and comfortable; that I drive my daughter door-to-door despite gridlock gives me a valuable 5 or 10 minutes more of precious time with her. Are safety, comfort and time with your children a luxury? 
 That the luxuries that Mr. Herring sees as selfish and destructive have become commonplace not only in Westchester but also in most areas of the country, demonstrates that our system works.
But Mr. Herring missed the real point. He noted that Westchester "is one of the nation's richest counties, so you would think that all that money could buy an awfully good way of life." I, too, thought that when I moved here two years ago. Unfortunately, it is not so. Despite a wealthy population, Westchester's retail is a cross between the Third World and relics from the 1950's. Its grocery stores rival those of Manhattan for their narrow aisles, bad lighting and out-of-date products on the shelves. If shoppers want to go to Putnam County, where the income levels don't approach those of Westchester, the grocery stores are modern with gourmet sections rivaling Zabar's. Connecticut boasts dozens of fresh grocers, such as Hay Day and Fresh Fields, which specialize in fresh and organic produce and gourmet goods not available in most grocery chains.
And food retailing is only the beginning. In recent years Westchester got its first Price Club, a concept that has become a suburban necessity that the rest of the country has had for 15 years or more. Also in recent years the county got its first Circuit City store; previously residents were forced to pay top dollar for less than top-of-the-line products at a limited number of stores.
The county recently witnessed a huge battle to build a Stew Leonard's, Costco and Home Depot on a large rocky tract on the Thruway in Yonkers. At issue was the quality of life of Yonkers residents.
What is more important to the quality of life: keeping traffic down (even though it brings with it more tax revenue and jobs) or fresh and competitively priced goods? If we don't keep our marketplaces competitive with new entrants and more choices, all of us -- rich and poor alike -- will be forced to pay ransom-like prices for basic necessities such as bread and milk.
Westchester's retail community seems to operate as a complete contradiction to American economic philosophy that supposes that consumers rule the marketplace with the power of their dollar.
In Westchester there often is no marketplace, so consumers drive to Connecticut or New Jersey to shop. I would welcome more development in my neighborhood, as would many of my neighbors. But with residents like Mr. Herring objecting to the simplest luxuries, such as driving our children to school, it is unlikely that Westchester retail will achieve 20th century standards for another few hundred years.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Watch Out Barney! Here Comes Zebby.

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail address: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
YOUNG children like to watch the same videos and listen to the same music cassettes over and over again. But repeatedly hearing their syrupy songs often makes parents cringe.
Enter Tim, Ed, Matt Wahl and Nora Wahl Firestone, siblings nurtured on the music of Van Halen, Madonna and the Grateful Dead, raised watching "Sesame Street" and "The Electric Company." If a purple dinosaur named Barney could capture the hearts -- and ears -- of millions of children, why couldn't they come up with a character who could enchant grown-ups too? 
 Four years ago, Ed Wahl, 33, a Nassau County police officer, and Matt Wahl, 26, an officer with the New York Police Department, wrote a rock 'n' roll soundtrack, using the same beat as the music they loved growing up in the Plainedge school district. Canvassing the alphabet, the Wahls chose a zebra as their star. Why? It was the only animal they could think of that wasn't already a known character.
The strategy worked. Recently, "Zebby's Zoo," believed to be the first nationally syndicated children's program conceived and produced on Long Island, was picked up by America One, the cable and satellite network. Added to Telecare, where the show has been broadcast twice a day, five times a week since its inception, and WLIW where it airs Saturday mornings at 7:30, "Zebby's Zoo" can now be seen in 62-million homes nationwide.
"It's 'Sesame Street' on steroids," said Tim Wahl, 32, who produces the half-hour show and runs the business end of the fast-growing "Zebby Zoo" empire out of his Westbury home. "It's very simple, but it's what the kids love; it's what the kids want to see," he said. "It's very upbeat. It's something that the parents could really relate to. It's something that's easily tolerated."
Even by their mother. There was Karen Wahl, 56, on the stage at the Nassau County Fair in Uniondale recently, dressed in a Zebby the Zebra costume, dancing her way across the stage.
From across the midway, by stroller and on foot, came the toddler and kindergarten set, gathering at the foot of the stage to sing and dance along with the zebra. "Do the Zebby, do the Zebby. . . ." blared from the speakers. While Zebby and a friend, the Lazy Lion, hoofed, Tim Wahl pulled out a table laden with Zebby T-shirts, audio and video cassettes and Beanie-Baby knockoffs of Zebby.
Merchandising, after all, is what "Zebby's Zoo" is all about.
The children's entertainment program started with online sales of music cassettes. The characters weren't brought to life until the Wahls created the television show. By then, thousand of videos, cassettes and stuffed animals had been sold.
"A TV show is developed and promoted and if it is successful, they go to the next step, which is licensing or manufacturing the merchandise," Tim Wahl said. "We went exactly the opposite way. We didn't do it that way by accident. That was our objective. We knew from the beginning that we didn't have the experience in the TV industry and we didn't have the budget to do a Manhattan- style shoot where we could shoot 52 episodes. So we said first things first, let's get people to identify with who the Zebby Zoo character is."
Tim Wahl, after all, had been wholesaling 8,000 to 10,000 units a week of licensed "Sesame Street," Barney and Arthur products. He knew the market. His brothers knew music.
"A lot of the stuff I write in my head while I'm working," said Ed Wahl, concentrating on lessons about manners, safety, family values, counting and spelling. He then sings the compositions into his answering machine.
Along with other partners, the Wahls have invested $350,000 in "Zebby's Zoo." They expect to turn a profit by the end of the year.
When the Telecare show started, Tim Wahl said, hits to the Zebby Web site -- www.Zebbyszoo.com -- soared. Fans, known as Zebheads, started chat rooms. A live "Zebby's Zoo" production at the Westbury Music Fair soon followed. Earlier this year, two shows at the Vanderbilt in Plainview were standing room only at $12 a ticket.
"We had a solid foundation," Tim Wahl said. "We had 120,000 kids ages 2 to 7 in Nassau and Suffolk county who not only knew who Zebby Zoo was, but they had merchandise in their bedroom they could identify with. We felt that really helped propel the TV show to its popularity."
Seven minutes of each episode -- 72 have been made -- are shot on location around the Island, from the Hewlett Fire Department to the Long Island Game Farm in Manorville and the jungle gym in Wantagh Park.
And Zebby has a new line of sliced white bread, baked at Zebby's Bread Company in Toronto. Already one million 24-ounce loaves have been sold. The bread is available at some Costcos, King Kullens, Farmers Bazaars, Key Foods, C-Towns and Waldbaums. Zebby's doughnuts will be out in the fall.
And the Wahls are compiling "Zebby Songs," an album of 13 popular songs, like Woody Guthrie's "This Land is Your Land," sung by the zebra. (Several vocalists sing Zebby's role; a search is under way for a single voice.)
Still, the show is not technologically sophisticated. Animation is done in a friend's basement in Franklin Square. "We didn't feel we had to compete with "Sesame Street" and Barney," said Tim Wahl, looking to take "Zebby's Zoo" to the next level. "There are always going to be kids. There are always going to be parents. Even if the economy is down, if the parents have $10 in their pockets they are going to buy their kid a toy before they buy themselves lunch. If we can turn on the kids, that's great, but if we can turn on their parents, it's a double whammy."
 
Spanish in English
For the cover of the inaugural issue of Latin Long Island, Ed Diaz chose a photograph of many of the leaders of the Hispanic community. "We're here," Mr. Diaz said recently at a party at the Huntington Town House celebrating the launching of the new magazine. "We're not going anywhere. We want to be recognized."
Among the featured movers and shakers: Yvonne Pena, executive director of the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission; Pilar Delgado, staffing coordinator for Sterling Personnel Services in Hauppauge; and Miriam Garcia, executive director of Adelante of Suffolk County, the cultural and civic center in Brentwood that sponsors the Hispanic Day Parade and myriad job training, youth leadership and social services.
"There are a lot of misconceptions and misperceptions about Latinos on Long Island," Mr. Diaz said. "That can be overcome by highlighting the positive in our community. This magazine is about bringing people together."
The second issue, due out later this month, will feature Jack Gallagher, chief executive officer of North Shore/LIJ Health Care System. Mr. Gallagher's mother was Colombian.
Twelve years ago, Mr. Diaz, of Babylon, the owner of a collections agency, helped found the Long Island Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. The glossy new publication, he said, is the next step and the proper venue to both tout the Island's top Hispanics and create a forum to bridge the communications gap between different Latino communities. Latin Long Island, however, is published in English.
"This magazine will allow people who don't know about the Latino community, who don't read or speak Spanish to read a publication that will highlight the creme de la creme of the Latinos, learn what we are all about and the contributions we make to Long Island, " Mr. Diaz said. Included among those potential readers of the soon-to-be monthly magazine, he noted, are English-speaking advertising executives who place ads in local Spanish periodicals like Hoy or Noticias but can't read their own copy.
"I am anxious to overcome some of that ignorance that still is out there," Mr. Diaz said. "Some people will perceive Latinos out of ignorance as unsophisticated, being worthy of only low-paying jobs in restaurants and assembly lines and that not what we're all about."
Latinos own more than 5,000 Long Island businesses, come from 26 different countries and live in communities from Riverhead to Freeport, Glen Cove and Brentwood. What they have in common is the Spanish language, although by the second generation, many no longer use it, Mr. Diaz said.
Mr. Diaz was born in the Bronx. Though his parents spoke Spanish, English was always his main language.
"In my English-dominant world, practically every person I know here who is Hispanic watches very little Spanish language television and rarely ever reads Spanish language newspapers," he said.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: No Blues for This Bowling Alley

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
IN a bygone era, someone might have made a musical about it: neighborhood families buy a 60-year-old bowling alley for $20,000 and fix it up by chipping in money and elbow grease.
A stockbroker figures out a business plan and a lawyer checks legal issues. A pair of architects orchestrate renovations. A mother of three decides to return to the workforce as manager. Teenagers volunteer to paint and ask for part-time jobs. In this kind of plot, Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland could pop up at the shoe rental counter and break into song. 
 But those fresh-faced youngsters would be upstaged. It's the twinkly-eyed grown-ups who sing the praises of owning a 16-lane duckpin alley in the West End section of Hartford.
"The first thing I hear when I tell people about buying it is, 'What a cool thing to do with a mid-life crisis'," said Christine Palm. Ms. Palm, the mother of four boys and the editor of a local paper, The West End News, said she heard through the grapevine that the alley was to close. She and her husband, James Baker, a graphic artist, considered buying it to prevent another neighborhood business from closing. Phone calls to five other couples confirmed their sentiment.
Not only did those first few friends want in, within several weeks the number of interested families climbed. Over the period of a few months, 23 families committed to the purchase. The initial cost of $20,000 was split 23 ways, but the families also raised an extra $44,000 for renovations. Although revenue from the bowling alley isn't the source of their primary income, the families formed a limited-liability corporation to protect their assets. The corporation is managed by three partners: Ms. Palm; John Gale, a lawyer; and Avery Buell, a stockbroker, all long-time West Enders.
"Our biggest concern was liability," said Susan Russell, who stepped forward to manage the lanes now known as the Alley. "We wondered, if it goes under will we lose our first-born child?" Yet the idea of a communally owned alley was so popular, would-be investors had to be turned away; a week before its May 27 grand opening, a neighborhood businessman stepped among the paint cans and asked if he could become an owner.
Serendipity also stepped in. The landlord, Steven Neiditz, whose father and uncle owned the building for longer than he could remember, offered things like a month-to-month lease. The alley purchase coincides with the publication of a book by a Harvard professor that asserts Americans need to join clubs, specifically bowling leagues. "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of Community in America" (Simon & Schuster), by Robert D. Putnam, makes a case that belonging to clubs like bowling leagues increases "human connectedness," and the trickle-down effect is improved relations within families and between people of different race, culture and economic levels. "One of them dropped me a note, and when I found out about what they were doing, I thought it was the kind of grass-roots initiative that if it were emulated in other communities around the country, could significantly increase social connectedness," Mr. Putnam said in a telephone interview from his home in New Hampshire.
Mr. Putnam's words echo what these mostly middle-aged professionals say they hope to accomplish.
They have plans to sponsor events in conjunction with their neighborhood elementary school. On a recent weekday, Ms. Palm was fielding calls from a shelter for homeless young women about a trip to the bowling alley. The Mayor of Hartford, Mike Peters, bought $500 worth of tickets that are kept at the alley for children who wander in to bowl, but don't have enough money.
Hank Murray, a labor lawyer who has lived in the West End with his family since 1977, said many residents were drawn to the area because of its racial and cultural diversity, not likely to be found in suburban neighborhoods. It was Mr. Murray who contacted Mr. Putnam.
Buying the Alley, opened 60 years ago as Mark Twain Lanes after the city's favorite son, was a way to keep the neighborhood alive, and the active social network was the means to the purchase, Mr. Murray said. "We weren't going to have one more neighborhood business bite the dust," he said. "We were still smarting from the closing of Cheese & Stuff," added Ms. Russell.
Cheese & Stuff was a grocery store specializing in organic foods that was emblematic of the funky style so dear to West Enders. It sold bulk flour and cereal as well as pricey prepared fare, organic produce and bath soaps. The staff was racially diverse and likely to dress in tie-dyed clothes and Birkenstock sandals. In the last decade, it was what remained of a corner that once included a shop that sold crystals as well as a feminist bookstore and restaurant.
Earlier this spring, the owners of Cheese & Stuff, the Wild Oats grocery store chain, announced it was closing the Farmington Avenue store and relocating to tonier West Hartford. West Enders wrote letters to the editor and picketed, saying they were promised by the store's owners that the market would stay put. In the end, it moved and the site is still empty.
Residents described the West End as a place where people meet on the sidewalk, walking dogs or following children on bicycles. On warm summer nights, someone is usually having a neighborhood cook-out. Most blocks have a book club. There is a mixture of multi- and single-family houses, most of them from the Victorian era or early 1900's. Most of the yards are well-tended, but some boast a charming lack of perfection.
The Alley purchase is not the neighborhood's first foray into business. Fifteen years ago, neighbors stepped forward when Mo's Midtown, a small and immensely popular diner near the Alley, was scheduled to close. A few families bought it and held it for six months, until a Mo's waitress raised the money to buy it herself.
The 23 families bought the bowling alley from an East Granby couple, Nancy and Jim Gesuelle, who owned it for more than 10 years and had spent close to $100,000 renovating and replacing the machinery and lanes. Mr. and Mrs. Gesuelle each work full time at the Cigna Insurance Company. They said they sold the business, formerly known as Farmington Avenue Duckpin to spend more time with their two school-aged daughters.
The Gesuelles said there were offers to buy the alley for the pin-setting machines, but that would have meant ending its 60-year streak as a bowling alley.
"It was a love of the sport that caused us to buy it in the first place," Mrs. Gesuelle said. "I'm happy we found people who will keep it going."
"There's also selfish impulse here," said Lindsey Karl, the architect who with her husband, Michael Cannon, led the renovations. "We want a place for our kids to go." The couple have two teenagers.
To this end, the Alley will be smoke-free, but the owners are divided over whether to have a liquor license. Although the sale of liquor means higher profits, it also makes the atmosphere less family-friendly, owners said. Many of the owners place a premium on this quality.
"I don't put up with what I call trash talk," said Ms. Russell, who as manager will be stalking the lanes to insure teenagers behave. There won't be computerized bowling either, bucking a growing trend at 10-pin lanes. The Alley owners want their children to add scores the old-fashioned way, to hone their math skills.
Nostalgia for things past, however, was ultimately trumped by taste when it came to the Alley's interior. Dark paneling was taken down. Walls were repainted. A soda fountain and cafe were built. Laser bowling with its glow-in-the-dark lights was installed to lure teenagers. Four lanes of anchored chairs were ripped out to make room for a dance area where salsa and tango lessons are planned.
For maintenance and repair of the pin-setting machines, the owners turned to John Gorman, a professional bowler who has worked at the lanes for many years.
There is a growing sense that the endeavor, initiated to keep a neighborhood business afloat, could turn profitable. "I think it's going to make money," said Mr. Buell, the stockbroker who wrote the business plan. "There's enough people in this neighborhood and the extended neighborhood and a fair number of leagues are interested." (Owners said the Alley is one of just three public duckpin lanes in the greater Hartford area.)
In a move that would please Robert Putnam, welcomes are being extended to bowling leagues. So far, five are on board.
"Susan held meetings with them and baked them banana bread," Ms. Palm said.
"It was really a cheese basket," Ms. Russell interjected.
"Yeah, but banana bread sounds better," Ms. Palm said. "More homespun."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY/NEW JERSEY;
Bergen Landlords Look to Manhattan for Tenants

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER nearly two years of watching rents soar and space dwindle in Manhattan's office market, Laurence Gluck made his move. Mr. Gluck and a partner recently brought a 650,000-square-foot office complex on Route 4, just over the George Washington Bridge in Hackensack, N.J.
The three-building complex, known as Continental Plaza, is the first office acquisition outside of Manhattan for Mr. Gluck, the principal in Stellar Management Ltd., which, with a variety of partners, owns or manages four million square feet of commercial space. In April his company, together with Capital Real Estate of Manhattan, paid $79 million for the complex, where 200,000 square feet of space is available or soon will be. 
 "The complex was a good value in an excellent submarket that is getting better, and in a location that could take advantage of the strength of the Manhattan market," Mr. Gluck said. "We feel we can attract core tenants from New Jersey as well as those from Manhattan who don't have to be in the city and want to avail themselves of lower costs."
There is no corporate occupancy tax in New Jersey, and electric power rates and real estate taxes are well below those in New York, said Mitchell Konsker, an executive director in the Manhattan office of Cushman & Wakefield, the international brokerage company.
He is a member of one of two teams of brokers, one based in the Manhattan office and the other in East Rutherford, N.J., who are leasing agents for Continental Plaza. This two-pronged approach reflects the two sources of tenants that are being tapped.
Asking rents at the complex average $32 a square foot, about half of those for comparable space in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Konsker said.
In the last few years such cost benefits have lured a stream of tenants from downtown Manhattan to office towers on the west bank of the Hudson, mainly in Jersey City, including Paine Webber; Goldman, Sachs; and most recently, Chase Manhattan Bank.
Last month, the bank announced it would relocate many employees from 55 Water Street in downtown Manhattan to one million square feet in a mixed-use complex being developed by the Lefrak Organization at Newport in Jersey City. The move, contingent on final approval of incentives from Trenton. will involve about 1,900 employees and several hundred consultants in the business services, general auditing and other departments.
BUT rents on the waterfront are rising, and the availability of space is limited (new construction, where possible, takes time). Aware of these factors and of the ever-tighter Manhattan market, Mr. Gluck is one of a number of landlords and investors with available space in existing buildings who are betting that now is a good time to attract Manhattan tenants with immediate space needs to other close-in markets in New Jersey, like parts of Bergen County.
Other property owners in the county gearing up to draw Manhattan tenants include a landlord with a 160,000-square-foot building elsewhere in Hackensack and an investment group buying an office building with 131,000 square feet in Lyndhurst.
Many commercial brokers said the space squeeze in Manhattan and on the Hudson River waterfront was causing companies to search inland in New Jersey for alternatives. But no one is predicting that a flock of New York companies will make the leap.
"The floodgates in the inland areas haven't opened because of concerns by New York companies of the potential loss of employees, and the minimal amount of large available blocks of prime space," said Jeffrey Babikian, the senior managing director at the Saddle Brook office of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company. Once they get over those hurdles and focus on the savings, areas of New Jersey away from the Hudson become viable options, he added.
In the case of Bergen County, Steven M. Frank, a senior vice president at the Teaneck office of the CB Richard Ellis brokerage company, said, "We've always seen a flow of Manhattan companies, and it has picked up in recent months."
Driving the market are smaller tenants taking 5,000 to 20,000 square feet of space, he said, because bigger Manhattan tenants are sensitive to the labor issue.
Another complicating factor is the lack of public transit. Unlike Jersey City, with its PATH train, Bergen County relies mostly on buses to link it directly with Manhattan. There is train service, but only to Hoboken, where passengers must change to PATH trains to Manhattan.
Nonetheless, with the current scarcity of blocks of space of 50,000 square feet or more in Manhattan, "tenants have to look outside the box," said Mr. Konsker of Cushman & Wakefield. Through lease expirations and relocating existing tenants elsewhere in the complex, two blocks, one of 50,000 and the other of 100,000 square feet, are being cobbled together at Continental Plaza. They will be available in the next four to six months, Mr. Konsker said, adding that a total of 50,000 more square feet, made up of smaller spaces, will also be available. Additional leases are coming due in the next 12 to 18 months, he said.
The landlord is improving the property, which is now almost 30 years old. The wiring in the three buildings is being upgraded for advanced telecommunications, including high-speed Internet access, and the common areas are being renovated. Mr. Gluck said the complex has its own postal substation, a branch bank and garage parking for 2,500 cars.
SINCE leasing began three months ago, five leases have been negotiated or closed, Mr. Konsker said. Of those leases, one for 8,500 square feet has been closed with Macromedia Inc., a San Francisco software company with offices in Teaneck. A second lease, for 22,000 square feet, is being negotiated with another New Jersey company. In addition, negotiations are under way with three Manhattan companies, for 20,000 to 60,000 square feet each, he said. He would not name them.
Another building in Hackensack that is seeking Manhattan tenants is at 21 Main Street downtown. Bergen County, which uses the entire three-story building for administrative offices, will vacate it by the end of the year, said Jerry L. Barta, the director of leasing and marketing at Alfred Sanzari Enterprises of Hackensack, the owner.
"We're not marketing exclusively to Manhattan tenants," Mr. Barta said, "but there has been a spillover due to the high rents, so they are one of the obvious suspects to go after, in addition to New Jersey firms which are expanding." Given the scarcity of big blocks of space, "this is not the worst time to get back 160,000 square feet," he added.
Rents have not yet been set at the building, which will be upgraded for advanced telecommunications, but they are expected to be about $30 a square foot. Mr. Barta said his company could also build a 190,000-square-foot building across Essex Street from the existing one, and the two could be linked together to create something of an urban campus.
In Lyndhurst, a group of Bergen County investors is in contract to buy an empty 131,000-square-foot building at 160 Chubb Avenue, with access to Manhattan via Route 3 and the Lincoln Tunnel. The building recently became vacant after its sole tenant, Ebasco Engineering, terminated its lease in a consolidation by its parent company, Raytheon.
"It's a classic alternative for New York firms considering the economic advantage of locating in New Jersey," said Leonard T. Miller Jr., a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, which represents the buyers. He said asking rents at the building, which could be expanded by 42,000 square feet, are expected to be $27 to $29 a square foot.
There are also development plans for new offices in the county. In Rutherford, near Routes 3 and 17, Lincoln Equities is preparing a 28-acre site for 900,000 square feet of office space in two buildings, plus a 220-room hotel. Mr. Babikian of Insignia/EGS said that Skymark Partners of Hackensack is advancing plans to build two million square feet of offices in three buildings, along with a hotel, on a 33-acre site at Route 46 and the New Jersey Turnpike in Ridgefield Park.
Mr. Babikian, who represents the developers, said discussions are under way with three prospective tenants, two from Midtown Manhattan. "The developers want to catch the market and take advantage of their proximity to Manhattan," he said, noting that the site is within a 10-minute drive of both the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel.

HEADLINE: State Grants to Foster Housing for the Elderly

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WESTCHESTER

 BODY:
County organizations have received $4.8 million in state grants for four projects that will create housing for the elderly and help first-time home buyers buy homes.
In Yorktown, Landmark Partners is receiving $1.8 million to provide 64 units of housing for the elderly in a project called Wynwood Oaks. The development team consists of Landmark Partners, the contractor, the Westchester Interfaith Housing Corporation and the architect, Anthony J. Coppolla. 
 The apartments will be available to households with incomes below 60 percent of the county's median income -- $79,900 for a family of four -- with one-bedroom units renting for $440 to $840 a month.
In Mount Vernon, Community Gardens is receiving $2.6 million to build 54 one-bedroom units for the elderly. The development consists of Community Gardens, Mountco Construction and Development Company and the architect, Swanke Hayden Connell. Monthly rents will range from $365 to $672 for households with incomes below 50 percent of the area's median income.
In White Plains, $50,000 will be used to provide emergency home repairs to low-income elderly homeowners, with a maximum of $5,000 for owners with incomes up to 60 percent of the median income. The city is the municipal sponsor there.
And in a countywide program, Community Housing Innovations will receive $400,000 to help low-income residents buy homes. An average of $16,000 a unit will be awarded to households with incomes at or below 80 percent of the median income.
Statewide, $80.4 million in housing development projects and programs was approved under the state's Low Income Housing Trust Fund ($28 million), the state's Home program ($31 million), Low Income Housing Credit ($20 million) and the Restore Program ($1.43 million).
Officials said the awards statewide would provide more than $267 million in additional public and private investment and give local governments, nonprofit organizations and developers with the resources -- including Federal tax credits -- needed to make thousands of affordable housing units available.
In some cases, Federal tax credits over 10 years will be offered to nonprofit organizations to help developers obtain financing, said Judy Calogero, deputy commissioner for the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal. "Many developers don't go out for low-income housing, because traditionally they don't get as high a return on their investment," she said.

DEAR DIARY:
Scene: Bedroom of a young couple watching "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." The show ends and the lights go off. 
 He: "I'm feeling very amorous tonight. How about you?"
She: "No, I have a headache."
He: "Is that your final answer?"
She: "Yes."
He: "I think I'd like to phone a friend." JOYCE JOSEPH
And in that vein, on the back of a black leather jacket worn by a burly and bearded motorcyclist was this message: "If you can read this, she fell off."
 
INFLATION
 Today I bought a two-door for
What Father bought a Tudor for.
BOB McKENTY
Overheard on a recent Sunday at the Clifton Commons mall, one young man to another: "I was thinking of going running, but I don't run."
Passing by a cashier at the Sears in Livingstone Mall recently, I could not help but notice a customer who was having a lively conversation with her friend. She was waving her arms, and it was clear that she was upset with something or somebody.
I only heard her final words' "People are worse than anybody."
 DORIS L. MEYER
 
SWITCHEROO
For Mother's Day they gave her aprons,
Frilly things of pink and blue.
On Father's Day, for his suit pocket,
Silken hankies of every hue
Regarding each other with eyebrows lifted,
And pondering whether the kids would feel bad
They quietly switched what they had been gifted,
This corporate Mom and stay-at-home Dad.
 MARILYN COHEN VASEN
I am waiting my turn recently at a dry cleaners in Denville when the first customer in line, a girl of 13 or 14, places a badly stained jacket on the counter.
"I need your service," she says.
With that, the clerk regards the large brown stain.
"Chocolate ice cream," the girl says. "I took my sister's jacket without her permission and got ice cream all over it. I need it cleaned and back in the closet before she finds out."
"I hear you," he says.
 AUDREY CORN
At the Short Hills Mall, shoppers have tried to follow the frequent addition of new shops and the ever-changing location of older ones. Now even the employees there are confused.
For example, while having lunch at Bloomingdale's recently, a store employee approached as I sought out the grilled veggies at the salad bar.
Employee: "Can you tell me where you found that great skirt?"
Me: "In my closet."
Employee: "And what level is that on."
 MARILYN COHEN VASEN
 
POSTCARD
FROM SEA GIRT
"The seashore's shrinking!" ecologists roar.
"It's shrinking, receding," they screech.
No news to me, fellas. Come look at my floor,
And see what's become of the missing seashore --
I'm sweeping it back to the beach.
 MAUREEN CANNON

HEADLINE: The Boston Area Adjusts to Rent Deregulation

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
FIVE years after Massachusetts voters ended rent regulation or, more precisely, ended it in Boston, Brookline and Cambridge, the three cities that still had some form of rent control -- rents have taken sizable jumps, the cities are spiffier and less pockmarked by deteriorating neighborhoods and many poorer people have been forced to move to communities farther from the urban core.
While no overall study of the effects of the end of controls on rents has been made, a survey by a leading landlord in Cambridge found that rents for his company's formerly controlled apartments have doubled. 
 With the economy of the Boston area booming, landlord and tenant advocates, politicians and academics who study housing all agree that the degree to which rent deregulation itself produced those effects is impossible to determine. Yet, for good or ill, they all see deregulation as a factor in the changing faces of the three cities.
"Clearly, we enjoy an especially strong rental market," said Edwin J. Shanahan, the executive director of the Greater Boston Real Estate Board. "Demand continues to outpace supply." That is caused by several factors, Mr. Shanahan said, "not the least of which was the 25 years when we had rent control."
"Over those decades nobody would come into Boston, Brookline or Cambridge to build rental housing," he said. "So we essentially ended up with 25 years of no measurable increase in supply."
Since the end of rent regulation, Mr. Shanahan said, "we've seen substantial rehabilitation of our housing stock in those three communities, and a tremendous increase in the number of developers looking to develop" -- although so far there has been a lot more interest than actual development, he conceded.
Peter Dreier, Boston's housing director from 1984 to 1992 and now a professor of public policy at Occidental College in Los Angeles, is not so sanguine. "What Boston shows is that a rising tide does not lift all boats," he said.
"Poor and working-class families are squeezed," Dr. Dreier said. "If you're a waiter, a chambermaid, even a schoolteacher or a nurse, you have to pay half your income or more to put a roof over your head. And if you're really poor, you're going to be doubling and tripling up."
Or moving out of town.
Dian Weaver, 31, a divorced mother of three, used to live in a six-unit building in a poorer section of Cambridge. She was paying $300 a month when rent control ended in 1995. By 1998, the rent was $600, and she had to move.
Ms. Weaver, who refuses to go on welfare, kept her jobs at two restaurants in Cambridge, earning about $500 a week. She moved to Attleboro, Mass., and now commutes to work by train, an hour each way. The rent for her old apartment, "last I heard," she said: "$850."
IN a referendum on Nov. 8, 1994, residents of Massachusetts -- though lacking a majority in each of the three affected cities -- ended rent regulation by a vote of 1,034,594 to 980,723, or 51 to 49 percent. The referendum had been spurred, particularly, by a coalition of small-property owners in Cambridge, which had the most stringent form of rent control covering most of the apartments in a city comprised predominantly of renters. The impact of rent regulation in Boston and Brookline had been muted in recent years by vacancy decontrol. In all, about 100,000 units were decontrolled on Jan. 1, 1995.
No comprehensive study of the effects of deregulation in the three cities has since been conducted. But in Boston, according to Elizabeth Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Mayor Thomas M. Menino, the average rent for two-bedroom apartments hit $1,550 in 1999, up 75.1 percent from $882 in 1995.
Perhaps the best currently available barometer is a study by Alex Steinbergh, a principal of Resource Capital Group, a large landlord in Cambridge, which used as a sample the 242 deregulated units in the 15 buildings the company owns.
"The sample showed that as of November 1999, the average rent for all of the previously rent-controlled units essentially doubled, from $510 to $1,016," Mr. Steinbergh said. The survey also showed that 89 of the 242 formerly rent-controlled units, or 37 percent, had the same tenant as in January 1995. "Now the rents of those tenants, on average, went up from $577 to $967," Mr. Steinbergh said, a 68 percent increase. "So those tenants' rents weren't going up as much as new tenants'."
Some of Mr. Steinbergh's apartments were already on the open market at the time of deregulation, "and the average increase on those market-rate units was 31 percent, from $1,025 to $1,343," he said.
On a recent meandering drive through Cambridge, Mr. Steinbergh pointed out that, "if you pick streets at random, you'll find rehab work on virtually every one." And, indeed, like rainbow sprinkles on a sundae, bright pastel shingles in an array of shades adorned the sides of grand old buildings -- many with turret-like bay windows and stately porticos -- on block after block.
"The exteriors have been fixed up, and inside there are new heating systems, electrical, plumbing," Mr. Steinbergh said. "We think about a third of the 15,000 formerly controlled units have done some rehab."
Similar patterns of housing rehabilitation were evident in Boston proper. And while Mayor Menino was proud of the facelifting and economic rejuvenation of many neighborhoods, he was unequivocal in his assessment of rent deregulation: "A disaster."
In his State of the City Address on Jan. 11, the mayor declared affordable housing one of his highest priorities. "We have an obligation to make sure that prosperity doesn't price people out," he said. "A stable economy needs workers at every level. And a stable city needs a variety of housing for a variety of incomes."
IN an interview, Mayor Menino said: "We're losing the middle class. I know a situation in South Boston where this young couple has gone up in the last year over $600 a month in rent. And there's no way to combat that; they are at the mercy of the landlord. The affluent are moving to our city in record numbers. But our homeless family numbers have gone up 10 percent over the last year." The city's vacancy rate is 1.6 percent.
The problem, Mayor Menino said, "is that there aren't any rental housing proposals out there."
"Rent control came off and the housing industry said they will help us build new housing," the mayor said. "Well, it's five years later and I'm still waiting for the industry to come forward with new housing proposals; any kind, but affordable housing for the most part."
"Million-dollar luxury homes; there are some of those being built in our city," the mayor continued, "obviously not for the working person."
Mr. Shanahan of the real estate board said that the lack of development of affordable housing "essentially has to do with the inordinate delays one encounters in trying to work through the maze of permits and approvals that are required in a city as old as Boston and with as much neighborhood activism as Boston enjoys."
"Quite frankly," he said, "when you are looking at a two and a half year process to find out whether you are even going to be able to play, the game requires a significant amount of capital to be put at risk."
To which the mayor responded: "I don't believe that. If you come up with a good proposal for rental housing in our city, we will expedite it."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3163 words

HEADLINE: For the Class of 2000, Renting 101

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
THE annual migration to New York of new college graduates, degrees in hand, entry-level jobs on the horizon, seems as inevitable as the changing of the seasons. Just as predictable is the sticker shock they face when they plunge into the hunt for an apartment, when they realize that what they might pay for an entire house in Birmingham or Boise is barely enough for a studio here.
That of course has been true, to one degree or another, for years, but the price tags presented to the class of 2000 seem particularly breathtaking, even compared to those of last year when the market was already torrid. 
 "The cycle of soaring rents has to break somewhere, but we've been saying that for years and years and it only gets more incredible and more shocking every year," said Michael Shapot, an associate broker with Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy in Manhattan who has many young people among his clients. "It is a landlords' market. They are demanding, demanding, demanding -- and getting, getting, getting."
Supply and demand, with a New York twist, are part of the reason.
Thanks to the booming economy in general and the demand for co-op apartments in particular, "co-op owners who once rented their apartments are now selling them because they are getting top dollar and are choosing not to rent any longer," Mr. Shapot said. "There are some new buildings, but they are selling out or renting out incredibly quickly at prices that the class of 2000 is unwilling or unable to pay."
So unless the graduates have trust funds or six-figure salaries, they are finding themselves scaling down the visions they brought to the city: trading in elevators for walkups, banding together with more roommates than they had planned on, putting up temporary walls to carve bedrooms out of living rooms or relinquishing the idea of Manhattan altogether and finding haven in Brooklyn, Queens, the suburbs.
Even then, they are making further compromises, like giving up a quick walk to a subway stop. Some, defeated altogether by the size of their paychecks relative to the going rents, return to the nest and parents.
"This is a wealthy city, and it is starting to shape up that only kids with silver spoons can be here," said Andrew Heiberger, president and owner of Citi Habitats, a residential brokerage company that rented 5,400 apartments in Manhattan last year and caters to what he described as "upwardly mobile professionals."
But even a silver spoon, inherited or earned, may not be sufficient. Consider the case of Chip Krotee of Minneapolis, who is about to begin a job as a trader with Merrill Lynch, and Arjay Jensen of St. Louis, who will work for Goldman Sachs. Roommates at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, where they received their masters of business administration degrees in May, they figured they would find a place to live with relative ease. The moving allowances their companies gave them included payment of brokers' fees.
"The brokers we called suggested we come to New York three or four weeks before we were ready to move and bring lots of cash," Mr. Krotee said the other day from his home in Minneapolis, where he was packing. "We came up on May 24 figuring we'd be safe if we brought two months' rent. We were hoping to find a two-bedroom apartment somewhere on the West Side below 90th Street for $3,500 a month for the two of us."
They were shown six or seven apartments, two of which they deemed "tenable."
"We were willing to take them outright, but we were rejected," Mr. Krotee said. "We were told we needed assets of $1 million, and even with those assets landlords wouldn't look at us unless we had worked in New York City for two years. We also needed a guarantor in the tristate region with income 100 times our rent."
THEY did find a two-bedroom apartment in a prewar building on West 73rd Street. "There the management was fine," Mr. Krotee said, "but because we had no New York City guarantor, we had to put six months' rent, or $24,000, in a security deposit and had to take out loans."
"The fact that we have M.B.A.'s, six-figure salaries, perfect credit ratings and fixed assets that are not too shabby didn't matter," he said, looking back on the painful search.
Steven Blase Boyd of Kearny, N.J., felt much the same way after he began looking for an apartment to share with three friends from Georgetown University: Benjamin Meyer of Kansas City, Kan., Nathan Swem of Shellbourne Falls, Mass., and Nicolina Kuh of Arlington, Tex. They all graduated last month and have jobs at investment banking firms like ING Barings and Warburg Dillon Read.
"We found a place on East 57th Street that was a steal at $4,900, a 35th-floor penthouse with three bedrooms and two terraces, and our four salaries covered the rent," Mr. Boyd said. "But they only wanted two people signing the lease and there were no two of us whose salaries covered 40 times the rent." (The annual income -- including salary, dividends and interest -- that landlords require of tenants can vary, Mr. Heiberger said; 40 to 52 times the monthly rent is usual.)
In addition, Mr. Boyd said, they were limited to one guarantor, and they had no one individual who could fill that role.
At one point, Mr. Boyd grew so frustrated by endless red tape that, he said, "even though I love the three people I'll be living with, friends since freshman year, I seriously contemplated dropping out and going to Hoboken or Jersey City by myself."
Pondering what it takes to make landlords become almost as picky as co-op boards, he said: "We have gone to a better school where we've all graduated with honors. I was only cum laude, the other three were magnas. We are financially responsible. I paid for a year of Georgetown out of my own pocket and we all have well-paying jobs." Now they have signed a lease on a sublet on West 106th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue for $4,100 a month. No guarantor was required, but they are awaiting approval from the board of the co-op building. "If they turn us down, I don't know who they want in that apartment," Mr. Boyd said.
The rents being paid by Mr. Krotee, Mr. Boyd and their roommates do not seem out of line with current prices in Manhattan.
"Based on the income requirement of nine out of 10 buildings, a salary of 50 times one months' rent, someone earning $60,000 would barely qualify for a $1,200 studio," Mr. Heiberger said. "And a $1,200 studio is the bottom of the barrel in the city. It would be a fifth-floor walkup or on the first floor facing an alley with a view of the trash."
"The minimum for most studios is $1,500 and they go up to $2,200," he continued. "One-bedrooms that you can convert to two are $2,400, and two-bedrooms that you convert to three are around $3,600. Once you get into three bedrooms, the prices jump greatly to $6,000 and you're competing with couples with families who are raising kids in the city."
In addition, landlords, who tend to prefer older and presumably more settled tenants, are raising the bar higher in other ways. For example, the requirements for guarantors, without whom many landlords will not consider a renter right out of school, are tightening up.
"Guarantors are required to make 75 times the monthly rent," Mr. Heiberger said. "They must submit their own financial information that is more onerous than a mortgage application to prove that they are able to support their own obligations plus the obligations of the tenant. Six out of 10 landlords require the guarantor to be from New York State, eight of 10 that they be from the tristate area and 10 out of 10 that they be from the United States. Kids and their parents are being forced to pay more than their tuition for their senior year of college in advance just to get the key."
Indeed, the fact that their nest may be empty no longer automatically ends parental financial obligation. Ryu Suzuki, who will start as an associate for UBS Warburg on Wednesday, came to New York in May right after graduating from Oberlin College. He would not have been able to move into the apartment he found -- a $2,000-a-month condo studio in Murray Hill -- had his parents, who flew here from Tokyo to make sure that he found a safe place, not been willing to put up a year's rent, $24,000, in advance. "Having recently purchased a new house in Tokyo, they were not shocked about the prices," Mr. Suzuki said.
Even a medical degree does not ensure safe passage through the roiling rental waters. "It seems to me that if someone is starting out as a physician in New York and has the credentials, landlords would bend a little," said John Lemery of Saratoga, N.Y., whose son, Dr. John M. Lemery, just graduated from Dartmouth Medical School and started work last week as an intern in emergency medicine at the Bellevue Hospital Center.
"He needed something reasonably close to Bellevue because he will work 12-hour shifts and undergo all that goes with being an intern," Mr. Lemery said. Dr. Lemery found a 300-square-foot studio in a doorman building on East 47th Street for $1,675 a month.
"We had to pay the first and last month's rent on a two-year lease, security deposit and brokerage fees which came to more than $8,300," Mr. Lemery said. "It all had to be deposited in certified funds with the broker. They wouldn't take a personal check, and I had to guarantee the lease, provide them with a copy of selected information on my income tax return and get a letter from my bank saying that we are creditworthy."
Besides providing advance payments, bank records, tax forms, references and guarantors, apartment seekers must be prepared to make snap decisions or almost inevitably forfeit opportunities even in less desirable apartments.
JACOB BERCOVICI, a new graduate of the New School for Social Research in Manhattan, is moving to Williamsburg in Brooklyn because the apartment he occupied for two years in Park Slope has been sold.
"I was told there was a new building in Williamsburg, and when I called, a woman told me there were eight apartments left," he said. "When I went to see it, there were only two left. So many apartments had been pulled out from under my feet that I was ready to take it on the spot. It was close enough to what I was looking for and I didn't feel like going crazy. There was a guy in line behind me, and once I said I would take it, the broker turned to him and said, 'Now there is only one left,' so he took it."
Mr. Bercovici, a painter who is looking for a teaching job, was scheduled to move in with a roommate yesterday, and together they will pay $1,775 a month for a 1,400-square-foot loft. "Everything else in the neighborhood was at least $500 more," he said. "There is no gas in the building yet, which is why it is so cheap." The building is being converted from commercial to residential status.
"Sadly, $2,000 a month is a steal," said Annie Livingston of Portland, Ore., who graduated from Yale last year, is now the assistant public relations director at Swann Galleries in Manhattan and has been renting a room in a friend's co-op.
She and her Yale roommate, Sarah Karnasiewicz of Southbury, Conn., an operations design assistant at the Whitney Museum of American Art, spent their lunch hours and evenings since the beginning of May pursuing an apartment, and said they had probably tramped through 30 of them.
They made every effort to avoid using the services of a broker, Ms. Livingston said, because brokers "charge 15 percent of the year's rent and don't do much," but in the end, they found their new home last Tuesday through an agent, Adam Feingold of New York City Apartments.
They said it was love at first sight when they saw the apartment -- which has two bedrooms, two baths, a living room and an eat-in kitchen -- in a newly renovated four-story town house on 78th Street east of Second Avenue. Especially because the rent is $2,200 a month.
The search was an education for the women, who just last weekend were told by a broker that it was unlikely they would find a decent two-bedroom apartment for less than $4,000 a month.
"When we started out, I thought that paying $1,000 a month was ridiculous," said Ms. Karnasiewicz, who has been camping out with friends, "moving from floor to floor depending on the kindness of strangers" since the start of the search. "Now I think we are getting a great deal for the money. To get anything halfway decent or clean for less than $2,500 seems like a bargain."
"I didn't think I would be in a palace, but I expected to find something small, clean and comfortable and would go where the prices took me, anywhere where I would feel safe," she said. "Then when we started looking, I realized we are definitely not in a position of power. No matter what state an apartment is in, it will be rented, probably to people making twice as much money as we are."
They got their apartment by getting to it first -- after they had begun to consider leaving Manhattan. "We had been looking for weeks," she said. "On Tuesdays at 1 p.m., when the new Village Voice listings come online, the day before the paper is printed, I go through them and make calls. I was the first person to call -- 20 minutes after the listing was posted -- and we raced over there right from work. We knew within minutes that this was it." Ms. Karnasiewicz's father is the guarantor.
In the past, the draw of communities outside Manhattan was directly proportional to their proximity to subway or PATH stations, but even that is changing with rising demand. "People are not so insistent any more on being right at the No. 7 subway stop," said Scott Cooper, a broker with Cooper Real Estate in Woodside, Queens. "Since apartments here are in such great demand, people who used to want to be no farther than four blocks from a subway now consider 10 blocks."
Asked what locales were the most popular alternatives to Manhattan, Mr. Heiberger listed Hoboken, Jersey City and Fort Lee in New Jersey, Astoria in Queens, Long Beach on Long Island, and Williamsburg, Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights.
But what is considered reasonable one year can become pricey the next. As rents rise in Park Slope, which once got the spillover from Brooklyn Heights, Windsor Terrace is becoming more popular. Rents there are 10 to 15 percent lower than in Park Slope, said John P. Burke Jr., a broker with John P. Burke Realty. A two-bedroom apartment in Windsor Terrace would be $1,650, compared to $2,200 in Park Slope, he said. "There has been more demand for two-bedrooms this year over last," he said, "mainly because few people can afford to live alone and must share to get by."
Rents in Astoria have been escalating as well. A one-bedroom apartment there that would have averaged $750 to $800 a month a year or so ago is now $900 to $1,000, Mr. Cooper said.
WHICH communities are considered likely to be the next magnets for the young? The graduates are not as willing as suburban homeowners to travel more than a half hour to reach the city, brokers say, but migration east in Queens to Bayside seems to be starting, and boundaries are beginning to stretch to Staten Island and Great Neck on Long Island.
Great Neck, that affluent North Shore community? "Yes," Mr. Heiberger said. "you can still get a one-bedroom apartment there for $1,200."
Tufts University class of '99 graduates Sarah Rosen, an assistant producer at Dateline NBC, and Chelsea Switzer, an events coordinator at Chelsea Piers, barely considered Manhattan, even though that was where they wanted to live.
"We knew it would be impossible," Ms. Rosen said. "We wanted to find something for $1,500 a month and with one bedroom that we could subdivide. We each wanted our own room and were not willing to have someone living in the living room."
They registered with an apartment listing service that provided them with addresses of places in their price range. "Nothing they sent us to was in Manhattan," Ms. Rosen said. They also responded to newspaper ads, through which they found a two-bedroom third-floor walkup in Park Slope that was $450 above their budget. "We saw it and said, 'We will kick ourselves if we don't take this,' and then the rent went up another $50 a month because we had them build a wall," she said. "We immediately decided we needed a third roommate."
Through an ad they put on the Tufts alumni Web page, they recruited Stefan Kimball, a new graduate of Penn State, who has a job as a paralegal with Latham & Watkins and who was scheduled to move in yesterday. The fact that the apartment is not in Manhattan doesn't seem to matter to Mr. Kimball, whose family lives in Finland. "I like the idea of living in New York, not New Jersey," he said. "Park Slope is pretty cool, and we have a nice view of Manhattan from the window. I'm paying $800, and for someplace like Park Slope, that seems like a bargain."
For those unshakable in their resolve to be in Manhattan, Gus Perry of Stein-Perry Real Estate in Washington Heights said, "We are absolutely seeing more young people up here, and in Inwood and the north Harlem areas. This is the only place you can find a large one-bedroom for under $1,500 on the island of Manhattan."
Nichole Argyres, a book editor who graduated from the University of Michigan four years ago, and David Gordon, who graduated from its school of music in April, are moving to Inwood in August.
"We had to choose whether we wanted a good location and a really small apartment or live in Brooklyn or the Bronx," Ms. Argyres said from Ann Arbor. "We knew that David would be studying at the Manhattan School of Music, which is near Columbia, so we wanted to try to be in Manhattan. To live elsewhere would be a huge commute."
They found what is termed a "junior four" (one large bedroom and one small) for $1,300 a month. "It's spacious in a great location 20 minutes from downtown on the express and there is lots of green," Ms. Argyres said happily.
How much farther young people will be willing to commute to work and play in Manhattan remains to be seen. And what current trends portend for the post-college generation of the future is an open question.
As Lucy Martin Gianino, an actress who is also a real estate broker with Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy, put it: "If I could give my children one gift, it would be a co-op." Ms. Gianino has three children, Gemina, 30, a teacher who is about to enter the Harvard Graduate School of Education, Antonia, 27, a stage manager for the play "Rent," and Gian-Murray, 22, a new graduate of Wesleyan University who will be an intern for a year with the Actors Theater of Louisville in Kentucky. "It is my big concern as the parent of three children who are all in the arts or education," Ms. Gianino said. "Will they be driven out of the city as everyone here becomes an investment banker? Will they have to leave professions they love to earn a buck so they can put a roof over their heads?"
