SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 4; Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 818 words

HEADLINE: Two Plans for White Plains Site

BYLINE: By PETER BELLER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
SEVENTEEN years after it first proposed developing portions of a 121-acre parcel adjacent to downtown, New York Presbyterian Hospital says it is time to act.
The hospital, which operates its psychiatric division here on a campus designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, has proposed a $300 million retail and residential development on land it owns surrounding the campus. 
 It would include an anchor store, similar in size to the nearby Bloomingdale's, an additional 225,000 square feet of retail space, 480 housing units and a hotel and conference center. To sweeten the deal, the hospital has offered to give the city 60 acres to create what would be the biggest park in White Plains.
But the plan requires zoning approval, and many city officials and nearby residents have called it far too ambitious. "Our primary feeling was that the retail development was much too large," said Marjorie Davies, who headed a League of Women Voters study of the plan.
As a result, the hospital has offered an alternative $96 million plan -- which it says does not require zoning approval -- for new medical and research buildings and, eventually, housing for hospital personnel. This plan, however, does not include any land for a park. And unlike the first plan, the new buildings would be tax exempt.
On July 10, the Common Council is to consider the two plans. It must decide whether to refer the original proposal (known as Plan A) to other city agencies for study. It must also decide whether the second proposal (Plan B) conforms with the hospital's current permit.
With five of the Council's seven members expressing reservations about Plan A, its referral to other agencies seems unlikely.
Some city officials have charged that Plan B, including the threatened loss of the park, was intended to put pressure on the city to refer Plan A to the other agencies. But Geoff Thompson, a spokesman for the hospital, rejected that charge.
"It's not a ruse," he said. "Many feel it's preferable to Plan A."
And yet it is clear that the hospital favors the retail project.
"We believe this is a well-reasoned plan, one that takes many points of view into consideration," said Connie Hildesley, the hospital's vice president for real estate. "With this plan, we create a park and permanent open space for the residents of White Plains, new revenue sources for the city and supplemental income and a stable future for the hospital."
She said the hospital envisions "high-end retail" shops and no "big box" retailers.
The commercial value of the land is substantial, said Chris O'Callahan, a partner at the McCarthy O'Callahan Company, a White Plains real estate company. "The land is very valuable because it is at the confluence of all the major roads in the county," he said. "So the access to the property is tremendous. There's a history of high-end retail development there: it would be very, very desirable."
Harold E. Vogt, president of the county Chamber of Commerce who supports the retail development plan, said it would not harm other retail areas of the city. But opponents see things differently.
Marc Pollitzer, president of the North Street Civic Association, said, "You're talking about commercial sprawl into pristine residential communities." He said that while the group supported limited commercial development, it would "like to see a more meaningful area of property" set aside for open space.
Alan Teck, president of Concerned Citizens for Open Space, a group formed in the early 1980's to oppose the hospital's 1983 plan for development, said his organization of about 600 residents wanted to see the hospital develop medical facilities on its own campus "and sell at least 100 acres of their property" to a land trust.
Councilman Benjamin Boykin called the retail development "massive" and in conflict with the city's 1997 comprehensive plan. He said he would have liked a "scaled down" version of the retail plan. He added that through negotiations he thought a compromise could be reached with less commercial space and a 100- acre park. Councilwoman Pauline Oliva agreed.
But the hospital has rejected such an approach.
"There has to be sufficient development on what is not park to make it economically viable for the hospital to give up the parkland," Mr. Thompson said. "We need to get some critical mass on the rest of it."
Mayor Joseph M. Delfino supports the retail plan and fears losing the park, as does Councilman Robert Greer, who favors at least referring Plan A to other city agencies.
"I view the recommendations for commercial and residential development as the price the city might have to pay for a park," Mr. Greer said., arguing that meaningful discussion was needed rather than two sides "threatening each other with total annihilation."
He said he feared that "if we turn the referral down, the hospital is going to sit down and go with Plan B."

HEADLINE: A Day in the Life Of Newark Airport

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE NEGRONI

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IT was not too long ago that Fiorello LaGuardia refused to get off an airplane here because his ticket showed New York as the destination -- an early example of the effectiveness of the publicity stunt. Lost in Mayor LaGuardia's geographic elitism was the fact that Newark International was the region's first major airport when it opened in 1928 -- and for a while the country's busiest.
Today, the three major airports in the New York City area move 89 million people a year, a transportation network second only to London's Heathrow and Gatwick. Kennedy International Airport links New York with the rest of the world. LaGuardia, with a large domestic operation, was the result of a sustained campaign by the colorful mayor. 
 As the two newer airports competed for its passengers, Newark fell on hard times. In the 1950's the airport's restaurants drew more customers than its airlines. But in the aftermath of airline deregulation -- when People Express, the no-frills carrier, chose an abandoned terminal at Newark as its base in 1981 -- the airport was reborn.
These days, Newark International is the 10th-busiest airport in the nation, surpassing even Kennedy in annual passenger volume. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, operator of all three airports, says Newark contributes $11.3 billion annually to the region's economy.
Indeed, the airport is so busy that its ability to provide necessary services is strained. Just getting to the airport on time is an exercise in frustration, parking is insufficient and the monorail system connecting the three terminals -- envisioned as a link from the airport with New Jersey Transit and Amtrak -- has itself become a problem.
Though the monorail, which began operating in 1996, has already cost more than $300 million, its performance has been inconsistent; and bringing the service up to expectations will cost tens of millions more. Worse, the monorail will be closed for months beginning this summer to work out the bugs.
The Port Authority has nearly a dozen construction projects under way to deal with crowding, including two parking garages -- one scheduled to open in 2001 and the other with no completion date set -- with a total of 6,600 spaces to augment the existing 17,000. Air traffic control, which handles 1,200 to 1,400 flights a day, is getting a new tower that will be completed by the end of 2002. And the offices of the Port Authority itself are moving from the airfield area to make more room for servicing airplanes.
The hall that houses United States Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization service processes 4 million passengers a year, and at peak times the lines resemble those at Disney World during summer vacation.
Customs officials said they are hopeful the situation will improve when Continental Airlines opens its own international area in Terminal C. The expansion includes 12 new gates for wide-bodied jetliners -- a mixed blessing that will insure the arrival of thousands of additional passengers.
"We want to add more capacity overall," explained Susan Baer, the Port Authority's general manager for New Jersey airports. That is no mean trick considering that there is little room for expansion on the 2,000-acre property. Kennedy, in contrast, has more than twice as much land.
Joel Jacoby, Ms. Baer's deputy, says keeping up with the success of the airport presents a huge challenge. "We're constrained in the amount of land," Mr. Jacoby said. "All developable property is developed. We redesign facilities with the same footprint."
In an airport that is constantly growing and never sleeps, keeping up is -- as one Port Authority official put it -- like doing "surgery on a patient who refuses to lie down."
Although the air passenger traffic winds down around midnight, the runways are kept busy and the south side of the airport throbs with the Federal Express operation. Fifty-four cargo flights, requiring about 1,500 employees, make the overnight shift the company's busiest time of day.
Newark airport is, in essence, a virtual city. It has a transitory population of 90,000, and its 24,000 permanent residents, the employees, are the heart of the operation.
"I'm the mayor," Ms. Baer said. "To manage facilities you must manage people."
 
FUELING THE JETS
Robert Dickerson
Keeps Them Flying
Robert Dickerson does not need any motivational speeches as he begins his day refueling jets at 5 a.m.
"Airplanes can go without people," Mr. Dickerson said. "They can go without bags. They can go without food, and many times they do. But they can't leave without fuel."
Mr. Dickerson, 42, of Hazlet, works for Ogden Aviation, which contracts with the Port Authority to receive, store, test and dispense up to 2 1/2 million gallons of Jet A aviation fuel every day. For eight hours, Mr. Dickerson, like his 128 co-workers, works alone as he pumps fuel from underground hydrants into the wings of seven or eight aircraft.
Mr. Dickerson likes to work the airlines that require him to deliver the completed fueling paperwork to the pilots in the cockpit, since he has not outgrown his childhood fascination with flying.
"That's a nice part of working here," he says. "To go into the cockpit and look around. Passengers never get to see a cockpit."
Every fueling operation begins with an order from the airline for enough fuel to get the plane to its destination and to an alternate airport, with a small percentage extra for unexpected delays. Pulling a stepladder from his truck, Mr. Dickerson walks beneath the enormous wings, climbs the ladder and opens a panel on the underside of the wing to check how much fuel is on the aircraft. Sometimes, there is already enough.
"In the beginning I was worried about the math," he confesses. "You think the math is going to be harder then it is." Pulling his security from his shirt pocket, he says, "They give us free calculators."
The actual refueling takes 25 to 30 minutes. Only the beginning and end are difficult. "The hoses are heavy and awkward, but you got to get used to them," he says. "You work hard for a couple of minutes then stand around."
Mr. Dickerson knows many of the ramp workers, and when there's time, there is socializing -- or commiserating if the weather is bad.
"Rain, heat, snow, I don't mind the cold, but I don't like the rain," he says. "A bad day is a rainy day and all the planes coming in need fuel."
Sometimes, the inclement bad weather that paralyzes the airlines and strands passengers is a welcome relief for Mr. Dickerson. "It's a good day when all your planes cancel," he said.
 
JUGGLING THE OPERATION
Jeff Krisiak, Point Man
For Continental
Mr. Dickerson's dream day is Jeff Krisiak's worst nightmare. Mr. Krisiak, the operations manager for Continental Airlines, remembers with a wince the unexpected snowstorm in April that stranded airplanes on the runway.
"We didn't know how bad the storm would be,' he says. "The planes left the gate and stayed out on the runway. We brought catering trucks and re-catered them. We took the trash and emptied the lavs. There were planes out there five or six hours."
When another snowstorm was forecast in May, Continental was more prepared. It arranged to transport its East Coast passengers to their destinations on Amtrak.
"We sent people by train to Portland, Providence, Hartford, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Virginia Beach, Albany, Buffalo," Mr. Krisiak recalled. "Our long-term goal will be to code share with Amtrak. We took care of about 600 people that day."
Mr. Krisiak, who joined Continental in 1983, says he has had to make plenty of tough decisions -- some right, some wrong.
"If you do a good job, everybody takes the credit," he said. "If you make the hard decision to downgrade from a DC-10 to a 757 and lose 100 seats, the bosses come back and say, 'Jeff, why, why, why?' "
Mr. Krisiak works in the airline's large operations center, illuminated for the most part by a wall of windows. After driving to work from his home in Pennsylvania's Pocono Mountains, he enters the office through an unmarked door in an area of the Continental terminal not yet open. The tranquility of the large tropical fish tank by the entrance belies the intensity of the activity. Two dozen people are responsible for monitoring every facet of Continental's operations here. They communicate with the ground workers and the crews aboard the aircraft. They watch each plane on the ground from video cameras mounted at the gates.
"We have 524 operations per day," Mr. Krisiak said, "262 arrivals, 262 departures. We have incoming information on all of the flights." With this information, the center's staff can dispatch such equipment as a replacement part or a wheel chair for a passenger before a plane arrives at the gate.
"A captain can call and have an issue," he said, motioning to three aircraft mechanics seated at computers. "We can go into the computer right here and tell him his plane's maintenance history."
Mr. Krisiak went on: "There's been a change in mindset. People were reacting. Now we're getting people to understand the time-saving benefit of pre-planning."
 
DELIVERING BAD NEWS
Robert Baldwin Serves
By Smiling (and Singing)
"In the morning I put my oatmeal on the table and mix it with humor," said Robert Baldwin, a customer service representative for the Port Authority. He wears the standard-issue grey trousers and red blazer to indicate he is one of 160 people hired by the airport to help confused travelers.
Yet Mr. Baldwin is one of a kind.
From the bright glass-walled monorail station in Terminal C, he sings: "Hello my friends. Welcome to Terminal C. Only the best to you," projecting his voice over the noise of departing trains. He is not happy when he has to tell travelers news they might find distressing.
"Sometimes I may have to talk about delays on the monorail and this is bad news, so I blend it with as much positive as I can," he said.
Women in saris, men in suits and ties, teenage girls, people pushing strollers, wheel chairs and luggage carts, ramp workers and flight attendants -- none of them escape his attention. He is a man entirely comfortable with amiability. "I give a million-dollar greeting to everyone," he said.
A young pilot emerges from the monorail and casts a quick and curious glance at Mr. Baldwin, who is singing again. The pilot, clearly uncomfortable, is not the only one who seems to want to avoid the jovial interaction. Mr. Baldwin doesn't notice.
"People almost always look and give him a smile," said Michael Bekiarian of Gateway Security, the Port Authority contractor that provides the airport with customer service representatives. "That's what the Red Coat program is all about, changing perceptions. Does he go over the top? Yes. But I see people change from their experience of him."
Two middle-aged Japanese women laugh and clap as a companion videotapes Mr. Baldwin crooning: "Train to terminals B, A and rental cars on the left. Step lively, now."
Mr. Baldwin of Belleville, who for years worked for years as a hotel bellman at the Marriott in Hanover, was hired by Gateway a year ago. In a typical eight-hour shift he can answer close to 500 questions. They can be posed politely, as in "Where are the restaurants?" or be no more than a simple "B?" barked rudely. His answers never reflect anything less than sheer delight at the chance to help.
 
EXAMINING THE BAGS
Tony Maresca,
Always Suspicious
If there is one time of day when international passengers should not arrive at the customs and immigration hall, it is from noon to 6 p.m., when most international flights land here.
"We can have six planes arrive all around the same time, each with 200 people or more," said Tony Maresca, an assistant chief inspector, "so that's 1,200 people in the prime arrival time. They go through Immigration and then they come here to wait for their bags."
When a flight gets a serious examination from the officers supervised by Mr. Maresca, the passengers have to wait a little longer for their baggage. "Every day we target a flight and give it a good inspection," he said.
On this day, it was Continental Airlines Flight 1866 from Bogota. The passengers deplaned and 10 Customs officers and a drug-sniffing dog got on. A portable X-ray machine was set up at the end of the belt loader, which held boxed cargo. Mr. Maresca looked on, sober in his dark uniform.
The luggage had been taken inside, where it was also on a conveyor belt, ascending to the baggage carousels in the room above. Two dogs were running the treadmill along with the suitcases, sniffing each approaching bag.
"You have to balance this activity because a lot of these passengers have connecting flights," said Marco Galiano, supervisor of the K-9 enforcement unit, who joined Mr. Maresca. "We don't want them to miss their flights, but we've got to get dope off the street."
As he talks, a suitcase gets one of the dogs scratching excitedly. A description of the bag is called up to a Customs inspector before it is sent into the baggage claim area with the others. A woman traveling with two young children retrieves the bag and a moment later she is standing at a metal table, the bag opened before a young agent.
"People hide drugs on kids," Mr. Maresca said, explaining how difficult it is to define usual suspects.
Then again, there are some dead giveaways. "Here's a classic," he said. "It's July and someone is wearing a coat. They won't take it off."
As Mr. Maresca and Mr. Galiano talk, they glance at the young mother. Three uniformed agents are standing much closer to her, doing a poor job of trying to look nonchalant. Small boxes of coffee are removed, examined and repacked.
A sigh of understanding emerges from Mr. Galiano. "Sometimes we train the dogs with coffee," he said. "She's got a lot of coffee there." Interest in her suitcase is waning, and five minutes later she and her children are on their way.
"Usually, we tell the passenger why their bag was selected for inspection," Mr. Maresca said. "We tell them it was the dog. If we're going to hold them up, at least we should tell them why."
 
CLEANING THE BATHROOMS
Elina Mendoza
Keeps Things Tidy
During the course of her shift, from 1 to 9 p.m., hundreds of women will encounter Elina Mendoza cleaning the bathroom by gates 60 to 68 in Terminal B. She is there to make sure the bathroom is tidy, but beyond that her presence creates an expectation.
"When there is not someone there, people won't clean up after themselves," Ms. Mendoza, from Elizabeth, explained in Spanish.
Susan Baer, the airport manager, agreed. "It's all psychology," she said. "In the bathrooms, seeing a person cleaning up assures you the bathroom is clean. It tells you 'this is a priority.' "
Sheets of mirror and brushed steel partitions around the toilets beg for polishing. Countertops need mopping up. Going about these tasks, Ms. Mendoza wears a uniform of black pants, white blouse and floppy bow tie. On her hands are disposable surgical gloves and she's ready with a rag and squirt bottle of cleaner. She also makes sure there is paper in the stalls and at the sinks and not on the floor. "My days are busy, very full," she said. "I'm constantly in motion."
Using the interview as an opportunity to sit down for a few minutes in the darkened supply area adjoining the bathroom, she went on, "Some people tell me this is not the best job, but when people ask me if I like my job I say, 'yes.' "
And there are always questions, some more peculiar than others.
One woman sticks in her memory. "She asked me where were the public showers," she said. "I told her there are no public showers here. Two days later I saw her again. She had been stuck in the airport for two days." She said, 'Please, please. Where can I clean up? I'm desperate.' Finally I let her use the big utility sink in the supply room."
 
LOADING AND UNLOADING
Ron Fizer,
Man in a Hurry
There is a determination to Ron Fizer's stride as he crosses the 200 yards of airway between the Continental ramp crew office to the Terminal C gate, where he will spend the next eight hours. Mr. Fizer -- who is responsible for everything that goes on or comes off an airplane while at the gate except fuel and food -- is dressed in blue pants, a work shirt and a high-visibility orange net vest. He swings a tool box in his right hand. On his left arm he wears a watch. He will refer to it often.
"The first thing I do is get information about my flights," explains Mr. Fizer, who has driven in from his home in Lakewood. For that he heads for a door a level below the jetway.
Just inside the doorway the hall is lined with pilots' black flight cases, stacked like bricks one atop the other. The 48-year-old Mr. Fizer moves quickly, passing first through the pilots' lounge, then a second room, this one dim and occupied by a dozen pilots dozing on recliners. In the room beyond, ramp workers sit at tables eating lunch.
"I need the upload for flight 319," he says to a man at a desk at the end of the lunchroom. Receiving a white printout, he returns outside to the MD-80 at gate 109, which is headed to Washington.
"Usually these planes are packed," he said, showing off the deep storage space of the plane's three open belly compartments, which are empty. "We can load 11,000 to 15,000 pounds in four minutes. Four guys can download 25,000 pounds."
Mr. Fizer checks the water supply on board from a panel on the front of the plane's wing. Then he moves on to the nose wheel. Taking a pin from his tool box he slips it into a joint on the gear, enabling the wheel to pivot freely. Now a tow bar and tug can be used to push the plane from the gate at departure. It takes two men to attach the tow bar, and the entire operation is complete is 30 seconds.
Mr. Fizer checks his watch. It's 3:11, and the first of the luggage for flight 319 arrives. He reaches into the curtained container and begins tossing bags onto the conveyor belt receding into the cargo compartment. He checks the tag on every third or fourth suitcase saying: "I don't want a Detroit bag on this flight. I don't want a Fort Lauderdale bag on this flight. I don't want a Paris bag on this flight. We're not going to Paris."
At 3:25 the cargo doors are locked. Mr. Fizer checks his watch. "Minutes are precious," he says. "They can make or break a flight." At 3:31 a small suitcase is delivered to Mr. Fizer by a uniformed pilot. A minute later a stroller is sent down a circular metal chute and the cargo door is opened once again.
The last-minute stowing of baggage is a regular occurrence these days as passengers strain the limits of the overhead storage bins.
"One hundred and fifty passengers all want to keep their luggage with them," Mr. Fizer said, shaking his head. "Somebody's got to cough up a bag."
As Mr. Fizer looks on, Flight 319 is pushed out to a position on the field where it will begin to move under its own power. But before the tug driver disconnects the bar from the nose gear, he takes one last, late-arriving suitcase and stashes it in the cargo area. One passenger complaint averted. Flight 319 is four minutes late out of Newark.
 
POLICING THE AREA
John Collis
Patrols on Bike
Pedaling his bicycle through the crowded international arrivals hall, Officer John Collis, 38, is blazing a trail. He wears a regulation blue jump suit and a saucy silver bike helmet as he patrols the terminals and parking lots.
The bike also allows Mr. Collins to ride a fine line between the image of the traditional police officer and that of a somewhat friendlier helper that the Port Authority wants to convey. He is one of five officers here who have received bike patrol training from the New York Police Department.
"You learn how to get on and off the bike and how to use the bike as a defensive weapon," he said.
On a typical day, Officer Collis, who lives in Verona, says he will ride 20 miles or more. "I cover a lot more ground with the bike," he said. 'It's an excellent tool."
Not long after his shift began one evening, he was summoned to the immigration hall at the end of a long concourse at Terminal B. A check of passports touched off a report that there was an outstanding arrest warrant for one passenger's.
"Police matters can get complicated here,' he said, ticking off the list of agencies and jurisdictions involved. "There are the federal authorities, the state police, the New York police, Newark police, postal inspectors and the Secret Service."
But days of routine patrolling outnumber those of excitement. The passenger in immigration was handed over to two officers and Officer Collis pedaled back to the terminal. An hour later he is explaining airport policy to an elderly diabetic in need of insulin who is out of syringes. Medics can be called, Officer Collis explains, though she will have to pay handsomely. The woman decides to take a cab to a nearby drugstore, and Officer Collis is off once again.
 
DELIVERING THE MAIL
Federal Express Works While Everyone Sleeps
While most people who work at Newark International spend the night sleepily oblivious to the passing of time, the Federal Express crew can document how every minute of the overnight shift is spent. In four hours they will take correspondence and cargo from 27 planes and 340 trucks, shuffle it, redistribute it and send it back out before daybreak.
This operation involves 1,500 people and millions of dollars in equipment in addition to a fleet of wide bodies, jetliners and feeder aircraft that take over the airfield each night. One delay or one dropped ball can create a frenzy.
"No matter what part you work, every person has an effect on the next person," says Joyce Kiesewetter of Woodbridge Township, an operations administrator. She is joined in the sentiment by Paula Krysa, a senior manager from Pine Branch, who adds, "Every little piece of the puzzle makes a difference."
Ed Patterson, a control manager from Queens, N.Y., says: "We've had nights when an aircraft down loads at 1:42. They should have been done by 1:15. Then we have to find a way to make up the time elsewhere."
Much rides on Newark, the company's biggest generator of freight, moving 385,000 pieces each night. Yet like soldiers exchanging battle stories, members of the overnight crew thrill at the obstacles they have overcome, the odds they have beaten while the rest of the airport is sleeping
"There's closure when the plane is buttoned up and takes off," Mr. Patterson explains. "For that day you're a winner."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Katie Mauro, Bram Zeigler

 BODY:
Katie Mauro, the daughter of Melanie and Frank W. Mauro Jr. of Stockton, Calif., was married yesterday in Stanford, Calif., to Abraham Ives Zeigler, a son of Alison and Joseph Zeigler of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Maurice Charles, an Episcopal minister and an associate dean for religious life at Stanford University, officiated at the Stanford Memorial Church. The Rev. Kenneth A. Gorsuch, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, took part in the ceremony.
The couple work in San Francisco, where the bride is an account supervisor at Porter Novelli, a public relations firm, and the bridegroom is a project manager at Charles Schwab & Company, the discount securities brokerage firm. 
 Mrs. Zeigler, 26, graduated and received a master's degree in English literature from Stanford. Her father owns the Stockton Wheel Service, which manufactures and repairs wheels for automobiles and agricultural equipment. Her mother teaches kindergarten at Hazeltown Elementary School in Stockton.
Mr. Zeigler, 29, is known as Bram. He graduated magna cum laude from Dickinson College and received a master's degree in economics from Washington University in St. Louis. His mother is a bookkeeper in Montclair, where his father is a consultant to arts organizations on planning and fund-raising.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 6; Column 1; Television

LENGTH: 574 words

HEADLINE: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
THERE have been many incarnations of Sally Bowles, Christopher Isherwood's divinely decadent "Berlin Stories" heroine, and Liza Minnelli didn't seem the most logical choice to play her. But Ms. Minnelli proved her critics dead wrong about that in Bob Fosse's brilliant film version of CABARET (1972) and won an Oscar for her efforts. Joel Grey did the same, as the sexually ambiguous emcee of the Kit Kat Klub, where everything is beatiful - or pretends to be, as Nazi swastikas appear and begin to change Germany forever. Michael York is Sally's bisexual love interest, Marisa Berenson is his innocent Jewish student, and Kander and Ebb's music is as heartbreaking as ever - Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 2 a.m. on Romance Classics. 
 In his New York Times review, Bosley Crowther called it an "obviously low-budget job," referring to the shocks as just "old-fashioned and melodramatics, however effective and sure." At least, he allowed, "the acting is fair." Despite Crowther's low opinion of it, PSYCHO (1960) is now considered Hitchcock's masterpiece. Anthony Perkins's portrayal of Norman Bates, the jittery mama's-boy manager of the dreary Bates Motel, typecast him for life, but it's fascinting cinema history, as is Janet Leigh's scary shower scene and every shot of the creepy Victorian mansion out back - Sunday at 8 p.m on AMC.
 Five years after "Citien Kane," Orson Welles made THE STRANGER (1946), a terrific, atmospheric suspense drama about a Nazi war criminal (Welles) posing as a college professor in a sunny little Connecticut town. Edward G. Robinson is wonderfully single-minded as the federal agent out to unmask him. Loretta Young gets the best lighting as the professor's new wife, who refuses to suspect a thing, even after he kills her dog - Sunday at 8 p.m. on Channel 55.
 Write about what you know, they say. So Kevin Smith, a former Quick Stop employee, created CLERKS (1994), a bleak day in the life of a New Jersey convenience store and the video store next door. Brian O'Halloran and Jeff Anderson play the title roles. Expect irreverence; this is a film that makes necrophilia in a public bathroom funny - Tuesday at 9:45 p.m. and Tuesday/Early Wednesday at 1:30 a.m. on IFC.
 The restaurateur brothers (Stanley Tucci and Tony Shalhoub) in Mr. Tucci and Campbell Scott's BIG NIGHT (1996) are a lot more dedicated to their careers. Despite that, their Italian restaurant is on the verge of closing. Now they're going for broke: they'll make a fantastic dinner for Louis Prima and his band (the film is set in the 1950's), and the evening will either make their reputation or they'll call it quits. "Babette's Feast" fans will be happy - Saturday at 6 p.m. on Lifetime.
 Geraldine Page is eloquently sad as a fading beauty and has-been actress in SWEET BIRD OF YOUTH (1962), Richard Brooks's take on Tennessee Williams's story about a lost weekend on Florida's Gulf Coast. Paul Newman is painfully needy as her companion, Chance Wayne, struggling, youngish would-be actor who has been struggling just a little to long. Ed Begley won the best supporting actor Oscar as Boss Finley, a local politician who will go to frightening lengths to keep his oddly named daughter, Heavenly (Shirley Knight), away from Chance. Hollywood's concept of age is always interesting: Mr. Newman was 37 when the film was released; Ms. Page was 38 - Wednesday at 6 p.m. on TCM.
 - Anita Gates

An article on Sunday about a white quarterback at the historically black Southern University in Louisiana misstated the number of colleges in the top division in college football. That grouping, known as Division I-A, comprises 114 institutions, not 500. (Southern plays in the next division, I-AA.)

HEADLINE: Asphalt Blues

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Edward Keating is a New York Times staff photographer. Verlyn Klinkenborg is a member of the Times editorial board.

 BODY:
Depending on how you look at it, Route 66 was a strip of the true vernacular or an asphalt hustle. Perhaps it was always both. Route 66 was commissioned in 1926, fully paved in 1938, its last stretch replaced by an Interstate in 1984. During the Depression and World War II, it was a historic migratory corridor from the Midwest to the Southwest and California. In "The Grapes of Wrath," John Steinbeck called Route 66 "the mother road" but also, more accurately, "the road of flight." It was the road across "the Western States," a road on which no one ever traveled east, on which caravans of drifters and laborers and uprooted families moved in the one iconic direction, toward the Pacific Ocean. "Need," Steinbeck wrote, "is the stimulus to concept, concept to action." The action that grew up along Route 66 during its boom years is legendary. That was where, and how, America learned what it means to be on the road with an automobile. Every motel, every auto camp, every drive-in along the way was somebody's pipe dream come true, and the road ahead was a pipe dream, too. The highway followed the lay of the land. It ran down Main Street and right out of town. It carried away the people you knew and brought strangers in their place.
As its economic importance dwindled, the highway's nostalgic importance grew, and it took only nostalgia to turn the Route 66 wayside into kitsch. The old continuous Route 66 is nearly as gone as the Oregon Trail. But America loves to memorialize its transience, and now Congress has passed a bill guaranteeing $10 million over the next 10 years to help rehabilitate Route 66. 
 What remains is the scenery -- the wide-open void -- and the towns themselves. You know the names from the Bobby Troup song, recorded by Nat King Cole: St. Louis, Joplin, Oklahoma City, Amarillo, Gallup, Winona, Flagstaff, Kingman, Barstow, San Bernardino. But also Chenoa, Ill; Baxter Springs, Kan.; Yukon and Elk City, Okla.; Tucumcari, N.M.; Peach Springs, Ariz.; Needles, Calif.; and a hundred others like them. They sound like left-behind places, but they're not. They're the dots that any cross-country highway connects almost anywhere in America.
Route 66 is still the road of flight. The migration goes on, as these photographs by Edward Keating attest. It's no longer a mass movement, but the sense of drift is much the same as it was when people were fleeing the Depression, the Dust Bowl and debt. Turn your eyes very far from the main road, and you come across some of the people Edward Keating found -- prostitutes, topless dancers, missionaries, Bible distributors and the dislocated. The migration is sometimes actual, and sometimes an internal one, a readjustment of expectations, whether you stay put or move along. The transience that Keating memorializes isn't the tourist traps or the roadside architecture of America's hectic fantasy. It's something in the glance, something in the feeling you can see in these eyes. You try to stand still, they seem to say, but the ground moves beneath you. No matter what you do, the highway ends up running right down your back.

HEADLINE: From Ruth to Rotisserie

BYLINE: By Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria; Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria is the author of "The Pride of Havana: A History of Cuban Baseball" and the editor of "The Oxford Book of Latin American Short Stories."

 BODY:

 PAST TIME
 Baseball as History.
 By Jules Tygiel.
 Illustrated. 258 pp. New York:
 Oxford University Press. $25.
 
 GAMES resist change; they incline to the timeless. So, inevitably, the histories written about them deal with the evolution of the society around them, not their own transformations. If a baseball fan from 1900 rode a time machine to this year's opening game, there would have been very little about the sport new to him: nine players, nine innings, three strikes, three outs, 90 feet between the bases, hits, errors, bases on balls -- most of the terms would be familiar. The uniforms would look slightly different, the blare from the sound system would be disconcerting and the players' salaries incomprehensible. Black, Hispanic and Asian players would be a novelty, too. But these changes are technological, social, economic -- not the game's. This is the history that Jules Tygiel tells in this extraordinary collection of essays, which, the author says, is a history not of baseball but of American culture as seen through the sport's interaction with developments in the social, political, financial and intellectual evolution of the United States.
"Past Time" is concerned with "how each generation reinvented the national pastime to fit its own material reality and ideological perceptions," but this is no plodding, would-be Marxist analysis of baseball. Tygiel's forte as a historian is his eye for what may appear nugatory or marginal but, when focused upon, illuminates the temper of a given moment. His nine essays concern turning points in baseball and American history, arranged in chronological order. They cover the rise of the game from the mid-19th century to the present, and while each chapter is an individual unit, the book leaves one with the feeling of having read a complete history of American baseball. Tygiel's heroes are large and small, and their accomplishments range from the invention of the box score to that of rotisserie baseball.
Tygiel, a professor of history at San Francisco State University and the author of "Baseball's Great Experiment: Jackie Robinson and His Legacy," places the sport in broad yet precise cultural contexts. He argues convincingly, for instance, that baseball became a national game because improvements in transportation and communication (railroads, the telegraph) unified the United States in the aftermath of the Civil War. Baseball became a symbol of that reunification. Tygiel also argues that the development of the social sciences and of statistics in the mid-19th century led Henry Chadwick to invent the box score and to establish methods to calculate and keep baseball records. Tygiel points out that Branch Rickey's creation of the farm system in the 1930's is coeval with the emergence of the first chain stores, which contributed to the creation of a national culture by making small towns feel they were part of a larger whole. While it is not particularly original to remark that Babe Ruth came onto the scene at the same time as radio broadcasting and the movies, Tygiel goes further by allowing that Ruth was also instrumental in the advance of public relations and advertising as businesses. He was among the first celebrities produced by those industries.
Tygiel's best essay traces the interlaced, contrasting -- and clashing -- careers of Branch Rickey and Larry MacPhail. The lives of these two moguls coil around the history of 20th-century American baseball like two snakes clasped in mortal strife. Rickey, the sanctimonious, hypocritical puritan who kept track of attendance from his home on Sundays while piously refusing to go to the ballpark; MacPhail, the crass entrepreneur with vision, able to discern the potential profit of night baseball, television and aviation -- these former associates who became bitter rivals wound up in New York leading the two top teams: Rickey the Brooklyn Dodgers, MacPhail the Yankees. Inspired by greed and his much-proclaimed principles, Rickey was willing to bring about the racial integration of the game -- his specialty was the exploitation of labor, and black players, owned by weak Negro leagues teams, were a free market. MacPhail thought that large numbers of black fans at the stadiums would diminish the value of major league franchises. Like many owners, he rented ballparks to Negro leagues teams, and saw clearly that the integration of the majors would destroy his tenants, putting an end to that lucrative sideline. Rickey and MacPhail had contrasting mixtures of vision, chicanery, ambition and the will to win. Rickey, the former catcher, was obsessed with training techniques to squeeze the most out of his players; MacPhail, more forward-looking, was obsessed with business innovations that could renew the industry. Tygiel's strength in this superb essay is his affection for these flawed figures.
Some of Tygiel's best and most revealing stories are about forgotten innovators. Thus we discover that Ben Shibe (after whom a park in Philadelphia was named) "made his fortune by perfecting the machines that produced standardized baseballs." It was Harold Arlin, from Forbes Field in Pittsburgh, who first broadcast a baseball game, on Aug. 5, 1921. A fascinating unsung hero is the prescient Allan Roth, who, as a hobby, began in the 1940's to compile "the most detailed analysis of baseball ever undertaken." Roth could cite hitters' averages against individual pitchers and what they did when ahead or behind in the count -- commonplace today but revolutionary then. Rickey, always fascinated by the scientific approach to the game, hired him. Tygiel recounts the dramatic moment when the Dodger publicist Irving Rudd, seeing Ralph Branca coming in to pitch to Bobby Thomson on that fateful Oct. 3, 1951, asked Roth how the right-hander fared against the Giant third baseman: "Roth, staring out at the field, just shook his head sadly."
"Past Time" is not a paean to baseball, but it is not a destructive critique either. On the issue of racial integration, for instance, Tygiel writes, the end of segregation meant that "fewer, rather than more, African-Americans would earn their living from baseball in the latter half of the 20th century. The failure of major league teams to hire black managers, coaches and front-office personnel compounded this problem. The nearly universal celebration of Jackie Robinson's triumph notwithstanding, integration would produce negative as well as positive consequences." Tygiel notes that in 1951, four years after Robinson joined the Dodgers, "only three teams in each league fielded black players." (Also by then, the Negro leagues were in sharp decline and midcareer players were scrambling for jobs.)
Mythmaking is, of course, part of the history of baseball, a story unto itself that someone ought to write. The urge to play cannot be explained by material need; it emerges either before or after it. Myths wanting to account for the origin of this urge cannot reach it -- not even a modern one like cultural history. Tygiel is aware of this and refrains from making overambitious claims. But he also engages occasionally in mythmaking of his own and is blind to the influence the game itself has on the business of baseball. A leitmotif in "Past Time" is the slow pace at which the baseball industry adapts to change. Could this not be a reflection of the game's inherent resistance to innovation? I do not see slowness in a negative light, perhaps because I am, like everybody else, a potential mythmaker myself.
But I fear that the consolidation of the two major leagues and the investiture of limitless power on a commissioner (who is, after all, one of the owners) could mean an unchecked rush to alter the game. In my nightmares I see the World Series in neutral, warm-weather sites, with teams not representing cities but only themselves as brand names. As with the new retro parks, nostalgia will just be another commodity, and the rules may even be tampered with, as in basketball, to generate excitement and greater revenue. Three sets of three innings, with the winner of two declared the victor, to create more endgame situations? Sudden death, as in other sports, by starting all extra innings with two outs and the bases loaded? Could something like this really happen? Tygiel is optimistic that it will not: "Despite the perennial warnings of baseball Cassandras, time has yet to pass baseball by. What remains to be seen is not whether the game will survive, but how Americans in a rapidly changing world will again reinterpret and reinvent their national pastime." I hope that, being right about so much in the game's past, Tygiel is also good at predicting its future.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Third Way

BYLINE: By Paul Berman; Paul Berman is the author of "A Tale of Two Utopias: The Political Journey of the Generation of 1968." His article on Cuauhtemoc C1/3rdenas appeared in the magazine in August 1998.

 BODY:
Vicente Fox climbed a podium in the broiling sun at Minatitlan -- a tropical oil town on Mexico's Gulf Coast oozing with heat and petroleum. A few thousand people gazed at him from under their sun umbrellas and straw sombreros. And he cried out in his booming bass voice, "When is Mexico going to change?"
Fox is running for president of Mexico in today's election, and the people in the street knew his slogan and shouted it back at him. 
 "Today!"
"When is Minatitlan going to change?"
Everyone shouted, "Today!"
Fox shouted out denunciations of Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The PRI has been governing Mexico for 71 years. The PRI is the world's oldest continuously ruling party. It is a tired old dinosaur, dragging its tail through the dust.
"They are corrupt!" he shouted, and the r's in the Spanish corruptos trilled through the loudspeakers. Fox said that 40 million Mexicans live in the most wretched poverty. Millions more have fled to the United States, where they are persecuted and mistreated. Those are the PRI's achievements! He talked about Mexico's presidential palace, Los Pinos. "When are we going to drag the PRI out of Los Pinos?"
And Vicente Fox Quesada and the people of Minatitlan began to chant, "Today! Today! Today!"
Those were campaign slogans. But Fox's question -- When is Mexico going to change?" -- is a question that, in a quieter mood, ordinary Mexicans have been asking themselves for a long time. People get wistful on the topic. They say -- they have said to me a hundred times -- Mexico is rich. We have oil, agriculture, industry. We have a good and honest people. We are creative. We have an artistic soul. So why is Mexico stuck where it is: poor, fearful, awash in baroque crimes and gargantuan bank scandals?"
Mexicans are perfectly aware that all over the world in the last dozen years, one country after another has shaken off the oppression of the ages, has overthrown its authoritarian government and has sometimes lifted itself out of poverty too. Fox plays on that awareness. He invokes the names of Nelson Mandela and Lech Walesa. When he cries out, "When will Mexico change?" he wants people to think, "When Vicente Fox gets into power." He wants them to swell with hope. And they do. They shout, "Today!" But you can almost hear them adding, in a dark tone of fatalism, "Maybe!"
For how else can Mexicans feel? They have had their hopes raised before. Twelve years ago, in 1988, one of the princes of the PRI, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, having defected from the old party, ran for president as an opposition candidate with support from the left. That time, the feeling of hope was sharp and fiery. Cardenas won the election, or so it is thought by a good many people. But the PRI is a past master at election frauds. The vote-counters announced a computer crash. The PRI's candidate, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, was declared the winner. And Salinas's circle turned out to be spectacularly corrupt, and slightly murderous to boot.
In the 1994 election, people again began to imagine that, at last, the PRI might get overthrown. Cardenas, the old hero from 1988, had lost some of his sheen by then -- partly because a wave of killings during the Salinas years had decimated his left-wing party. But in Mexico there has always been a right-wing opposition, too, the National Action party, which is Catholic and pro-business. In 1994, someone from National Action stepped forward to lead the new crusade -- a dapper, bearded politician named Diego Fernandez de Cevallos, who seemed to be a man of talent.
That year, as in 1988, I watched the goings-on. I remember Diego Fernandez's face glowing from a television screen in a Coyoacan cantina, and the whole room shouting "Diego!" Yet, just when Diego Fernandez seemed to be doing pretty well against the PRI, he stopped campaigning; no one knows why. The PRI sailed to victory yet again. Ernesto Zedillo became president. And ordinary Mexicans sank still deeper into the gray swamp that surrounds authoritarian societies everywhere -- the miasmas of resignation and cynicism, streaked with bizarre and sinister conspiracy theories and brightly colored millenarian fantasies that cannot possibly come to pass.
In the years after Cardenas's powerful showing in the 1988 race, Mexico did, in its timid way, begin to change. The PRI was always a giant octopus of an organization, with business interests, state enterprises, its own labor unions, street mobs and mass organizations of the poor and a dozen other tentacles, known and unknown, all of them attached to the octopus's head, which consists of money and corruption. Even today, the old organization makes a fairly open habit of buying votes in poor neighborhoods. The PRI's candidate for president in today's election, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, has shown no embarrassment at all in surrounding himself with some of the shadiest faces from the PRI's old guard.
And yet, the democratic breeze has been blowing for a long time now, and the PRI has had to bend with the wind. The old party has allowed one and another opposition politician to win local elections in the last few years, including Cardenas, who became the mayor of Mexico City, and Vicente Fox, who became the governor of Guanajuato state. Freedom of the press, which used to be minimal, has become more than minimal. And so the PRI has ended up weaker and more vulnerable, and the opposition has grown bigger and richer (no small thing). And this time, in Fox, the opposition has found a candidate who is sensational even in his looks.
For as everyone loves to notice, Vicente Fox, at a rugged 58, is the Marlboro Man. He wears black cowboy boots. His belt buckle, in a slightly ominous touch, touts the oversize letters FOX. His mighty shoulders point like ax blades in either direction. His chin is a steel prow, cutting the air. Every bristly hair of his Dapper Dan mustache expresses impudence. The crown of his head stands a full 6 feet 6 inches above the ground. He is a giant. And that is only half the story.
Fox wears his big leather boots because, having grown up on a farm, the rancher's manner is his by right. But having studied with the Jesuits, he left the farm behind and took up a career in business. And because some cliches are, in their boundlessness, positively sinister, the Marlboro Man steadily rose in the world until he had become the president of Coca-Cola in its Mexican branch.
When he shifted over to politics, he enlisted in National Action, the right-wing party. But he also cleverly applied a few soft-drink marketing methods to constructing a parallel organization of his own, the Friends of Fox, in order to keep a distance from the pesky barons and troglodytic ideologues of National Action. He raised money, apparently with no trouble at all (though his enemies complain about foul play). And he has shown that he knows how to work a crowd.
I rode in his campaign bus into villa isla, a few miles from Minatitlan, where his local organizers had gathered a few thousand people together with a long row of farm tractors. Fox shook a couple of hands. He strode over to the first of those tractors and climbed into the driver's seat. He clapped a straw sombrero on his head. And right away he began, very slowly, to drive.
The tractor was a big green John Deere with rear wheels five feet tall, and it was surrounded on all sides by the jostling crowd, which made driving a delicate business. But he pushed forward. And with one hand on the wheel, guiding his tractor through the human sea, Fox raised his free hand in the V sign, which is a symbol of his campaign. The crowd roared. And down the street he went, the conquering general, riding in triumph on his white steed, which happened to be a green tractor.
It was quite a stunt. It was the performance of a man who really might get himself elected president -- cheerful, confident, well organized, efficient with time. And so, as any number of Mexicans have come to believe, in today's election the moment for change on the biggest of scales may finally have arrived. Every single condition for a democratic transition at the national level seems to be at hand: a popular disgust for the PRI, a lust for change, a feeling of freedom, a smaller likelihood of large-scale fraud and an opposition leader who radiates brio with every oversize step he takes.
There is only one problem. Vicente Fox is not the only well-liked insurgent running for president. Cuauhtemoc Cardenas is also running. No one seriously believes that Cardenas can win, though his supporters sometimes convince themselves otherwise. His poll statistics dropped into single figures just a few months ago. But many millions of people in Mexico will always have a place in their hearts for the wronged and defrauded hero of 1988, and his poll statistics began to rise. He still can't win, short of a miracle. But if his numbers climb high enough, he will guarantee that Fox can't win, either. And the PRI will triumph once again.
When will Mexico change? This year, the question can be answered with exactitude. Mexico will change when enough people among the opposition democrats, on the right and left, agree to pull together against the PRI. You might imagine that, in our postideological age, a principled alliance of right and left would have been easily enough arranged. In any number of countries around the world during the last dozen years, democratic revolutions have succeeded precisely because of that kind of coalition. In 1990, coalitions of the democratic right and left overthrew the governments of Augusto Pinochet in Chile and the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. It was the same in Eastern Europe in 1989, where some of the anti-Communist dissidents were social democrats and others were free-market Thatcherites.
In Mexico, Fox and Cardenas did entertain the same idea. Their emissaries negotiated, and in the southern state of Chiapas the two parties managed to come up with a single candidate for governor. But no such luck at the national level. It could even be that by the time you read this article, some 11th-hour maneuver might have taken place, and Cardenas or some of his allies might have thrown their support to Fox. But even if some such alliance did take shape, it is impossible to imagine Cardenas and his allies working up any enthusiasm for Fox. So the real decision will have to be made by the voters themselves, with or without their leaders -- by many thousands of ordinary Mexicans who might normally prefer to vote for Cardenas and the left but who will now have to consider voting, in the name of democracy, for Fox, the right-wing cowboy.
One day I visited Cuauhtemoc Cardenas in his campaign headquarters. I told him, in all sincerity, that he was the hero of Mexican democracy, due to his race in 1988 and his dignity afterward. And I asked if he didn't worry that by splitting the opposition, he was going to bring his heroic career to a tragic end. My premise was that Fox's victory would represent an obvious forward step for democracy. But Cardenas didn't agree, for reasons that mirror a crucial ambiguity that you find among a lot of people in the Mexican left. If you ask those people to explain why they hate the PRI, sometimes they will say: because the PRI is corrupt and dictatorial. But other times they will fall into an old-fashioned, left-wing style of thinking, which looks on economics as the foundation of life and on politics as secondary. When they slip into that particular mood, Mexico's leftists are likely to say: we despise the PRI because it is the agent of the rich.
From Cardenas's perspective, the PRI wasn't so bad until the early 1980's, when it began privatizing the old state economy. But from that point of view, Fox's National Action offers very little alternative. National Action is strictly pro-business, and given its druthers, would surely privatize everything in sight. National Action and the PRI disagree on many things, but on macroeconomic issues, their instincts are the same.
Now, you might suppose that after all these years the Mexican left could tell at a glance the difference between a corrupt, authoritarian octopus like the PRI and an ordinary pro-business party like National Action, even if both parties speak the language of market economics. But the Mexican left has modern moods and antique moods, and when antiquity prevails, the left sees no difference at all. That was Cardenas's position. He said about Fox, "I don't think he represents the real and deep change that Mexico needs."
Cardenas had a deeper worry, too -- a gut belief that, even apart from economic policy, Fox is no democrat at all. It is because of his tempestuousness and because of the crafty shifts in his campaign positions. Cardenas worried about National Action and its old-fashioned Catholic prudery and its line on abortion and other sexual questions.
And this gut belief of Cardenas's, as I discovered, was by no means his alone. I visited the new mayor of Mexico City, Rosario Robles Berlanga, who took over City Hall after Cardenas resigned to run for president. Robles is a vigorous woman in her mid-40's, a big talent who has made herself tremendously popular in no time flat -- someone with a real possibility of becoming a presidential contender herself six years from now on a left-wing ticket. She told me that in her judgment Fox is an authoritarian-in-waiting. "There is no difference between him and Fujimori," she said, referring to the Peruvian strongman.
I visited Carmen Boullosa, who is one of Mexico's liveliest literary figures. Fox reminded Boullosa of the macho Catholic authoritarians she knew as a child, against whom she had to rebel -- the kind of figure who has always blocked the door to any kind of modern life. I visited Marta Lamas, Mexico's leading feminist and the editor of "Debate Feminista." Lamas nearly exploded at Fox's name. She saw in him a threat to every forward step that women have taken in Mexico, a threat so large and dangerous that, unlike all the other left-wingers with whom I spoke, she said that six more years of a lamentable PRI dictatorship would suit her better than a wild experiment with Vicente Fox as president.
The whole attitude was expressed in detail by Carlos Monsivais, the cultural critic, in the weekly magazine Proceso and again over coffee and Coke. Monsivais looked on Fox as the worst sort of Catholic reactionary. He had gathered together an alarming collection of quotations to prove it, too: Fox complaining about the useful laws that long ago defined the secular state; Fox criticizing the lay character of public education; Fox saying he wants the schools to teach religious values, meaning Catholic values. Monsivais observed that on matters of abortion, Fox has expressed a hostility even to the extreme cases, like the rape of a child, where Mexican law does permit the procedure. Fox on homosexuality: "A degenerate act which goes against human nature."
Monsivais saw a dangerous messianism in Fox. It bothered him no end that Fox began his campaign by hoisting the banner of the Virgin of Guadalupe, the ancient symbol of Mexico's Catholic extreme right. But then, for all his hair-raising quotations, Monsivais wouldn't go so far as Lamas, the feminist. He looked on Fox as horrible, and on the PRI as even more horrible. It was just that Monsivais couldn't possibly bring himself to vote for the lesser of two horribles. He told me he was going to vote for Cardenas and hope for the best.
That sort of reaction has not gone unnoticed among Fox's advisers. And so, in the latter days of the campaign, Fox set out to undo some of his more disastrous gestures to the extreme right. The banner of the Virgin of Guadalupe was quietly put away. In one of his television debates, Fox poured words of praise on the Mexican left for its historic role in opposing the PRI. He praised the student uprising of 1968. He praised Cardenas himself for his battles on behalf of democracy.
It is true that in trying to soothe the ruffled left, Fox also managed now and then to hurl a few unforgivable personal insults. I watched him stand up in Veracruz and call Cardenas a traitor to his own party for refusing to withdraw from the race. He insulted Cardenas's mother. A bad move! Still, he calmed down and resumed his courtship, with an occasional success. A group of some 30 left-wingers announced that they were endorsing Fox in spite of their philosophical differences. Those were serious radicals -- people from the defunct Mexican Communist Party and from the '68 student rebellion. They held a meeting in Mexico City, and Fox stood on the podium and pushed his courtship even further. In a sober tone, as if swearing an oath to the entire public, he promised not to do any of the scary things, point by point, that he had been accused of wanting to do.
"I commit myself to maintain the lay character of the Mexican state and public education," he said. "I commit myself to maintain the liberty, diversity and pluralism of Mexican society and never to use the power of the state to impose lifestyles, religious beliefs or codes of personal behavior. To respect the liberty of creation, of culture and of expression of all the groups who form Mexican society."
He promised to limit the power of the presidency, which, under the PRI, has been almost monarchical. He promised to make the struggle against poverty and inequality the "supreme priority" of his new government. And he absolutely promised not to do what, in the past, he has always been itching to do, which is to privatize Mexico's state oil company, Pemex.
It was everything he could possibly do to placate the left, short of cutting off a hand. But the response among a good many left-wingers was, I must say, to recoil from Fox even more violently than before -- as if he had now revealed himself to be not just a dangerous reactionary but a dangerous liar too, a man without any principles whatsoever, not even reactionary principles.
It should be added that Fox's enemies on the left have not been the only people to glance in his direction and worry. Enrique Krauze is Mexico's leading historian and one of its most eloquent defenders of liberal democratic ideas, and in May he published his own estimation of Fox. It was a balanced appraisal, not entirely condemning Fox but fretting about his political background. Krauze reminded his readers that during the 1920's, thousands of peasants in central Mexico rebelled against the anticlerical wing of Mexico's Revolution and in the name of Christ the King went to war. They were known as the Cristeros, from the Spanish for Christ. The war was a calamity.
Fox, as Krauze saw him, comes out of the fiercest of the Cristero districts and has always nursed a vivid and slightly alarming nostalgia for Cristero values. Then, too, Krauze observed that Fox went to visit Fidel Castro not long ago and came away full of praise. That was not exactly a right-wing thing to do. Krauze found it worrisome, though.
There is, of course, one other group that has been steadily tossing its own criticisms at Fox. An internal dossier of Francisco Labastida's PRI campaign has fallen into my hands -- a book-length analysis of Fox, part of which appears to have been written by a psychologist, in the grimmest of terms: "An obsessive character, possibly associated with messianic delirium," not to mention misogyny and authoritarianism. And, sure enough, no sooner did I leaf through the PRI dossier than I began to notice attacks of that nature on Fox's character appearing in the press. It was even suggested, somewhat indirectly, that Fox is not only a madman but also a fascist.
Labastida spoke at a PRI rally in Jalisco. "Long live liberty and long live tolerance!" cried the candidate of the world's oldest ruling party. "Let's not let reaction, intolerance and fascism spread!"
So is Vicente Fox the hope for Mexican democracy? or, if you will pardon the pun, is Fox a wolf in sheep's clothing? I cannot peer into his head to identify his actual intentions. But I have been able to observe him and chat with him on a number of occasions. And I can offer an impression. His personal values on questions of abortion, homosexuality and the importance of religious education came to him from his Jesuit upbringing, in the conservative environment that Krauze has described. Those ideas are not going to change.
Even now he collects books on Cristero themes. But business became his passion. When he changed course in life and became a politician for National Action, he had no difficulty in squaring his antique Catholic sentiments with his modern business ideas. National Action has always had its Catholic nostalgias. The party was organized in 1939 to fight against the leftward tilt of the Mexican Revolution, and its early sympathies veered toward Generalissimo Franco in Spain. Franco's Falange wore blue shirts and so did Mexico's National Action. Still, the old fascists in Spain have mostly evolved into democratic conservatives. And in Mexico, National Action, which was never entirely fascist, likewise evolved -- from the party of Christ the King to the Catholic party of business and democracy.
Fox himself shows the evolution. as soon as he opens his mouth, it becomes obvious that he despises the PRI -- despises it with a quick, hot passion that endears him to ordinary people. He remembers the PRI's murders, massacres and corruption. But mostly he hates the PRI because it has run Mexico's economy badly. He is an outraged businessman. And then, having evolved into a businessman-politician, he adopted one more set of ideas, which you don't find anywhere else in National Action.
This last set of inspirations came to him from an unhappy experience in his first, unsuccessful race for the governorship of Guanajuato state, back in 1991. The PRI converted that particular election into an obvious fraud. Fox mounted a furious protest. And he found himself standing shoulder to shoulder with a number of activists from the left, Cardenas's supporters, who were campaigning for a modern electoral system. One of those people was Jorge G. Castaneda, a political writer who is well known in the United States as a commentator on Mexican affairs and as a professor at New York University.
In 1991, Castaneda was an ambitious young man from an elite but slightly peculiar background. His father had been foreign minister for the PRI. He himself had spent a few years in the Mexican Communist Party. By the time he met Fox, though, the young Castaneda had given up on Communism and was hard at work trying to rethink the whole concept of leftism and its goals. His research led him to still another Latin American professor in the United States, Roberto Mangabeira Unger, a Brazilian who teaches at Harvard.
Mangabeira Unger had soured on the traditional left-wing dream of a giant social-welfare state. He wanted Latin America's left-wing movements to build smaller and more efficient states that would use market methods to improve the condition of the poor -- to harness higher taxes to the methods of the pro-business right, in order to achieve the egalitarian goals of the left. Mangabeira Unger was a Latin American theorist of what only later has come to be known as the Third Way.
Castaneda picked up on those ideas, and he and Fox began to talk. Castaneda introduced Fox to Mangabeira Unger. And Fox became entranced with the notion of using his Coca-Cola skills to do what the PRI in recent decades has never been able to do: achieve something lasting for the poor.
Those are the ideas that seem to fire up Fox's imagination. When I spoke with him two years ago, he nattered on about economics, market programs to help the poor, democracy and corruption. Riding around with him on the campaign bus in the last weeks of his campaign, I must have watched Fox deliver a dozen speeches to audiences of every kind, and those speeches, too, hit the same notes. Sometimes he stressed the importance of labor unions -- real unions, run by their own members, instead of the state unions that are run by the PRI.
Late one night on the bus, when everyone seemed to be nodding off except the driver and the candidate, I took the seat next to him at the front of the bus and asked him about Fidel Castro. Fox told me that he genuinely admired Castro's achievements in public education, in creating "human capital." But what most caught Fox's imagination in Cuba seemed to be how beautifully Castro has restored a portion of downtown Havana. "That kind of thing is valuable for tourism," he explained, as if everything ought to have its business justification. He reflected on Mexico City and its failure to capitalize on the tourist potential.
The bus was hurtling through darkness, with no cars on the highway and no houses on the side. We pulled up at a toll booth, and Fox interrupted our chat to lean out the window and flash his V sign at the astonished toll collectors and win two more votes.
Then he wanted to talk about an interesting system for spreading financial credit to the very poor that he has seen in Bangladesh. He is a big fan of what he calls "microenterprises," the tiny businesses of the poor. And he veered into a discussion of the international business of freelance political consultants -- people like Dick Morris, who struck Fox as rather creative, and James Carville, who struck him as less creative (and who has gone to work for the PRI). But can foreign consultants make any sense of Mexican politics? "I don't think they have a nose for Mexico," he said. Fox hired his own consultant from the ranks of Mexico's Coca-Cola. And such was the conversation: business, politics, business and more business.
In my hearing, he never did harp on what, in the United States, are called "family values" or "Christian values." Those were simply not his campaign themes. Still, I did hear him let rip more than once with a slogan from the Cristero fanatics of the 1920's. He said: "If I advance, follow me! If I hold back, push me! If I retreat, kill me!" Which does sound a little extreme. And there you have the problem with Vicente Fox. He dreams a businessman's vision of a modern Mexico. But now and then, when the moon comes out, he reverts to his old nostalgias. He can't help himself.
Most of the people who line up to hear him speak aren't thinking about religious questions or about sexual and cultural controversies. They want him to lambaste the PRI and to lay out his business ideas, which sound so much more inventive and impassioned than anyone else's. But there are any number of historical-minded people whose ears twitch at the sound of those ancient Cristero slogans and who begin to reflect that Fox's National Action does contain a number of genuine fanatics of the old-fashioned Catholic right. Which is true; I've met them.
And so the worries begin. Fox has only himself to blame. But it must be said that in Mexico's left-wing opposition, he and his National Action have met their counterpart. For the Mexican left is likewise a mix of modern ideas and old-fashioned prejudices. And under the pressure of a desperately close election, Mexico's right-wing party and its left-wing party have, between them, ended up refighting the Cristero War of the 1920's, or perhaps the Spanish Civil War of the 1930's -- the eternal battle of class-struggle left-wingers against the warriors of Christ the King. And they have managed to forget that the largest and most intractable of Mexico's problems today don't come from Catholic fanatics or from anti-Catholic fanatics but from a corrupt authoritarianism whose end could be easily arranged -- if only the right and the left would stop their quarreling.
What Mexico needs, you might suppose, are some lucid intellectuals, capable of dragging their own political movements into modern times. All over the world in the last dozen years, when authoritarian governments have been overthrown, the intellectuals have been in the forefront, and a few of them have even become political leaders. Vaclav Havel, the Czech hipster, is the supreme example. But Mexico is not like other countries. Mexico's intellectuals can boast of one of the world's most brilliant literary cultures, and they bask in prestige and wield influence and have always received handsome subsidies, in one form or another, from the state, which means, the PRI. The subsidies have not exactly made them slaves either.
On the contrary, most of Mexico's intellectuals vociferously oppose the PRI. But the greatest number of them do so by supporting C1/3rdenas, even if he can't win. Some of them support an utterly marginal left-wing politician named Gilberto Rincon Gallardo, whose poll statistics hover around 2 percent. And only a handful have supported Fox -- joined in the last days of the campaign by a reluctant and slightly larger number. It is an amazing situation, given how much hangs on this election. But the most striking phenomenon in this campaign has been an outpouring of articles and op-eds supporting democracy in general -- essays so watery and indistinct that you could easily conclude that democracy must be already well established and that the PRI must be no less democratic than any other political organization and that it hardly matters whom you vote for, so long as you vote.
Carlos Fuentes is the most prestigious of the literary intellectuals, and he has made himself a master of such watery endorsements. "Vote for yourself," he wrote. And so Mexico teeters on the edge of an enormous decision -- teeters on the brink of achieving, through peaceful and legal means, a democratic transition of power in the world's largest Spanish-speaking country. And because Fox is an outsider among the intellectuals and because Fox's background has some worrisome aspects, the overwhelming majority of intellectuals have found all kinds of rhetorically elaborate ways to remain safely on the sidelines.
When will Mexico change? What can surely be predicted is that in today's election Mexico will undergo either a larger tragedy or a smaller tragedy. The larger tragedy will come about if the Mexicans simply cannot figure out how to escape the only political party they have ever known. The smaller tragedy will come about if, in spite of every obstacle, Vicente Fox does succeed in defeating the PRI. Fox will move into Los Pinos. And he will discover that bringing democracy to Mexico is going to be harder than it ought to be, if only because he and the rest of Mexico's democrats are still caught up in ancient myths and feuds, and people who should be his allies aren't.
