SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Hurdles that online grocery shopping must jump range from the logistical to the generational.

BYLINE: By Constance L. Hays

 BODY:
LAST week, two big names in the online grocery business announced they were merging, with Webvan agreeing to pay $1.2 billion for HomeGrocer.com. Online grocers seem to be coming quickly to the realization that there is strength through scale, but significant kinks in the business continue to present big challenges to its long-term viability.
Online grocery shopping beckons like an electronic Statue of Liberty to the tired, the time-pressed and the hunkered masses who consider going to the grocery an odious task. Why drive all the way to the supermarket to tangle with a shopping cart and risk getting the one with the sticky wheel when you can sit quietly at your computer and click through your choices at your convenience? 
 The converted sing the praises of online grocery shopping, calling it convenient, reliable and, yes, no more expensive than conventional supermarket shopping. "It probably ends up being more cost-effective because you don't pick up the things you don't need," said Robin Bonenfant of Norwalk, Conn., who recently began using Peapod, the Chicago online grocery pioneer that will have its 10th birthday on Wednesday. "They take coupons as well."
Armando Quintero, a father of two who stays home with his children in San Rafael, Calif., said ordering from Webvan had simplified his life in some ways. "They can deliver very early in the morning, so if we need lunch items for our kids, we could get them delivered before school," he said.
Sometimes, he said, he and his wife, who is at work at an office all day, "interact online" -- going over their electronic shopping list and adding or deleting items from their separate computers.
Despite the fans, only about 2.8 percent of Americans buy their groceries online, according to estimates by Evie Black Dykema, a senior analyst with Forrester Research. Among the drawbacks people typically cite are having to plan and having to think about the delivery schedule.
"You have to be organized and thinking ahead," said Tracy Petrak, a legal secretary from San Rafael who orders occasionally from Webvan. At one point, she was surprised to receive a large postcard from the company, observing that she had not ordered in a while and asking, "What did we do wrong?" Webvan also sent her a $25 coupon to use on her next order, she said.
Some people just do not want to give up the social opportunities or the nostalgia they associate with grocery shopping. It ties in with memories of their parents, sometimes, or contributes to a sense of community.
"People feel guilt about shopping online," Ms. Dykema said. "Anecdotally, there is this feeling that it's a little artificial to have their groceries sent to them. It's similar to when Procter & Gamble introduced cake mixes, and they found that women wanted to add their own egg. That way, it was their own cake."
To get people to buy groceries online, companies are using a variety of models. Peapod, which appeared on the edge of extinction just three months ago when its chief executive quit suddenly and a financing deal fell apart, has now aligned itself with a traditional supermarket giant, Royal Ahold. In Fairfield County, Conn., where Mrs. Bonenfant points and clicks, Peapod used Ahold's Stop & Shop stores to fill produce orders, while turning to a Peapod warehouse for other items.
So thorough is the alignment that Royal Ahold owns 51 percent of Peapod, and a former Ahold executive, Marc van Gelder, is running Peapod. Mr. van Gelder seems convinced that Peapod's new model will work. "This is a leverage of the Stop & Shop chain, which stands for good value and good quality," he said. "And we are also leveraging, from a procurement perspective, all the advantages you get from being linked to a $26 billion company. It is a great competitive weapon."
Stop & Shop stores are also being used to promote Peapod, and the two companies are running joint advertisements. "We do advertising in local newspapers as well as public relations and door hangings," Mr. van Gelder said. "What we want to get to is to really personalize e-mail for customers. We will be able to communicate with our customers on a personalized basis."
By hooking electronic shopping so thoroughly to an old-style chain, Peapod is following the example of many European online grocers, which in many cases were started by the traditional retailers. J. Sainsbury and Tesco in Britain and Carrefour and Promodes in France, some of the biggest chains in Europe, all have online services they promote through their stores, said Jacob Jensen, a consultant with Roland Berger Associates, a consumer-products consulting firm in New York, who has studied e-grocers in Europe and in the United States.
But does the model really work? Online grocery companies are typically plagued by two issues: making sure their orders are packed and delivered properly and keeping their costs down -- something that is particularly difficult when a fleet of trucks or vans is involved.
Mr. Jensen said creating a large warehouse, along the lines of Amazon.com, was the only way to meet the first goal effectively. The cost issue is best addressed, he said, by keeping geographic markets closely circumscribed.
"From a cost perspective and from a fulfillment basis, the dedicated warehouse is the best model," he said. "What really upsets the consumers is if you don't deliver the products they ordered, or if you don't hit the window you promised for delivery. And in terms of managing delivery costs, it means the route density has to be mapped out ahead of time."
One French online grocer, Tele-Market, has tried to solve the distribution issue by subcontracting its delivery service. "They have independent couriers driving around with their products, and they take other companies' products along as well," Mr. Jensen said.
Generally, the more deliveries in a given area, the lower the costs over all. But except for a few cities, Americans who can afford computers and Internet access are more likely to live in suburbs, if not exurbs, which means more driving for any company that offers delivery.
When it comes to building critical mass for online shopping, timing may turn out to be everything.
"The next wave is when these 18- to 20-year-olds start replenishing their own households," Ms. Dykema said, noting how that age group already goes online to do much of its shopping, from cars to electronics to groceries. "They can't imagine why consumers wouldn't look online first for products. They don't suffer from any of these hang-ups."

PUB-DATE: July 3, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1443 words

HEADLINE: London Buyers Ignore Auction Inquiry

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 2

 BODY:
As collectors and dealers gathered here last week for Christie's and Sotheby's big sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art, the auction houses' legal troubles in the United States seemed to make no difference to the buyers. Still, it was clear that the shadow cast by the federal antitrust investigation in New York had crossed the Atlantic. At the same moment on Tuesday night that Sotheby's was holding its important sale of Impressionist and modern art at its Bond Street headquarters here, Christie's was conducting its auction of contemporary art just a few blocks away on King Street.
Such scheduling conflicts never happened in the past when the two companies met openly to plan the year's auctions. But with prosecutors investigating whether the auction houses fixed prices and questioning every move they make, it was obvious that a message was being not so subtly delivered, even at this distance. 
 "We can't talk to each other at all anymore," said one top auction house official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other than that, no one in charge offered any explanation.
As the auctions here progressed, the strong economy gave collectors confidence about the art market, making last week's sales successful for both Sotheby's and Christie's. Prices were consistently high, especially for the rarest, most expensive works. If these sales are any reflection of today's tastes, then Impressionist paintings, sculpture and photography are especially popular. But while prices were strong, few bidders went wild.
"It's an intelligent market," said Franck Giraud, head of Christie's 19th- and 20th-century art departments worldwide. "Nobody got carried away, but at the same time they didn't let the best things go for low prices. There were no bargains."
Melanie Clore, a deputy chairman of Sotheby's who runs its Impressionist and modern art department here, defined the market as healthy and controlled. The biggest difference between today and the 1980's boom, she said, is that people now are more discriminating. "They aren't in a rush. They don't need to buy mediocre material, and there's no absolutely speculative buying."
The best works sold for prices consistent with the boom years of the late 1980's. At Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art, for instance, Degas's "Young Dancer at 14," a 1922 posthumous cast of a dancer with a cream-colored silk bodice and a tulle-and-gauze tutu, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $11.5 million, above its $10.9 million low estimate.
This was the fourth time a 1922 cast of this statue had sold at auction in 12 years. In 1988, at the height of the market, one was included in a sale of art from the estate of William Mayer Goetz, a founder of 20th Century Fox, and his wife, Edith, at Christie's in New York, where it sold to Prince Jefri Bolkiah, the brother of the Sultan of Brunei, for $10.1 million. In 1996 Sotheby's sold another such Degas in New York on behalf of the Shelburne Museum in Vermont for $11.9 million. And in November, Prince Jefri sold his at Sotheby's in New York for $12.3 million.
Some prices last week exceeded those in the late 80's boom. Monet's "Beach at Trouville," a sun-dappled seascape, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder at Sotheby's on Tuesday night for $16.4 million, well above its $15 million high estimate. The painting had fetched $10.7 million at the Goetz sale at Christie's in New York 12 years ago.
A 1942 Matisse, "Dancer in an Armchair With a Checkered Floor," that was expected to bring $3.9 million to $5.4 million at Sotheby's, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $7.4 million. Four people wanted the painting, which shows Carla Avogadro, a dancer who was a friend of the artist, posing in a bright yellow chair against a background of black and white checks. The buyer bid through David Norman, head of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department in New York.
(Final prices include the auction house's commissions: for Sotheby's it is 20 percent of the first $15,000, 15 percent of the next $85,000 and 10 percent of any amount over $100,000. Christie's charges 17.5 percent of the first $80,000 plus 10 percent of any amount above that. Estimates at both auction houses do not reflect commissions.)
This season Christie's combined its Impressionist and Post-Impressionist auction with its sale of 20th-century art in one evening, and both areas of the market were strong. Its star painting was Cezanne's "Still Life With Fruits and a Ginger Pot" from 1895. It was exhibited in the artist's first retrospective in Paris the year it was painted and later belonged to two famous dealers, Ambroise Vollard and Bruno Cassirer.
"For Cezanne, who was never satisfied with a painting, this was unusually finished and resolved," Mr. Giraud said. Two determined bidders vied for the painting, which ended up selling to William Acquavella, the Manhattan dealer, for $18.1 million, just at its high estimate.
Three bidders at Christie's were willing to spend upward of $6 million for Monet's 1894 "Spring Landscape (Giverny)," which sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $6.6 million, just above its low estimate of $6 million. A later, more abstract Monet, "The Japanese Bridge," painted between 1918 and 1924, was mightily fought over by two determined telephone bidders. It finally sold to an unidentified bidder for $4.3 million, above its high estimate of $2.2 million.
One rare and much sought-after painting, a brightly colored Fauve portrait of the artist Jean Metzinger painted by Robert Delaunay in 1906, sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $2.9 million, far above its $2.1 million high estimate. Delaunay, who was better-known as an abstract painter, did few Fauve paintings. Metzinger is posed at an angle with a cigarette hanging out of his mouth, and in the background is a Japanese print, reminiscent of the famous van Gogh portrait "Le Pere Tanguy.
"When you think of Fauve artists you think of Matisse, Braque, Derain and Vlamink; you don't think of Delaunay," Mr. Giraud said. "So for a collector of Fauve works, this was a great find."
At both Sotheby's and Christie's sculptures tended to be popular, as they have for the last year. Works by Rodin, Giacometti and Picasso all brought prices far above their high estimates. One reason was that as the prices of paintings have steadily risen in recent years, sculptures by artists like Matisse, Picasso and Degas have seemed cheap by comparison.
Among contemporary collectors the same can be said for photographs. Artists like Cindy Sherman, Nan Goldin, Gilbert and George, and Thomas Struth were fought over by a crowd of young, international collectors who were willing to pay any price to take home famous images. Never mind that these photographs are printed in multiples.
"In this media-saturated world, young collectors were raised on images," said Tobias Meyer, head of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide. "They are not concerned with things being unique, they want to know that they have something that is exactly the same as a photograph hanging in the Museum of Modern Art."
This group of buyers, Mr. Meyer added, tend to come from the film industry. "They are completely uninterested in abstract painting. It's a midcentury struggle they have no connection to."
Contemporary art in general continued to command high prices, as it did at the big auctions in New York in May. At Christie's sale of 20th-century art, Bacon's "Study for a Portrait (Man Screaming)" from 1952 sold for $4.4 million, far above its $2.7 million high estimate. A Jeff Koons, "Large Vase of Flowers," a 1991 polychrome wood bouquet of 140 spring flowers that stands 4 feet 3 inches high and was estimated to sell for $380,000 to $520,000, fetched $994,961. The buyer was identified only as a European collector.
At Sotheby's a photorealist painting by Gerhard Richter of a view of Corsica with a sailboat in the distance was bought by another unidentified collector for $1.3 million, twice its high $670,00 estimate. Two people fought to take home a late de Kooning, "Untitled XVII," from 1982, an abstraction of bright blues and reds on a white background. It sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $1.9 million, more than twice its high $900,000 estimate.
Experts at both Sotheby's and Christie's noticed an increase in European buyers this season. No longer were the Top 10 works in each sale bought by Americans.
"The presence of Europeans was a significant change," Mr. Meyer said. "This is a market fueled by new buyers and new money. It's the economy that drives it."

HEADLINE: Magazines Combat Proposed Increase in Postal Rates

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
When magazine publishers and chief executives of media companies discuss the latest problem facing the magazine industry, they use words like "passion," "devastation" and "death."
Executives who usually favor brevity will spend an hour in conversation detailing the potential "horror" of the crisis. The feared trauma is such that magazine publishers have been cruising the halls of Congress for the last five months, spending millions of dollars lobbying for relief. 
 It is not a grand theme like freedom of speech or censorship that is kicking up all the emotion. The panic involves a rate increase the United States Postal Service has proposed to take effect next year, that would raise the cost of mailing subscription copies of magazines by 15 percent.
Estimating that the rate increase will cost their industry $300 million in the next two years, magazine publishers are going -- well -- postal.
"This could be potentially devastating for many magazines," said Nina B. Link, the president of the Magazine Publishers of America.
The Magazine Publishers of America plan to spend $10 million this year lobbying Congress on the issue, while companies like Time Warner, the parent company of Time Inc., have put their own lobbyists to work on the case as well.
The Magazine Publishers, a trade group to which more than 1,020 of the largest consumer magazines belong, has placed ads in trade journals stating that the proposed increase is twice the average increase the Postal Service usually proposes, is three times the rate of inflation and is double what the Postal Service actually needs to cover the projected costs of processing magazines.
But economists for the Postal Service say that while the service is willing to negotiate the proposed increase, it is not only necessary -- it is mandated by federal law. The Postal Reform Act of 1970 mandates that every class of mail must cover its own mailing costs.
This latest rate-increase proposal comes at a tense time for the industry: newsstand sales are sinking, subscriptions are down for many consumer magazines, and several smaller but high-profile magazines have closed this year.
And some publishers still remember the last time such a large postal increase went into effect for the magazine industry -- in the early 1970's, when the added financial burden contributed to the demise of even some venerable publications like the old weekly Life.
"Small magazines are the ones that will be most devastated because they have smaller margins," Ms. Link said. "This will hurt them the most. And it will be hard for other magazines with larger circulations that don't have much wiggle room."
Ms. Link has spent a substantial part of the last five months on Capitol Hill, pleading with members of the House and the Senate to encourage the Postal Service to turn back the rate hike. She has encouraged both Democrats and Republicans to unite in asking William J. Henderson, the Postmaster General, to reconsider the increase.
And Ms. Link has been joined by some of the most powerful figures in magazine publishing: Cathleen P. Black, the president of Hearst Magazines; Christopher M. Little, the president of the Meredith Publishing Group, and Daniel B. Brewster, the former chief executive of American Express Publishing who is now the chief executive of Gruner + Jahr magazines. She has hit Capitol Hill with as many as 10 magazine publishers in tow.
"We have been trying to educate anyone and everyone as to why this is so unfair and unjust and unreasonable," Ms. Link said.
The proposed rate increase applies to consumer magazines that are mailed under the bulk classification of "periodicals." Rate increases for other categories, such as first-class mail, are in the single digits. Greg Frey, a spokesman for the Postal Service, said that the last increase -- only 4.6 percent -- was proposed two years ago and went into effect in January 1999. Ms. Link said because that increase was so much smaller, the decision met less criticism from the magazine industry.
Mr. Little of Meredith said that every Meredith title would be affected by the proposed rate increase, the news of which he described as "a bombshell."
"Every copy of Better Homes & Gardens will be affected," he said, referring to a Meredith title. "And at Hearst every copy of Good Housekeeping will be affected, and at Conde Nast, every copy of Vogue."
The proposed rate increase has also made strange bedfellows; two of the most concerned crusaders against the increase are The National Geographic Society and Playboy magazine. Both magazines depend on subscriptions for much of their circulation.
Of The Geographic's 8.5 million circulation, 8.2 million copies are sent by subscription. Playboy's subscribers number 2.6 million out of a total circulation of 3.1 million.
Robert Sims, senior vice president for magazine publishing at the National Geographic Society, said that it costs the society 24 cents to send a subscription issue out: the proposed increase could raise that to about 27.6 cents an issue. Do the math: at 3.6 extra cents an issue each month for 8.2 million issues, that is an increase of $295,200 a month in expenses for the society.
"It doesn't sound like much at first," he said. "But when you when you add up the costs of print, editorial, and other distribution costs, well, pretty soon you don't have any money left." He described the rate increase as "potentially devastating for us."
Gail Day, a senior vice president at Playboy Enterprises and the publisher of Playboy, said, "If this goes through, we will have to look to other lines of our business to fund that."
Ashley Lyons, an economist and the manager of pricing for the Postal Service, acknowledged that the proposed increase was a substantial one.
"What we are saying is that the costs of handling magazines will go up by roughly 12.8 percent over the next three years," he said, adding that the Postal Service was actively investigating ways to reduce the increase. The Postmaster General testified before the House's Postal Appropriations Subcommittee that he would take steps to achieve $150 million in savings that would apply to magazine handling.
Mr. Frey of the Postal Service said that the service was not singling out any industry and was making every effort to include cost-cutting measures proposed by the publishers.
"The various classes of mail must support themselves and we cannot cross-subsidize," he said. "And that is mandated by law. For them to feel singled out or to imply that there is a conspiracy against some of our best customers is ridiculous." Mr. Frey said that additional increases in postage would be likely this year because of the recent spike in gas prices.
But even the Postal Service's avowal to try to curb the increase does not placate publishers like Mr. Little, who criticized the Postal Service as poorly managed. He said the Postmaster General had disregarded the Magazine Publishers of America's recommendations over the last two years to keep the increase in the single digits.
"When we first heard of this 15 percent hike, we came in and said, 'Now wait a minute,' " Mr. Little said. " 'We have been working with you for two years and we have been promised that the rate increase would not be anything in the double digits, and then you present us with a 15 percent rate increase.' That to us is just unacceptable."
If the magazine industry and the Postal Service cannot reconcile their differences, the magazine industry may be left with little recourse. Ms. Link said that publishers had begun to explore other options, such as shipping magazines via non-government means like United Parcel Service, DHL and Federal Express.
Mr. Sims of The National Geographic said that the National Geographic Society had broached the idea of negotiating a contract rate with the Postal Service, such as the Society does with foreign postal services like England's Royal Mail. But he said the United States Postal Service will not negotiate individual corporate contracts.
On June 12, Representative Chaka Fattah, a Democrat from Maryland, introduced a bill in Congress that would reduce the rate increase. Congress and the Senate have until November to approve the new rate.
"Did you ever think you'd hear so much passion about postage rates?" Ms. Link asked. "It's ridiculous. I dream about it at night."

Two More Points in Privacy Debate

Consumer groups demanded that online advertising companies give consumers more notice when tracking their behavior and give them the choice to avoid such tracking. HEADLINE: A Race to Save Roman Splendors From Drowning

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: BELKIS, Turkey, June 27

 BODY:
As waters rise inexorably over the ruins of an ancient Roman town here, an international team of archaeologists has sprung into action to save whatever can be rescued in the next three months.
Buoyed by a $5 million grant from an American foundation, the team hopes to dig up mosaics and artifacts, and to create a historical park and resort. 
 A new lake is being formed as water from the Euphrates River backs up behind a new dam. Turkey is in the midst of a huge dam-building project that is to provide electric power for the country's booming economy and irrigation for parched farmland in southeastern provinces.
The ruins here are those of Zeugma, an important Roman garrison town on the ancient Silk Road. Trade made many of its merchants wealthy, and they decorated the floors of their villas with elaborate mosaics.
Experts say there may be hundreds of exquisite mosaics under the dusty hills, along with a rich trove of other artifacts.
Although archaeologists have been working here sporadically for more than 20 years, they began intensive work only recently after realizing that the inundation was imminent. It quickly became clear that Zeugma was a far more bountiful site than most specialists had realized, but by then it was too late to stop the flooding.
Belkis, the town that once stood below the Zeugma site, has already disappeared under the new lake. A new Belkis is being built on a nearby hillside, but many residents are embittered by what they say is the government's indifference to their plight.
News accounts of the flooding of Zeugma have appeared in many countries. Hardly a day goes by without a foreign journalist or television team appearing here.
In Gaziantep, the nearest city, more than 1,000 tourists have arrived in the last few weeks, according to hotel managers, restaurateurs and taxi drivers. Before the wave of publicity, they said, it was a rare month when even a dozen tourists came.
Some Turkish archaeologists and government officials seem uncomfortable with the clamor from abroad, apparently viewing it as a form of interference that borders on insult. Directors of the Gaziantep archaeology museum, where artifacts dug up at Zeugma are piled high, scorned an American philanthropist, Shawn Estes, who appeared here two weeks ago and offered the museum a gift of $20,000. They also refused to allow him to work as a volunteer at the site, and when he addressed the local Rotary Club he was accused of harboring a secret plan to steal mosaics.
"I suggested that he ask permission from the Directorate of Museums in Ankara if he wanted to work or donate money," said Kemal Sertok, who is coordinating work at the site. "In Turkey we only employ staff archaeologists."
The authorities have, however, accepted a $5 million grant from a California-based foundation, the Packard Humanities Institute. Louise Schofield, who represents the foundation here, said it might donate more money in the future.
"Our work is going to be in three phases," she said. "First is the rescue excavation of the area that will be covered by water after Oct. 4. Then there will be a very large conservation program in cooperation with the Turkish team. And then, in the long term, there is a plan to turn this site into a major archaeological park."
With at least 10 more dams scheduled to be built in southeastern Turkey in the coming decades, conflict between advocates of economic development and historical preservation may grow.
The next focus of this conflict is likely to be Hasankeyf, a historical town 260 miles east of here that is to be inundated in a few years.
A British company has won the contract to build the dam at Hasankeyf, but opponents are waging a vocal campaign in Britain. When they invited the mayor of Hasankeyf to attend one of their protest rallies in London, the Turkish authorities advised him not to go, and he canceled his trip.
"We're hoping to defuse this sense of confrontation," said Richard Hodges, a British archaeologist who is helping to direct the Zeugma excavation. "I'm interested in preserving culture, but I also like to drink water and use electricity. If we can make this project work, it can be a model for Turkey's future."
But some Turkish preservationists reject the idea of such compromises. "The appropriate lessons should be drawn from this and newly planned dam projects should be halted," said Asket Tibet, general secretary of the Archaeologists' Association.
That call was echoed by the general secretary of the History Association, Orhan Silier. "The world's leading historians are trying to reinterpret history by using findings from these regions," Mr. Silier said. "Yet we leave them under water."
It is still unclear, and may be for years, how much of Zeugma is being lost. Some specialists believe it may be less than 10 percent. Others say there is no way of being sure, since an unknown portion of the city is already under water and no one is certain how much remains buried beneath the adjacent hills.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Shades of Gloom and Gleams of Confidence With Miles to Go

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
He may be Al Gore's most ardent booster, but President Clinton sounded rather tentative this week when he was asked about the vice president's prospects in November. "It's still more likely than not that he will win," Mr. Clinton said.
It is no secret that even with 130 days to go before the election, Democrats are unsettled, even gloomy, while Republicans are confident. Could the presidential race be over barely after it started? 
 Once again this week, it seemed that Al Gore could not catch a break: One national poll even had him 13 points behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. Gore found himself again confronted by questions over whether the Justice Department would investigate his fund-raising practices. And Ralph Nader was elected the nominee of the Green Party, leaving Democrats to fret that he would steal votes from Mr. Gore's base. All this occurred within days after Mr. Gore named a new campaign chairman.
But even Bush loyalists concede that Democrats should not despair -- at least not yet.
No one should underestimate Mr. Gore's potential political potency: Voters may, in the end, give him credit for helping preside over the longest economic expansion in the nation's history. He is a disciplined, if lackluster, campaigner who is known for performing best in adversity. He displayed that ability when he toppled former Senator Bill Bradley in the primaries. Now, he plans to zero in on Mr. Bush's support of a rather unpopular but enormous tax cut, as well as the governor's stands on Social Security and Medicare.
Another advantage for Mr. Gore is that no one questions his competence to make decisions and to grasp issues -- and to understand how to navigate the often befuddling world of government and politics in Washington. If voters find they are not sufficiently confident of Mr. Bush's preparedness for the Oval Office -- or his heft on the issues -- they could turn to Mr. Gore by default.
There is truth to the spin from the Gore camp that the public has yet to focus on the presidential race. In an ABC News/Washington Post poll conducted in mid-June, only 13 percent of expected voters said they were following the race very closely.
The reality is that many voters may be waiting for the conventions or the fall debates to learn more about the contenders and settle on a choice. That could be a plus for Mr. Gore, who has far more extensive experience as a debater and is steeped much more deeply in national and international issues. (One danger is that the high expectations for Mr. Gore in debates could work against him if Mr. Bush performs unexpectedly -- and reassuringly -- well.)
One of Mr. Gore's biggest problems is, simply, that voters seem to like Mr. Bush more and think the vice president is too politically calculating and relentlessly ambitious. But Gore aides said they hoped to turn that into a virtue by convincing voters that as president he would channel that determination and energy into his policy agenda.
Another often neglected reality is that the race may be closer than it now looks. Despite Mr. Gore's troubles in winning over loyal Democrats, in the end the likelihood is that most Democrats will side with him and most Republicans will side with Mr. Bush, leaving the contest to turn on a relatively narrow swath of swing and independent voters.
Rather than dwell on current polls, Democrats can take heart that in three of the last five presidential elections, the candidate behind in the polls at this point won in November: Ronald Reagan in 1980, George Bush in 1988 and Bill Clinton in 1992.
It could be, of course, that Mr. Gore will never climb out of his rut in the polls and that the electorate has settled early on Mr. Bush. As one top Gore aide put it, voters "might decide that they like the other guy better and that's that."
In an interview on a flight from Cleveland to Austin, Tex., on Wednesday, Mr. Bush was careful not to be overconfident -- or to raise expectations for himself.
"He's a sitting vice president with an economy that seems like it's doing pretty well," Mr. Bush said. "He's going to be very difficult to beat. I am not the favorite. Nor is he. I think it's going to be a very close race. I do."
The governor went on to advise: "I wouldn't be putting your money anywhere right now. I'd be calling it too close to call. But I'm going to nip him in the end."
Maybe so. But some Republicans are not so sure.
"The polls that show Bush ahead are extremely soft and misleading," said Mike Murphy, who was a top strategist for the primary campaign of Senator John McCain. Referring to Medicare and Social Security, he said, "Gore has a muddy bag full of ugly wedge issues and he knows how to use them. It's very possible that this race will snap back to near even after the conventions."
Indeed, it could be that the dynamics of the national nominating conventions this summer and the televised debates in the fall, not to say tens of millions of dollars in commercials, could change everything.
"The seminal events of this campaign have yet to occur," said Carter Eskew, one of Mr. Gore's closest advisers. "There's been a lot of early auditioning, but the race has not been engaged. We continue to believe that this race is ultimately going to be over stewardship of the economy and stewardship of the prosperity."
For all their public confidence, some Gore advisers privately worry that Mr. Gore should be far ahead in the polls right now -- not lagging -- given the robust economy and the fact that all seems well in the world. They are concerned that as Mr. Bush reaches out to moderates, Mr. Gore is still having trouble winning over reliable Democratic voters.
At their weekly meeting, top campaign strategists in Nashville last week mulled over what could be going wrong. Everyone seemed to have a suggestion: Some aides concluded that Mr. Gore was coming off as too liberal and needed to be even more aggressively reaching out to moderates. But, participants said, there was also a discussion of what some strategists think is Mr. Gore's fundamental problem: that people do not seem to like him as much as they like Mr. Bush.
Democrats may be uneasy, but they are not panicking because they can still make quite a plausible case for Mr. Gore. And the news media may be allies here: If the vice president demonstrates any glimmer of a comeback, he is bound to draw upbeat coverage (outsized perhaps) depicting him as on the rebound. That is because the news media, by nature, thrive on the dramatic -- and a comeback meets that standard.
"This is a very winnable race for him," said Fred Yang, a Democratic pollster. "Bush still hasn't proven that he can take the heat. And Gore seems to shine the most when the pressure is on."
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said he was confident that both the healthy economy and Mr. Gore's deep command of issues would assure him victory. It is certainly true that on many of the most important issues, voters rate the Democrats more capable than Republicans.
"On the big policy issues, I think Gore wins," Mr. Cuomo said. "By the time the debates are over, Bush is not going to be able to dominate on any of these issues. The obvious issue is: 'Didn't these people produce the biggest and best economy in modern history?' And Gore has an edge on the gravitas issue. It will be: 'Who is intelligent enough and who is competent enough to keep us going the way we've been going?' "
Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, a Republican, said he was optimistic, but cautiously so. What could go wrong? "I don't know that there's anything specific," he said. "It's just an understanding of the dynamics of our human existence."
But some Republicans simply refuse to buy the possibility of a Gore triumph. "There's very little that worries me about him," said Gov. John Engler of Michigan, who is working closely with the Bush campaign. "He's going to put together a scorched-earth operation. And he's going to slash and burn."
And Governor Bush, in a slip of the tongue, apparently was so confident at an event earlier this month that he dispensed with the formalities -- like the actual election. "As president," he declared, "I'm here in Knoxville, Tennessee, to tell America I'll set a new tone in Washington."

HEADLINE: With Time Short, Albright Stays Aloft

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
How does Madeleine K. Albright want to be remembered as secretary of state? As Dr. Albright zoomed from country to country, region to region -- 4 hours here, 36 hours there in 9 days -- the legacy question was never far away.
Part of her mark in history will be as the first woman to hold the post, a role she relishes. In Seoul, South Korea, last week, she emerged from her plane in citrus yellow, a bold look she said was intended as a metaphor for President Kim Dae Jung's "sunshine policy" with North Korea. In Berlin, she was not too shy to tell an audience that she was grateful for cosmetics to help disguise her exhaustion. 
 Dr. Albright has also taken on issues that others may have considered too soft, like the empowerment of women in developing countries and Internet literacy in nations under dictatorships.
But as Dr. Albright traveled from Beijing to Seoul and on to Warsaw in late June, with an interlude in the Middle East and a drive through the Brandenburg Gate, it was clear that, in the last six months of her term, she wants to concentrate on her vision of democracy.
Democracy, she said in Warsaw, was her "lodestar." And to emphasize the message, she intends to stay on the road.
"What we're going to do is keep traveling around the world and have 36-hour days, so six months is nine months," she told reporters as her plane headed home last Thursday.
She has already visited 82 countries since she took office in January 1997, a record for any secretary of state. She plans two trips to Asia this month, and perhaps another in the fall, including a possible stop in Nepal, where she has never been.
Dr. Albright says her travel shows how the job of secretary of state has changed since the end of the cold war. Her predecessors, she says, concentrated largely on the Soviet Union and the Middle East. Since then, there has been an explosion of new countries -- 189 in the United Nations at last count.
Similarly, foreign policy issues, Dr. Albright likes to say, have expanded beyond traditional questions of arms control and balance of power to international business corruption and illegal immigration. She feels obliged, she suggests, to push United States interests to new corners of the world. And for Dr. Albright, a child of Central Europe whose Czechoslovak parents fled the Communists and arrived in the United States in 1949 to begin a new life, the nurturing of democracy is a prime interest for the United States. (As she bounced from culture to culture during this latest trip, she appeared most at home chatting into the late evening over coffee in Warsaw's old town.)
The centerpiece of her stay in Poland was a conference that pulled together 107 democracies. But the gathering -- born very much of Dr. Albright's guiding hand -- revealed undertones of resentment at American hegemony.
That was most stridently expressed by France, which refused to sign the closing statement. But there were criticisms elsewhere, too.
Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch in New York, whose organization was present in Warsaw, says the promotion of democracy by the United States is useful but is done in such a way that it "fuels growing hostility."
"The United States is increasingly viewed as a government that preaches to the rest of the world but is unwilling to be bound by international standards," he said.
Despite Dr. Albright's efforts, Washington has failed to sign United Nations accords on an international criminal court or on the control of land mines -- largely because the administration and Congress want to immunize American military personnel against international laws imposed on others, and Dr. Albright failed to beat out the Pentagon in internal administration debates.
Dr. Albright seems to believe that she does best abroad, riding imperial motorcades and speaking unchallenged at a broad variety of forums. There, she is away from the political sniping of Congress and day-to-day management from the National Security Council.
She finished this last tour of the world in Berlin with a speech on democracy in the Balkans, which dealt with Serbia as a last holdout of repression.
The secretary began her term rebuking Saddam Hussein. She was one of the strongest advocates within the administration for military strikes and economic sanctions against him, but the Iraqi leader remains in power.
Since then -- before, during and after the war in Kosovo last year -- she has paid much attention to another repressive leader, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. A year after the NATO air campaign, he, too, remains in power -- much to the evident disappointment of Dr. Albright.
In Berlin, she reiterated that Mr. Milosevic belongs in The Hague, home of an international tribunal that indicted him on charges of war crimes. "If Milosevic cared at all about the rule of law," she added, "he would turn himself over to The Hague."
"I'm sure he will go," she said as she headed home, offering no clear way to achieve that goal beyond what she called a combination of people working inside and outside Serbia, and her opinion that his government is increasingly brittle.
"Patience is what is necessary," she said. "The calendar is not what we're looking at."
Dr. Albright is keenly aware of her own calendar, however. She was asked whether the Balkans, which have consumed much of her time, would remain a top priority for the next administration. "It depends on who gets elected," she replied, adding, "No matter where I am, we're not going to forget them."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
At 24, a Political Veteran, Vacuum Cleaner to Platform

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SO how did you spend the summer after seventh grade?
Mowing lawns? Rereading "Born Free" at summer school? Andrei Cherny had grander plans for his vacation. 
 The year was 1988 and he had recently read Theodore H. White's "The Making of the President, 1960." (No comic books for this preteenager.) Inspired by that portrait of John F. Kennedy, he volunteered to work on the Los Angeles campaign of another Massachusetts-bred, Harvard-trained candidate for president, Michael S. Dukakis.
A skeptical campaign official asked what he would like to work on. "Foreign policy," 12-year-old Andrei confidently replied. The official offered a vacuum cleaner instead. By fall, he had graduated from doing floors to stuffing envelopes and answering phones.
But from that modest beginning came more precocious things. By his senior year at Harvard, Mr. Cherny was writing speeches for President Clinton. A week after graduation, he became a senior speech writer for Vice President Al Gore. At 23, he edited a big-thought magazine for the Democratic Leadership Council, the party's leading centrist organization. And at 24, he wrote a book describing the new politics of the new economy.
Now, a month from reaching the ripe old age of 25, Mr. Cherny is writing the Democratic platform, a 20,000-word spiritual guide to the party's political soul that dedicated Democrats will fuss and bicker over all summer, whether or not voters pay any attention to it in the fall.
"I think there are a lot of people who really do look at the platform," Mr. Cherny said. "Perhaps especially in this day and age, it's an important way of saying: here's what the Democratic Party stands for, here's what we've done and what we're going to do."
As platform director, Mr. Cherny joins the ranks of other platform writers with silky prose and grand ideas who later became leading policy makers within the party. In 1984, it was Susan Estrich, who managed the 1988 Dukakis campaign. In 1992, it was Bruce Reed, now a top domestic policy adviser to Mr. Clinton. And in 1996, it was Mr. Reed and Elaine Kamarck, who is now policy director for the Gore campaign.
As any of those people could tell you, platform writing is its own special art form. The prose must be pithy, elegant and inspiring. And the wording must deftly skip across the ideological minefields that have surrounded Democratic and Republican platforms of the past.
For instance, when Senator Edward M. Kennedy challenged President Jimmy Carter in 1980, a combative Kennedy team -- which included the mayor of Cincinnati, Jerry Springer -- produced 25 minority reports on the platform. Things got so testy that a Kennedy adviser named Paul Tully nearly came to blows with a Carter delegate named Mario M. Cuomo.
This year, after former Senator Bill Bradley yielded early in the primaries, the intraparty struggle is much quieter. To be sure, gay rights activists, environmentalists and union leaders are laboring behind the scenes to insert pet phrases into Mr. Cherny's draft. But the process, he insists, has been remarkably consensual and free of acrimony.
"Certainly trade is one place where there's been some debate," he said. "But it's not like you have these groups at each other's throats. You have the single goal of winning in November."
A gentle platform process would befit Mr. Cherny's unassuming style. Lanky and soft-spoken, he fills his spare time, what little there is, with history books, films and, he confesses, "junk TV" shows like "Ally McBeal" and "Friends." In his cluttered office at the Democratic National Committee, a photograph of his favorite scholar-writer-politician, Winston Churchill, sternly stares down from the white wall.
THE older of two sons born to immigrants from Czechoslovakia, Mr. Cherny was raised in the Valley Village section of Los Angeles, a heavily minority, working-class community. His father, a schoolteacher, and mother, a psychotherapist, are proud of his achievements, he says, but not overly awed by the company he keeps.
"They still expect me to pick up my socks and wash the dishes when I'm home," he said.
Mr. Cherny first caught the eye of Democratic heavyweights during his senior year at Harvard, when Donald Baer, then the White House communications director, read a piece he had written for the student newspaper, The Crimson, analyzing President Clinton's landslide victory of 1996.
Mr. Baer showed the article to the president, who liked it so much he made it required reading for his cabinet and cribbed part of a sentence for his second inaugural address. "We need a new government for a new century, a government humble enough not to try to solve all our problems for us but strong enough to give us the tools to solve our problems for ourselves," the line from the address went.
Mr. Baer commissioned Mr. Cherny to write speeches for Mr. Clinton during his final semester at Harvard. After graduation, he moved to Washington to write for Mr. Gore, an author and former reporter whom Mr. Cherny found to be a perfectionist about language.
"We would bring him drafts, he'd sit down and change every word, and then some," Mr. Cherny said. "In the end, they were his speeches."
A year ago, Mr. Cherny returned to California, where he managed to work as a part-time policy adviser to the speaker of the State Assembly while attending Boalt Hall, the law school at Berkeley, and writing a book. The book, "The Next Deal," will be published by Basic Books this winter.
And what if there is a Gore administration? Mr. Cherny says he wants to return to California, finish law school and become a criminal prosecutor. "When the convention approves the platform, my job is done," he said. But the hesitation in his voice suggested that he senses this will not be his last stint in Washington.

HEADLINE: Changing Senate Race Changes Mood of Some Voters

SERIES: UNDECIDED: Watching and Waiting

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
More than a month into what is essentially a new race for the United States Senate, Cathy Harrison and Dave Temkin, both party stalwarts, have just about climbed off the fence of indecision and chosen the candidate they will vote for in November, barring scandal or surprise.
Mrs. Harrison and Mr. Temkin -- she now set on Representative Rick A. Lazio of Suffolk County and he on Hillary Rodham Clinton -- are part of a panel of nine voters that The New York Times is following as they make their decisions in this pivotal Senate race. 
 They were culled from respondents to early New York Times/CBS News Polls, back when Rudolph W. Giuliani was the Republican candidate in the race, the number of undecided voters was unusually small and their indecision was based not on ignorance of the candidates but rather on antipathy for them.
All that has now changed, with Mayor Giuliani out of the contest because of prostate cancer, and Mrs. Clinton, in the eyes of these voters, a less contentious figure than she was a year ago. But except for Mrs. Harrison and Mr. Temkin (and Tom Beck, a Long Island guidance counselor familiar with Mr. Lazio's record who embraced his candidacy from Day 1), the six other voters continue to watch and wait.
Tom and Barbara Smith, a struggling working-class couple from Saugerties, say they still do not feel that they know enough about the candidates, partly because they live in a part of the state without the saturation news coverage of New York City, Albany, Syracuse, Rochester or Buffalo.
Charlene Clinton, a single mother in Buffalo who recently lost her first job since leaving the welfare rolls, says she pays no attention to politics, did not know Mr. Lazio had entered the race and would make up her mind at the last minute, as she always does.
Other voters on the panel have pet issues that will determine their vote. Doug Taggart, vice president of a financial services concern and a resident of Cortlandt Manor in Westchester, wants to know how each candidate would spend the growing budget surplus.
Karl Schwartz, a computer consultant on Staten Island whose wife is undergoing experimental cancer treatment, wants a senator who cares about the disease, its causes and its cures. And Bob Harrison, a high school social studies teacher from Amsterdam, who is Cathy's husband, wants to know how Representative Lazio and Mrs. Clinton plan to invigorate the failing upstate economy.
Mrs. Harrison, a nurse and a lifelong Republican, had a hard time supporting Mr. Giuliani, despite party affiliation, because she found him too harsh and autocratic, too focused on downstate concerns and too indelicate in his personal life.
But Mr. Lazio is another story. "From what I've been seeing and hearing, I like the family feeling he gives off," Mrs. Harrison said. "He's a Republican candidate and now I don't feel any need to cross over."
The choice is also simple now for Mr. Temkin, a telecommunications expert from Flushing, Queens, and a lifelong Democrat. His reservations about Mrs. Clinton remain real, Mr. Temkin said. And he would vote Republican if the candidate had the stature and courage to cross his party when it was in the interest of New York State, as Jacob K. Javits did when he was senator, he said.
But Mr. Lazio's defining act so far, in Mr. Temkin's mind, was deferring to the Republican governor, George E. Pataki, by abandoning the race in favor of Mr. Giuliani and then jumping back in on command. "He's too loyal to the party," Mr. Temkin concluded.
All these voters (two of the original group dropped out of the project in May) are learning about the candidates amid the din of their daily lives, generally more compelling than politics. There are gaps in what they know and little spare time to fill them.
The Smiths, for instance, have been preoccupied with the birth of a grandchild, the search for a new apartment and plans to paint and hang bookshelves. Ms. Clinton, the single mother in Buffalo, lost a job as a monitor at a school that was stripped of its certification. She is back in the bureaucratic maze of welfare and faced with a shut-off notice for an unpaid water bill. The Harrisons just celebrated their son's high school graduation, helped him choose a community college and left for a family vacation in Hawaii, which took two years of savings.
Still, most of them are aware of certain policy announcements, gaffes and tiffs. They agree that mudslinging, a word used by many, has increased since Mr. Giuliani's withdrawal. They agree that Mrs. Clinton has been more visible in the metropolitan region and less visible upstate, where she has less chance of winning with Mr. Lazio as her opponent. They all are hoping for debates and better elaboration of positions.
Most of the sniping between the candidates is of no interest, except to irritate them. The accusations that Mr. Lazio had inappropriately profited from a securities deal, for instance, drew ridicule because equivalent accusations have been made against Mrs. Clinton.
"It's posturing and pandering," Mr. Temkin said. "It's like Dr. Strangelove. They're afraid if the other guy does it and they don't. We're not given enough credit for intelligence as voters."
Mr. Smith had a theory on why there was less negative campaigning when the mayor was still in the race. "Maybe she didn't feel as threatened," he said of Mrs. Clinton. "Lazio is young and energetic and he exploded out of the block. Maybe that shook her up."
These voters seem unmoved by the barrage of television advertising. It is tempting to think that they discount the power of the ads because they think that is what sophisticated voters should do. But in nine interviews, only the Harrisons were able even to describe a television commercial for a candidate -- a warm and fuzzy one in which Mr. Lazio is surrounded by his wife and children.
"Family values and such," Mr. Harrison said of the Lazio commercials. "Upstate, that's a plus."
But while Mr. Lazio's attractive family won over Mrs. Harrison, her husband, who comes from less conservative Republican stock, says he needs something more. "On the economy, I haven't heard much from either candidate," he said. "That's an important issue up here, to make sure New York State prospers. So I'm waiting."
Mr. Taggart, who has been impressed with Mr. Lazio's energy, is waiting to hear his plans, and Mrs. Clinton's, for the surplus. Large tax cuts, a common Republican lure, would be both foolish and selfish, in Mr. Taggart's view. First, cuts put very little money in any individual's pocket, he said. And second, prosperous times are an opportunity to be magnanimous.
"One of the ways we define ourselves as a people," he said, "is how we get through the best of times."
Mr. Schwartz, a former schoolteacher, is quick to acknowledge that these days he has become a myopic voter, with only one thing on his mind: his wife's non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. He has learned on the Internet, from his lymphoma news group, that Mr. Lazio last year won the Paul Tsongas Memorial Award from the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America.
Normally a Democrat, and aware of Mrs. Clinton's focus on health care issues, he has offered the first lady a chance to weigh in, sending an e-mail message to her campaign office that has not been answered. "I would like to get her viewpoint," he said.
Mr. Schwartz is abashed to be so self-centered. "I do understand there are other issues for other people," he said. "But for us, this is life and death." In addition, he said concern about the increased incidence of certain cancers "branches into respect for the environment and your position regarding corporate power and the responsibility of big business for the mess they create."
Charlene Clinton, who has voted in all but one election since she was eligible, has been consistently unaware of campaign developments, including Mr. Giuliani's cancer diagnosis, the announcement of his planned marital separation, his withdrawal from the race and Mr. Lazio's entry.
In elections past, she has relied on an elderly neighbor, an avid newspaper reader, to keep her informed. Lately, that woman has been ill. In addition, there has been a change of pastors at the Cedar Grove Missionary Baptist Church. The former paster talked a lot about politics, and the new one does not, Ms. Clinton said.
She has never voted for a Republican, nor have her parents, Ms. Clinton said. Yet she insisted that she remained undecided. "I'm not that into politics," she said. "But issues do concern me."
 
Undecided
This is the sixth article in a series following a group of New York State voters from diverse backgrounds as they make up their minds on which candidate to support for the United States Senate.
The previous articles were about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's withdrawal from the race, his separation from his wife, the mayor's prostate cancer, the information already available about the candidates, and the voters' first impressions.
