The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: July 3, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 3940 words

HEADLINE: UNDER PRESSURE: A Special Report;
Even for Sixth Graders, College Looms

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN and JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Lauriston Nunes takes sample SAT's as if he were taking batting practice, signing onto a Web site with practice questions a few afternoons a week from his home near Atlanta.
Chanel Meanor regularly awakes with a start past midnight, fretting about overlapping assignments at her Silicon Valley school. "Sometimes I'll wake up thinking something's due the next day," she said, "and it's not." 
 After a Duke University basketball game a few months ago, Max Mashore's father introduced him to a university admissions officer, who told Max to take Spanish rather than Latin and sign up for calculus as soon as possible at his school in Washington, D.C.
These students have one thing in common: They are in sixth grade.
On top of the timeless complications of being 12 years old, an age of bubbling hormones and anti-authority stirrings, sixth graders today face a combination of pressures that their parents never encountered.
To understand how the country's continuing educational makeover and the pace of American society are transforming the lives of students, The New York Times conducted round-table discussions over the past six months with 221 sixth graders, youngsters on the bridge between childhood and adolescence, at 21 schools -- public and private, cutthroat and coddling -- in 11 states and the District of Columbia.
The interviews showed that with a college degree increasingly seen as a prerequisite for a decent life -- and admission to prestigious universities more competitive than ever -- higher education has become a preoccupation for children even before they reach puberty.
At the same time, the students face new layers of standardized tests that judge not only what they know -- and whether they should be promoted -- but the performance of their teachers, their schools and their towns.
Concerned about the future of the nation's economy, American educators have over the past decade imported pages from the strict curriculums of Asian schools and Europe's elite academies, imposing the rigor and seriousness of high school on the lower grades. Though the United States has surpassed its competitors economically, public dissatisfaction with the preparation of American workers remains, heightening the hurdles for students.
In this era of earlier and higher expectations, most of the students interviewed said they were driven to excel by parents who had seized on test scores and early college readiness as new benchmarks for success.
Some of the students suffer tension headaches and bouts of anxiety, raising questions about the costs of growing up quickly. But a number of the students embraced this intense focus on the future, saying it gave more meaning and direction to their lives than idle hours in front of the television.
They drink in the challenges like a first sip of coffee, a tantalizing if slightly bitter taste of adulthood.
"I try to strive for stuff that I know I can't achieve right now," said Yesenia Mendez, 13, of Boston. "I read harder books that I can't understand right now."
Yesenia attends the Academy of the Pacific Rim, a three-year-old charter school that has adopted some Asian educational principles -- children take martial arts for gym, clean their own classrooms and are often rewarded or disciplined as a group for an individual's behavior.
"I stay in school longer than my mother goes to work sometimes," Yesenia said of the 210-day calendar of classes stretching from 8:05 a.m. to 4:10 p.m. "I feel like I need to get paid."
Though Manhattan's prestigious private schools are well known for their pressure-cooker atmosphere, the interviews show that similar stresses pervade students' lives regardless of geography or socioeconomic station. In fact, students at the nation's most expensive academies seemed among those most at ease, perhaps confident that their course in life was assured.
The level of anxiety prevalent in sixth-grade lunchrooms appeared almost to grow in proportion to a school's distance from the ivory towers of the Northeast. Middle-class children in cookie-cutter subdivisions say they fear that attending no-name local universities will consign them to mediocrity, while minority students and those living in poverty are scrambling to prepare themselves for any college, a path pursued by few of their predecessors.
In affluent Newton, Mass., and suburban Orlando, Fla., children are already drawing road maps to follow their parents' footsteps into the Ivy League; in the hardscrabble neighborhoods of Milwaukee and New York, there are also sixth graders fixated on Harvard and Yale as their ticket to surpass relatives who never finished high school.
At a Muslim school in Atlanta, just as at a Jewish school in Las Vegas, preteenage overachievers sweat even fractional fluctuations in grade-point average. From Nogales, Ariz., on the Mexican border, to East Palo Alto, Calif., a ghetto bordering the mansions of Silicon Valley, tutors and resume-padding activities have supplanted after-school play dates.
That means 10 more years of hated piano lessons for Lucy McDaniel, 12, whose mother tells her that music improves math scores. "I barely even get to go outside when I get home," said Lucy, who attends the Westminster Schools in Atlanta, where tuition is more than $12,000 a year.
As sixth graders confront these challenges, they also worry that the school shootings they see on television will invade their own classrooms, and they are saddled with new responsibilities in families overwhelmed by dual careers or damaged by divorce.
Even educators are confounded by this precarious age. In some districts, sixth grade is elementary school's finale, with recess and classrooms as comforting as warm milk; elsewhere, it is the opening act of middle school, where sixth graders switch rooms for every subject and fumble with locker combinations while jostled by eighth graders topping six feet.
No matter the setting, the sixth-grade curriculum is changing, too, as teachers and parents push higher-level material like geometry and geology, a trickle-down effect from high schools, where enrollment in college-level advanced placement courses has doubled over the last decade.
"There's too much going on in sixth grade," said Nora Farley, 12, of Pleasantville, N.Y., in Westchester County. "It's all being crammed in your brain. It's too much to take."
To be sure, there are sizable pockets of students at private and public schools who say they feel little pressure in their lives and who have given no thought to college. But it was only at a one-room schoolhouse in Montana that the sixth graders -- both of them -- seemed confused by the very notion of pressure.
Most schools were more like Mantua Elementary in Fairfax County, Va., where the county requires a one-time class lesson on stress -- and how to deal with it -- for every sixth grader.
"What happened to childhood?" asked Ellen S. Schoetzau, 45, Mantua's principal. "The pressures on children are much greater now than when I was teaching -- certainly than when I was in school."
 
The View
Does Any School Beat Harvard?
One new chain of thought that runs nearly unbroken through today's sixth-grade classrooms is the belief that a college degree -- particularly a parchment from someplace with a pedigree -- comes with a passkey to the good life.
"I just see education as the way to get rich," said Keenan Robinson, 12, the son of a tax appraiser and a secretary from DeKalb County, Ga., outside Atlanta. "You can't get a multimillion-dollar entertainment company by being a bum on the street."
Keenan, who used to live in New York, wants to attend St. John's University. "That's all that runs through my mind," he said.
With applications to four-year colleges, especially the most selective, increasing every year, the intense competition over admission is filtering all the way down to sixth grade.
Students like Keenan are not just ruminating about colleges; they are researching them. In Las Vegas, Nogales, Atlanta and Milwaukee, among other places, sixth graders reported surfing college home pages on the Web, some with an eye on future majors, others seeking scholarship opportunities.
"I'm not really thinking so much about which college," said Chelsea Hammack, 12, whose father is a Las Vegas police officer and whose mother works in a casino. "It's more, what am I going to do when I get there?
"Once in a while me and my parents talk about what I'm going to take for my subject that could help me with the job I want to do," said Chelsea, an aspiring writer ("fiction, short stories, mostly"). "I want to take something I'm interested in, but not something that's so easy I won't learn anything."
Chelsea has been using the Web to compare Brigham Young University in Utah with a college in Hawaii. "I'm sort of split between the two," she said. "I'm actually thinking of going to U.N.L.V. for a year to get a better chance of getting into a good school."
That is why Lauriston Nunes, the 12-year-old Atlanta boy who drills himself on the SAT's, keeps going back to the Web site of the College Board, www.collegeboard.com.
"The first few times I went there, I got every question right," he said. "It makes me feel smart. It lets me know that I can do more than what I have to do right now."
Lauriston is already experimenting with a kind of higher education: a school for models, Sundays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. "I like being on stage," he said. "I like seeing people clap for me."
For other students, particularly those with older siblings, weekend activities include leafing through college guidebooks -- or even visiting campuses. Kristen Summerall is getting advice from her sister, a high school junior.
"She's going to Spelman, I wanted to go to Harvard," said Kristen, 12, a 4.0 student at Stephenson Middle School outside Atlanta. "Then I was like, 'Is there a school better than Harvard?' She was like, 'Its initials are M.I.T.' It's in Michigan or something.
"The farthest I've ever been is Virginia," she added. "I want to see more of the United States. When I was little, I used to tell my parents I wanted to leave the United States and go to school in Paris."
Some children are clearly self-motivated, but more often the prod is a parent or grandparent -- whose success in life has set an example that students want to follow, or whose failures the children hope to avoid.
Max Mashore's pilgrimages to Duke, his dad's alma mater, began in second grade. Max went to a basketball camp at Duke last summer.
"This whole year I've been thinking about college," said Max, a B student at Sidwell Friends school in Washington who was wearing his Duke sweatshirt, as usual.
"I don't want to go to some small college in the middle of Maine or something." he said. "I heard someone say once, 'C is community college, B is state college, A is Ivy League school.' "
Rahel Haile, 12, of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School in the Bronx, said her parents, immigrants from Eritrea, were determined that she achieve more than they have. Rahel's father, a grocery store manager, went to Rutgers, but that "isn't the best college," Rahel said.
"Since third and fifth grade, I used to think I wanted to go to Harvard, Harvard, Harvard," she said. "I was looking at Harvard. I don't want to sound harsh, but Harvard was just too preppy for me. I'd rather go to N.Y.U."
One might expect students at Fieldston, a feeder school to the Ivy League, to have a college focus -- though perhaps not at age 12. But what is striking is the nervous attention to college admission -- fed by misinformation -- in schools elsewhere.
Sixth graders in suburban Washington, Las Vegas, Nogales and East Palo Alto all believe, mistakenly, that colleges will examine elementary school transcripts.
"If you go to Stanford, they might look at your records and see if you've been bad," said Tuuta Tuipulotu, 11, who is worried that his one-day suspension at his northern California school, for fighting, might result in a rejection letter.
For the college class of 2010, it seems, it is never too early to start.
"With the Ivy League schools, my dad always says that to get into them, it's like a race," said Joshua Bordin, 12, the son of a Pleasantville businessman and nursery school teacher. "Let's say we could put the whole grade in a race. People have to fall. People have to stop to tie a shoe. But if you keep getting good grades, you race and race to the top."
 
The Tests
'I'm Worried If I'll Get Held Back'
In Arizona, it is AIMS. In Massachusetts, M.C.A.S. Florida has the FCAT. Virginia, the SOL. In East Palo Alto, there is the SAT-9 and the R-SAT. Las Vegas spells it out: Terra Nova, which greets sixth graders just a month after they arrive at middle school.
They are the standardized tests beloved by politicians, business leaders and those who call themselves education reformers, and they have sixth graders nationwide chewing on their No. 2 pencils. The tests are part of a concerted effort to elevate achievement, leaving students far more worried than their predecessors that poor marks could land them in remedial classes, in summer school or even back to suffer sixth grade all over again next year.
"They can feel the pressure," said Mark A. Valenzuela, the principal of Desert Shadows Middle School in Nogales, "from teachers, administrators, parents, older siblings -- from older students in the school."
It will be two years before Nogales sixth graders face the new state tests, the Arizona Instrument to Measure Standards, and four years before they take a math exam required for a high school diploma. Still, Mr. Valenzuela convened an assembly this spring to tell sixth graders, many of them the children of truckers and distributors in the tomato industry, that their homework today is critical to their AIMS performance.
To Ben Larriva, 11, such warnings echo the daily mantra from his teachers: "This will be on the AIMS test." Ben, whose parents unplug his computer if he slips off the honor roll, is warily watching his brother's experience in eighth grade. "He can't keep up," Ben said.
The pressure is more immediate at the Menlo Oaks School, where the have-nots of Silicon Valley must pass a standardized state test in three subjects to be promoted and take the Ravenswood Stanford Achievement Tests, a set of district exams, for three days each quarter.
"Every time I take a test, I get nervous," said Jeremiah Sagote, 11, the son of a truck mechanic and a store clerk from Samoa. "Not like a spelling test -- I don't get nervous on those. Like the R-SAT test. I'm worried if I'll get held back."
Jeremiah's expression of concern about promotion was repeated by sixth graders across the country. And, with scores published in local newspapers, students in several districts said they were also anxious about what the tests meant for the teachers they love (or hate).
"I think sometimes the teachers have the tendency to stress them out," said Clara Rice, the principal at Menlo Oaks. "Because the teachers will look bad if the students don't do well. Their jobs are on the line. The principal's job. And the superintendent's."
Private schools are not immune, either. At Fieldston, sixth graders have been taking standardized tests since kindergarten, and they were frazzled by a recent math exam.
"We had 30 minutes to do this test, which means we had like a minute and 5 seconds to do each problem," Joseph DeJesus, 12, said. "Most of those problems took two to three minutes."
Rocky Russo, 12, another Fieldston student, said he felt as if he was being used. "You think they could come up with a better way to figure out if the teachers are doing their jobs correctly," Rocky said.
In Fairfax County, students expressed frustration that a test on Virginia history had squeezed other educational activities out of the schedule.
"We were going to have an archaeological dig, make artifacts and bury them, and another class would dig them up, and it would be really cool," said Monica Kumar, 11, a student at Mantua Elementary.
Instead, Monica's class spent two weeks reviewing for Virginia's Standards of Learning test. "The teachers stuck note cards from every single event -- from when Jamestown was founded to Arthur Ashe winning tennis tournaments -- they put them all around the walls," said Meredith Keller, 12, a classmate.
With stakes so high, grades now count more than ever.
"I got a B on a homework assignment," said Julia Cohen of Newton, Mass., a Boston suburb known for its stellar schools. "It, like, ruined it. I couldn't say I'd gotten all A's. Everyone was making fun of me.
"If you're going to get A's, then you might as well get them all the time."
To that end, many families have devised intricate incentive plans borrowed from corporate America and pegged to even the most mundane assignment.
Jon Lipinski of San Carlos, Calif., used to write one-sentence responses to homework questions. Then his mother, an emergency medical technician, started paying him two cents per word. Now, Jon says he can pull down "six bucks" an essay. His mother also pays 10 cents for every page he reads, and Jon says he is owed $44.
At Sidwell Friends, where Chelsea Clinton is an alumna, Cameron Pastrick is striving to reach a B average by employing tutors four times a week. To stay focused while doing her homework, she uses an egg timer.
"My mom's always like, I can't get you any more tutors, unless you want one Friday and Saturday and Sunday," said Cameron, who has had tutors since third grade.
"My mom went here. Whenever I bring home, like, a C, she's like, 'When I was your age, I got an A,' " Cameron said. "I keep telling them this, and they say, 'We don't pressure you, we encourage you.' "
 
The Outside Forces
Fear of Guns In the Schoolroom
As high academic expectations hang over their young lives, this year's sixth graders have been distracted by outside forces that did not buffet their predecessors.
Five months after the massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., Mia Grill skipped the first day at Molasky Middle School in Las Vegas. She was nervous that it would prove more violent than her elementary school because the pupils were older.
"My mom, she said not to worry," said Mia, 12, whose parents sell tile. "I'm still worried. Sooner or later, someone's probably going to bring a gun to school."
In the New York borough of Queens, Christopher Bennett's mind sometimes fills with doomsday scenarios as he moves through the hallways of Public School 21, a tan-brick box of an elementary school crammed with Eastern European and Asian immigrants.
"When we do a silent meeting after lunch," said Chris, 11, "I always look at the door and imagine someone big and dressed all in black coming through."
For others, though, the classroom is a respite from home lives rendered turbulent by parents' work schedules or divorce.
A cog in an increasingly mobile work force, Suzannah Mullen's mother has been shuttled through four states in recent years, often starting new jobs before her family can catch up. Suzannah, 11, and her older sister stayed with their father in the Orlando suburbs this spring while her mother, a human resources administrator, commuted to Charlotte, N.C. "Sometimes, I kind of search my house for my mom and it's like, 'Oh, she's in North Carolina,' " Suzannah said.
Joaquin Vega lives with his mother in Milwaukee, but said he might as well live alone. While Joaquin likes the DVD player and big-screen television paid for by his mother's job at a car dealership, he said they "can't pay for the time she's gone."
"I would like her to help me with my homework," Joaquin said, adding that he has never met his father. "If we have teacher conferences, she can't come. I was on the basketball team. I got first place, and she couldn't come to the ceremony."
Kayleigh Wittman, 12, of Altamonte Springs, Fla., also a child of divorce, gets a monthly allowance of $110 -- but she said that had to cover all her expenses, from shampoo to tithing and saving for college.
"I write down how much money I use, and what I use it on," she said. When Kayleigh worried aloud about paying for her future education, saying she expects no further subsidy from her family, a classmate seated nearby wondered, "Why don't you just save all your money for college?"
"Because," Kayleigh said, "I have to pay for lunch."
 
The Toll
Defining Stress And Dealing With It
At Mantua Elementary, a red-brick school a few miles down a wooded road from Prosperity Avenue in Fairfax, Va., stress is part of the curriculum: the county mandates a lesson on the subject for every sixth-grade class.
In a recent session, Suzzette Rodriguez's students easily defined the word. "A thought or something that you think about that causes strain on your mind," Matt Wong explained. "On your body, too. Say you have a big test coming up. Your body stiffens."
But, echoing some educators, Jenny Drenkard said, "A little bit of stress is probably actually good for you. You shouldn't be so laid-back that nothing matters."
Ranking the stresses in their lives on work sheets, most of the students placed school difficulties and divorced parents highest. (One boy offered a write-in candidate: "Girls in general.") When talking in groups about their most stressful situations, every cluster of children picked tests. As for the side effects, they listed headaches, queasiness, anger, depression, insomnia, exhaustion, lack of appetite and butterflies in the stomach.
At the San Carlos Charter Learning Center, an alternative public school in the Silicon Valley that does not use letter grades, many of the 15 students interviewed, including Chanel Meanor, said they had at least two bouts of sleeplessness a month because of pending schoolwork.
A coast away in Atlanta, John Hobart said that while baseball was "probably my favorite thing in the world to do," he had so much homework this year that "I get really excited when I don't have practice because I can relax."
And Sonia Dahliwal, a student at Teague Middle School in Altamonte Springs, Fla., is so desperate to get into the English class for gifted students that it is starting to show. "As you can see I don't like eating," Sonia, 13, said with a sour face. "I have better things to do than put stuff in my mouth and chew."
At Oaklands Elementary in Prince George's County, Md., Calisa Carter just dreams, every day, about being back in fifth grade.
"The only time that I don't feel stressed out is nighttime," she said, "when I'm sleeping."
But even as Calisa yearns for the past, other sixth graders are already looking beyond the summer to the fall -- and the pressures next year will bring.
Helen Park, 12, of Queens, recently toured her new junior high school, No. 185, near the elementary school that has been her security blanket, P.S. 21. "I heard a group of people there saying, 'I can't wait till Freshman Friday,' " she said. "I think they beat you up."
For many, the new school year will be filled with firsts: foreign language instruction, math and English classes sifted by students' academic abilities and junior varsity athletic tryouts.
Michael Bartomioli, 12, plans to play football, which means he will be required to attend practice daily until dusk even though he is very likely to warm the bench behind the bigger boys on the roster. He is already worried about starting his homework -- sure to be heavier -- three hours later than he did this year.
"I've heard seventh grade is the hardest grade," Michael said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:

NYUonline, New York, a for-profit unit of New York University where students can take courses online, to Toolbox Inc., New York, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.
 
Bombardier, Valcourt, Quebec, to the Cossette Communications Group, Montreal, and Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, to handle Ski-Doo skimobiles, which had been with Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, Dearborn, Mich., part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

HEADLINE: THE MEXICO ELECTION: BALLOTING AT THE BORDER;
BORDER BALLOTING

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 2

 BODY:
They began arriving before dawn, crossing south over the border in cars and pickup trucks and small caravans, with an unusual degree of optimism in their hearts and their voter registration cards in their wallets.
They were Mexicans who live in the United States returning to elect a new president, drawn by the possibility that the somewhat paradoxically named Institutional Revolutionary Party would lose the presidency for the first time since it was founded 71 years ago. Since Mexico does not have absentee ballots, they had to come from as far away as San Francisco, Washington and Chicago to cast their ballots at special polling places for out-of-district voters that were set up here and in several other cities along the 2,000-mile border. 
 "We all want change," said Ramiro Ramirez, a 48-year-old mechanic from Fontana, Calif., who arrived late Saturday night to ensure that he would get a good spot in line at one of the special polling sites today. Mr. Ramirez, who left his home state of Michoacan for the United States as a child, said he had made the trip today because he is thinking of his own future.
"We all left because of the same problems," he said. "But I would like to go back someday. And if the government changes, if things get better, if there's work, I will return."
By the time his turn came here, at 9 this morning, to pick up a paper ballot, fill it out in a cardboard booth behind a plastic curtain that said "The Vote is Free and Secret," and stuff the folded ballot into a cardboard box with a clear plastic window on each side, roughly 250 people were waiting behind him, many of them from California as well.
Their polling place, outside an all-night drugstore, was one of 15 in Tijuana where Mexicans away from home could vote. They wore cowboy hats and Dallas Cowboys hats, pearl-buttoned shirts and Hard Rock Cafe T-shirts, cowboy boots and Air Jordans. They came, they said, out of a belief that this election would be different from those in the past that were tainted by fraud. An opposition candidate, Vicente Fox Quesada, was virtually tied in the polls with the nominee of the governing party, Francisco Labastida Ochoa.
The vote is to be counted for the first time by an autonomous group, the Federal Elections Institute, rather than by a branch of the government controlled by the governing party. And many Mexicans north of the border were the targets of advertising and even campaign stops by the candidates.
"I think change is really possible this time," said Gabriel Castellanos, 26, who arrived here at 6:30 a.m. after driving down from Huntington Beach, Calif., with his wife, Miriam Sanchez, 19, to vote for Mr. Fox.
Fausto Soriano, 60, who came from San Francisco with four friends to vote for Mr. Fox, said, "I think this will be a cleaner election."
The election dominated Tijuana this weekend. There were the long lines at polling places, and most striking of all, there was no drinking allowed. The government imposed a dry law until after the elections.
It was quite a switch for a place that began its rapid growth, from a village to a city of 1.5 million people, during Prohibition, when Californians made this a favorite place for a boozy weekend getaway.
Without the usual rowdy revelry, the voters stood out even more than usual. The great fear expressed among them was that there would not be enough ballots to go around; an old voting-law reform, aimed at preventing fraud by ballot-stuffing, limits the number of ballots at each polling place to 750.
With only 15 sites in Tijuana where people could vote away from home, the maximum number of ballots available to them here would be 11,250. And some of those would be cast by people who live in Mexico -- soldiers, business travelers, people who moved but had not registered their new addresses.
That is why Jacqueline Vargas, 26, set her alarm clock at home in Garden Grove, Calif., for 3:40 a.m. She was so worried about oversleeping that she awakened on her own at 2:30. Ms. Vargas, who left her home in Monterrey four years ago for a marketing job in the United States, said she had followed the campaign online.
"After I graduated from the university, my aim was to move abroad as soon as I could," she said. "I didn't like the situation either politically or economically. I didn't see much future for myself there."
Mexicans living in the United States were assiduously courted for their votes this year for the first time. "The democratic process of Mexico is finally permeating north of the border, making us Mexican citizens aware of what's happening politically in our country," said Luis Pelayo, the president of the Hispanic Council in Chicago, who helped organize several caravans to cross the Texas border.
Of the estimated 10 million Mexicans who live in the United States, 1.5 million are believed to be eligible to vote. No one expected that many people to cross the border to vote -- in fact, fewer than 75,000 ballots were available at the special polling sites.
But the Mexicans living in the United States were wooed not only for their votes but also for their influence. Many of them still hold sway in the villages they left behind and with the families they support with money each month. By some estimates, Mexicans abroad send $7 billion home each year. They like to point out that this makes them Mexico's third highest source of income, after petroleum and tourism.
When Ms. Vargas called home, she said, she was disappointed when her father told her that he would vote for the governing party. "He just told me, 'They've done so much for us,' " she said. "I couldn't believe it."
It was a sore point among many Mexicans in the United States that Mexico lacks an absentee ballot. A bill that would have created one stalled last year in the Senate, which is controlled by the governing party. Party officials said they supported the concept of an absentee ballot but there was not enough time to create a fair system. Their opponents accused them of scuttling the measure out of fear that people who had to leave Mexico to find good jobs would vote them out of office.
Raul Ross Pineda, who lives in Chicago and is taking the unusual step of running for the Mexican Congress this year to represent the interests of Mexicans abroad, wrote a book on the issue called "Vote Without Borders," to call for an absentee ballot.
"Legally we are Mexican citizens; we have the right to vote, we love Mexico, we have families there that we sustain," Mr. Ross said. "We are not asking for any special privilege."
But without the absentee ballot, many Mexicans living north of the border simply took to the road. "Look at this," said Hector Alvarado, 45, from Maywood, Calif., pointing to a line of Mexicans from the United States that stretched nearly an entire city block here. "This isn't a rock concert or a football match. These are people who want to vote."

HEADLINE: U.S. Monitor Now Argues Iraqis Have Little to Conceal

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 30

 BODY:
Scott Ritter, the former United Nations arms inspector who quit two years ago charging that Secretary General Kofi Annan and American officials were undercutting efforts to disarm Saddam Hussein, now says the Iraqis have no prohibited weapons of any importance left.
Writing in the current issue of Arms Control Today, the journal of the independent Arms Control Association in Washington, Mr. Ritter says that the inspection team he served as an expert on concealment had effectively rid Iraq of dangerous weapons by 1997. And he argues that less aggressive monitoring of Iraq will now suffice and that inspectors on any new team should not pursue access to Iraqi presidential and security sites, which caused grave conflict with Iraq in the past. 
 Mr. Ritter's article was written before American officials disclosed that Iraq was rebuilding and testing a short-range missile system, which is permitted under United Nations sanctions and does not appear to be immediately threatening. But those reports appear to support Mr. Ritter's thesis that while the missile tests may be legal, they are the kind of activity that must be monitored on the ground to know if the Iraqis are trying to go beyond what us permissible, or are loading the missiles with prohibited warheads.
In an interview, Mr. Ritter said the purpose of his article was to suggest a way to overcome a deadlock with Iraq that has left the country without arms inspections for a year and half.
He said the United States has little support abroad for either unseating President Hussein or continuing sanctions indefinitely. The Russians, Chinese and French will no longer follow America, he said, and Iraq is strengthened by the division among the Security Council's five permanent members. "I propose that maybe people should take another look at the disarmament issue in a way that's more satisfactory to all the parties," he said.
Richard Butler, the former executive chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, or Unscom, which was responsible for monitoring Iraq, said in an interview that Mr. Ritter's assertions run directly counter to the reports Mr. Ritter submitted when he was in Iraq.
Mr. Butler, who has just published a book on his tenure, "The Greatest Threat: Iraq, Weapons of Mass Destruction and the Growing Crisis in Global Security" (Public Affairs, 2000), said in a telephone interview that Mr. Ritter was interpreting data he helped collect in an entirely different way.
"I didn't see one shred of evidence for these assertions," said Mr. Butler, an Australian arms control expert who is a diplomat in residence at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.
"Ritter's claim that it was evident then that nothing of any importance remained is completely contrary to the advice that he repeatedly and robustly gave me when he was on the staff," he added.
Several expert panels formed by the United Nations inspection commission as well as the Security Council also concluded that Iraq had not adequately disarmed, particularly in biological weapons.
In the interview, however, Mr. Ritter said that if he was considered tough when he was an inspector, he was only carrying out a rigid mandate from the Security Council. The days when international inspectors could demand every scrap of Iraqi war materiel are over, he added, and it is now time to adopt more pragmatic goals if there is ever to be a resumption of inspections in Iraq. That meant looking at what Iraq may have left qualitatively, rather than quantitatively, he said.
Mr. Ritter, who was routinely vilified by the Iraqis as the chief of a band of "cowboys" who wanted to kick down doors, met with Iraqi officials before writing the article. He said in the interview that he never took the Iraqi vilification personally.
Iraqi officials themselves had told him that the sharp criticisms were "politics," he said. And he now adopts their long-held demand that the lifting of economic sanctions should be linked with the introduction of any new inspections.
In his article, Mr. Ritter wrote that given the comprehensive nature of the former monitoring regime, "it was possible as early as 1997 to determine that, from a quantitative standpoint, Iraq had been disarmed."
By 1997, Mr. Ritter's article says, "Iraq no longer possessed any meaningful quantities of chemical or biological agent, if it possessed any at all, and the industrial means to produce these agents had either been eliminated or were subject to stringent monitoring. The same was true of Iraq's nuclear and ballistic missile capabilities."
In March 1998, however, a report after one of Mr. Ritter's visits pointed to "indisputable proof" that Iraq was still concealing weapons programs.
In his article, Mr. Ritter uses the search for missing artillery shells apparently filled with mustard gas as an example of the wrong focus. "A few hundred 155 mm mustard shells have very little military value on the modern battlefield," he wrote.
His former boss, Mr. Butler, said in an interview that such a critique of the inspections misses the point.
"Unscom never asserted that these shells were themselves militarily significant," he said. "What was made clear in our reports to the Security Council was that so long as they remained unaccounted for, the veracity of Iraq's overall declarations could not be relied upon.
"Our purpose in wanting those shells was to be able to bring to final account, to verify, Iraq's overall claims," he added. "Those shells represent a far wider question."

He wrote that "it was possible as early as 1997 to determine that, from a qualitative standpoint, Iraq had been disarmed." He did not write "from a quantitative standpoint."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Digital Economy's Demand for Stable Power Strains Utilities

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Read-Rite, an electronic components maker in Milpitas, Calif., has been in no position to complain whenever fluctuations in electrical service shut down a vital computer-controlled milling machine. After all, the local utility, Pacific Gas and Electric, has lived up to its contractual obligation to keep the power flowing and to prevent voltage surges or dips of 10 percent or more.
Unfortunately, the milling machine, which helps Read-Rite make the tiny devices that read and write information on computer disk drives, crashes if voltages vary as little as 5 percent. And such flutters have occasionally occurred the last two years as Pacific Gas, a unit of the PG&E Corporation, has performed its daily juggling act of matching power demand and supply in the region. So far, Read-Rite's solution has been to monitor the incoming power closely and adjust settings on the milling equipment manually. 
 "We have to watch it closely because we can lose materials worth thousands of dollars," said Shahzad Mahmud, director of facilities.
Read-Rite's milling machine is indicative of a long-running, but accelerating problem: the nation's electrical power supply system is not up to the task of meeting the digital economy's needs. While the utility industry has historically prided itself on delivering fairly stable power 99.9 percent of the time, today's computerized economy is demanding even fewer interruptions and a much steadier current.
That is because electricity is more than just energy for computers -- it is the medium they use to do their job. Rapid, minute changes in voltage represent the ones and zeros that make up digital information.
Those patterns are ultimately translated into a human voice during a phone call, a calculation during a banking transaction, a dose of radiation during cancer therapy or a photo of a new baby e-mailed to scattered relatives. Any disruption in the power supply that compromises the processor's ability to manage those voltages can lead to lost data or system crashes.
Power disturbances around the world cause more than 17,000 computer disruptions every second, from annoying frozen cursors to serious destruction of equipment, according to the latest calculations of American Power Conversion of West Kingston, R.I., which began building backup power systems for computer users in 1984.
"What we have worked well for an economy that ran on motors and lights," said Peter Gross, a leading designer of giant telecommunications hubs, data centers and other buildings that operate around the clock. "There's a major disconnect with what's happening in the digital world."
There is also an explosion of interest in technologies and services that address the new economy's power needs. And the remedies go well beyond the surge suppressors that most home PC users employ to protect their computers during lightning or voltage spikes. The solutions aimed at businesses include backup generators manufactured by companies like Caterpillar and smaller power supplies from American Power Conversion and the Liebert unit of Emerson Electric. There are innovative fuel cells from start-ups like FuelCell Energy; new flywheels from Active Power and Beacon Power and a variety of battery improvements. Companies like International Rectifier and Ixys are finding strong demand for new microchips that manage power equipment.
The computer-driven economy's push to transform the electricity business adds up to a $500 billion opportunity for the companies selling into it, according to Mark P. Mills, a Washington-based consultant who, along with Peter Huber, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, coined the term "powercosm" to describe the evolving market. The two men jointly publish The Digital Power Report for the Gilder Group.
The message certainly is resonating on Wall Street. International Rectifier has soared from less than $12 last summer to more than $55. Ixys, a smaller competitor that was hovering around $3 in November, reached $69 last Tuesday. Start-ups like H Power, a fuel-cell maker, and Active Power are on the runway for public offerings this summer, hoping to find the same kind of welcome as Capstone Turbine, which went public on Thursday at $16 a share and ended the week at $45.0625. Meanwhile, giants like General Electric and the deregulated arms of numerous utilities have been pouring venture capital into the field.
The expansion of the digital economy is causing electrical headaches in two ways. The most straightforward is that it drives up demand for electricity in regions like the Northeast where capacity is already strained in the peak summer months. Last week, on Manhattan's Upper East Side, for example, Consolidated Edison shut off service to eight apartment buildings and lowered its voltage in the neighborhood for several hours on a hot, muggy day.
The rising demand involves much more than air-conditioning, of course. Consider the transformation of a 16-story building in downtown Newark, which formerly housed a Macy's department store and consumed roughly 10 watts of power a square foot before the store was shut down in 1992.
Now, the upper floors have been reopened as a "telecommunications hotel" where companies like WorldCom, IDT, Qwest and Level 3 Communications park rows of data servers, routers and other electronic equipment, as well as cooling systems, backup power and other devices. According to Public Service Electric and Gas, the local utility, such users require 40 to 50 watts a square foot.
One developer looking at another site in North Jersey for the home of a potential million-square-foot data and communications center asked Public Service for 100 megawatts of power, according to Patrick Downs, the utility's vice president for operations support. "That's one-third of what we give the whole city of Newark," he said.
Still, even the most extravagant estimates of the new economy's impact on sheer demand put the level at less than 10 percent of the total capacity of traditional utilities. To energy managers, engineers like Mr. Gross and, more recently, Wall Street, the volume of demand for power is less noteworthy than the higher quality of electricity that digital users are insisting upon.
"Three nines is great for the grid," Mr. Mills said, referring to 99.9 percent reliability, or roughly eight hours of power losses a year. Indeed, it is hard to imagine this figure becoming much better, given the vulnerability of power supply grids to bad weather, animals shorting out transformers and other equipment and drunken drivers hitting utility poles.
But even "three nines," Mr. Mills said, is "trash for a computer."
Mr. Mills's prescription for microprocessor-friendly power quality is 10 nines, or 99.99999999 percent reliability -- a mere 32 seconds of power loss a year -- plus equipment to protect against those gaps and the sags, spikes and surges in between.
So great is the cost of computer disruptions to the economy that the sale of services or equipment to prevent such problems is starting to be seen as a can't-miss proposition for those with the right technology.
"When the Model T was introduced, people didn't worry about the grade of gasoline," said Larry R. Wilson, director of strategic planning for the electric power unit of Caterpillar. The invention of high-performance cars changed that, Mr. Wilson said, and now the same thing is happening on a much broader scale with electricity.
"Where people have a power quality need, price is not an issue," Mr. Wilson said. He predicts strong growth for Caterpillar's generator sales to a "premium" market of users for whom price is no object when it comes to reliable backup energy. Such users are willing to pay the equivalent of $20 a kilowatt for backup supplies, compared with about 7 cents a kilowatt, on average, for electricity drawn directly from the utility grid.
Although it varies by state around the nation, utility regulators generally define a momentary power loss as one lasting one to five minutes. Such interruptions can cause havoc in stock-trading systems, automated paper mills and other computer-driven processes unless there are backup power generators and equipment to switch to them seamlessly.
But in many cases, trouble does not wait for an outright power loss. A voltage dip of just 10 percent, with no interruption, can cause problems for some systems in a sixth of a second, according to Marek Samotyj, who manages power quality programs for the Electric Power Research Institute, a Palo Alto, Calif. research group owned by utility companies. And some sensors in medical equipment fail if current is cut off completely for as little as four milliseconds, he said.
Even as the crowd of suppliers that offer remedies swells, the question of who will pay for better power is very much unsettled.
Last year, American Electric Power, a large utility based in Columbus, Ohio, and the equipment maker Siemens Power Transmission and Distribution began studying what combination of monitoring equipment and system improvements would be required to supply premium-quality power to an industrial park in Delaware, Ohio. American Electric's goals included learning whether premium power could command premium prices, according to Harry Vollkommer, one of the project managers for the utility.
But James Osteen, senior industrial engineer at the Nippert Company, a wire manufacturer that is one of the major utility customers in the park, does not see a more stable power supply as a premium product. He said all companies were expected to improve quality continually these days, and the utility should be no exception. "Our expectation is that we won't pay more for premium power," he said.
A similar attitude prevails in Detroit. In order to keep business from the Big Three auto companies, Detroit Edison is currently supplying power under a contract that penalizes it if it fails to steadily reduce the number of power losses and fluctuations. The number of power losses at General Motors has been reduced by two-thirds since the contract began in 1995, and Detroit Edison has improved enough to avoid any penalties so far for power sags, according to John C. Anderson, director of energy services for G.M.
Addressing the new economy's power needs, however, is not simply a matter of improving the utility grid. Studies show that 70 percent of disruptions originate from electrical problems at customer sites, according to Richard P. Bingham, a manager at Dranetz-BMI, a power quality products and consulting company, in Edison, N.J.
"Laser printers often take out computers when the heater comes on," said Mr. Bingham, citing but one example. Electronic ballasts in overhead lighting and compressors in soda machines also cause unexpected loads. And electronic devices, like drives that adjust speeds on motors to save energy, generate electrical interference on the lines that power them. The interference, known as harmonic signals, can trip up other equipment unless it is canceled by filtering devices. And many schools, he said, are creating problems for themselves by overloading their electrical systems with new electronic equipment.
The variety of problems and the public's dwindling patience with disruptions means that trouble-shooters like Dranetz-BMI can no longer restrict themselves to the utility-dominated world, where the person on the other end of the phone is generally an engineer. "There are a lot more people with less and less knowledge of electricity calling me with questions," Mr. Bingham said.

An article in Business Day on Monday about the challenge of maintaining a reliable flow of electricity to meet the needs of the computerized economy miscalculated the amount of time that a user would be without electricity if the power supply were 99.99999999 percent reliable. It would be 0.0032 of a second a year, not 32 seconds.
The article also described FuelCell Energy incorrectly. The company, which changed its name last September, was founded in 1969 as the Energy Research Corporation. It is not a start-up company. SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Truest Measure of Patriotism

BYLINE: By David M. Kennedy; David M. Kennedy teaches history at Stanford University. His most recent book, "Freedom From Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945," won the Pulitzer Prize.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
Commodore Stephen Decatur, freshly returned in 1816 from subduing the Dey of Algiers and swollen with nationalist fervor, rose to his feet at a banquet in Norfolk, Va., and offered a notorious toast. "Our country!" he said, glass held aloft. "May she always be in the right; but our country, right or wrong." Decatur's salute is often cited as the quintessence of American patriotic feeling. It's also the kind of remark that has given patriotism a bad name.
In our own time, sentiments like Decatur's have fallen far out of fashion, but so has a more tempered and cogent kind of patriotism, a classic case of throwing out the baby with the bath water. "A patriot is a fool in every age," jeered Alexander Pope, but perhaps in no age have patriots been deemed more foolish than in our own. To confess love of country today is to invite sneers from sophisticates, to court banishment to the supposedly lunatic fringe, to risk indictment as smug, stupid and reactionary -- or, vilest of all possible epithets, corny. How did this sorry state of affairs come to be? 
 Always a plural people, Americans in recent years have grown downright fractious -- not a condition that conduces to patriotic emotion. Loyalties to tribe and race and communities both virtual and vital, not to mention ardor for mergers and startups and global networking, have apparently crowded out love of nation. The booming economy also tends to make mere sunshine patriots of us all.
"The days of palmy prosperity are not those most favorable to the display of public virtue," wrote Edward Everett -- the other speaker at Gettysburg on Nov. 19, 1863, when Abraham Lincoln managed in just three pithy paragraphs to craft a surpassing argument for devotion to American nationhood. Only "in hard, doubtful, unprosperous and dangerous times," Everett claimed in an 1860 essay, do the "patriotic find their way."
It has been a long time since privation and danger have blighted this lucky land. The Civil War was one such occasion. The era of the Great Depression and World War II was another -- a decade-and-a-half-long ordeal when widely shared penury and peril combined to nurture a feeling of common cause and to inspire a truly healthy sense of patriotic feeling. It was a momentous era, one that has lessons to teach us still, not least about our relation to our country.
The patriotism of the generation that suffered the Depression and waged the war was no witless endorsement of "our country right or wrong." So far from being "the last refuge of a scoundrel," their patriotism was the first haven of those who revered the promise of America even while recognizing its defects.
Franklin Roosevelt knew how stricken his land was. He demanded relief for the one-third of its people who were ill-housed, ill-clad and ill-nourished. But in the opening words of his first inaugural Roosevelt also affirmed that "this great nation will endure as it has endured," and in the next breath gave his famous warning that "the only thing we have to fear is fear itself." That passage amounted to a fond appreciation of the high value of American institutions, even as F.D.R. was about to extend their embrace to that excluded one-third.
Popular culture in the Depression decade reflected the same fusion of admonition and attachment. Through all the prodigious outpouring of contemporary photographs, films and writings that documented the Depression's devastation -- works like Walker Evans's and James Agee's portraits of busted tenant farmers in "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men," or Pare Lorentz's dirge for the despoiled Mississippi in his haunting film, "The River," or John Steinbeck's indictment of the ravages of capitalist agribusiness in "The Grapes of Wrath" -- there beats a clear subtext.
All throb with shame for their country, with anger at its failures, but they pulse with unmistakable affection for it, too. The critic Alfred Kazin recognized this distinctively American attitude of what might be called critical patriotism when he described the cultural mood of the 1930's as "born of the depression and the international crisis," but also suffused with a feeling of "affirmation," with "an insistence to know and to love what it knew." It was as if artists and writers in Depression-era America turned instinctively to the better angels of their nation's nature to guide their countrymen through their greatest crisis in nearly a century.
World War II, of course, unleashed a further upwelling of patriotic fervor. But even wartime patriotism was not without its critical element. Black Americans, for example, embraced the "double-V" campaign, demanding both victory over aggressors abroad and victory over discrimination at home, deftly combining loyal commitment with constructive criticism.
No less striking was the publication in 1944 of the Swedish economist Gunnar Myrdal's classic investigation of race relations, "An American Dilemma." Its basic argument was twofold: in accents that even the most red-white-and-true-blue American could endorse, Myrdal praised "the American Creed," a set of values that included "liberty, equality, justice and fair opportunity for everybody."
But he also composed a withering condemnation of racial oppression, inequality, injustice and denial of opportunity -- probing America's most vexed social issue even during the most anxious months of the war, and thereby helping to lay the foundation for the triumphs of the civil rights movement in the succeeding generation. "Let us go forth to lead the land we love," said John F. Kennedy on the eve of those triumphs. But Kennedy also branded the current treatment of black Americans as a "moral crisis," and summoned his fellow citizens to honor their own best beliefs. That second statement was surely no less patriotic than the first.
The words "patriot" and "paternal" stem from the same Latin root, meaning "father." Critical patriotism toward one's country might be likened to the love that fathers and mothers alike ideally tender to their children: unconditional, but still demanding. What good parents do not both love and challenge their young, supporting them but at the same time pushing them to be all they can be?
Stephen Decatur got it only half right. May our country always be in the right, to be sure. But the truest patriotism -- critical patriotism -- will not hesitate to hold up the mirror of this nation's better, ideal self to expose its wrongs and urge its citizens to right them. Critical patriotism demands not mindless veneration, but strict accountability. It judges as well as celebrates. It is neither foolish nor corny. It is simply necessary if this nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all of us are created equal, is to long endure.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Growth Rate Is the Slowest in 17 Months

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded in June at the slowest pace in 17 months as companies started to feel the effects of six interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve the last year, new figures showed today.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly factory index fell to 51.8 in June from 53.2 in May. June's reading was the lowest since January 1999, when manufacturing began to climb out of a yearlong slump in export sales to Asia and Latin America, but any reading above 50 still indicates an expansion. 
 "The cumulative impact of the interest-rate increases is beginning to bite," said Kenneth Mayland, president of Clear View Economics in Cleveland.
Automakers are feeling the pinch. June sales of North American-built cars and light trucks fell 5.8 percent at General Motors, 3.1 percent at Ford and 9.8 percent at DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler arm, the companies reported today. Industrywide sales fell an estimated 1.4 percent last month, the second straight monthly decrease.
At the same time, business at service companies and others not involved in manufacturing grew at a faster pace in June, another association survey showed. The association's nonmanufacturing business index rose to 64 last month from 61.5 in May, putting it close to its record of 65 set in April.
Another report today showed construction spending barely budged in May, lifted only by an increase in work on factories and office buildings. Spending rose 0.1 percent in May after falling 1.1 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. Recent data point to cooler demand for manufactured goods other than semiconductors and other electronic equipment.
Economic statistics the last month suggested higher rates started to curtail home buying and sales of cars and other retail goods. That, in turn, cut into orders for factory goods.
Today's manufacturing report showed that the production index, a gauge of current output, fell to 53.6 in June -- the lowest since January 1999 -- from 56.3 in May. The new orders index, a gauge of current demand, fell to 50.6 in June -- the lowest since December 1998 -- from 51.1 in May.
The purchasing association's prices-paid index in June fell to 61.2 -- the lowest since August 1999 -- from 65.8 in May. The prices index has fallen since March, when it reached a five-year high of 79.8.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Up On New Data On Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday in light preholiday trading, getting a boost from a manufacturing report that showed signs of an economic slowdown.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 10/32, to 103 24/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.98 percent from 6.01 percent on Friday. 
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 105 12/32, while the yield fell to 5.87 percent from 5.89 percent on Friday.
The bond market closed at 1 p.m. yesterday ahead of the Independence Day holiday today, when United States financial markets are closed.
A report from National Association of Purchasing Management found the nation's manufacturing sector grew at a significantly slower pace in June, another sign that the Federal Reserve's efforts to cool the economy by increasing interest rates are working. The manufacturing growth was considerably lower than expected.
If the economy is indeed slowing it could forestall the Fed from further increasing interest rates as it has six times in the last year to keep a lid on inflation. Higher interest rates hurt the value of bonds in circulation since they pay a fixed rate of return.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged at 96 7/32. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.91 percent.

HEADLINE: Texas Nursing Home Financial Crisis Seen

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., July 3

 BODY:
Texas nursing home operators say they are facing a financial crisis in the next two years if the state does not increase reimbursement rates or help contain rising liability costs.
"We've taken a hard look at our situation," said Tim Graves, president of the Texas Health Care Association, which represents 700 nursing homes. "We're running on fumes." 
 About 22 percent of nursing homes in Texas, with an estimated 23,000 beds, are in bankruptcy, and this could jump to as much as 45 percent, Mr. Graves said. The state would need to increase nursing home spending by as much as $800 million in the 2002-2003 budget to help the industry, he said.
State lawmakers will draft the state budget in the 2001 session.
Earlier this year, the state adopted a 3.7 percent increase in nursing home reimbursements, but industry officials said it was too small. The industry said it needed a 7 percent increase to offset the rising costs of liability insurance and labor.
The legislature, however, had authorized only enough money for the smaller increase, the same amount as the year before.
The reimbursements pay nursing homes to care for patients covered by Medicaid, the state-federal health care program for low-income people.
Industry officials say Texas nursing homes lost money every day on Medicaid patients in 1999. Health care providers say the state's $78-a-day average payment was one of the lowest in the country last year while liability coverage has tripled since 1998, raising the average premium from $650 a bed to about $1,800.

HEADLINE: Saudi Arabia to Raise Oil Production 500,000 Barrels a Day

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
In a move to bring down stubbornly high oil prices, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, announced plans yesterday to increase production by 500,000 barrels a day.
The decision will go into effect within the next few days "if the price doesn't decrease," according to a statement from the Saudi Arabian oil minister quoted by the official Saudi Press Agency. 
 The unilateral step by the Saudis comes less than two weeks after the 10-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which Saudi Arabia is the de facto leader, decided to increase production by 708,000 barrels a day, hoping to rein in crude oil prices that exceeded $30 a barrel. The price of crude instead rose, driven by the disappointment in the market that the production increase was not greater, as had been widely expected.
The announcement came after commodities markets in London closed, and the first United States reaction will only become apparent after the Independence Day holiday. Analysts believe the new increase in output will dampen crude oil prices. The increase most likely comes too late to affect United States gasoline prices this summer, analysts said, but they are cautiously optimistic that it will push down prices for heating oil, which have jumped 10 percent the last month.
"Any additional oil supply is good news for the American consumer," said John Felmy, chief economist for the American Petroleum Institute, a Washington trade group. "But demand continues to grow, so it's not clear how much prices will decline."
The 500,000 barrels a day constitute a small fraction of the 75 million barrels a day the world consumes. Typically, for every $1 decrease in the price of crude oil, there follows a 2.5 cent decline in the price of gasoline and other petroleum products.
The United States market will not see the first of the new oil until early August or so, because it takes about 40 days for Persian Gulf crude to reach American ports. By that time, gasoline prices should be tapering off on their own, as vacation season winds down and people begin to drive less. But the oil would arrive just as refineries begin to build stocks of heating oil for the winter.
The Energy Department reported last week that inventories of distillate, which includes diesel and heating oil, were 21 percent lower than last year. Surging demand for diesel has drawn distillate out of refineries as quickly as it flowed in, leading to a rapid rise in heating oil prices. New Saudi oil could ease the supply shortage and help drive heating oil prices lower, though perhaps only slightly. But recent production increases by OPEC have failed to reduce crude oil prices, primarily because robust economies, especially that of the United States, demand more oil than the cartel has so far offered. After weathering years of depressed oil prices, OPEC cut production drastically in March 1999 to boost prices. But once crude oil surpassed $30 a barrel earlier this year, OPEC came under pressure from the world's industrialized nations to raise output. The high crude prices also worried some OPEC members, particularly Saudi Arabia, which have seen worldwide recessions unfold because of costly oil.
OPEC increased output significantly this spring, with little impact on crude prices. When cartel members met again in Vienna 10 days ago, the oil market had been primed for a second increase, on the order of one million barrels a day. It was widely known that cartel members were producing an estimated 500,000 barrels a day more than they had agreed to in spring. So an increase of one million barrels a day would have brought on the market an additional 500,000 barrels of so-called new oil.
When OPEC announced a more modest increase of 708,000 barrels that would release only about 200,000 barrels of new oil, the market rejected the gesture and crude prices jumped to more than $32 a barrel.
"OPEC was really surprised that prices went higher after Vienna," said Leonidas P. Drollas, chief economist with the Center for Global Energy Studies, a London research group. "Most people expected one million barrels a day. That would have been enough for the soft landing that people had sought. But that seemed a bridge too far for the hawks in OPEC."
Hawkish OPEC members have little to gain by a more substantial increase. Of the 10 active members, all but three -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates -- are producing at full capacity. The other seven countries lose revenues with any increase in output because they lack the capacity to make up for the fall in crude prices by pumping more oil. That may explain why Saudi Arabia acted swiftly and apparently unilaterally, though in their statement the Saudis said they would raise output "in consultation with other producers." Some observers expect Kuwait and the emirates to also increase production.
The lopsided decision could increase tensions within the cartel, but that is unlikely to affect Saudi Arabia's decision. "They were getting really antsy about prices not coming down and about their inability to affect market psychology," said Roger Diwan, managing director of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington consulting group. "Now, the Saudis have taken the oil bull market by the horns and pulled it down."

HEADLINE: Big U.S. Automakers' Sales Dropped 1.4% Last Month

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 3

 BODY:
Americans bought fewer autos from General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler than expected in June, opting to buy vehicles made by Japanese and European companies or to keep the vehicles they own.
Sales of North American-built cars and trucks fell 5.8 percent at G.M. and 3.1 percent at Ford. DaimlerChrysler, beset by an aging minivan lineup, said its sales excluding Mercedes-Benz fell 9.8 percent. 
 Industrywide sales rose 0.2 percent, to 1.61 million cars and light trucks, according to the Autodata Corporation, based on reports from 17 of 24 carmakers and estimates for the rest. Monthly records by Toyota Motor, Honda Motor and gains from other overseas makers, including Volkswagen, helped surprise analysts who expected United States sales to fall 1.4 percent. First-half sales rose 6.1 percent, to a record 9.12 million.
Asian and European automakers have "competitively priced, attractive product" that is luring buyers, said David Garrity, an auto analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
Record gasoline prices, rising interest rates and stock market declines may be starting to take the wind out of a yearlong buying spree, analysts said. Even so, the estimated annual selling rate in June of 17 million is in line with record sales of 16.96 million in 1999.
The United States auto sales boom began in earnest in May 1999, when the annual selling rate hit 17.3 million. Until last year, 15 million was considered a strong performance.
Toyota, the fourth-largest automaker in the United States, reported a 7.8 percent gain, while Honda, the No. 5 maker, said sales rose 16 percent; it was the best June ever for both companies. Volkswagen of Germany said its sales rose 9 percent.
Shares of DaimlerChrysler rose $1, to $53.0625, today, while G.M. rose $1.5625, to $59.625. Shares of Ford rose 93.75 cents, to $43.9375. Sales were announced after trading closed at 1 p.m. for the Fourth of July.
General Motors sold 459,994 North American-built cars and light trucks, a bigger decline than the 5.2 percent average analyst forecast. Total sales including imports and large trucks fell 5 percent, to 472,078. Total car sales fell 2.3 percent, while total truck sales slid 8.7 percent.
Car sales in June were hurt by declines at its Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Cadillac divisions.
Ford sold 401,680 North American-built cars and light trucks in June, down 3.1 percent, compared with the 2.3 percent decline forecast. Total sales including Volvo, Jaguar and heavy trucks fell 2.6 percent, to 419,932. Total car sales declined 5.5 percent while total truck sales slipped 0.3 percent.
Ford is phasing out production of its Mercury Mystique and Ford Contour cars to build a new compact sport utility that goes on sale later this year. Sales of the Taurus car were unchanged.
The Chrysler arm of DaimlerChrysler sold 215,597 cars and light trucks in June, missing forecasts that sales would fall 5.9 percent. Car sales fell 20 percent while sales of trucks, minivans and sport utilities declined 5.8 percent. Total sales including Mercedes-Benz fell about 8.6 percent, to 233,516.
Sales of DaimlerChrysler's minivans, which will not be redesigned until later this quarter, fell 25 percent, even though discounts increased on some of the longer models.
Analysts expect United States auto sales to cool the remainder of the year because of higher interest rates and declines in the stock market, the source of some car-buyers' wealth.
The Federal Reserve's six interest rate increase in the last year "have definitely hurt, as has the market's reaction to the moves," said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va.
The United States average retail price of regular gasoline hit a record $1.681 a gallon in June. Some automakers reported softer vehicle demand in Midwest, where the average price was highest, but said gas prices did not affect sales nationwide.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

ASIA
 
MONGOLIA: FORMER COMMUNISTS WIN
The country's former Communist rulers won a landslide victory in elections on Sunday and vowed to push ahead with economic reforms while doing more to combat the social costs of the painful 10-year transition from Soviet satellite to a free market. Unofficial results showed the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party won 72 out of the 76 open parliamentary seats. The party had ruled Mongolia from the 1920's until 1996, when it was ousted by a democratic coalition. (Agence France-Presse) 

INDIA: SRI LANKA PEACE PLAN
India said it had devised a package to end fighting in Sri Lanka and was ready to take part in talks between the Sri Lankan government and Tamil rebels. Junior Foreign Minister Ajit Panja said India favored a united Sri Lanka but did not disclose details of the proposed package. Officials said Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, would send a special envoy to India this week. (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: U.S. MARINE ARRESTED IN OKINAWA
The police arrested a United States marine for allegedly molesting a 14-year-old girl, threatening to stir up already tense relations between local residents and American forces weeks before a meeting of the world's leading industrialized economies. The 19-year-old marine, accused of breaking into a home and molesting the girl in her room, denied the charge. (Agence France-Presse)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: TRUCE TALKS
Government officials and leaders of the country's main guerrilla movement, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, met in Los Pozos, 435 miles south of the capital, to exchange proposals aimed at bringing an end to decades of fighting. Their plans for an eventual cease-fire, however, were expected to contrast sharply. (Agence France-Presse)
 
EUROPE
 
SWITZERLAND: MOSSAD AGENT ADMITS SPYING
An Israeli secret service agent testified that he took part in a bungled wiretapping two years ago in the Swiss capital, Bern. The agent, using an alias for the trial, is accused of having tried to bug the apartment of a suspected Hezbollah sympathizer. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
SLOVAKIA: PRESIDENT'S POWERS TRANSFERRED
Prime Minister Mikulas Dzurinda and the Parliament speaker, Jozef Migas, have assumed the powers of President Rudolf Schuster, 66, who remains hospitalized in Austria after emergency abdominal surgery. (AP)
 
LITHUANIA: NAZI CRIMES TRIAL HALTED
A court called an indefinite halt to the country's first Nazi-era war crimes trial, citing the poor health of 93-year-old defendant, Aleksandras Lileikis. Mr. Lileikis, a former American citizen stripped of his passport, has denied charges that he turned over Jews to Nazi executioners during the German occupation of Lithuania. (Reuters)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: VIOLENCE OVER MARCH
Dozens of Protestant militants attacked police in Drumcree, Northern Ireland, with bricks and bottles after the province's Parades Commission barred members of the Protestant Orange Order from parading after services this Sunday. The commission said they could march at a future date if they agreed to speak with Catholic residents who object to the march coming through their neighborhood. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: WHITE FARMERS' BID
Zimbabwe's white farmers union said more than 200 white-owned farms would be offered for immediate sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for black resettlement. The offer came on the last day for commercial farmers to object to Mr. Mugabe's plan to seize 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to landless peasants. (Reuters)
 
SOUTH AFRICA: DISPUTE ON CAUSE OF AIDS SWIRLS
President Thabo Mbeki's administration fired back at 5,000 scientists who signed a letter affirming H.I.V. as the cause of AIDS, saying their declaration was a "waste of time" and a distraction days before the International AIDS Conference opens in the South African city of Durban. Mr. Mbeki, whose country has more H.I.V.-positive people than any other, has angered many AIDS researchers and activists by his position. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
EGYPT: PROTESTS OVER ARRESTS
Human rights groups called for the release of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, an American-Egyptian sociologist who was arrested Friday night. Mr. Ibrahim, a professor at the American University in Cairo and head of an Egyptian think tank, said he was charged with preparing a documentary about elections that harms Egypt's image and receiving foreign funds without government permission. (AP)
 
ISRAEL: MILITARY EXEMPTION BILL
After long debate, Parliament passed a preliminary bill that would legalize a practice of granting draft exemptions for ultra-Orthodox seminary students. The bill, sponsored by Prime Minister Ehud Barak, would change the present system, which keeps some religious men in school and out of the workforce well into middle age to keep their exemptions. It would allow religious students who left school to serve four months in a special unit in place of three years of mandatory service. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
PACIFIC
 
FIJI: CIVILIAN GOVERNMENT
Defying the gunmen holding the deposed government hostage, the military leader appointed a temporary civilian government but said he would retain power until the captives are freed. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who took power 10 days after rebels stormed Parliament on May 19 and seized top officials, appointed the new government without consulting the gunmen, who demanded a role. (AP)
