HEADLINE: Mexico's Democratic Breakthrough

 BODY:
Never before in the memory of living Mexicans has presidential power passed peacefully to an opposition party. But just such a transition is now under way, following the decisive victory of Vicente Fox Quesada and his center-right National Action Party, or PAN, in Sunday's Mexican elections. It is a great advance for democracy in Latin America's second-largest country and Washington's second-biggest trading partner.
Mexico began prying lose the authoritarian grip of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, more than a decade ago, as its citizens came into contact with the democratic currents sweeping Latin America and the world. Initial electoral challenges were repulsed by intimidation and fraud, or bought off with patronage. But opposition parties persisted, and during the six-year term of President Ernesto Zedillo important reforms opened up the electoral system. Statehouses fell to opposition governors. Three years ago the combined opposition won a congressional majority. That allowed scrutiny of the federal budget and cabinet ministers. But Mexico's Constitution concentrates power in the presidency. Its passage into opposition hands is a transforming event in the political life of Mexico. 
 Mexico's transition toward a modern democracy also has significance for the United States. No major policy differences divide Mr. Fox's PAN from the long-ruling PRI. But the inauguration of democratic competition at every level of Mexican politics can have a salutary effect on a wide range of issues. It can provide a check on official corruption in Mexico and mitigate the feelings of political and economic powerlessness that have driven so many Mexicans to emigrate illegally to the United States. Some officials in Washington may miss the predictability of permanent rule by the PRI. But wiser heads will see the positive potential in this week's change.
Besides winning the presidency, the PAN will also be the largest party in the Congress. But to command a majority, it will have to make deals with other political groups. This need for a broadly based government should prove healthy, encouraging the PAN to reach out to members of the center-left opposition as well as the PRI.
Catholic intellectuals formed the PAN more than 60 years ago to fight the secularism and land reform programs of Mexico's post-revolutionary governments. More recently, the PAN has evolved into a moderate pro-business party, well represented by Mr. Fox, a former chief executive of Coca-Cola in Mexico. In building his victory margin, Mr. Fox attracted considerable support from left-of-center voters, many of whom felt that ending the PRI's enduring grip on the presidency was the most important issue in this year's election.
The PRI, associated with so many electoral manipulations in the past, behaved wisely and responsibly in defeat. Its candidate, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, conceded early and gracefully, getting the lengthy five-month transition period off to a firm start. The PRI's constructive new attitude owes much to Mr. Zedillo's enlightened leadership.
Mr. Zedillo correctly understood that the only way to restore public confidence in elections was to create an independent electoral institute to supervise campaigning, balloting and the tallying of votes. Without that crucial reform, this year's generally clean campaign and Sunday's reliable count might not have been possible.
Mr. Fox will not take office until Dec. 1. Past presidential transitions have been marred by economic turmoil. In 1994, the administration of Carlos Salinas failed to coordinate its financial policies with Mr. Zedillo's incoming team, badly undermining international confidence in the peso. The result was a painful recession, which cost Mexicans dearly. Mr. Zedillo should draw the appropriate lesson from that experience. Having given Mexico its cleanest election ever, he can make a further contribution by working closely with Mr. Fox and his advisers through the crucial months ahead.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Links Drug Industry and G.O.P. to High Costs

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CLAYTON, Mo., July 3

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore today accused drug companies of "price-gouging" and "special interest schemes" to keep drug prices high, and he pledged to a crowd of the elderly to "fight for you, not for the powerful drug companies."
Mr. Gore's appearance at a community center in the swing state of Missouri began a weeklong Gore drive to highlight an issue that has emerged as one of the most potent this election season: the spiraling cost of prescription drugs. 
 The vice president worked to tie his main opponent, Gov. George W. Bush, and the Republicans in Congress to the drug industry. "It is not all that complicated," Mr. Gore said at a news conference. "Governor Bush is with the big pharmaceutical companies."
He also contended that drug companies had written the House Republicans' recently passed bill that provides a prescription drug benefit for Medicare recipients. The Republican bill would rely on private insurance companies to sell drug coverage polices to the elderly, backed by government subsidies and incentives.
"I think they crafted the actual words," Mr. Gore said.
The Democrats support a more expansive measure, relying directly on the Medicare system. Mr. Bush generally supports the House Republican plan.
Mr. Gore has a history of taking on the drug companies, dating to his years in Congress, although some of his friends and advisers now represent the pharmaceutical industry as lobbyists. His campaign advisers believe the issue allows him to draw a sharp contrast with Mr. Bush, who received more campaign contributions from the industry.
Mr. Gore's aides distributed a list of contributions that drug companies had made to Republicans. Separate figures, provided by the Campaign Study Group, a nonpartisan research organization, showed that Republican Party committees have received $4 million in unregulated "soft money" contributions from pharmaceutical companies since January 1999, while Democrats received $1.4 million.
In response to Mr. Gore's speech, the Bush campaign released a statement by Representative James M. Talent, Republican of Missouri, asserting that the Clinton administration had been "an obstacle" to overhauling Medicare for eight years.
"After eight years of failing to propose a solution," Mr. Talent said, "the vice president is now saying he wants reform."
For several years, Democrats have put the cost of prescription drugs for the elderly at the top of their agenda. With drug prices rising faster than the rate of inflation, President Clinton a year ago proposed an expansion of the 34-year-old Medicare program to cover drugs. House Democrats have been riding the issue hard in their quest to regain control of the House -- even running bus trips for the elderly to Canada and Mexico, where drug prices are lower.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, who was at Mr. Gore's side today, said House Democrats would campaign on the issue across the country this week.
Republicans originally denounced Mr. Clinton's plan as a costly expansion of a program that already faces fiscal difficulties and said they would not take it up unless it was part of a broader overhaul of Medicare.
But trying to blunt the Democrats' drive, House Republicans just before the July 4 recess pushed through on a near-party-line vote their own measure costing $40 billion over five years, changing the debate to which party's plan is better. John Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, said Republican House members were also told to conduct town meetings this week to promote their plan.
Mr. Feehery said the Republican bill avoided "a government takeover of health care" and did not rely on a "huge government bureaucracy."
Mr. Gore pointed to assertions by insurance companies that the Republican bill would not work. He said the Republican bill reminded him of a story about a veterinarian and taxidermist who "go into work together and they put up a sign saying, 'Either way, you get your dog back.' " He added, "There is a difference."
Mr. Gore today heard stories from hard-pressed elderly people, including a woman who told of buying 16 boxes of macaroni and cheese dinners because they cost only $4, saving her money for medicine.
"You've been eating macaroni and cheese for every meal?" Mr. Gore prompted her.
"I can save a little bit of it for the next day, too," said Jacqueline Steele Johnson, 72.
"We don't want to have a system where you are completely at the mercy of the big drug companies and no one is standing up for you," the vice president said. "I want to stand up for you."
The drug companies had too much power over drug costs, the vice president said.
Mr. Gore singled out for criticism the manufacturer of Claritan D, a top-selling allergy medication, because it is circulating legislation to extend its patent. He said drug patents were not designed to create a situation "where we can be just exploited forever by the wealthy and the powerful."
The Republican drug bill would offer a drug benefit to Medicare recipients that would use private insurance companies to sell drug coverage polices to the elderly, backed by government subsidies and incentives.
The difference between the Democratic and Republican approaches on prescription drugs involves philosophy and detail. The Democrats rely on the Medicare program, while the Republicans rely on incentives to private insurers to sell policies to the elderly.
Under the Republican plan, the government would set the parameters of a standard drug policy for the elderly, but premiums and co-payments could vary from one private drug plan to another as long as the overall values met the government standard. The plan envisions premiums of $35 to $40 a month. After a $250 deductible, the policies would pay for half of a recipient's annual drug costs, up to $2,100.
Mr. Gore, like other Democrats, has proposed a more generous benefit than the Republicans, which would cost $255 billion over a decade. It would carry no deductible and would cover half of the costs of drugs, up to $5,000. The premium would start at $25 a month.
The vice president's plan and that of the House Republicans would both contain subsides for low-income seniors and protections for those with high drug costs. The Republicans would provide 100 percent drug-cost coverage after an individual's out-of-pocket costs reached $6,000. Mr. Gore would pay for all expenses after out-of-pocket costs reached $4,000.
The drug industry is the second industry that Mr. Gore has gone after in recent weeks, having just finished a series of broadsides against the oil companies. Today, he hailed news that Saudi Arabia was raising oil production and called on the "big oil companies" to pass along price reductions.

HEADLINE: THE MEXICAN ELECTION: WASHINGTON;
Change in Leadership Is Welcomed as an Opportunity for Greater U.S.-Mexican Cooperation

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
The Clinton administration welcomed the transition of power in Mexico, saying today that the election of Vicente Fox Quesada was evidence of the maturing of democratic institutions and that it set the stage for economic growth.
President Clinton telephoned Mr. Fox to congratulate him, and also spoke to President Ernesto Zedillo, the departing leader, to express his gratitude for his role in strengthening democracy in Mexico. 
 "Mexicans should be proud of the extraordinary steps they have taken during the last six years to strengthen and consolidate democratic institutions and set Mexico on a course of economic growth and prosperity," Mr. Clinton said in a statement released by the White House.
Mr. Clinton dealt frequently with Mr. Zedillo in the past six years, especially after the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which saw trade between the two nations soar. The two leaders held their eleventh meeting here last month when Mr. Clinton praised Mr. Zedillo for advancing the process of trade integration with the United States.
During the campaign, the Clinton administration had been fairly scrupulous in not showing a preference for either Mr. Fox or his main opponent, Francisco Labastida Ochoa of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI.
It also had expressed confidence in the integrity of the electoral process.
That confidence was borne out in the conduct of the elections on Sunday and in the results, the White House said.
For Washington, dealing with a Mexican administration led by the PRI, which had been in power for 71 years, has been an ingrained habit that survived countless bouts of economic crisis in Mexico and American-led financial bailouts. Through all the crises, Washington was generally grateful to have a stable neighbor even though it was poor and in more recent years became the major conduit for illegal narcotics into the United States.
But Mr. Fox is not an unknown quantity in Washington. In an introductory pre-election visit here in May, he met with Under Secretary of State Thomas Pickering and gave talks at several foreign policy institutions.
He impressed people here not only as a businessman who once worked for Coca-Cola but also as a politician who understood the United States, a senior administration official said. One of his major points was further expansion of American investment in Mexico.
"He wanted to reassure us that the United States would have a good partner, that he would be reliable and would co-operate across the board," the official said. "Relations under Zedillo had reached an all-time high and we would expect Fox to continue the momentum."
But this was not to say that Mr. Fox would not inject some new ideas into the relationship.
On the three main issues between Mexico and the United States -- immigration, trade and the flow of drugs -- Mr. Fox, as a former governor of a northern Mexican state, would likely bring some fresh thinking, officials said.
During his campaign, Mr. Fox said he would like a more even relationship with Washington on the handling of immigration which, from the Mexican point of view, has largely been treated by the United States as a criminal justice and police issue.
"I think this is one issue that the new president and the new president of the United State will have to deal with quite quickly," said Andres Rozental, a business consultant in Mexico City, who was a deputy secretary of state dealing with American relations in a former Mexican government.
Mr. Rozental said he believed that Mr. Fox would like to look beyond just "managing" the question of illegal Mexican immigrants into the United States and turn toward reaching agreements with Washington that would allow better terms for semi-skilled Mexican migrants to enter the United States.
He pointed out that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had recently noted the value of semi-skilled foreign workers to the United States, and that the Treasury Department had attributed some of the economic growth during the Clinton administration to immigrant labor. This presented a "window of opportunity" for Mexico to try to persuade Washington to sit down and take a new look at immigration policies with Mexico, he said.
Despite disputes involving trucking and sugar -- two sectors in which Mexico would like a bigger share of the American market -- Mexico's trading relations with the United States have moved steadily since NAFTA was signed into law by President Clinton in 1993.
An administration official said that Mr. Zedillo had refrained from repeating the practice of his predecessors of ramping up the Mexican economy in an effort to have his party win the election.
"There is stability, not boom," in the Mexican economy, an administration official said.
There was also the prospect of continuity in the economy with the head of the central bank, Guillermo Ortiz, slated to stay. It also appeared possible that the finance minister, Jose Angel Gurria, might remain in office.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Sales in June for Big Three Were Less Than Expected
Americans bought fewer autos than expected from General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler in June, opting to buy vehicles made by Japanese and European companies or to keep the vehicles they already own.
Sales of North American-built cars and trucks fell 5.8 percent at G.M. and 3.1 percent at Ford. DaimlerChrysler, beset by an aging minivan lineup, said its sales excluding Mercedes-Benz fell 9.8 percent. Industrywide sales rose 0.2 percent, to 1.61 million cars and light trucks. Shares of DaimlerChrysler rose $1, to $53.0625, while G.M. rose $1.5625, to $59.625. Shares of Ford rose 93.75 cents, to $43.9375. Page C2. 

Start-Ups Struggle in Silicon Alley
These are trying days for Silicon Alley, an industry made up of as many as 7,000 enterprises, most of them tiny start-ups. They tend to specialize in content rather than technology, making them more vulnerable to gyrations on Wall Street. Several high-profile Internet companies in New York have gone under or are barely hanging on, and more are expected to succumb in the coming months. B1.
 
Napster Seeks to Forestall Closing
Napster, the Internet music start-up, asked a federal judge not to shut down its service, asserting in a court brief that individual Napster users are doing nothing illegal by making personal collections of copyrighted music they download over the Internet. C4.
 
Growth in Manufacturing Slows
Manufacturing expanded in June at the slowest pace in 17 months, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management, which said its monthly factory index fell to 51.8 in June from 53.2 in May. A separate report from the Commerce Department showed construction spending rose 0.1 percent in May after falling 1.1 percent in April. C5.
 
Stocks Rise in Sluggish Trading
Stocks rose broadly in light trading before the holiday as investors reacted to a lower-than-expected reading for manufacturing activity in June. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 112.78 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,560.67. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 25.82 points, or 0.7 percent, to 3,991.93, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 14.72 points, or 1 percent, to 1,469.32. C4.
 
Treasury prices rose as the yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.98 percent from 6.01 percent and the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.87 percent from 5.89 percent. C4.
 
Microsoft Bolsters Defense Team
Microsoft added more firepower to the defense team in its antitrust case by hiring Carter G. Phillips, a leading appellate lawyer. C5.
 
An Inflation Warning for Russia
Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, warned that inflation is rising at an annual rate of nearly 35 percent, a trend economists say could severely strain the incomes of Russians. Mr. Putin, who is making his first attempts at economic policy, was quoted as suggesting at a Kremlin meeting that the government should take steps to slow the pace of inflation. C2.

 
Shareholders Back Telephone Deal
Minority shareholders of Cable and Wireless voted overwhelmingly to be acquired by Pacific Century Cyberworks, an Internet company run by Richard Li. The deal needs to be ratified by a judge on July 25, but analysts say the vote guarantees that Mr. Li, 33, who runs Pacific Century, will soon own Hong Kong's flagship telephone company. C3.
 
Wireless Venture May Sell Stake
A British wireless venture backed by the Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchinson Whampoa and Telesystem International Wireless of Canada, is in talks to sell about a third of the company to NTT DoCoMo and Royal KPN for as much as $2 billion. C15.
 
U.S. Financial Markets Closed
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets, however, will be open. United States markets will reopen tomorrow.

LENGTH: 464 words

HEADLINE: Washington Reneges on a Bargain

 BODY:
Congress made a welfare deal with the states in 1996 that it now threatens to tarnish. Under the deal, the states relinquished their 60-year-old entitlement to additional federal money when their welfare rolls rise. In exchange, every state received a big fixed annual grant to cover its welfare costs. Congress also gave 17 needy states extra help in the form of supplemental grants. Congress now threatens to reclaim part of these supplemental grants.
This misguided proposal would punish poor states with high rates of child poverty. It would also send the terrible message that states will be better off if they spend money quickly and foolishly rather than slowly and well. 
 Congress provided the supplemental grants partly to help states that were paying low benefits to existing enrollees. The idea was to close some of the huge gap in benefits paid by rich and poor states. But as a soaring economy and stiff welfare reforms drove down welfare rolls by 30 percent in the years following the 1996 law, states found they did not need to spend every last federal dollar. In addition, the families left behind were often the most disadvantaged and hardest to help. Some states, needing time to figure out how to reach them, held on to their money until they could develop the right strategy.
The administration proposed many months ago to raise revenue for budget purposes by reclaiming some of the unspent supplemental grants -- an idea embraced by the House and now under consideration by the Senate. But according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group, the supplemental grants are essential in helping poorer states achieve parity in federal grants. In the beginning, these poorer states spent a smaller portion of their federal allotment than the wealthier states, creating the impression that they did not need the extra money. But their hesitancy was temporary. Now, according to the center, the states receiving supplemental grants are using more of their federal dollars than other states.
Money is not the sole answer to poverty. But a recent evaluation of an ambitious program in Minnesota shows that it can produce startling results. The Minnesota welfare program combined generous work incentives with child-care assistance and support for enrollees after they find work. The result was a decline in the number of poor people living solely on welfare and a rise in employment and marriage rates among enrollees. At a time when the federal treasury is flush with cash, Congress need not deprive states with high rates of child poverty of the money they were promised. It is also money they desperately need to help the families left behind by prosperity and facing federally imposed time limits on cash assistance.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: ADDRESSING CHANGE;
Gore and Bush Agree on Basics, But Differ Sharply on the Details

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CLAYTON, Mo., July 3

 BODY:
With their competing array of policy speeches, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush seem to be turning this election into a referendum on which candidate can best reshape government to meet the challenges of the New Economy.
From health care to education to tax cuts to Social Security, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore are placing before the voters significant questions about how some of the most fundamental public institutions should be shaped for a global, digital age that offers the prospect of sustained prosperity -- and enormous uncertainty. 
 Mr. Bush's advisers say the technology-based economy and the growth of a middle-income investor class will make voters far more responsive to Republican ideas for decentralizing government and reshaping the New Deal and Great Society programs for the elderly. Governor Bush would like the private sector to provide more government services and make people less dependent on one-size-fits-all federal programs.
Mr. Gore, on the other hand, wants to expand the traditionally Democratic entitlement programs. His aides argue that the lower and middle classes need more government assistance with education and health care and retirement pensions at a time when knowledge is ever more important to success and when employers offer less generous and less secure health and pension plans.
Those differences were on display again today as Mr. Gore promoted his plan for a Medicare prescription-drug benefit and attacked a House Republican version, supported in concept by Mr. Bush, that subsidizes private insurers to offer the coverage. Page A10.
"It's a misnomer," Mr. Gore said here in Clayton of the Republicans' plan. "It's nothing. It doesn't work."
 The face-off may not have the same high drama of the cold-war era. Nor have the two candidates focused in a sustained way on hot-button social issues the way the presidential rivals did in 1988 when crime, welfare and flag-burning were the agenda. But analysts in both parties say the stakes are high.
"The party that seizes the wave of change sweeping our economy is the one that is destined to lead for the coming generation," Peter Ross Range, the editor of The New Democrat Blueprint, a magazine of the centrist Democrats, wrote in its latest edition.
Stephen Goldsmith, Mr. Bush's chief domestic policy adviser said, "There's a big fault line here."
Some talk of the new economy is as much about symbolism as about substance. It allows Mr. Gore to try to capitalize on what should be his greatest strength, the extraordinary economic expansion of the Clinton years. And for Mr. Bush, analysts say, presenting himself as a managerial reformer lets him look less ideological than other Republicans, particularly those in Congress.
But it is also true that since the last presidential election, the economy has changed sharply. Robust growth has turned deficits into surpluses. Internet use and electronic commerce are exploding. And the stock market, while cooling somewhat in recent months, has generated huge new pools of wealth.
At the same time, new issues have arisen about the divide between the winners and losers in the New Economy, one that has produced less stable jobs and less stable benefit plans and left millions of Americans without health insurance.
"The challenge of the New Economy, one of the biggest challenges, is to expand the winners' circle so you don't leave people behind," said Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist Democrat organization. "Because one of the dangers of the New Economy is if you leave too many people behind and you have a backlash."
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush agree on some broad themes. They both embrace free trade in the increasingly global economy, in contrast to the third-party contenders, Patrick J. Buchanan and Ralph Nader, and many Congressional Democrats.
They also each call for the federal government to take a stronger role in education policy at a time when the knowledge-based economy rewards the higher educated. And they each speak frequently of helping those whom prosperity has left behind.
Still, the two have fundamental differences about how to shape government.
For example, Mr. Gore would expand three government entitlement programs, Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. He would bring more of the uninsured under the auspices of Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. He would create a new Medicare prescription-drug benefit for the elderly. And he would offer more Social Security benefits to women.
In addition to Social Security, he would also create a new retirement benefit for the working poor and the middle class.
Mr. Bush argues for more individual choice. So he would allow workers to divert an unspecified part of their Social Security payroll tax to private investment accounts. He would turn Medicare from a fee-for-service guaranteed benefit program to one that lets people buy different levels of health insurance.
And while he too would create a prescription-drug benefit for the elderly, he wants to create subsidies for private insurers so that they, not the government directly, would offer the benefit. He would give tax credits for health insurance but send people to the private market to buy it.
A similar contrast concerns education. Both men would invest in schools and teachers -- Mr. Gore putting in about 10 times more money than Mr. Bush -- and both have plans for how to improve accountability and performance. But two proposals are particularly telling.
Mr. Gore would extend the reach of public-school systems by giving states grants to create public pre-schools. Mr. Bush, as a lever against failing schools, would give low-income parents whose children attend such schools vouchers that could pay for private-school tuition.
And while both candidates favor tax cuts, they differ in method and degree.
Mr. Bush calls for a $1.3-trillion across-the-board tax cut over a decade, saying, "A government with unlimited funds soon becomes a government of unlimited reach." Mr. Gore offers $500 billion in tax cuts intended to reimburse people for particular needs -- like child care or college tuition -- and phasing out as income rises.
Mr. Bush's aides call the top-down, big-government structures outmoded relics of the Great Depression. "Governor Bush will put more control over decisions -- whether they are health, retirement or savings -- in the hands of individuals," Ari Fleischer, a Bush spokesman, said. "The vice president will maintain them in the hands of government."
Democrats respond that Mr. Bush's ideas would erode the common commitment to many government institutions.
"The big danger with a lot of the Bush programs is what we call cherry-picking," said Robert Reich, the former labor secretary. "The healthy, the wealthy or the well-educated will be the first to opt out, leaving the poor, the sicker and the lesser-educated behind in the general insurance pools or in the education system. This is a sure-fire recipe for social stratification."
Mr. Gore's aides are also trying to turn the debate to the issue of whom the competing plans help, particularly pointing to the tax cuts.
"Bush takes the old-fashioned approach of cutting everybody's rates which ends up really, really, really helping wealthy people because they pay so much and being of marginal help, if any, to people in lower brackets," said Elaine Kamarck, Mr. Gore's policy director.
Mr. Bush promotes his tax cut by saying it would remove six million low-income families from the tax rolls. Critics say it would also give most of its benefits to higher-income groups simply because those pay the most taxes.
An analysis by Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal public policy group, found that Mr. Bush's plan would give the top 1 percent of tax payers 42 percent of the tax cuts, while the bottom 20 percent of tax payers would get less than 1 percent.
Mr. Bush's aides counter that their approach to tax cuts gives individuals more choice on how to use their money. "Gore views government's roles as manipulating people and uses people's own tax money to manipulate their behavior," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser. "Bush says it's your money. You keep it. Do what you think is best with it."
A similar debate is brewing over Social Security. Depending on how it is structured, Mr. Bush's plan to switch some Social Security payroll tax to individual savings accounts could prove more lucrative for upper-income groups.
If two percentage points of payroll tax were diverted to individual investment accounts, someone earning $76,000 annually would have slightly more than $1,500 a year to invest in private markets. Someone earning $25,000 would have $500 to invest. Critics of the idea say it is not hard to see which taxpayer is likely to build up the better retirement account.
Some plans on Capitol Hill try to address this by cutting the basic Social Security benefit more for higher-income individuals than lower-income ones or by giving extra contributions to low-income workers. Mr. Bush has said the idea of matching funds for the lower incomes should be considered. But he has not committed to it.
Mr. Gore would preserve the current Social Security system, and create a new retirement plan in addition to it. This plan would be similar to a 401 (k) plan and geared toward helping lower-income groups.
For example, the government would give couples earning less than $30,000 a year $3 for every dollar they put in this savings account; the government match would then reduce as income grew. The program would not be available to couples earning more than $100,000.
Mr. Bush's aides also say Mr. Gore would make Medicare and Social Security more expansive and costly at a time when the boomer generation's impending retirement threatens to bankrupt the systems.
"The fundamental challenge facing the next president is to solve this problem," Mr. Lindsey said. "What Gore just proposed is layering another new unfunded entitlement on top of what's already out there."
Mr. Bush's aides also prefer to steer the debate to how people are helped. They say they want to give people with lower incomes the same kinds of choices the wealthy have -- whether it is the choice of attending a private school or the choice of investing their retirement money in the stock market.

HEADLINE: Shift in the Mix Alters the Face Of California

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 30

 BODY:
At some unknown moment between now and July 1, 2001, if demographers are right, California will become the first big state in which non-Hispanic whites are officially no longer a majority. Or, to put it another way, California will become by far the largest proving ground for what it may eventually be like to live in a United States in which no one racial or ethnic group predominates.
The California of postwar popular imagination, of the Beach Boys and the John Birch Society, of Disneyland and monochromatic Pleasantvilles full of aerospace workers, is not dead. But it is, literally, dying fast. Non-Hispanic whites now account for about three-quarters of the deaths in California, and barely a third of the births. As recently as 1970, the state was 80 percent white. 
 Some experts argue that this shift, fueled by millions of new immigrants, mostly Latin American and Asian, and the higher birth rates of foreign-born residents has already taken place and has yet to be reflected in estimates by the state Department of Finance only because of counting glitches. It has already had striking social, political, economic and psychic effects, including bitterly fought ballot initiatives to cut government services for illegal immigrants, and to end state affirmative action programs and bilingual education. Polls show that the disappearing white majority is generally more pessimistic than other groups.
But with the state's economy booming again, and the overall population expected to grow by close to 18 million in the next 25 years, Californians are grappling anew with the meaning of this momentous shift, which the State Department of Finance now projects will happen sometime in the next year, and many are finding reasons for optimism.
"Who knows when that line is crossed, but it surely will be," said Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat. "I believe leadership requires one to look on the bright side. There's no question that a more diverse population creates some potential discomforts and even potential conflicts, but it also brings great strengths."
The demographic shift has begun to change the state's politics as scores of Hispanic voters have registered as Democrats in a backlash spurred by Republican-led campaigns against illegal immigration. That is complicating efforts by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to make inroads in a state where his aides believe his Southwestern brand of Republicanism should be appealing.
In Los Angeles, where the demographic transition has already occurred, it is at once invisible and omnipresent, apparent in the miles of neighborhoods where signs are printed in every language but English. This city has the largest population of Koreans outside Korea and the largest concentration of Iranians in the Western world, a polyglot port of entry comparable to New York at the turn of the last century. The region's latest gang battle is between Hispanics and Armenians in the once lily-white suburb of Glendale.
California is not the first state where non-Hispanic whites will not constitute a majority; they do not in Hawaii, whose population is mainly Asian and Pacific Islander. In the past, there have been times when they have not been a majority in New Mexico, while before the Civil War, South Carolina had a black majority.
But California is the biggest state to experience the shift, and for longtime residents, the changes seem breathtaking. Just 40 years ago, the most common language of foreign-born Californians was English, reflecting the population of British and Canadian immigrants, said Peter Schrag, the former editorial page editor of The Sacramento Bee and the author of "Paradise Lost: California's Experience, America's Future" (1998), a study of the state government's failures to deal with social and economic change.
"In the history of the state, we've gone up and down on this issue, and there's a kind of inherent ambivalence," Mr. Schrag said of the demographic diversity. "But a lot of it is conditioned by economic circumstances. When times are good, we like these folks, because they give us cheap labor. And when times are bad, we say, 'Who are these damn Mexicans taking our jobs away or using public welfare?' I'm not saying that's a cycle we're fated to live with for the rest of our existence, but it's been the pattern."
The prevailing classification scheme of demographic groups is itself fraught with anomalies. "Hispanic" is an ethnic description, not a racial one, that lumps together Latin Americans of all descriptions: whites, blacks, mixed-race people, and descendants of Mayans, Aztecs, Incas and other Indian groups.
Similarly, "white" in the California usage can include immigrants from the Middle East who may be dark skinned. By this standard, some analysts argue that Californians of Anglo-European ancestry have actually been a minority here since sometime in the late 1980's.
One such analyst is Ron Unz, the Republican millionaire who sponsored the 1998 measure to end bilingual education in the public schools in an effort to help forge what he sees as the state's best hope: a new multiethnic assimilationism that could avoid the racial wars of the past.
"Asians and Latinos are intermarrying at 30, 40, 50 percent rates, so the reality of the melting pot is stronger than ever," Mr. Unz said. "But the ideology has been driven out of the public arena. Very few members of the media or politicians are talking in terms of glorifying and ratifying the melting pot, so whether assimilation is doing well or not depends a lot on how you define the terms."
When California joined the union 150 years ago, it was the nation's most diverse state, with a population of international adventurers drawn by the Gold Rush. But beginning with the Southern California real estate boom of the 1880's, Midwestern whites poured in, and ever since, the state has followed cyclical patterns of welcoming, and then rejecting, immigrants, from the Asian exclusion laws of the late 19th century to Proposition 187, the 1994 ballot measure sponsored by the Republican governor at the time, Pete Wilson, to cut off social services for illegal immigrants. Blacks have never been the presence here that they have in other large, industrialized states.
The current estimated population of 34 million includes 17.4 million non-Hispanic whites, 10.7 million Hispanics, 3.9 million Asians or Pacific Islanders and 2.3 million blacks.
Anxiety over immigration seems to have abated. By 1998, polls found that fewer than 10 percent identified either legal or illegal immigration as a major concern, and recent surveys by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group, show residents about evenly divided over whether immigrants are a benefit or a burden, with whites the most skeptical. In various surveys, Hispanics, who are expected to surpass non-Hispanic whites in total population by 2025 and become an absolute majority by 2040, express more optimism about the future.
"Optimism is alive in the barrios," said Harry P. Pachon, a political scientist who directs the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research organization with branches at the Claremont Graduate University and the University of Texas. "It is constantly being renewed by an influx of immigrants and however bad things are, relative to the home country, things are better here.
"The dispersion of a population of color throughout California means that white Californians now routinely see others who are unlike them," Dr. Pachon added. "So at a political level, the anti-immigration rhetoric has subsided. But nativist groups are sitting out there in the wings, and we can't underestimate how some of that is bubbling under the surface and may erupt in an economic downturn."
Nearly three million legal immigrants came to California between 1980 and 1994, and perhaps another two million entered illegally. Analyses are divided over the net costs and benefits, though a rough consensus suggests that the short-term costs have been high and the long-term benefits are potentially great, as new generations of immigrants assimilate and fuel the economy.
"This plurality that we have is what allows us to be so creative," said Maria Contreras-Sweet, the state's Mexican-born secretary of business, transportation and housing. "In Silicon Valley or wherever, as you're developing a product, you're doing so mindful of the different needs and cultural nuances of world markets."
The political implications of the change are hard to predict. Hispanics accounted for nearly all of the increase of one million registered voters over the last decade, and went from about 4 percent of the electorate in the 1990 gubernatorial election to 14 percent two years ago, while whites declined to 74 percent from 84 percent in the same period and blacks shrunk to 7 percent from 8 percent. The new Hispanic voters are predominantly Democratic, in what is regarded as a protest against Mr. Wilson and Proposition 187.
Yet in other ways, surveys show, including a recent extensive statewide sampling by the nonpartisan Field Institute of San Francisco, the overall ideology of Hispanic voters is similar to California voters on the whole, with nearly half calling themselves middle-of-the-road. On some issues, like abortion, Hispanic voters tend to be more conservative than other groups as a whole.
And though California is often celebrated as the crucible of trends, and other big states like Texas, Florida, New York and Illinois are on the road to becoming similarly diverse, demographers note that the nation will not catch up to California's diversity until midcentury, and even then small, interior states may remain disproportionately white.
"It's not the precursor for the rest of the country," said William H. Frey, a demographer at the Milken Institute in Santa Monica. "A lot of white, baby-boomer retirees are going to be moving to the Rocky Mountain West and the South Atlantic states and other high-amenity states."
But even some of the most pessimistic critics of California's experience find hope in the prospect of diversity and rising intermarriage.
"The California that I love is incipiently Hawaii," said Mike Davis, who wrote "City of Quartz" and other studies of the California dream's downside. "That's not to embrace multiculturalism, everybody in their little box, but to embrace all the leakage and the fact that the boxes don't work anymore. Here in L.A. you have this seashore that could be Polynesian, but it's been owned by Midwesterners for most of the 20th century who built this Puritan city on the edge of the Pacific. For generations, Hawaii's been trying to break out of that, and there's a real chance for that again this generation."

HEADLINE: Taking Stands and Taking Shots, Lazio Hops a Bus for Campaign Tour

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 3

 BODY:
Representative Rick A. Lazio began a five-day bus tour across the state today, balancing an effort to direct his United States Senate campaign toward issues against consistent attacks on his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
At times, he managed to do both. 
 After beginning his tour with a visit to a Long Island health clinic, where he called for more money for breast cancer research and took credit as the "point man in the House" on cancer issues, he labeled Mrs. Clinton's effort to come up with a universal health care plan a "monstrosity."
At times, he overlooked apparent incongruities.
At a rally in Yonkers before about 75 supporters, Mr. Lazio said Mrs. Clinton "can't get out of the motorcade" to empathize with drivers frustrated by high gasoline prices. But he did so while standing in front of his large, idling, customized campaign bus -- hardly a model of fuel economy -- which had just been escorted by motorized police through city streets.
Mr. Lazio, a Republican, is on his second such bus tour since beginning his campaign May 20. He is making the most of a Congressional recess after a few weeks of being largely pinned down in Washington while Mrs. Clinton went on the offensive with strident language on the stump and a barrage of attack television advertisements. She, too, plans a tour upstate later this week, as both candidates court voters in a region campaign officials see as crucial to victory in November.
Mr. Lazio's tour, orchestrated down to the kind of attire he will wear at certain stops, will include campaign staples like parade appearances, including three planned for Independence Day. But as he rides a bus named "Mainstream Express," he will also use campaign stops to highlight legislation he has sponsored or supported and make pointed contrasts to Mrs. Clinton. Mixed in will be traditional party rallies, like one here tonight that drew about 50 people to a park under a steady drizzle.
Mr. Lazio used strong language today, but some of the strongest words came from his surrogates, including Mayor John Spencer of Yonkers, a Republican who at the rally in his city railed against "elite Democratic liberals looking down the nose of the people of Yonkers."
And as he boarded his bus, Mr. Lazio's campaign aides blasted a snippet from a Ray Charles song, "What'd I Say": "Tell your ma, tell your pa, going to send you back to Arkansas."
In an interview, Mr. Lazio said he was merely reciprocating the negative campaigning that Mrs. Clinton had started, a claim the Clinton campaign disputes. "We were in the race for less than a month before she personally went on the attack and began airing these negative distortion ads," Mr. Lazio said.
He continued tonight, telling supporters at the Schenectady rally that "character does count," as well as integrity, without directly accusing Mrs. Clinton of lacking either.
Mr. Lazio's theme today was health care, and he toured a hospital in Suffern, in Rockland County, and a clinic in Brentwood, on Long Island, to speak on women's health issues. He referred to legislation he co-sponsored last year that provides Medicaid to poor women needing treatment for breast and cervical cancer. He counts the bill, which eventually passed, among his signature achievements, although House Democrats often assert that the Republican leadership stalled its passage.
Mr. Lazio also urged the passage of a bill he introduced last week that would continue financing for breast cancer research through the sale of postage stamps. "We need to make sure we put the foot on the research accelerator," he said in Brentwood.
Mrs. Clinton's campaign office issued a statement deriding Mr. Lazio's record on health care and criticizing him for not supporting a "patients' bill of rights" backed by Democrats last fall that would have allowed people more latitude to sue their health maintenance organizations over mistreatment.
"Carefully staged photo ops won't change the fact that Rick Lazio has committed legislative malpractice," Howard Wolfson, a spokesman for the Clinton campaign, said in the statement. "He voted against a real patient's bill of rights, against a prescription drug plan that will cover all seniors, and voted to cut Medicare by $270 billion. For New Yorkers looking for real health care solutions, Rick Lazio's rhetoric is a bitter pill to swallow."

HEADLINE: With Light Show, Jersey City Hopes to Make a New Name for Itself

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 3

 BODY:
Call it a case of light-show envy.
Long overshadowed by its neighbor across the Hudson, this booming back-office hub will not allow itself to be entirely upstaged by Macy's 60,000 exploding rockets, most of which will burst just beyond the view of the 250,000 people expected to gather Tuesday night in Jersey City's Liberty State Park. 
 With millions of spectators oohing and aahing over the pyrotechnics on the New York side, Jersey City officials proudly plan to launch their own illuminated extravaganza Tuesday night, an eight-and-a-half-minute splash of psychedelic imagery projected on the facade of a new 10-story office building that faces Manhattan. The weeklong show, which was to begin tonight but was rained out, is to be visible each night from sundown until 1 a.m. It is the work of Rudi Stern, 63, a lighting artist who has collaborated with the likes of Igor Stravinsky, Timothy Leary and the Doors over a 40-year career.
But unlike parts of New York's fireworks display, which Jersey City's mayor, Bret Schundler, has loudly complained will be hidden from viewers in his city, Mr. Stern's illuminated projections are clearly visible to those on the opposite side of the river. "We're sharing our show with everyone," said Mr. Schundler, who is planning to run for governor in 2001. "We just wish they would share theirs with us."
Of course, Jersey City's "Theater of Light," as it is called, is not meant to compete with New York's fireworks display, which is being billed as the largest in history. It is a relatively modest affair, a $60,000 production that includes prerecorded music and a 50-foot-high kaleidoscope of hand-painted abstractions, which Mr. Stern describes as "a romantic voyage and visual story involving sensual shapes and forms."
The installation, using municipal money, says a lot about how this city of 238,000 is trying to reinvent and market itself, especially now that it is no longer an economic basket case. As its waterfront bulges with office construction, drawing scores of companies from Manhattan, Jersey City officials want to make sure that it does not end up as a staid collection of buildings best known for cheap rents, low taxes and nice views.
Stuart Koperweis, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said many prospective tenants tell him they have no interest in relocating to a sterile office park, no matter how enticing the rents are. "At this point, development is taking care of itself," he said. "Now, we have to let people know that Jersey City has all the amenities of a great city, including art and culture."
City officials boast about their special arts district, where rents are shielded from steep increases, and the old Jersey Loews, a 1929 movie palace once destined for demolition but now being restored as a nonprofit performance space. In an impressive sign that Jersey City is becoming more culturally relevant, workers broke ground in April on an $11 million museum to showcase the work of Jersey City artists.
Eager to raise his city's profile, Mayor Schundler said it was no coincidence that the light show was largely aimed at those living on the other side of the river. "With all the national media here for the Fourth of July, we're literally beaming our message to the world," he said.
"It's a chance for us to flaunt the artistic abilities of our citizens."
In that sense, it is especially fitting that the city has chosen Mr. Stern for its cross-Hudson flourish. Mr. Stern, a longtime resident of Lower Manhattan, moved to Jersey City last year after he was unable to find an affordable space to construct his sprawling light displays. Like the dot-com start-ups, accounting firms and investment banks that have fled Manhattan rents, Mr. Stern, who had never before set foot here, said he was surprised by what he found. "It's so diverse, so vibrant," he said.
This is the first time that Mr. Stern is trying to show his work on a building, and he said he was finding it hard to persuade all the tenants of 90 Hudson Street to turn off their lights or shade their windows after sunset. "With all the moldings and mullions, it's like projecting onto a crossword puzzle," he said. "If the facade isn't dark, it just doesn't look right."
Using nail polish and paint, Mr. Stern creates his images on glass and transfers them to Mylar scrolls, which are fed through 350-pound projectors with huge 6,000-watt bulbs. The result is colorful but understated. Those expecting a soul-shaking display of light and booming sound, he said, may be underwhelmed.
Across the river, Macy's officials expressed annoyance over Mr. Schundler's repeated claims of being snubbed, saying their fireworks would be visible from all points along the Jersey City riverfront. "They can see them bright and beautiful," said Ronnie Taffet, a spokeswoman.
Though she said she had not heard about Mr. Schundler's light show, she said it was in no way competition. "I'm sure it will be nice," she said. "But it just can't compare to 60,000 shells going off at once."

Voters in Mexico End A Monopoly on Power
Election returns showed that Mexican voters handed the opposition presidential candidate Vicente Fox Quesada a substantially more decisive victory over the governing party on Sunday than any poll had predicted. With almost all ballots counted, Mr. Fox had 43 percent, to 36 percent for Francisco Labastida Ochoa, the candidate of the party that has governed Mexico for 71 years. But when the dust settles on the first democratic transition of power in Mexico's history, no major party, including Mr. Fox's center-right party, will control either house of Congress. A1
 
Mexicans seemed stunned but excited by Mr. Fox's triumph, and a feeling of empowerment echoed among people of many backgrounds. A7

HEADLINE: THE MEXICAN ELECTION: Man in the News;
The 'Sell Me' Politician the Mexicans Bought

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 3

 BODY:
The confirmation of his election as president of Mexico was still hours away, the victory real only in the computers of his pollsters, but Vicente Fox Quesada was already three steps down the road. There would be a quick sip of Champagne, a victory speech, and then he would get to work.
"Right tomorrow I want to be working," Mr. Fox told an American journalist in between nonstop interviews handled over his ever-present cell phone. "My hobby is work. It enchants me. I thoroughly enjoy it." 
 Mr. Fox, who turned 58 on the day that Mexicans elected him the first president in the nation's modern history from an opposition party, is nothing if not a man of considerable ambition and energy. He is a politician who once told his political marketing strategist to "sell me" like any other product.
By background he is a rancher's son whose career has traversed business and politics. A manufacturer of cowboy boots and a former Coca-Cola executive, Mr. Fox entered politics by being elected a congressman and later was a governor.
But perhaps more than anything else, Mr. Fox is a maverick. In Congress half of his votes followed the line of his conservative, pro-business party. The other half were leftist positions, many of them backed by the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which he vanquished on Sunday night.
Even before his campaign began, he was careful to manage expectations. "Ending 70 years of dictatorship will be a great heroic exploit for Mexico," he said, "something like when you Americans put a man on the moon. Reaching the moon took a decade of work, and defeating the ruling party will also require lots of time, talent and money."
During the campaign, Mr. Fox sought to allay fears that turmoil might result were he to prevail by pledging to form what he has called a government of transition. After his victory, he reiterated those promises, extending friendly messages to his rivals and calling for unity.
Indeed, as governor of Guanajuato in central Mexico from 1995 until he resigned to campaign for president, Mr. Fox appointed a woman with ties to the PRI as his state auditor and enlisted the help of a member of the largest leftist party to devise programs to benefit rural women.
Undoubtedly the government he will lead will contrast sharply with those of the 13 consecutive PRI presidents before him, partly because he is likely to bring his business instincts to the job.
When he formed his campaign team last fall, Mr. Fox asked a headhunting firm to locate superstar executives to act as his top aides. He is unabashed at using marketing techniques for political communication.
"Look at me as a product, and figure out how to sell me," Mr. Fox said to Francisco Ortiz, the former Procter & Gamble marketing wizard he hired to direct his broadcast campaign, Mr. Ortiz recalled in an interview.
Although Mr. Fox ran as the candidate of the center-right National Action Party, he reached out to leftist intellectuals across Latin America, and in discussion groups he demonstrated considerable political flexibility, said Jorge Castaneda, a liberal New York University professor and author who lives here part-time.
"These people were from a different world, ideologically and socially, and he was learning how to get along," Mr. Castaneda said. "These were establishment and leftist intellectuals. They dressed differently; they liked different things. To put it mildly, he was not in his element. But he'd sit down and he'd manage."
Dick Morris, the American political consultant, who worked for Mr. Fox, said: "Vicente Fox is a phenomenon. This has not been a situation where the consultant runs the campaign. Fox has a chemistry with the people of Mexico that is beyond belief."
Born on July 2, 1942, in Mexico City, Mr. Fox spent his childhood on an 1,100-acre ranch in San Francisco del Rincon, Guanajuato, purchased during the Mexican Revolution by his paternal grandfather, an immigrant to Mexico of Irish descent.
His mother, Mercedes Quesada, was born in Spain, a legal impediment for Mr. Fox's eventual political ambitions until a clause barring the children of immigrants from serving as president was eliminated from the Mexican Constitution.
Mr. Fox has eight siblings. His father was a prosperous landholder, although not vastly wealthy in Mexican terms.
"Something I'm proud of is that I became good friends with the children of the smallholders and peasants," he wrote in a campaign autobiography. "With them I shared my infancy, my playthings, my house and my food. From that time I began to understand our country's painful inequalities."
A Catholic, he was educated by Jesuits and spent a year at an academy in Prairie du Chien, Wis., learning among other things how to speak fluent but accented English.
He could be the most unapologetically religious of Mexico's modern presidents. The governing party that coalesced after the Mexican Revolution of 1917 had a strong anticlerical bias, and the armies of the revolutionary governments that ruled during the 1920's carried out a violent counterinsurgency against Catholic rebels in the west-central region that surrounds Mr. Fox's birthplace.
Mr. Fox has expressed historical fascination with the legacy of the Catholic insurgents, known as Cristeros, and during his campaign often ended rallies with a Cristero war cry: "If I advance, follow me! If I stop, push me! If I retreat, kill me!"
If his predecessors have learned the country's local idiosyncracies as military men or as bureaucrats, Mr. Fox's sense for the texture of grass-roots life came as a route supervisor for Coke, working in six cities in seven years. After his transfer to Mexico City in 1971, he climbed to the top of Coke's corporate hierarchy, serving as its chief executive in Mexico from 1975 to 1979.
"What I hated most about those years at Coca-Cola was the time I had to spend dithering with the government," he said recently, recalling how the president would convene meetings of Mr. Fox and hundreds of other business executives to the presidential palace "so we could listen to a lot of foolishness."
In 1979, Coke offered to make Mr. Fox the head of its Latin American operations, which would have required that he move to Miami. Instead, he quit and returned to Guanajuato to work with his brothers.
While at Coke, Mr. Fox married his secretary, Lillian de la Concha, and the couple adopted four children. They were divorced in 1991.
The early 1980's saw many devaluations of the Mexican peso, and Mr. Fox has said that the harrowing experience of running a small business with a chaotic economy helped convince him of the need for political change.
During that economic turmoil, Mexico's opposition forces were achieving their first major victories in local elections in the north, and in 1988 dozens of entrepreneurs ran for Congress representing the National Action Party, including Mr. Fox.
He won, served one term and then ran for governor in 1991, losing an election marred by fraud. Four years later he won. Three years into his governorship, he began his quest for the presidency.

HEADLINE: A Few Ways to Spend $60 Billion

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In deciding whether or not we Americans should spend $60 billion to build an antimissile system (front page, June 30), two questions must be answered. 
 First, would it be able to destroy incoming missiles consistently? Qualified people, other than those who would benefit economically or politically from its construction, have expressed consistent skepticism.
Second, if peace and security are our goal, is military hardware the best investment? For example, might we live in a world of less risk if we invested the $60 billion in promoting primary education and public health in low-income countries, thereby improving living conditions and good will toward the United States?
For the sake of future generations, we should not permit this discussion to be framed and monopolized by the military-industrial complex, and the politicians who do their bidding.
 
STEVE LUBY
Stone Mountain, Ga., July 2, 2000

HEADLINE: THE MEXICAN ELECTION: THE OVERVIEW;
MEXICO, VOTING IN NEW LEADER, BEGINS A POLITICAL SEA CHANGE

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 3

 BODY:
Swept to power by younger, better-educated voters fed up with corruption and one-party rule, President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada today began the transition from a republic led for decades by autocratic presidents to one in which political power suddenly seemed up for grabs.
As Mr. Fox fielded congratulatory phone calls today from world leaders, including President Clinton, and met with President Ernesto Zedillo, election returns showed that Mexican voters on Sunday handed him a substantially more decisive victory over the governing party than any poll had predicted. 
 With 93 percent of the ballots tabulated, the Mexican electoral agency reported that Mr. Fox had won 43 percent of the votes, while Francisco Labastida Ochoa, the candidate of the governing party, won 36 percent and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, a leftist candidate, 17 percent.
Mr. Fox will take office on Dec. 1.
For many Mexicans it was still sinking in today that after 71 years, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which evolved from an alliance of revolutionary generals into a model nationalist party imitated across Latin America before degenerating into a clique of corrupt insiders, was finally deposed from the presidency.
But when the dust settles on the first democratic transition of power in this country's history, for the first time none of the major parties -- the deposed one, Mr. Fox's center-right party or the largest leftist grouping -- will be in control of either house of Congress.
At a news conference tonight, Mr. Fox said he had assured President Zedillo that he did not intend to carry out a purge of the government bureaucracy, at least in the first stage of his new administration. The two leaders agreed to meet frequently between now and December to plan next year's budget and to discuss the transition, Mr. Fox added.
"Our team will take office with creative ideas and new philosophies, but there'll be no change in federal work rhythms," Mr. Fox said. "Mexico will be a country on the move, headed by a government that keeps its commitments."
Mr. Fox will preside over a government unused to coalition politics but one in which all major business will require the consent of one or the other of his rival parties.
"All the parties are going to have to relearn the art of making politics," said Carlos Elizondo Mayer-Serra, a political scientist who is rector of the Center for Research and Teaching. "The fundamental pillars of Mexico's political system have changed."
These unsettled results were reflected around the country. Mr. Fox's National Action Party won the two governors' seats up for grabs on Sunday and will now govern in 7 of Mexico's 31 states. In Mexico City, the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., retained control of the mayor's office, but the president-elect's party took control of the City Council.
As president, Mr. Fox will face the ticklish task of meeting the hopes for quick and sweeping change of the diverse voters who backed him. He has promised, simultaneously, to modernize the economy and spur 7 percent growth, carry out political reforms and initiate an "educational revolution."
He has pledged to better the lot not only of the largely young, middle-class professionals in his own party, but also millions of poor urban workers as well as dirt farmers who have in the past supported the governing party.
"We've all got to get to work right away," Mr. Fox said in an interview early today after his triumph. "I want to be certain to deliver good results to the people of Mexico, to govern and to govern well."
The election results provoked a debate over how successfully President Zedillo's party would navigate its journey from its powerhouse position into the ranks of the opposition. Some said the party had already proven its adaptability and resilience in states where Mr. Fox's party had already won control of the governors' chairs.
But others, comparing the position of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, to some Communist parties in Eastern Europe, argued that without presidential support and control over federal patronage, the party would crumble.
Dulce Maria Sauri, the party chairwoman during the presidential campaign, quickly announced her resignation, and some party officials said they feared that it could be the first in a significant exodus.
The results of the elections to fill all 128 seats in the Senate and all 500 in the Chamber of Deputies indicated that Mr. Fox's party would finish with its powers significantly enhanced, mainly at the expense of the leftist P.R.D., with which it shared opposition powers during the last legislature. Still, it will not control a legislative majority.
The PRI lost the Senate majority it had enjoyed since the party's creation, and without the power of the president to coordinate its efforts, the PRI's entire legislative delegation will wield considerably less strength.
Mr. Fox's party was receiving 38 percent of the votes for Congress, the returns showed. The PRI was receiving 36 percent and the P.R.D. 18 percent.
As the ballot counting continued, Mr. Zedillo met privately in the presidential compound with the top PRI leaders. Aides said Mr. Zedillo had outlined his views of the challenge to the survival of the party, which had gone undefeated in presidential voting -- often through the simple exercise of its vast powers of patronage and public works and sometimes through outright ballot fraud -- for 71 years.
In a second encounter, Mr. Zedillo addressed the 21 of Mexico's 31 state governors who belong to his party, urging them to cooperate fully with Mr. Fox's government.
"The PRI is like the phoenix," Melquiades Morales, the PRI governor of Puebla, told reporters as he entered the meeting. "It will rise again from its own ashes."
If Mexico is entering absolutely new political terrain with the PRI's defeat, neither foreign nor domestic investors appeared concerned. The Mexican stock market surged 6.1 percent on news of Mr. Fox's victory, and the value of the peso, which had been battered in recent weeks as nervous Mexicans converted savings to dollars, climbed 2.7 percent.
"Investors are very enthusiastic," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, president of Ecanal, a Mexico City consulting firm. "The market is seeing Fox as a man who can bring important changes, in the sense of modernizing the economy and the system."
In the interview early today, hours after his triumph became apparent, Mr. Fox outlined his hopes to forge tighter relations with the United States, where he has traveled extensively and attended high school for a year, in Wisconsin.
"Fortunately, I know well the philosophy of the American people, because I've worked all my life there both in business and in politics," he said. "I know that we are going to be able to accomplish many things together. We can develop our great potential, which still stretches before us. I want to work intensely with the United States because it is the world's largest market. It's our neighbor. It's our partner."
Mr. Fox offered words of conciliation to Mr. Labastida and to Mr. Cardenas, after having traded extraordinarily harsh criticisms with both during the campaign.
Of Mr. Labastida, he said: "I send him my regards. I recognize his participation and his passion in defending his ideas."
In a victory speech, Mr. Fox said he would withdraw the libel suit he filed last week against his rivals, who had accused him, without providing documentation, of accepting illegal campaign donations from a Belgian company.
"Ours is going to be a government of national concord, a government of unity, a government with its eyes fixed on the future," Mr. Fox said.
President Clinton called Mr. Fox this morning to congratulate him on the election.
Several delegations of international observers praised the elections as well organized and free of fraud. Jimmy Carter called the elections "a turning point of great significance."
Analysts were puzzled about why Mr. Fox's victory was far more extensive than most surveys had predicted. Several polls had shown Mr. Fox and Mr. Labastida running neck and neck, but Mr. Fox won by a 9-point margin.
Stanley Greenberg, an American pollster who worked on contract to the PRI, said Mr. Labastida had failed to compete for young, urban middle-class voters.
"Labastida and the PRI simply had to attract votes beyond their longtime base in the rural areas," Mr. Greenberg said.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;
Rangers' Deal Falls Through

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

 BODY:
One of the Rangers' most perplexing problems this past season was that they could not seem to find a defenseman to play with the team captain, Brian Leetch. They were working on a possible solution to that issue yesterday, but Glen Sather's plans fell through.
Sather, the Rangers' new president and general manager, spoke yesterday to Mark Witkin, the agent for the free-agent defenseman Don Sweeney. Last night, however, Sweeney decided to re-sign with the Boston Bruins, with whom he has spent parts of the past 12 seasons. 
 As Witkin said earlier in the day, "Things change very quickly."
They sure did.
And so Sather's quiet summer stayed that way -- and may continue until next Monday or Tuesday, when Ron Low is expected to be announced as the Rangers' new head coach.
Low, a former goaltender, was Sather's coach for a spell in Edmonton, where he succeeded George Burnett during the 1995-96 season and continued through the 1998-99 campaign.
After Sather could not guarantee Low a raise for last season, Low stepped down and coached Houston in the International Hockey League. With Madison Square Garden's backing, Sather can now pay Low better. He is believed to have offered Low a deal worth about $700,000 annually. Low also interviewed with the expansion Columbus Blue Jackets last Wednesday.
"I'm in a no-comment mode," the 50-year-old Low said from his summer cottage in Manitoba yesterday. "Everything is in freeze frame. It's likely I'll be able to say something next Monday or Tuesday."
By then, Low could be speaking from a dais at his introductory news conference in Manhattan.
The team he inherits, right now, will look much like the one that failed to make the playoffs for the third consecutive season this spring. Unlike last season, when the Rangers went out and signed every available big-name free agent, it has been a silent summer in the hockey offices at Madsion Square Garden thus far.
Other than the June 1 news conference to announce Sather's appointment, that is.
Not that Sather isn't trying. Sweeney would have given Leetch someone to play with on a regular basis.
The Rangers were not the only metropolitan-area team interested in the veteran defenseman. The Islanders' Mike Milbury has always been high on Sweeney, who turns 34 on Aug. 17, dating to Milbury's days in the Bruins' organization, where he was a player, a head coach and an assistant general manager.
Milbury entered into negotiations with Witkin this week regarding Sweeney. But, according to one league official, the Islanders bowed out because Sweeney's asking price was above $2 million a season. Instead, the Islanders went younger and signed 29-year-old Kevin Haller to a three-year deal that averages about $1.7 million a season.
St. Louis, meanwhile, signed 30-year-old defenseman Sean Hill, who played for Carolina last season, to a four-year, $9 million contract.
Sweeney, a Harvard graduate with a degree in economics, was looking for figures closer to what Hill signed for. The Bruins, known for being tight with their purse, ended up giving Sweeney enough for him to stay. JASON DIAMOS
