HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Child's Play The Way It Used to Be

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
R2D2, meet Barbie. Vintage toys and dolls are in, not that they ever went out. There are specialty auctions, Web sites, collector clubs, swap meets. There are sales four times a year in Gaithersburg, Md., as well as the twice yearly Atlantique Fairs, sales that attract tens of thousands to Atlantic City. There are more than 80 dealers on nadda.org, the Web site of the National Antique Doll Dealers Association.
"It's a baby boomer thing," said George Glastris, head of the toy and doll department at Skinner, the Boston auction house. "It's about nostalgia and recapturing our youth, even for 35-year-old yuppies like me. The robots are a guy thing. Dolls are for girls." 
 He said tomorrow's auction at Skinner, with 694 lots, is its biggest toy sale to date. The sale includes wind-up toys, lithographed tinplate vehicles, dolls, 18th-century Neapolitan creche figures, toy soldiers, cast iron banks, board games, puzzles and robots.
Vintage toys are evaluated according to rarity and condition. "Great age is not important for toys, dolls and collectibles," Carol Prisant writes in the "Antiques Roadshow Primer." "Toys made before World War II are considered 'antique,' while toys made after the war are 'modern.' "
Old toys need not be expensive. Skinner has given many lots $200 estimates, though not the star ones. These include rare robots like the Robby Space Patrol. (The word robot, coined by the Czech writer Karel Capek, comes from the Czech word robota, meaning compulsory labor like that of a serf.) Robby the Robot was made famous by the classic 1956 science-fiction film "Forbidden Planet." A robot who drove a space vehicle across a windswept alien planet, he has become an icon among robot collectors.
"He's also rare," Mr. Glastris said. "I've never sold one before."
Mark Bergin, a private dealer in New Hampshire who specializes in vintage robots and space toys (www.bergintoys.com), said: "Today, kids and Generation X, at least the 15- to 20-year-olds, are turned on by them. They are even showing up in MTV videos."
To Mr. Bergin, robots represent not nostalgia but the future and the unknown. "These robots are futuristic in form and design," he said. "The toys are 50 years old, and we still don't have real robots yet. We are just on the verge."
Robots are also popular among graphic artists. "It's because they have a 'Pulp Fiction' kind of art," Mr. Bergin said. "Robots and robot boxes probably have better graphics than any other toy."
This may explain the astronomical prices robots can fetch. Sotheby's New York sold a Robby Machine Man for $74,000 in December 1997. That set a record for a robot sold at auction, but Mr. Bergin said he had sold robots for more. At the moment he has a red Robby Space Trooper in its original box for $7,500 and a black Robby Space Trooper without its box for $1,500. He recommended that would-be collectors read "Future Toys," by Antoni Emchowicz and Paul Nunneley (New Cavendish Books).
A quick survey on the Web proves you can also buy other movie-star toy robots made more recently, including a robot inspired by the Maria in Fritz Lang's 1926 German film "Metropolis"; Hal 9000, from "2001: A Space Odyssey"; both 3CPO and R2D2 from "Star Wars"; and Vanessa Rembot from "Austin Powers." Robots rule!
Dolls have been cherished since men lived in caves. "Dolls are the second most highly collected antiques, after stamps and coins," said Dorothy McGonagle, the doll specialist at Skinner.
They tend to be classified according to the material used to make the head: wood, china, cloth, wax and plastic, among others. "The head is 90 percent of a doll," Mrs. McGonagle said. "Some manufacturers made only heads, and others made the bodies. Then dolls were sent off to the couturier for dressing. In the late 1800's, Paris shops like Au Nain Bleu acted as a middleman. It would have samples, so the customer could specify what head and dress she wanted. They must have had teams of seamstresses making the outfits.
"Dolls are a mirror of society," Mrs. McGonagle continued. "Dolls reflect what is going on in a culture at a given time. In the 19th century, for example, France was the fashion capital of the world, and costume was an important part of French life and the French economy. So the French produced fashion dolls, dolls depicted as upper-class ladies in couture. They are the predecessors of Barbie, the fashion doll of the 20th century."
Manhattan specialty shops like Second Childhood on Bleecker Street and Iris Brown Antique Dolls on East 57th Street sell such dolls. Richard Wright, a dealer in Birchrunville, Pa., also has a selection of rare European toys and dolls.
There are two schools of thought about fashion dolls, said Mrs. McGonagle, author of "The Dolls of Jules Nicolas Steiner." "Some say they were a way France exported its fashions. I think these dolls were to play with. They were made at a time when the middle class was burgeoning and people had money. It was the right time for a huge development in doll making. Such dolls came with accessories: crosses, enameled watches, rings, rosary beads and necklaces, to name a few."
Iris Brown disagrees. "These dolls are not really for children," she said. "They have survived because they were put on shelves. Girls just looked at them."
Until the 19th century, dolls tended to look like miniature adults, probably, Mrs. McGonagle said, because children were expected to act like adults. "Early dolls were also very pale, because ladies stayed inside," she added. "Later on you see healthier coloring." Dolls were adults dressed as children until the 1870's, when the child began to be glorified and doll forms were rendered as babies and children.
French companies like Bru, Jumeau and Steiner all produced fine child dolls. Lot 171 in the Skinner sale is a rare French Bru Bebe doll called Zepherine from the late 1870's. Her beautifully modeled head and delicate (repainted) hands are bisque, while the body is made of kid leather. She looks very grown up, with protruding breasts and a (replacement) blond wig framing her face. She has enormous cornflower blue eyes made of paperweight glass, arched eyebrows and long eyelashes that have been painted on. She wears her original cotton chemise underdress, which originally would have had a fabulous outfit over it. The estimated selling price for the doll is $8,000 to $12,000.
Collectors have arcane criteria when judging dolls. "A good doll, like a good woman, keeps her eyes open and her mouth shut," Mrs. McGonagle said, quoting an adage.
To Mr. Bergin, a robot is really an industrial doll. "They mesh the computer age with the human age," he said. For him, the only good doll (or robot) is one that can move in mysterious ways. To each his own.

HEADLINE: A Call for Fair Access to Future AIDS Vaccine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: DURBAN, South Africa, July 6

 BODY:
Though a vaccine to prevent AIDS is years away, steps should be taken now to enable a vaccine to be distributed widely in the third world as soon as it becomes available, a leading group in the vaccine effort said here today.
As the 13th International AIDS Conference prepared to open here on Sunday, the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, a research consortium supported by government and private grants, issued a blueprint to provide simultaneous access to an AIDS vaccine in rich and poor countries. 
 The public and private sectors need to learn new ways of doing business, the research group said in recommending sweeping changes in the way vaccines are produced, licensed, priced, bought and distributed.
The group argued that economics alone fails to fully explain the long delays that often ensue before vaccines become available in developing countries, and urged steps to harmonize the hodgepodge of national regulations and international guidelines that govern vaccine approval and use. The blueprint also calls for creation of an international group to monitor and assess experimental vaccines.
"It is not too soon to plan for an AIDS vaccine because failure to act promptly would repeat the tragedy of the widespread lack of availability to anti-H.I.V. drugs," said Dr. Seth Berkley, the president of the Vaccine Initiative, which collaborates with Unaids, the United Nations' joint program on AIDS.
The United Nations has concluded that AIDS threatens to severely damage the economies of sub-Saharan countries like South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Botswana and Swaziland where H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, has infected at least 20 percent of adults.
Most health officials believe a vaccine would be the most effective weapon in stopping the epidemic. However, the most severely affected countries would be the least able to afford a vaccine, just as they cannot pay for anti-H.I.V. drugs that are helping extend the lives of many infected people in developed countries. Also, many developing countries do not have the network of health systems needed to deliver a vaccine.
Rarely, if ever, have health officials introduced vaccines into developed and developing countries simultaneously. Vaccine manufacturers usually limit their initial production capacity for markets in developed countries. Only with time and after production capacity increases do prices fall to a level that poor countries can afford.
Thus, a delay of about 15 years has usually occurred between the time when vaccines for infections like hepatitis B were widely introduced into developed and developing countries. The first hepatitis B vaccine was developed in the early 1980's.
The United States and other developed countries quickly organized systems to deliver polio vaccines in the 1950's. But it took decades to conduct similar programs in countries with less effective health care systems and polio was eradicated from the Western Hemisphere only in the 1990's. The World Health Organization's goal of eradicating polio in the rest of the world by 2000 has been set back a few years.
The delay in introducing vaccines to the third world is "a colossal public health failure" that should not be repeated with AIDS, Dr. Berkley said. He also said that with more than five million new H.I.V. infections occurring each year, a delay of five years in delivering an AIDS vaccine could cost 20 million or more lives.
Scientists are challenged in developing an AIDS vaccine largely because of the virus's ability to mutate. Two years ago, the pipeline for AIDS vaccines was nearly empty. But today, the Vaccine Initiative said, there are promising products in early development, although there is still no plan to get any to the most affected communities in the world.
In 1985, Margaret Heckler, then Secretary of Health and Human Services, promised an AIDS vaccine within a year. In the intervening years, however, only 3 of 25 vaccines that have been injected into humans have advanced to the second stage of the three-stage testing system. Two are still in the second stage. One is known as an Alvac canary pox vaccine and is made by Aventis Pasteur of France. A second combines the Alvac vaccine and one prepared from a molecular component of the surface of H.I.V., known as gp120.
A vaccine made by VaxGen of Brisbane, Calif., is the only one to reach the third stage. VaxGen's product is being tested in the United States and Thailand, and findings are not expected until at least 2002.
New techniques are needed to estimate demand for an AIDS vaccine in developing countries and to assure sufficient production capacity because it takes five years to design, build and bring to full capacity facilities to produce vaccines.
An AIDS vaccine would be unlike most immunizations because it would be accompanied by counseling to promote safe sex practices and reduce risky behavior. Moreover, in the developed world, an unknown number of people might decline an AIDS vaccine out of concern that it might produce side effects that would not appear until years after the immunization. Also, some may shun an AIDS vaccine because it would make the standard H.I.V. blood test for a recipient positive. Additional tests would then be needed to document that the blood findings were from an AIDS vaccine, not from infection with the virus.
In the third world, there seems to be less concern about side effects because of the epidemic's severity.
Even if coordination with the World Health Organization's existing international vaccine programs produces maximum use of a vaccine for AIDS, the Vaccine Initiative said, new delivery systems will be needed to reach adolescents and adults at high risk of infection. And the work to create delivery systems could cost more than the vaccine itself.
The Vaccine Initiative urged the World Trade Organization and the major industrialized nations to create a tiered pricing structure to help poor countries pay what they can afford and allow companies to obtain a satisfactory return on investment.
The research group cited support for the blueprint from Sean Lance, chairman and chief executive officer of Chiron, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif., that seeks to develop an AIDS vaccine.
Although Chiron collaborates with researchers in South Africa and has distribution agreements for other products with South Africa, the company has vastly reduced its representation at the AIDS conference because of concerns of personal safety in Durban, a spokeswoman for Chiron said. Mr. Lance, a native South African, is not attending.

HEADLINE: Sharp Gain In May Orders At Factories

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Factory orders in May recorded the largest gain in almost seven and a half years, suggesting that signs of a slowdown in consumer demand are having only a limited effect on manufacturers, government statistics showed today.
Orders rose 4.1 percent after falling 3.8 percent in April as demand increased for electronics, autos and chemicals, the Commerce Department said. The increase in May was the largest since a 4.9 percent rise in December 1992. 
 "No one should underestimate the resiliency of this expansion," said Kevin Flanagan, a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter economist.
The gain in orders, along with a separate Labor Department report showing claims for jobless benefits fell 12,000 last week, to 296,000 -- the lowest level in five weeks -- indicates the record nine-year economic expansion may not be cooling as much as Federal Reserve policy makers would like.
Still, orders to factories may slow in coming months if the increases in interest rates cut more deeply into consumer spending. Reports today from retailers showing that the sales increase in June was the smallest in almost three years may be a sign that is already happening.
The May increase in factory orders was paced by the biggest increase in orders for electronic and electrical equipment since August 1997, Commerce Department officials said. Orders for electronic equipment rose 26.4 percent after falling 17.6 percent in April.
The electronic goods category includes communications equipment, appliances and video equipment, as well as semiconductors, circuit boards, capacitors, resistors, coils and transformers.
Orders for autos and auto parts rose 3.3 percent after falling 5.9 percent in April. Excluding transportation equipment, orders increased 4.3 percent in May, the largest gain since a similar rise in January 1980.
May shipments of goods from factories, used in the government's calculation for gross domestic product, rose 1.9 percent, while inventories increased 0.2 percent. That pushed the inventories-to-shipments ratio to a record low of 1.26 months in May.
"The continued downtrend in the inventory-to-sales ratio argues for a continued strengthening in production," said Greg Jones, chief economist at Briefing.com in Jackson, Wyo. Analysts were expecting a 3.5 percent gain in overall orders after projecting a 4.3 percent decrease in April.

HEADLINE: Mortgage-Delinquency Rate at 28-Year Low

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
The number of Americans behind on home mortgage payments declined to the lowest level in 28 years in the first three months of the year, an banking industry group reported today.
Surging income and employment and low interest rates have helped consumers keep up with payments, according to the group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. 
 Mortgage delinquencies were a seasonally adjusted 3.72 percent in the January-March quarter, down from 3.82 percent in the fourth quarter of 1999 and 4.06 percent in the first three months of 1999, the group's latest survey showed.
The 3.72 percent rate is the lowest mortgage-delinquency rate since the second quarter of 1972, when it was 3.49 percent.
Delinquencies declined in all three categories -- home mortgage loans that are 30 days, 60 days and 90 days or more past due -- and for all three types of home mortgages: conventional, those insured by the Federal Housing Administration and those insured by the Department of Veterans Affairs.
The delinquency survey covers some 25 million home mortgage loans made by about 200 lenders. No margin of error is given for the survey.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Shares Rebound, but Blue Chips Are Static

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks closed mostly higher yesterday as Wall Street looked for bargains in technology shares that were battered on Wednesday.
But blue-chip stocks treaded water as investors turned their focus to an important jobs report to be released today that some hope will give clues to the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. 
 Gains in semiconductor shares helped lift the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index 97.47 points, or 2.5 percent, to 3,960.57.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which made a brief foray into positive territory late in the day, edged down 2.13 points, or 0.02 percent, to 10,481.47, cushioned by gains in Intel and financial stocks.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished up 10.44 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,456.67.
Technology shares benefited from a rebound in the semiconductor sector, which was severely beaten on Wednesday after a negative report on the industry by Salomon Smith Barney.
"Trading remains very thin, very volatile and the market is subject to these swings at this point," said Charles White, president of Avatar Associates. "I think everything is meandering around with people getting set up and comfortable for the number tomorrow."
Analysts expect the report, closely watched by the Fed as a gauge of inflation, to show continued tightness in the labor market, which some fear could prompt another rate increase.
The Fed left interest rates unchanged at its last meeting in June, after raising them six times over the last year, but it also warned that its job may not yet be done.
Intel, the chip maker, climbed 5, to 136 5/8, while the semiconductor equipment maker Applied Materials gained 3 1/4, to 86 11/16. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rose 4.51 percent after dropping 9.32 percent Wednesday.
"There's a little bit of bargain-hunting in the technology sector," said Alan Skrainka, chief market strategist at Edward Jones.
But all was not rosy for technology stocks.
Declines in I.B.M., down 2 1/4, to 101 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard, off 1 1/4, to 118 3/8, weighed on the Dow.
The Dow had a few bright spots, including financial shares like J. P. Morgan, which rose 1 5/8, to 116 15/16.
But Wall Street's main focus remained on today's employment figures for June, which are expected to show that the job market tightened further compared with May and that average hourly wages rose at a faster pace.
"I think the market is clearly treading water ahead of the report that is going to be released tomorrow," said Ned Riley, chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisers in Boston. "The market is torn between believing that the technology story is viable long term and the fact that there are some cracks developing, especially in second- and third-tier tech companies."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices posted their biggest drop in two weeks before a report today that may show employment rebounded in June, keeping alive speculation the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month.
Investor confidence that the Fed's six rate increases over the last year have cooled growth was dented by a report that factory orders posted the biggest gain in seven and a half years in May, analysts said.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note fell 1 3/32, to 103 11/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.04 percent from 5.98 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year bond dropped 2 3/32, to 104 26/32. Its yield rose to 5.90 percent from 5.86 percent.

HEADLINE: Preparing to Remake Mexico

 BODY:
Mexicans have understandably high expectations for Vicente Fox Quesada, the man they elected to break the 71-year presidential monopoly of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. In the euphoria that has followed his decisive victory Sunday, they now look to Mr. Fox to eliminate the official corruption, economic inequalities and political repression that were the defining characteristics of PRI rule. Mr. Fox's initial declarations are promising. But he will need persistence and cooperation from Mexico's other parties to succeed.
Taking over from an entrenched autocracy is never easy, and Mr. Fox faces more than the usual difficulties. The PRI remains in power for five more months, long enough to destroy records of corrupt dealings and deny Mr. Fox a smooth transition. His party will lack a Congressional majority, requiring him to make deals with other political forces, including the PRI. President Ernesto Zedillo should make sure that the current government shares information fully with Mr. Fox's nominees. 
 The most important issue facing Mr. Fox is government corruption. He has promised to remove police functions from the highly politicized Interior Ministry and the attorney general's office and establish a new, more professional ministry of security and justice. Those are necessary steps. Mexico's police have become notorious for protecting drug dealers and preying on ordinary citizens while facing little threat of investigation or punishment. But merely creating a new ministry is not enough. The training and management of police and prosecutors must be overhauled to ensure that criminal investigations are conducted properly and all law enforcement officers are held accountable for misconduct.
Mr. Fox has also pledged to channel public resources toward reducing poverty and to bring the benefits of the North American Free Trade Agreement to smaller businesses. Washington should offer him strong support. A Mexico with economic opportunity more widely distributed among its 100 million people would not only provide a better market for American consumer goods, it would also be a more comfortable economic and political partner for the United States. Washington should consider Mr. Fox's sensible ideas about expanding legal immigration.
Mexico's size, proximity and prominence as a trade partner tie it inextricably to the United States. Washington should do all that it can to support Mr. Fox's efforts to transform his country from an autocracy based on patronage and privilege into a law-abiding, pluralist democracy.

HEADLINE: Egypt Arrests an Activist

 BODY:
Egypt arrested a prominent sociologist last week, along with at least eight of his colleagues, and shut down the democracy institute where they work. The government said the sociologist, Saad Eddin Ibrahim, was suspected of, among other things, accepting funds from the European Union and harming Egypt's image by making a voting rights video that discussed past election fraud.
The arrests follow a campaign of attacks on Dr. Ibrahim in the Egyptian media and represent the latest harassment of advocates of democracy and human rights by the government, which appears to be trying to silence them before parliamentary elections this fall. If Egypt is truly worried about its image, it should end its embarrassing assault on independent activists. 
 The accusations against Dr. Ibrahim and other staff members of his institute, the Ibn Khaldoun center, are similar to those brought in the past two years against other activists. The Egyptian authorities also tightened regulations on nongovernmental organizations last year with a law that was recently declared unconstitutional on technical grounds.
Egypt's human rights community is understandably alarmed that the government would move against the prominent and well-connected Dr. Ibrahim, who also holds American citizenship and is a professor at the American University in Cairo. According to one of Dr. Ibrahim's lawyers, several of his staff members are still in jail, and no one has been able to visit Dr. Ibrahim since Monday. The government has 15 days to investigate charges against him, but can renew his detention indefinitely. His request for bail was denied.
Egypt seems to be harassing Dr. Ibrahim for his democracy work and for activities like accepting foreign donations and criticizing government actions. This is not criminal conduct and should not be treated as such. Washington, which gives Egypt $2 billion a year, says its ambassador has raised the case with Egypt's prime minister. The United States should continue to press for the release of Dr. Ibrahim and his staff, and for the political rights of all Egyptians.

HEADLINE: As Profits Soar, Corporate America Takes On More Debt

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
WHEN things go great, the winners go into debt. Sometimes they go too far.
With the American economy in its longest period of expansion ever, the news for corporate America has been as good as it can be. Profits have soared and are at or near record levels by almost any measure -- in dollars, as a percentage of revenue or as a portion of national income. Investors eagerly paid unprecedented multiples of those profits when they bought shares. 
 Yet, with profits pouring in and investors eager to buy stock, corporate America is deeper in debt than ever before. Corporate debt now equals 46 percent of gross domestic product, up from 38 percent five years ago.
One might expect companies to pay down debt in good times, and they tend to do so early in an economic recovery, when the bad times are still fresh. Corporate debt fell in 1991, after the last recession.
But as the economy continues to grow and people become more confident that good times are here to stay, such conservatism comes to appear foolish. "It's the perception of certainty that causes so many prosperous companies, individuals and companies to get in over their heads," says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
As a result, the richest of one era can end up in deep trouble when times change. Mexico raked in the cash when oil prices soared during the 1970's and could not pay its debts in 1982. Japanese corporations seemed to conquer the world in the 1980's and could not pay their bank loans a decade later.
In the current corporate borrowing spree, the money borrowed has been far in excess of what was needed for capital spending, notes Paul Kasriel, the chief economist of Northern Trust. Much of the money went to buy back stock -- in large part to offset the shares that were issued to executives when they cashed in stock options. Corporate America has bought back more shares than it issued in recent years.
None of this is unprecedented. The two longest periods of expansion before the current one were during the 1960's and 1980's. In each case, corporate debt rose rapidly in the final years of the expansion. In the 1980's, Drexel Burnham Lambert, the leader in junk bond underwriting, came up with a new measure -- the "MAD ratio" -- to reassure investors that debt levels were not excessive. That stood for market-adjusted debt, and it showed that many companies were not really very far in debt, considering the market value of their stock. That was great, until share prices fell.
Now, evidence is growing that the economy is slowing, and worries are picking up that corporate profits may not be as robust as expected. Credit markets are becoming tighter. The junk bond market is reluctant to finance many companies, and banks are growing more cautious.
If such trends continue, some companies that assumed they could refinance debt when it came due will find that they cannot. And then we will see corporate defaults and bankruptcy filings rise to a level much higher than might be expected even if there is only a modest slowing in economic growth.
Inevitably, some of the companies that default will be ones that need never have borrowed money, given how eager investors were to buy their shares. But the managers feared that issuing too many shares would depress the stock price, and they knew that their duty was to maximize shareholder value. So they took on debts that did not look dangerous -- but that proved to be fatal.

HEADLINE: Playing the China Card;
One Company's Decision, and the Employees Left Behind

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla.

 BODY:
American business is rushing into China, and Marilyn C. Grant, 56, who drives a forklift for a fishing reel company, is being left behind.
The Zebco Corporation, Ms. Grant's employer, began moving much of its fishing reel production to China at the end of June. Though the company has been under pressure for a long time, the move came just a few weeks after the House passed a measure that would end cold war restrictions on trade with China. Most of Zebco's 240 workers will eventually lose their jobs, and Ms. Grant, who has worked at the company's stone headquarters plant in Tulsa for 25 years, expects to be one of them. 
 "I thought this only happened to other people, and now it's about to happen to me," Ms. Grant said. "We're just another company moving over there."
In promoting permanent normal trade relations with China, which the House approved in late May and the Senate is expected to vote on in late July, President Clinton predicted an "almost incalculable" increase in exports of American goods to China. But critics say the move also seems likely to encourage exports of some American jobs.
China agreed to open its markets to join the World Trade Organization and to get permanent trading rights in the United States. That should make it easier to sell American-made products there. But as China modernizes and loosens controls, its lure as a manufacturing base, which has been growing since the early 1980's, is also proving irresistible to many multinationals.
International trade is not a zero-sum "you win, I lose" game, and most economists say that even if some people lose their jobs, the United States reaps big advantages from trade and foreign investment -- like greater productivity, higher corporate profits and cheaper spincast reels. But while those substantial benefits are diffused among a vast number of people, the recipients are not celebrating as much as Zebco's workers are seething.
"Our government just handed our jobs to a Communist country," said Brenda McCoy, 50, a Zebco assembly-line veteran who wore a T-shirt to work that bears an image of two Chinese police officers choking a Chinese labor activist. "It just makes you feel angry and helpless."
The Chinese claim to have invented the modern fishing device more than a millennium ago by spooling line onto wicker reels. But it was the Zero Hour Bomb Company of Tulsa that invented and patented the spincast reel 50 years ago, with line spinning off the end of a stationary spool and remaining, famously, backlash free.
Now called Zebco, the company is a classic American success story. Its nearly fool-proof reels helped make fishing perhaps the nation's most popular leisure activity. They carry a "Made in America With Pride" logo.
Even in the last decade, as it had to fight competitors that paid much lower hourly wages to workers in Asia, Zebco remained the dominant fishing tackle brand. Though Zebco once tested production in Mexico, it pulled back when its Tulsa workers proved they could produce more reels in less time with fewer defects.
The dike finally gave way this year, however. With most of Zebco's competitors having already set up fishing tackle plants in China, allowing them to undercut Zebco's prices at Wal-Marts everywhere, Zebco began a year ago to explore the possibility of moving its own lines to China. The company found that it could commission Chinese factories to produce and deliver reels to the United States for one-third less than it could make them at home, company officials said.
Zebco decided to make most of its low-end reels at factories in China. For now, it will continue to produce more expensive reels in Tulsa, though union officials say the company has put them on notice that it is searching for further ways to lower labor costs, including the possibility of shifting the remaining reels to China, too.
"We made valiant efforts to keep production in the United States," said Kathryn J. Chieger, vice president for corporate and investor relations at the Brunswick Corporation, Zebco's parent company, in Lake Forest, Ill. "We just had a flood of product coming from Asia at prices we could not meet."
Even so, the layoffs, which began on June 27, left Zebco's unionized workers, who are mostly women, perplexed and angry.
Sitting in a dimly lit Transport Union Workers hall, the air soured by cigarette smoke and the tables stacked with copies of protest literature that workers distributed at a recent anti-China trade demonstration, Kristie L. Cater said she had expected to retire in the job.
"They kept telling us we were members of the Zebco family," she said with angry sarcasm. "I guess they just forgot about that."
As assembly-line factory jobs go, Zebco offers ordinary pay but solid benefits, including Christmas gifts of stock certificates. Workers returned the loyalty. Turnover was low. Some workers also became avid anglers, showing off Zebco's reels at bass and crappie fishing tournaments.
For Linda Allen, 41, an assembly-line supervisor since 1976, work was literally a family affair: her mother and grandmother preceded her in the job.
Those ties started to unravel last year. When company executives visited Qingdao, a city in northeastern China, to inspect factories, word leaked out. Then, earlier this year, the company pushed assembly-line workers to raise their output by at least 10 percent a month, and China became a cattle prod.
"When we don't get quota, it is another day closer to China taking our jobs," read a Feb. 3 memorandum from the company that was circulated among employees. "So today China won by 45 points."
Ms. Chieger of Brunswick said such memos were intended to show workers what they were up against in terms of competitors that had factories in China.
Still, the shop floor fell into stunned silence one March afternoon when the president of the company read a brief statement as first-shift workers finished their day. Zebco was moving some production to China. Many of those listening would lose their jobs. Zebco reels no longer commanded an "adequate profit," the statement said.
The explanation offended Ms. Grant, the Zebco forklift driver.
Ms. Grant has gray hair and delicate manners. As she speaks, her eyes dart about the living room of her A-frame house, which is decorated with porcelain figurines and homemade quilts. Only her strong shoulders reveal the heavy lifting she does each day as a Zebco receiver.
"They have never said they don't make a profit," she said. "It's that word 'adequate.' They're going over to China because of greed."
Just a few years from retirement, she said she had begun looking for a new job. Tulsa's economy is relatively strong, and she found one prospect. But if she got the job -- she worries that a touch of arthritis might hurt her chances -- she would lose her quarter-century seniority and $1.50 of her current $10.63 hourly wage, she said, money she needs to make payments on her secondhand Jeep.
Ms. Cater, 37, a mother of two, said that after she learned of her layoff on the assembly line, she told her 17-year-old daughter to check out community colleges in Tulsa; the higher-priced Colorado school she had been considering was now out of reach.
"I had some savings put away, but that's going to disappear," she said.
At least in theory, the recent steps China has taken to open its markets should be good for American factory workers and farmers by making it easier for companies to export goods to that nation.
But as union leaders argued when they tried unsuccessfully to block the China trade bill in the House, many leading United States companies are like Zebco: they face competitive pressure to save money by producing in China -- often exporting back to the United States -- rather than making goods here to sell in China.
The United States has been losing manufacturing jobs for decades, of course, and dire warnings about the hollowing out of the economy seem a little hyperbolic during the longest expansion in the nation's history. Most economists believe that the trade boom of the last decade -- more exports, cheaper imports and the reallocation of jobs to more productive parts of the economy -- forms a central pillar of the 1990's expansion.
Moreover, although the Clinton administration often listed exports as the headline benefit of broadening trade with China, the real advantage for United States companies is probably enhanced rights of investment and ownership there. Phone, Internet, bank and insurance companies can buy larger stakes in Chinese counterparts and set up operations in more cities under the terms of China's entry to the World Trade Organization. Most companies try to crack the difficult China market by setting up local operations, often using those plants as export production bases as well.
That means that the push into China is not limited to low-wage assemblers. Cisco, Intel, Eastman Kodak and Motorola are among the multinational companies that have lobbied Congress to grant China permanent normal trade relations even as they have expanded their manufacturing operations in China, according to a survey by the United States Business and Industry Council, which has been critical of Clinton administration trade policies.
Over all, exports to China will probably grow. But the volume of imports is expected to grow even faster. The United States International Trade Commission, a government agency, predicts that American exports will increase 10 percent a year if China opens its markets as promised. But it also sees China's appeal as a manufacturing base rising fast, bolstering China's exports to the United States by 7 percent annually. Since imports from China already exceed exports to China by a wide margin, the gaping $62 billion trade deficit is likely to widen rather than contract.
The way many workers see it, America loses.
Asked whether the United States was better off with cheaper fishing reels or job security for Zebco workers, Ms. Grant reflected for a moment.
"People might like buying things cheaper," she said. "But there's a price. They're going to wake up one day and find that nothing's made here."

HEADLINE: Big Retailers Say June Sales Were Weak

BYLINE: By KRUTI TRIVEDI 

 BODY:
Squeezed by rising gasoline prices and discouraged by cool, rainy weather, Americans put a brake on retail spending in June, new figures showed yesterday.
Sales in stores open for more than a year, a crucial figure for measuring the health of the retail industry, rose 2.6 percent for the month compared with the period a year earlier, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. Except for March, when Easter sales were delayed by a month, that is the lowest percentage increase since September 1997. 
 As anemic as the numbers were, analysts said that they were in line with expectations that the economy was losing steam.
"We expected to see a slowdown," said George Strachan, a retail analyst at Goldman Sachs. "The weather was bad. Fashion was bad. Basically, it was a pretty bad month."
Consumers are not increasing their spending as much at all types of stores, ranging from specialty apparel stores like the Gap to discount stores like Kmart and department stores like Dayton Hudson, a unit of Target.
Much to the dismay of the merchants, consumers have shown an increasing distaste throughout the year for buying clothes, in particular. "There's no question that apparel sales have slowed as we've moved through the year," said Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "We've seen a steady deceleration in same-store sales. This month they were barely positive."
In what could be another sign of a consumer slowdown, Federated Department Stores, the parent company of the Macy's and Bloomingdale chains, said its second-quarter earnings would be hurt by credit card defaults at Fingerhut, its catalog arm. Fingerhut sells merchandise mostly to lower- and middle-income Americans, and credit troubles there could foreshadow more widespread consumer woes.
Even discount chains like Wal-Mart, Target and Kmart, which led the booming growth last year, all reported moderate to poor sales in June. Wal-Mart's sales increased 4.8 percent at stores open for more than a year, but the rise was mostly a result of food sales, analysts said. Target's discount stores reported growth of 2.1 percent, in large part because of difficulties with its women's apparel business, a company spokeswoman said. Over all, Target's sales rose 1.1 percent. Kmart fared the worst, showing a 1 percent drop in sales, also because of problems with apparel, one analyst said.
Department stores and specialty stores also had difficulties. There were widespread markdowns to get rid of excess inventory, and analysts said such price cuts could eventually reduce profits.
In the specialty retail sector, Gap Inc., which has been struggling to get the fashion mix in its stores right for nearly nine months, missed again in June as sales fell 2 percent. Sales at the company's Old Navy division dropped by at least 7 percent, but analysts said that was because Old Navy had phenomenal growth of more than 30 percent last year.
Gap also announced yesterday that it would miss earnings estimates by 3 cents a share for the current quarter, but its shares rose $3.75, to $33.625, because analysts expected the news to be worse.
The Limited, on the other hand, reported a 6 percent increase in same-store sales, but its stock hardly moved. It continued to benefit from its teenager-friendly Express division, analysts said, but investors were less confident about the Structure and Lane Bryant divisions, both of which reported decreasing sales.
There were a few standouts in terms of sales. Neiman Marcus, for example, pulled in more customers by having its annual men's sale in June instead of May and by cutting back on its more moderately priced lines. Its sales rose 17.3 percent. And Intimate Brands, which reported a 9 percent sales increase, was bolstered by lingerie sales at its Victoria's Secret Stores.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Victor Faces Choices On Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Instead of the turmoil that many feared a close election in Mexico could set off, Vicente Fox Quesada's seven-percentage-point victory margin, wider by far than most polls had predicted, has buoyed the spirits not just of Mexican voters but of investors and business executives across North America.
The Mexican peso strengthened immediately after the election, the Mexican stock market hit a three-month high before dropping back a bit, and American investors generally were delighted -- not necessarily because Mr. Fox won, but because the decisive way he won kept Mexico calm and open for business. 
 But as people get used to the idea that Mexico's 71 years of one-party rule are coming to an end, investors, analysts and business leaders are beginning to ask just how Mr. Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive, intends to handle the complex economic issues facing his country. And there are questions whether, in the interconnected global economy that he says he wants Mexico to remain part of, he has much leeway at all.
"First there was this euphoria, then everybody was standing around scratching their head," said John M. Bruton, executive vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Mexico City. "People of all classes voted for him because they think he can change their situations. Now, managing expectations is going to be Mr. Fox's greatest challenge."
So much of the campaign was focused on change for the sake of change that other issues did not get much attention. There was never much distance between the economic platforms of the principal candidates, and throughout the campaign Mr. Fox avoided laying out a detailed program of economic change. Instead, he offered standard campaign promises of increasing jobs, promoting investment and producing economic growth that would help the millions of Mexicans living in poverty.
Mr. Fox has made it clear that he intends to stay the economic course -- opening Mexico to the global economy and embracing free-market discipline -- set by previous administrations, but he has made it equally clear that he is not happy with the way that many Mexicans have been left behind. He supports an independent central bank, a free-floating exchange rate and increased exports. He even said earlier this week that the North American Free Trade Agreement should be amplified to further integrate North America, perhaps with a common currency for Mexico, the United States and Canada, "20, 30 or 40 years from now."
But he is facing many far more immediate issues, including the millions of Mexicans who have never recovered the purchasing power they had before the first of several end-of-administration crises in the early 1980's.
"A lot of Mexicans feel their economic circumstances have gotten worse and they expect results very quickly," said Joyce Chang, global head of fixed-income research at Chase Securities in New York. "Fox has to be careful about how he handles expectations."
Mr. Fox has a reputation as a pragmatist when it comes to business and the economy. As governor of the small state of Guanajuato, he started a program of providing loans for very small businesses as a way of promoting entrepreneurship, and he intends to repeat the program on the national level. He has also talked about copying Chile's program of providing tax relief for companies that reinvest in Chile.
One of Mr. Fox's first economic tasks will be to name an economic cabinet that inspires investor confidence in a party that has never run Mexico. He is said to be considering a treasury secretary from the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI. One name being mentioned is Luis Tellez, the current energy secretary.
Mr. Fox must also prepare a federal budget that by law has to be approved -- by a congress his party does not control -- within 15 days of his inauguration on Dec. 1.
Mr. Fox's chief economic adviser, Luis Ernesto Derbez, a former World Bank official who is often mentioned as a possible treasury secretary under Mr. Fox, told investors in New York yesterday that work on the budget had already begun.
Mr. Derbez said Mexican political leaders had been asked to outline budget priorities, and preliminary talks were under way with the PRI, as well as with the left-leaning Party of the Democratic Revolution, to gauge the limits of cooperation. Mr. Fox wants to name his cabinet by the end of August and present a budget proposal by Sept. 1.
Analysts will be watching to see how Mr. Fox squares his campaign promise to increase spending for education and social programs with his pledge to decrease the current budget deficit by half. Mr. Derbez said legislation would be introduced to close tax loopholes. He also said the government would consider extending the value-added tax to medicine and food -- but only if there was a way to soften the effect on the poor.
John B. Chambers, deputy head of the sovereign ratings group at Standard & Poor's, said his company's analysts would be following the budget process and the fall legislative session in Mexico City for clues to whether the major parties will cooperate or stumble into gridlock.
Another rating company, Moody's Investors Services, upgraded Mexico's debt to investment grade in early March, but Standard & Poor's did not. This week, S.& P. affirmed its rating of one notch below investment grade, with a positive outlook for an upgrade if the new administration takes care of some pending issues.
"It really is a question of how effective we think the Fox administration is going to be in implementing the structural reform agenda," Mr. Chambers said. "Clues on that could come as early as the fourth quarter of this year." S.& P. says it will be watching for further strengthening of Mexico's banking system and deregulation of the electricity and petroleum sectors.
The last three Mexican administrations ended with currency devaluations and economic turmoil. Fears of another crisis diminished with the strength of Mr. Fox's victory, and the continuing strength of Mexico's economy. Jonathan E. Heath, a Mexican economist who wrote a book on the causes of the end-of-administration crises, says most of the factors that caused them -- a fixed exchange rate and an oversized current accounts deficit, for example -- have been eliminated.
"There's still the slim possibility of a shock that would be caused by an assassination attempt on Fox," Mr. Heath said, "but barring something weird like that, the chances of another crisis are very slim."
Rather than a meltdown, some investors are worried that the post-election ecstasy could actually make Mexico's economy overheat just as the United States economy begins to show signs of slowing down. The first two days after the election, the Mexican stock market jumped 8.2 percent, but profit taking wiped away some of that gain, leaving the market up 5.1 percent since the vote.
"Consumption, capital inflows, domestic investment, foreign direct investment, all are increasing because of this injection of confidence," said Jorge O. Mariscal, chief Latin American investment strategist for Goldman, Sachs. "The thing to do now is slow down the Mexican economy using fiscal and monetary means. Fox needs to address that in the transition."
Mr. Mariscal said that for him one incident best described the current mood of excitement and uncertainty in Mexico. Just before the election, a manufacturer in Mexico City who supported Mr. Fox loaded barrels of fragrances on a pickup truck and drove around the city's main highway. He wanted voters to know that the possibility of change was so real they could smell it.
But something went wrong: a barrel spilled onto the roadway, and there was a multicar pileup.
"Mexico," Mr. Mariscal said, "still presents tremendous challenges."

End deficit spending.

HEADLINE: A Spirited Campaign for Ohio Court Puts Judges on New Terrain

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
Candidates for State Supreme Court here are usually so unknown that contestants with familiar names have often won because, political scientists say, voters thought they were actually voting for someone they knew.
But this year, at least two candidates for Ohio Supreme Court -- and quite possibly all seven members of the panel -- may soon be wishing for those days of glorious obscurity. A boisterous, multimillion-dollar election battle for one seat on the court is making two candidates household names, while drawing uncomfortable attention to all seven members of the rancorously divided court. 
 The race is making Ohio a case study in an aggressive new judicial politics that is reshaping courts and drawing unprecedented political spending to campaigns for state judgeships nationwide.
"People around the country are watching the Ohio judicial race," said Seth S. Anderson, director of the Hunter Center for Judicial Selection at the American Judicature Society, a nonpartisan group. "It typifies the intense involvement of interest groups in judicial races that has been growing for the last 15 years but that could reach its apex in Ohio this year."
Listeners to WSPD radio in Toledo have been hearing an unusual advertisement that seems to put the entire Ohio Supreme Court on trial. It was placed by the Michigan Chamber of Commerce to lure Ohio businesses to the state, chamber officials said.
"The Ohio Supreme Court," the commercial says, "has rejected reasonable legal reform," when it blocked efforts by the Ohio Legislature to limit liability suits against businesses.
Some people here (Democrats) said the advertisement was an example of plotting by Chamber of Commerce types against their candidate, Justice Alice Robie Resnick, an incumbent abhorred by business groups because she wrote the decision blocking the liability measures.
Other people (Republicans) said the advertisements were just a reminder of why Ohio jobs would be saved by their candidate, Terrence O'Donnell, a Cleveland appeals court judge who broadly hints he would have voted differently, saying he is against "activist judges."
The Michigan Chamber of Commerce president, E. James Barrett, denied being in league with anyone. But whatever their true purpose, the advertisements were another reminder that judicial races are beginning to provoke the same partisanship as races for other offices.
In a year when state Supreme Court campaigns across the country are transforming judges more fully into politicians, Ohio is leading the way, said Mark F. Kozlowski, a lawyer at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University Law School, which studies judicial independence.
"If there is success in defeating Resnick in Ohio, that could very well become a model." Mr. Kozlowski said, "Because there is an extremely focused, specific campaign against her, and if they defeat her that could become the textbook case."
Although the election is not until November, accusations have been flying here for months. With predictions that spending on the race could reach $12 million, the campaign is expected to be the most expensive judicial race in Ohio, and is likely to be one of the most expensive in the country.
A race is also under way for another seat on the court, but the Republican incumbent, Deborah L. Cook, is favored over her challenger, a Democratic Municipal Court judge, Timothy S. Black.
At stake in the Resnick-O'Donnell race is the ideological balance of the court, which has been split 4 to 3 on many economic issues, including so-called tort reform, which is how supporters describe the efforts to reduce the number of lawsuits.
But, with many state courts around the country similarly divided, the Ohio election has also drawn the attention of national groups that view it as a test of strategies in battles over state courts.
Each judicial campaign is limited by law to spending $550,000. The balance of the spending is expected to be by unions, lawyers, business groups and political parties, which are coming to see the courts as a political forum like any other. Ohio imposes no limits on spending by interest groups.
In interviews, Judge O'Donnell and Justice Resnick expressed surprise at finding themselves the objects of so much attention. Judge O'Donnell virtually squirmed during an interview in his chambers and talked of earlier campaigns in which, he said, reputation and integrity had been the only issues.
Justice Resnick seemed breathless from the intensity of the campaign. "With these special interest groups," she said, "people are beginning to think judges are politicians, that seats can be bought on courts."
Over the last year, Justice Resnick has inflamed Republican legislators and business groups by writing majority opinions in two highly publicized cases. The decisions struck down measures to limit suits by people claiming injury, and the state's system of financing public schools.
For many here, the rulings highlighted an ideological standoff on the court, in which two Republicans have voted with the court's two Democrats on some issues.
In her opinion in the school case last month, Justice Resnick seemed outraged by what she said were the inequities of financing public schools largely through property taxes. For the second time in three years, the court ruled that the school financing system controlled by the Republican governor and Legislature had deprived students in poorer districts of the education guaranteed them. In her opinion, Justice Resnick dwelled on descriptions of sewage leaks in Ohio schools.
Republicans have declared that a "Resnick tax" will be necessary to pay for the public schools, and the state's Republican chairman, Robert T. Bennett, created an acronym for the race -- DARTH -- for Defeat Alice Resnick Tax Hike.
The three Republicans in the minority on the court, including the court's chief justice, Thomas J. Moyer, have appeared to be crying for rescue.
At a political meeting in April, Justice Moyer said Judge O'Donnell shared his philosophy of judicial restraint. Without mentioning Justice Resnick, according to The Toledo Blade, the chief justice added that "when a Supreme Court justice decides he or she is smarter than the Legislature, what they are doing, in my view, is overruling the will of the people."
An ethics panel of Ohio judges is considering complaints filed against Justice Moyer by a critic of the court and a county Democratic Party chairman, who said he had violated rules intended to keep judges outside the political fray. Chief Justice Moyer has said he did not make a political endorsement, but acknowledged that he would not have spoken so glowingly about Judge O'Donnell if he had known reporters were in the room.
Judge O'Donnell, 54, who often uses the word "traditional" to describe himself, was chosen by Republican leaders to oppose Justice Resnick. A review of more than 50 of his decisions shows that he has expressed a conservative view of the role of courts, but has seldom made sweeping comments about legal issues.
In a lawsuit by the mother of a young man killed at a gay nightclub, for example, Judge O'Donnell tersely ruled that the club could not be held liable for failing to provide adequate security because its owners had no reason to expect a homicide. A Democratic judge, Leo M. Spellacy, dissented, saying the dead man's family had a right to a trial because owners had failed to provide security inside the club, even though it was in a high-crime neighborhood and there had been previous violence.
In the interview, Judge O'Donnell declined to characterize his judicial philosophy and said he had also voted for plaintiffs in some cases. Judges, he said, "should not be for or against anything."
Some of Judge O'Donnell's critics here have said his emphasis on opposing judicial activism is a coded way of saying he would vote to overturn some of the decisions written by Justice Resnick.
"I am not talking in code," he said.
Justice Resnick, who was first elected to the state's top court in 1988, is no firebrand, either, though she has consistently ruled that injured people have a right to have their claims heard in court. Now 60, she patiently climbed the ranks of Democratic judicial politics from the trial court after first winning election in Toledo in 1975. Earlier, as a prosecutor, she was a staunch death penalty proponent, with 10 death sentences on her resume.
On the State Supreme Court, Justice Resnick has been neither particularly famous nor liberal. She has enthusiastically agreed with conservative criminal justice rulings. Once, in a case involving a protester who had burned an American flag, she voted against a decision that said the jury should have been told that flag burning is protected by the First Amendment.
Justice Resnick said she saw the current campaign as a battle of fundamental values. Her opponents, she said in an interview, "want business to not have to worry about any negative decisions. To me, the most serious thing going on in this country is what corporate America is doing to working men and women."
The liability decision last summer made Justice Resnick a political target. For more than a decade, the Legislature had passed measures limiting injury claims and the court had struck them down as violations of the Ohio constitution's guarantees of the right to access to the courts.
Then in 1996, the Republicans who had gained control of the Legislature passed many of those same laws again. In what legal experts said was a rare challenge to a court's authority, the legislators included provisions that simply said they "respectfully disagree" that the provisions violated the constitution.
In a 4-to-3 opinion, Justice Resnick said the court had no choice but to strike down the laws again. To do otherwise, she wrote, would make the court "a co-conspirator in the abdication of fundamental individual rights and liberties contained in our Constitution."
The decision certainly gained notice for Justice Resnick.
Insurance, medical and other business groups began working against her. She "defied the will of the people" as expressed by the laws limiting injury claims, said Andrew E. Doehrel, the president of the Ohio Chamber of Commerce, who said his members were mobilized to defeat her.
But the decision won Justice Resnick support, too. Plaintiffs' lawyers, consumer groups and unions are behind her. The Democratic Party will spend "whatever it takes" to defend her, said David J. Leland, the state chairman.
In the quaint ways of the law, it was a procedural fluke that landed Justice Resnick in the position of writing two of the most visible court decisions here in years. After the justices vote on cases, the court selects which justice will write the opinions by lot, drawing numbered marbles out of a leather jar.
So, just as she was facing a re-election bid, it happened that Justice Resnick's number was drawn both for the liability and school cases. The spokesman for the court here in Columbus, Jay Weubbold, said the number on the marble assigned to Justice Resnick is seven. It is not yet clear whether it is her lucky number.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PROCESS;
A Select Group Speaks Out On the Democratic Platform

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 6

 BODY:
The Democratic Party opened public hearings on its platform here today with a tightly scripted display of party unity, hearing from a parade of witnesses who endorsed Vice President Al Gore's positions on almost every major campaign issue, including gun control, the economy, health care, education and the environment.
The daylong hearing provided further evidence that Mr. Gore, who easily defeated former Senator Bill Bradley in the primaries, will not face the kind of bitter policy divisions that have bedeviled Democratic presidential nominees of the past. 
 Democratic officials intend to release a draft of the platform on Friday. And they made it clear that they expected it to be a clear articulation of Mr. Gore's vision rather than the kind of ideological treatise he might feel compelled to run away from.
"My sense is that much of this is straight out of what he has already had to say, what he has already proposed," Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, chairman of the platform drafting committee, said today. "And I think he can run on it and win," Mr. Hunt said.
The Democrats are hoping that their unified front will give them the appearance of greater party strength than the Republicans, whose platform meetings continue to provide a forum for fierce debate over abortion.
This year, the trade issue was widely expected to be the Democrats' platform equivalent of abortion. Many trade unions and environmentalists, major components of the Democratic base, have opposed the Clinton administration's position on global trade, arguing that it has hurt the environment and siphoned jobs away from American workers.
But today, trade was rarely mentioned. Indeed, the one person expected to raise the issue, Alan Reuther, legislative director for the United Automobile Workers, did not show up. Democratic officials said Mr. Reuther had a scheduling conflict.
One of the few discordant notes was sounded by Amy Isaacs, national director of Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal group. Speaking on the trade issue, Ms. Isaacs said: "Granting China permanent normal trade relations is a step in the wrong direction, we believe. As a nation, we must state clearly that profits over people is untenable."
Ms. Isaacs added that "liberals in the country are very uneasy" with the nation's political drift. And she urged the people writing the Democratic platform not to blur the distinctions between the two major parties, a criticism often leveled at the Democrats by Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president.
Mary Leigh Blek, a registered Republican from Orange County, Calif., who helped organize the Million Mom March for gun control earlier this year, typified their tone. Ms. Blek, without explicitly endorsing Mr. Gore, complained that the leadership of the Republican Party had not heard the voices of mothers who want stronger gun laws.
"But I think in November, they are going to hear it," she said.
Democratic officials said the committee was likely to face some policy debates behind closed doors tonight as they hammered out the final draft. For instance, labor officials are pushing for stronger language defending the rights of workers to form unions. They also want a clearer pledge of support for trade agreements that protect the environment and workers' rights.
Some members of the committee are also expected to push for a more sweeping declaration of the party's support for ending discrimination against gays and lesbians and a more powerful condemnation of racially motivated violence.
But those debates are expected play out on the fringes, not at the heart, of the 10,000- to 20,000-word document.
"We're not looking for a fight here at all," said Gerry Shea, a top official with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who is on the platform drafting committee.

HEADLINE: 2 Views of Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 6

 BODY:
There is a go-for-broke quality to the Israeli and American approach to the coming Camp David summit meeting, which starts on Tuesday with the stated goal of ending a 52-year-old, blood-steeped conflict.
But for the Palestinians, whose participation is more reluctant, there is at best an aspiration that the three-way meeting will serve as a stopgap to keep alive the stalemated peace effort so that a partial deal can be achieved by September. 
 Prime Minister Ehud Barak will arrive in Maryland as a weakened Israeli leader with one thing on his mind: to push the peace effort with the Palestinians to a conclusion before he loses his grip on power. Battered by the right over his peace moves and by the left over his concessions to the religious parties, he will try to rise above the partisan politics that, with two parties poised to quit his coalition, is about to cost him his parliamentary majority.
Mr. Barak will seek to forge the framework of a final peace deal with the Palestinians on the basis of what he considers a directive from the Israeli people, who overwhelming elected him last year on a platform of peacemaking. And if he fails, he said today, he will have given it his best effort in the face of a potential for the conflict to disintegrate "into Belfast or Bosnia."
Similarly, President Clinton appears to have decided that he cannot make things worse by forcing the parties into an endgame, since no summit meeting and a failed summit meeting have the same potential outcome: violence. If the chemistry of the moment produces a breakthrough, the accomplishment is substantial. If not, the risk to the American president is minimal.
But the Palestinians' leader, Yasir Arafat, whose lifelong struggle rests on this effort, will approach Camp David far more skeptically and cautiously than the other two leaders. He will take part against the counsel of his senior advisers, who think the groundwork has not been laid for a compromise on any major issue.
Of mixed mind, Mr. Arafat is saying that he is going only because he cannot refuse an invitation from President Clinton. But he is also betting that if negotiations are to work, he stands to gain the most at a high-stakes summit meeting presided over by this American president, with whom he has forged a bond. Weighing the alternative -- a unilateral declaration of statehood, which is bound to be accompanied by violence, an Israeli annexation of West Bank land and complications for Mr. Arafat's international acceptance -- he is willing to gamble.
Like Anwar el-Sadat, before the last Middle East peace gathering at Camp David, in 1978, Mr. Arafat needs to deliver some kind of victory to his people, weary of bloodshed.
Having proclaimed and disclaimed previous deadlines for establishing a state, Mr. Arafat and the Palestinian leadership this week tied the Palestinian fate to a new one, Sept. 13. This one will be harder to ignore if he is to retain his credibility; it marks the formal end of the interim peacemaking period, which was extended from May 4, 1999.
But the chief economic adviser to Mr. Arafat, Mohammed Rachid, said tonight that the Palestinians would willingly bypass the deadline if they were engaged in serious negotiations. And many experts think the Palestinian people, who would prefer a real state to a nominal one, could be persuaded to endure another postponement if they saw any tangible progress, like a substantial transfer of West Bank land.
"The people are pragmatic and they'll accept a bird in the hand," said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian political analyst. "There is a growing minority that rejects the peace process, but it is not a majority, and there is no alternative. There is no other game."
A cartoon in the Palestinian newspaper Al Quds today showed the spirit of the meeting as a whirlwind blowing out the candle of the Palestinian declaration of independence.
Israeli military analysts paint a different picture. In a briefing for foreign reporters today, a senior military officer in the West Bank said Mr. Arafat had introduced a "struggle consciousness" to accompany the negotiations. He said Mr. Arafat wants to achieve independence "through friction and blood."
"The rules of the game are low-intensity conflict accompanying the diplomatic process with the threat of terrorism in the background," the senior officer said. "Arafat wants to appear as both the pyromaniac and the fireman."
One could be whipsawed by the surface contradictions here today between the bounding optimism of Israeli doves and the thick skepticism of Palestinian officials.
Leaving a meeting with Mr. Arafat in Gaza City, Yossi Beilin, Israel's justice minister, expressed unconditional faith in the eventuality of a peace deal. "I don't believe that all the leaders will go to Camp David and come back empty-handed," he said. "We are going to make peace. And after all these years, we will have to compromise, both sides, to find solutions and come back home and tell our kids that they will not have to take part in the wars we took part in."
In contrast, Abu Ala, the speaker of the Palestinian legislature and a senior negotiator, said he does not think the summit meeting will achieve any of its aims. "It is clear that Barak is trying to escape from negotiations and jump to a summit because he thinks he can force deals," he said. "But if he thinks that he can give us some land on which to declare a Palestinian state and then we will forget the other issues, then he's living in a dream world."
Mr. Rachid, a relatively unideological and pragmatic adviser, spoke more practically about what could be achieved. He said that, in Israeli style and on an Israeli scale, the Palestinians would ask the Americans for $40 billion in aid to accompany a peace treaty. Most of that would go toward refugee aid, he said.
He also that the Israelis were overly focused on the percentage of the West Bank they would transfer to the Palestinians. He noted that Mr. Barak, who started out talking about turning over 50 percent of the land, had increased his offer most recently to 88 percent -- 78 percent now and 10 percent over time. But Mr. Rachid said the Palestinians wanted the Israelis to stop thinking of it as their land to give away and to start accepting the principle that the Palestinians have a rightful claim to the West Bank. That, he suggested, would make the Palestinians more flexible.
Mr. Barak is unlikely to travel to Washington with his most hard-line ministers because they are expected to quit before he leaves. Interior Minister Natan Sharansky, who leads a small Russian immigrant party, has said he will tender his resignation on Sunday, and Housing Minister Yitzhak Levy, who leads the National Religious Party, is prepared to step down too. Eli Yishai, leader of the rigorously Orthodox Shas Party, is undecided about whether he will travel with the prime minister.
Mr. Barak is expected to be accompanied by a delegation including Foreign Minister David Levy, Internal Security Minister Shlomo Ben Ami, and Attorney General Elyakim Rubenstein and his security advisers. Mr. Arafat's delegation will include Mr. Abu Ala, Mr. Rachid, the senior negotiators Abu Mazen and Saeb Erekat, and Mohammed Dahlan, a security chief.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Political Football: Germany Lands the 2006 World Cup

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
In a mild surprise, Germany was awarded the 2006 World Cup over South Africa yesterday as international soccer officials apparently chose the certain success of the world's largest sporting event in a European country over concerns of stability and safety about post-apartheid South Africa.
Germany prevailed by one vote in a dramatic result that carried much political soccer intrigue in Zurich, the home of the sport's world governing body, known by its French initials as FIFA. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany said the victory showed that his country was "open to the world and hospitable" a half-century after Nazism and nearly three decades after the slaying of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich. 
 Meanwhile, President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa called the defeat "a tragic day for Africa." Securing the World Cup was being viewed as a way to help transform South Africa as it continues to reshape itself from its recent past of government-mandated racial separation by boosting national pride, attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors and a billion television viewers, adding several billions of dollars and more than 100,000 jobs to the struggling economy and ameliorating the concerns of skittish international investors. While rugby and cricket are the national sports of white South Africans, soccer is the sport of choice for the overwhelming black majority.
South Africa had been host to the 1995 Rugby World Cup and the 1996 African Nations Cup soccer championships and believed it had the necessary stadiums, infrastructure and technology to stage the 2006 World Cup. Instead, for the second time in three years, it was denied a major international sporting event. In the fall of 1997, Cape Town lost to Athens in its bid to be host of the 2004 Summer Games as members of the International Olympic Committee voiced concerns after Nelson Mandela left office as president of South Africa.
Alan I. Rothenberg, the past president of the United States Soccer Federation who headed the FIFA committee that inspected the countries bidding on the 2006 World Cup, said his group had ranked Germany just ahead of South Africa in terms of preparedness. Germany is an international soccer power, having won three World Cups and three European titles, and it has Europe's strongest economy. It also entered yesterday's voting with the firm backing of the eight Europeans who are one-third of the 24-member FIFA executive committee, whose main job is to award the World Cup. For the 2002 World Cup, South Korea and Japan will be the co-hosts.
On Monday, Brazil had withdrawn its candidacy and thrown its support behind South Africa, reportedly in exchange for South Africa's support of its bid for the 2010 World Cup. Joseph (Sepp) Blatter, the president of FIFA, had also thrown his public support behind South Africa. England's chances disappeared with the thuggish acts of hooliganism committed by its fans at the recently completed European Championships held in Belgium and the Netherlands. Morocco was never given a serious chance of winning because the North African nation had a severe lack of necessary stadiums.
"I would say the vote was a mild surprise, not a shock," Rothenberg, who organized the most successful World Cup ever held, in the United States in 1994, said by telephone from Zurich. "We felt for some time that it would come down to Germany or South Africa and be very close."
Both countries were considered well qualified, Rothenberg said, but increasing violence in South Africa appeared to make some voters hesitant.
"On the one hand, nothing could be surer than having Germany or any other major western European country hosting a World Cup," Rothenberg said. "It's going to be enormously successful. South Africa came down to people assessing in their heart that while they may want it to go to South Africa, it is better to wait a while longer. This new country is only six years old. Obviously it has certain safety problems. We were satisfied after speaking with law enforcement and security people that people would be safe going there during the World Cup. We were satisfied; possibly other people weren't."
In the end, yesterday's voting was also affected by the ubiquitous and complicated political intrigue that attends the awarding of all major international sporting events. Three rounds of polling were necessary before Germany prevailed with a majority of votes from FIFA's executive committee. In the final round, Germany prevailed by 12-11, with an unexplained abstention from Charles Dempsey, a delegate from New Zealand.
The South Africans claimed that Dempsey had reneged on a promise to vote for them after England had been eliminated. His abstention led to speculation that Blatter, FIFA's president, had orchestrated the German victory behind the scenes even though he publicly supported South Africa. Had Dempsey voted for South Africa, leaving the result even at 12-12, Blatter would have been called upon to break the tie.
"I was a little bit sad that the executive committee had not the courage to innovate," Blatter said. "We have to trust Africa and we have to take this decision. We have to take the risk, otherwise they will never have a chance."
"It's very strange, unfortunate," Rothenberg said of Dempsey's abstention. "He claimed he was under enormous pressure. So is everyone on the committee. It's probably the single most important thing you do as a member of the FIFA executive committee, vote on the host of the World Cup. You make your vote and take the consequences. Some like it or hate it, but that's life. You do the right thing. I don't understand."
