SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1423 words

HEADLINE: Business Links On Web Raise Antitrust Issues

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
As companies in practically every industry rush to join business-to-business exchanges on the Internet, regulators are growing concerned that they will face a rash of new antitrust questions for which they are not prepared.
Known as B2B Web sites, the exchanges create a place for companies in the same industry, be it automobiles or grain, to buy and sell goods, potentially saving millions of dollars in back-office costs by setting up a national marketplace online. But the sites, which can compile huge amounts of sensitive data and are often jointly owned by corporate rivals, also create opportunities for collusion and price-fixing that did not exist before, antitrust experts say. 
 Both regulators and executives agree that the stakes are enormous. B2B sites already account for about $150 billion in annual sales, significantly more than the better-known consumer sites like Amazon.com. And that number is expected to grow exponentially as businesses move more and more into buying and selling on the Web.
"Antitrust has never had this kind of factual scenario to look at before," said Susan DeSanti, the director of policy planning for the Federal Trade Commission.
Last week, the commission took the unusual step of holding a two-day conference to which it invited executives, lawyers and consumer advocates to advise it on how to regulate B2B marketplaces. Already, the commission is examining Covisint, the site being planned by the nation's Big Three automakers, and last month the Department of Justice said it was investigating one that is being led by six large meatpacking companies.
The Senate Commerce Committee also plans to hold a hearing this month on the airline industry's joint Web sites. And law firms are doing a brisk business in advising business-to-business exchanges on how to organize themselves so as to avoid regulatory scrutiny.
Government officials are beginning to take notice now because in recent months one group of major companies after another has announced plans to form exchanges.
Indeed, legal experts say B2B exchanges are likely to present the next major forum -- after the Microsoft trial and the proposed WorldCom-Sprint and America Online-Time Warner mergers -- for the debate over how century-old antitrust laws should be applied to the new world of the Internet. As in the previous cases, lawyers say, the questions are not new: What is collusion and how can it be stopped? When are competitors allowed to cooperate with each other? Which rivals can they exclude from an alliance?
The new twists are the speed with which companies are able to communicate with one another and the frequency with which longtime rivals, like DaimlerChrysler and General Motors and Ford, are setting up joint ventures. Legal experts say those ventures -- the B2B exchanges -- will give suppliers the opportunity to signal each other about price increases, for instance, or manufacturers a chance to conspire to pay artificially low prices for their supplies.
"It's like the issue that came up with Microsoft," said Andrew I. Gavil, a professor at the Howard University School of Law. "Is antitrust up to dealing with technology?"
Corporate executives, for their part, say the exchanges will increase competition by giving companies access to the most updated, accurate information about prices. That in turn will lower businesses' costs, increasing profits for efficient companies and eventually bringing lower prices to consumers, they add.
For now, regulators say they are trying to learn as much as they can about the B2B sites before issuing any far-reaching policies or bringing lawsuits against individual exchanges. "We at the F.T.C. are very much in a learning phase," Sheila F. Anthony, a commissioner, told executives and lawyers at last week's conference.
"The promise of huge efficiencies is certainly tantalizing," Ms. Anthony added. "On the other hand, I can't help but wonder if there might be a serpent in the garden of efficiencies."
And Orson Swindle, another commissioner, said: "We must get this right. Otherwise, we could do terrible harm."
The sites take any number of forms, from auctions that resemble eBay to online catalogs that allow buyers to sift through products. Some, like Covisint, are set up by the companies doing the buying. Others, like MetalSite, which is owned mainly by steel manufacturers, are run by sellers.
In either case, though, regulators' worries fall into two general areas, Ms. DeSanti said. In shorthand, Professor Gavil added, the issues can be thought of as "exclusion" (who is allowed to participate in the exchanges, under what conditions) and "collusion" (what the participants might do with the information they gather).
At the heart of the regulators' concerns is how the rapid exchange of information on the Web sites will affect the companies' behavior.
In almost every sector of the economy, industry groups now spend weeks collecting data on prices and sales volumes. On the B2B exchanges, by contrast, companies will be able to see current information immediately. That could make it easier for them to coordinate the pricing of goods without ever speaking to each other about it -- a practice that legal scholars call conscious parallelism.
Lacking detailed, current information, a company might decide to cut prices in a few markets and hope it can steal some market share before a rival catches on, said Jonathan B. Baker, a former F.T.C. official who now teaches at American University's law school. On a business-to-business Web site, however, information travels more quickly and could eliminate the price wars.
The worry is more than than just hypothetical, antitrust experts say. In 1992, the Justice Department sued the nation's large airlines, accusing them of using their computer reservation systems to send up trial balloons on price changes. Smaller airlines also opposed the system, saying they lacked the money to buy computers that had suddenly become necessary to compete.
As a result of the suit, the airlines agreed to stop publishing information about future changes in fares.
Though the legal proceedings surrounding it ended years ago, the airline reservation system has become a frequent topic of discussion among executives, corporate lawyers and government officials today. The central questions it raised in the early 1990's -- of the ways that a network can cause collusion and exclusion -- are the same ones at the core of the new B2B debate, lawyers say.
"It's a fair analogy," said Mark L. Walsh, the chief executive of VerticalNet, which owns 56 B2B marketplaces. Business-to-business exchanges offer "a similar potential for abuse," he added.
Consumer advocates also say that because so many of the exchanges are owned by competitors, the Web sites will allow rivals to make decisions jointly about production levels and inventories, becoming de facto cartels in the mold of OPEC. "These are serious, structural issues," said Mark Cooper, the research director of the Consumer Federation of America.
To address the concerns -- and avoid regulatory run-ins -- the companies setting up the exchanges are including antitrust lawyers at almost every stage of the planning, executives say. The lawyer for MetalSite has attended all of the site's board meetings, and MetalSite executives avoid giving specific data to its board members, who work for the steel companies that own the site, said David B. Bordo, the site's chief operating officer.
"We probably show our board less information than most boards see," Mr. Bordo said. "They only see aggregated data,"
The exchanges hope to convince their customers that the Web sites are independent of the companies that founded them. Covisint, for example, is now negotiating with the F.T.C. over the terms of its formal separation from the car companies that created it, said A. Alan Turfe, the G.M. executive who is the exchange's interim co-chief executive.
The customers, meanwhile, are concerned that proprietary information -- like how much aluminum they are buying and at what price -- will become available to rivals or clients.
Francis P. Lopez, the chief executive of the Aztec Manufacturing Corporation, an auto industry supplier in Romulus, Mich., said B2B Web sites could cut costs and offered "tremendous, tremendous advantages."
"But there are a lot of gray areas people are concerned about," Mr. Lopez added. "We have to make sure we have the ability to protect privacy" of companies' sensitive data.

Over the last year, companies in a wide range of industries have announced plans to form Internet marketplaces where they and their suppliers can buy and sell goods. The flurry of announcements has caused government regulators to begin examining the potential antitrust problems that the exchanges could create.
 
Recent announcements of major marketplaces, known as business-to-business Web sites, include:
 
Covisint -- A joint venture among several major auto companies, including DaimlerChrysler, Ford and General Motors. The automakers have agreed to do all of their purchasing on one Web site.
 
GlobalNetExchange -- Sears, Roebuck and Carrefour of France, together with Oracle, plan to create a global online marketplace for the retail industry, inviting other retailers to join. The joint venture will initially focus on the combined $80 billion in purchases that Sears and Carrefour make from 50,000 suppliers, partners and distributors.
 
Orbitz -- Several airlines have banded together to create a fare site for leisure travelers. Delta, United, Northwest, Continental and American will take part. The site is expected to offer fares similar to the discount tickets available on the airlines' own sites.
 
Transora -- Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola, Nestle and 46 other consumer-goods makers are investing $250 million in Transora.com, an online marketplace where they can negotiate prices with suppliers, buyers and distributors to lower costs. The companies generate about $500 billion in annual sales.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1367 words

HEADLINE: As Teacher in the Classroom, Internet Needs Fine-Tuning

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WEAVERVILLE, Calif.

 BODY:
When it learned last year that a private company was offering college-level Advanced Placement courses on the Web, the lone high school in this remote gold-rush town thought it had finally discovered a perfect way to mine the genuine academic potential of the Internet.
For the school, Trinity High, with 500 students, the prospect of hiring its own Advanced Placement teacher had always been an unaffordable luxury, even though taking such courses has become a near necessity for students to get into the most competitive colleges. 
 So the school, in the redwood-dense mountains halfway between San Francisco and the Oregon border, logged on. In essence, it took the Clinton administration up on its pledge that there was educational salvation in new technology, and that the Web could help the nation's poorest schools approximate the offerings of the wealthiest, particularly in a corner of the curriculum where the discrepancies are most stark.
But so far the results here and elsewhere have been ragged, suggesting that a computer can be a crude substitute for a live teacher, particularly when the students are so young, the stakes for them are so high and the technology is so new.
Several thousand high school students nationwide took college-level courses online this year through a private company, Apex Learning, or one of three state university systems. They included two teenagers here, each of them enrolled in an Advanced Placement government and politics class in which the lessons were transmitted through electronic text and animated short films, with grades reported via e-mail. The teacher was never seen.
One Weaverville student dropped out midway through the spring semester because, he said, he could not summon the stamina to continue, absent a teacher standing in front of him; the other student finished the same course, but two weeks late, frustrated by countless technical glitches that often prevented him from logging onto the Web for hours.
Similar growing pains were felt by other districts, including some of those that also contracted with Apex, of Bellevue, Wash., a leader in providing Advanced Placement courses online. Of the 600 students in 28 states who enrolled in at least one of the company's online Advanced Placement courses in the last school year, two-thirds did not complete enough of the course work to take the final exam, Apex officials said.
"This is still pretty new and we are all learning about it," said Sally Narodick, the chief executive of Apex, incorporated two years ago.
Much is riding on whether such efforts succeed. While President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have heralded the educational possibilities of the Web, most of what has been labeled instruction in cyberspace is supplemental at best -- SAT training, college counseling and virtual field trips.
But online Advanced Placement courses represent something else, one of the first real opportunities to marshal technology to plug gaping holes in the core curriculums of financially pressed rural and inner-city high schools that cannot afford luxuries like college-level courses. Apex charges schools $325 to $400 per student. Hiring a teacher could cost more than $50,000 a year.
Apex, one of the few for-profit ventures in the online Advanced Placement business, has raised $40 million from investors, including Warburg Pincus, a Wall Street firm; Vulcan Ventures, a fund led by Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft, and Edison Schools, the public school management company led by the entrepreneur Christopher C. Whittle.Michigan State University, the University of Nebraska and Johns Hopkins University are also offering college-level courses to high school students online.
All are seeking to close one of the widest gaps between rich and poor schools. First begun as an experiment in the 1950's involving fewer than 2,000 students and a handful of college-level courses, the Advanced Placement program, run by the College Board, now involves more than 700,000 high school students who took 1.1 million final course exams for college credit this spring.
Enrollment in at least one such course is regarded as an unofficial prerequisite for admission to the nation's most selective colleges, and the University of California system gives applicants who take such courses extra credit on their transcripts. Yet only half of the nation's high school students have access to Advanced Placement courses, which are regarded as a perk in districts strapped for cash.
The Secretary of Education, Richard Riley, has proposed that every high school in the country offer at least one Advanced Placement course by 2002, and add at least one new course each year over the next 10 years. The Clinton administration has asked Congress to spend $10 million to help rural and inner-city schools purchase Advanced Placement courses online.
To Gaston Caperton, the president of the College Board, such online courses are a weak stand-in for what he says the country needs: 180,000 teachers trained to offer college-level courses to two million more high school students.
But Francisco J. Hernandez, vice chancellor of the University of California at Santa Cruz, says such plans are pipe dreams, considering that many of the districts lacking Advanced Placement courses have a severe shortage of teachers in even basic subjects. Often, Mr. Hernandez said, an online course, however flawed, is the only opportunity a student has. This past school year, the University of California College Prep Initiative, conceived by Mr. Hernandez and operated out of the system's Santa Cruz campus, used state grants to pay for 800 California high school students to take Advanced Placement courses online. They included the two at Weaverville.
"Our intent is not to be an alternative to a high quality teacher and classroom," Mr. Hernandez said. "Our intent is to be an alternative to nothing, and that's what they're getting right now."
In Weaverville, a town of 3,370 people, many of them loggers and forest rangers, the experience of the two students who took Apex's online government course underscored the program's promise and its flaws.
For Brian Jones, 19, a senior who wants to be a record producer, and Jeremy Forbes, 18, a classmate who dreams of becoming a cartoonist, taking college-level "U.S. Government and Politics" introduced them to the concepts of pluralism, federalism, liberalism and conservatism. Both said they now looked at presidential politics in a new light.
But each was tripped up by shortcomings that, so far, are embedded in such courses.
In mid-March, in the 7th week of the 15-week course, Mr. Jones was still doing work he should have completed in the second week. He said he was overwhelmed by the idea of writing a two-page essay twice a week and taking an exam every three weeks. And with his professor, Steve Sandweiss, 448 miles away in Tacoma, Wash., where he is a professor at a community college, Mr. Jones dropped out, enrolling instead in his high school's civics course.
"I didn't feel like doing any work," he said. "I'm just not organized a lot of the time."
Mr. Forbes was far more dogged, but he had continual problems signing onto the Apex Web site -- sometimes because of problems on Apex's end, and sometimes because of the limited capacity of the computers in his school. Mr. Forbes finished the course two weeks late, and took the Advanced Placement exam. He will know his grade soon -- but said that for all the disruption he felt well-prepared for the exam.
Apex officials said that they were already working to rectify the problems, smoothing software miscommunication, extending the course calendar by three weeks and providing training for mentor teachers in students' high schools. But Mr. Forbes's guidance counselor, Noreen Bradbury, said that even in their present form, the online courses were a godsend.
Ms. Bradbury said she already had 11 students signed up to take advanced courses next year in history, statistics, psychology, government and economics.
"It opens the world to our kids," she said. "They're not distant and different from everyone else out there. They're as good."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Begins Upstate Tour in Familiar Spot, Focusing on Economy

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 6

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to an electronics plant today that was the scene of an event during her early days as a prospective Senate candidate last year. She talked today about reviving the economy in upstate New York and chose this spot to begin a five-day tour throughout this region of the state.
As Mrs. Clinton began her upstate campaign swing, her Republican opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, was on the final legs of his trip. In a meeting with about 100 workers at a Lockheed Martin electronics plant and in speaking with reporters, she was quick to point out the differences in her campaign tactics from those of Mr. Lazio. 
 "He's got moderate talk on the trail and extreme rhetoric in his mail," Mrs. Clinton said. "I just think it's hard to tell what he means and where he is from day to day. I'm not going to respond to his personal insults. I'm going to run a campaign on issues, not insults."
In particular, Mrs. Clinton reacted to a fund-raising letter sent to voters this week by Mr. Lazio's campaign in which he attacked Mrs. Clinton and President Clinton for having "embarrassed our country and disgraced their powerful posts." Mrs. Clinton, the letter states, "covets power and control and thinks she should be dictating how other people run their lives."
Mr. Lazio has said he had not reviewed the fund-raising letter before it was sent. "It's hard for me to get this straight," Mrs. Clinton said, speaking to reporters. "Last week he was telling New Yorkers that he wasn't responsible for his voting record. And this week he's telling us that he's not responsible for his fund-raising letters. I think he ought to rename his bus. Instead of the Mainstream Express, he ought to call it the Double-Talk Express."
Speaking at a news briefing outside a senior housing apartment building in Syracuse today, Mr. Lazio said he still had not seen the letter and he continued to decline to specify what the president and Mrs. Clinton had done to embarrass the country.
"I think you can make a big distinction between a solicitation letter for funds among your supporters and communicating with commercials," Mr. Lazio said, referring to television ads by Mrs. Clinton's campaign that he has characterized as attack ads.
At the plant, where electronic controls are made, Mrs. Clinton met today with managers, took a tour and experienced simulated flying in a military aircraft. Meeting with employees, she answered questions on topics ranging from transportation in the Southern Tier region of the state to federal spending on research and development.
Mrs. Clinton also attended a cookout with about 1,500 people in Endicott, N.Y., sponsored by the Democratic Party organizations in Broome, Tioga, Tompkins and Cortland Counties. Her trip throughout the region comes a year after she unofficially entered the race for the United States Senate when she visited the farm of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, whom she hopes to succeed.
On this trip, however, Mrs. Clinton is a full-fledged candidate and her tour across the state's western half is focused on economic issues. She has produced a pamphlet that is being distributed to voters discussing various ideas, including tax credits for investments in new technology and making high-speed Internet access more widely available.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA;
RUPIAH WEAK AGAINST DOLLAR

BYLINE: By Seth Mydans 

 BODY:
The Indonesian currency, the rupiah, traded against the dollar at its lowest exchange rate in 16 months, and analysts in Indonesia said it was unlikely to rebound soon. The rupiah settled in Jakarta at 9,290 to the dollar and in New York at 9,252.50. Analysts said politics, not the economy, was pushing down the currency, adding that they did not expect a significant upturn in the currency's value until after a session of Parliament next month that is expected to be volatile. HEADLINE: The Price of Gas, Here and There

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Steep Rise Is Forecast for Winter Heating Bills" (front page, July 5): 
 I get the impression that someone has forgotten to tell America that natural gas and oil are nonrenewable resources. Prices are not only bound to continue to rise; eventually, these resources are going to run out!
Instead of complaining, perhaps Americans could spare a thought for the rest of humanity and for coming generations, including their own children and grandchildren.
Unlike the Apollo astronauts, we have nowhere to get back to. We have to sort the problem out while still on board, changing from a nonsustainable to a sustainable economy and to lifestyles that do not threaten our planet's life-supporting ecosystems.
At the moment things are not looking good. Most people do not even seem to realize that we have a problem, or have deluded themselves by believing that it is being addressed.
 
ROGER HICKS
Braunschweig, Germany, July 6, 2000

HEADLINE: By The Boom That Threatens Chinatown

BYLINE: By John Wang; John Wang is president of the Asian-American Business Development Center in Manhattan.

 BODY:
Boom times are the worst thing ever to have hit New York's Chinatown. Twenty-five years ago, New York needed Chinatown. The city was on the brink of bankruptcy, and many neighborhoods were declining. Chinatown was a rare area of growing prosperity in the tight times, emerging from an area occupying few city blocks to transform a dilapidated Lower East Side into a thriving community.
And now that things are good, New York seems to care little about its old friend, turning its attention instead to Silicon Alley entrepreneurs and Wall Street barons. Chinatown has stagnated in the past several years, hurt by rising rents, aggressive enforcement of old city laws and a digital divide. 
 Chinatown's economy, now as in the past, depends largely on a core of small businesses in mature and declining industries: small-scale manufacturing, much of it in the garment industry; restaurants that specialize in Chinese cuisine; retail and wholesale trade; tourism and gift shops. We in Chinatown need the city's help in both preserving our traditional businesses and generating more modern ones.
The garment industry, which once employed 30,000 people in Chinatown, has been hardest hit. Foreign competition, low-cost production overseas and occasional charges of sweatshop operations have driven manufacturers away from Chinatown: its garment factories have decreased from 500 to less than 300. This decline has had a multiplier effect as lost income in the community has sent sales plunging in other businesses. Now garment factories struggle to pay $10 to $12 a square foot for loft space in Chinatown while dot-com companies, which are edging in from the outside, would gladly pay double or triple that. Some provision should be made to keep at least some buildings operating with affordable rents.
Senator Charles Schumer has appointed a task force of prominent business leaders, known as the Group of 35, to find more commercial space in the city for growing companies. Perhaps a representative of a small business or manufacturing industry should be appointed to this task force, too, to reflect more diverse business needs.
Lower Manhattan's residential boom has also hurt Chinatown. In the 1980's and 1990's, the upscale development that started in SoHo began to to hem Chinatown in, causing economic and cultural clashes. The sidewalk fish and vegetable stalls that most New Yorkers once saw as quaint are viewed by some of our new neighbors as dirty and smelly inconveniences. The wholesale trades of poultry and groceries, with their early morning deliveries and congestion on the sidewalks, are seen as a nuisance.
Appeals have been made to the local community boards to restrict certain business operations. The Police Department and Department of Consumer Affairs have dusted off all the rule books, ticketing sidewalk vendors for all types of violations that had not been enforced in decades and, in some cases, are still not enforced elsewhere. Not long ago, the city unearthed a quarter-century-old Little Italy special zoning district, limiting types of businesses and setting requirements for stores, and attempted to force merchants to comply with its rules and regulations -- in an area where properties have been more than 90 percent Chinese-owned and Chinese-occupied for more than a decade.
Of course, Chinatown's own entrepreneurs must recognize the need to modernize. Within New York's Asian-American community, a yawning digital divide has appeared. National studies show that Asian-Americans as a group have the highest computer ownership and Internet connection rates for any ethnic group in the United States, but a recent survey by the Asian American Business Development Center found a different picture in Chinatown. Although 85 percent of the small businesses that responded use computers, most of those are outdated and cannot be connected to the Internet. Most Chinatown entrepreneurs don't yet fully appreciate the need to develop educational and economic resources to turn around declining businesses.
What's most important for the preservation of Chinatown, however, is a recognition by the city itself that this neighborhood is an endangered asset. The City Planning Commission should study how best to preserve Chinatown, whose special character has always been a point of municipal pride. Our city's leaders should recognize, too, that by helping to sustain New York in difficult years, Chinatown helped lay the foundation for today's boom. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Earmarked for Colombian Rebels, a Region Asks to Be Left Alone

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: YONDO, Colombia

 BODY:
For years, the people of this thriving little oil town on the bank of the Magdalena River complained that the authorities back in Bogota never paid them any attention. But now that they and their neighbors have suddenly become pivotal to a government plan to open peace talks with second-largest guerrilla group here, they want only to be left alone.
When President Andres Pastrana announced the plan in April, it seemed a simple matter. To lure the Marxist rebels of the Army of National Liberation, or E.L.N., into negotiations, Yondo and two other municipalities north of here were to be turned into a "zone of encounter" under guerrilla control, with all army and police units withdrawn. 
 There has never been a shortage of armed groups roaming this area. So the government apparently thought that an end of hostilities would be welcome. Left-wing guerrillas, right-wing paramilitaries and the military have all sought to control this resource rich and strategic region, the Middle Magdalena. And all have left casualties in their wakes.
What the authorities in Bogota did not expect, though, was the popular resistance that has emerged. Soon after the announcement, thousands of protesters blocked the Pan American Highway, cutting off most commerce between central and northern Colombia.
"If they really want to talk peace, all they need to negotiate is a table and chairs," said Leonel Uribe Hernandez, a municipal official here and a leader of the protest. "They don't need all this territory. If the E.L.N. leaders are worried about their safety, let them talk overseas, in Venezuela or Spain or Germany. But we don't want to be a part of this."
After several weeks, Mr. Pastrana relented and agreed to a "dialogue" with residents. As part of a recent accord, the government has agreed to delay formally establishing the zone until undertaking "popular consultations," a phrase that the government seems to interpret as town meetings and workshops, but that residents take to mean a plebiscite.
"This is a democracy, so let the people vote on this and let their will be respected," Councilman Nixon Arrieta said. "If they say yes, then fine. But I don't think that is likely to happen, because we have nothing to gain from this and everything to lose."
The territory that the government has agreed to hand over is roughly the size of Delaware, or barely one-tenth the size of a separate demilitarized zone granted to the largest guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. But the strategic importance of this area is much greater because it sits astride the country's main waterway and is within striking distance of a railway line and the Pan American Highway.
"I don't know what the president was thinking," a teacher here said. "The E.L.N. has a long history of blowing up oil pipelines, power stations and transmission lines. And he wants to put them right across the river from the biggest oil refinery in the country," which processes the bulk of Colombia's gasoline and is in Barrancabermeja.
Like the more sparsely populated FARC zone to the south, which is larger than Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island combined, this is cattle country and abounds in fertile pastures. But cows and water buffaloes have to graze alongside oil wells that produce millions of dollars a year in royalties.
Farther north, the mountains of the Serrania de San Lucas have large deposits of gold, emeralds, nickel and mercury. The gold mines have been shut for years because of the violence but could easily reopen after the fighting stops and soon thereafter begin filling the coffers of the E.L.N., which has met with military reverses in recent months.
The biggest and fastest-growing source of wealth in the area, however, is farming coca. The E.L.N. controlled drug trafficking here until 18 months ago, when it was violently supplanted by paramilitaries of the United Peasant Self-Defense force. And the E.L.N. would clearly like to regain the dominance and the revenues that it once enjoyed.
"This is anything but a fight over ideology," said Mayor Danuil Mecera of San Pablo, a town an hour's boat ride north of here that is in the E.L.N. zone. "This is a struggle for economic control and power, pure and simple, between two illegal armed groups that only want to strengthen their position at the expense of the other."
As government negotiations with protesters drag on, disgruntled E.L.N. forces are staying out of the towns and holing up in their mountain stronghold north of here. In a recent television interview, the senior commander, Nicolas Rodriguez Bautista, acknowledged that "there is much fear" of a peace zone but attributed that to "the pressure of paramilitary groups."
Residents and local officials say their real concern is that violence may increase after the zone has been set up, because the accord between the government and the rebels excludes paramilitary forces. With the army and the police withdrawn, the critics said, residents would be even more likely to be caught in cross-fire between the rebels and adamant paramilitary units.
"This territory is ours," said the local paramilitary leader, who is known as Comandante Julian. The fundamental problem, he added, is that "there are three states here, that of the guerrillas, the real one of the government and that of the self-defense forces."
Nevertheless, he added, "We will respect what the population decides, and if they accept a zone, we will withdraw our troops."
Hoping to win over the residents, the national government arranged for local officials to visit the FARC zone and talk with their counterparts and other residents there. But that effort backfired when the officials returned home with tales of extortion of businesses, summary executions, forced recruitment of teenagers and other guerrilla abuses.
"We can see for ourselves what happened down there, and we've been contacted by people down there who tell us that we should fight by all means to prevent what happened to them from happening to us," a pharmacist in San Pablo said. "The FARC zone has become an independent country, and we don't want that happening here."

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
KOSOVO: EX-REBEL LEADER SHOT
A former Kosovo Liberation Army commander was wounded in a shootout with supporters of a Kosovo Albanian political rival, witnesses said. Ramush Haradinaj, who now leads Kosovo's third-largest party, was traveling with a relative when the two were attacked in the village of Streoce. United Nations police officers were investigating. (AP)
 
RUSSIA: NO TO SECRET POLICE MONUMENT
In a sign of the waning influence of Communists and their allies, the lower house of Parliament voted down a measure calling for the restoration of a monument to the father of the Soviet secret police. A similar bill passed in 1998, but was ignored by Moscow city authorities. The new bill called for the restoration of a Stalin-era bronze statue of Felix Dzerzhinsky, founder of the ruthless Cheka secret police, which evolved into the N.K.V.D. and K.G.B. security forces, responsible for the death of millions. The statue, above, was torn down by jubilant crowds in 1991. (Reuters) 

GERMANY: GAY UNIONS BILL
The government presented Parliament with a bill to permit "gay weddings" in which same-sex partners could officially register their relationship and gain the same tax and inheritance rights as married couples. It could also give foreigners in homosexual relationships with Germans a right to German residency. The bill now goes to a parliamentary committee. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
GERMANY: ACQUITTALS IN BORDER SHOOTINGS
Three former members of East Germany's Politburo were acquitted on manslaughter charges related to the killings of people trying to defect across the Berlin Wall. The court said it had not been proved that Siegfried Lorenz and Herbert Haber, both 69, and Hans-Joachim Bohme, 70, could have stopped the killings. Prosecutors said they would appeal. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
BRAZIL: ANTI-VIOLENCE DEMONSTRATIONS
Several million people in cities across the country marched in the largest citizen protest against violence in this nation of 175 million, wearing white and organizing silent vigils in an effort to pressure the government to take a tougher stance against both criminal gangs and police brutality. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: AID DECISION POSTPONED
The European Union has delayed action on a Colombian request for economic and social assistance to supplement the $1.3 billion in largely military aid that the United States will supply as part of an effort to curb drug trafficking and finance a peace deal with leftist guerrillas. At a donors' meeting in Madrid, the United Nations said it would supply $130 million and lending agencies agreed to kick in $300 million, but the European group postponed a decision until September. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
CANADA: ABORTION PILL TESTS
Canada's first clinical trials of RU-486, the French abortion pill, have started in four cities: Vancouver, Toronto, Quebec City and Sherbrooke, Quebec. Dr. Ellen Wiebe, the Vancouver doctor who is directing the study, won a $35,000 government grant to study the pill's health effects on 1,000 women. She hopes the trial will pave the way for government approval for the drug. James Brooke (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
JAPAN: CLAMPDOWN ON MARINES
United States Marines in Okinawa will not be allowed to drink alcohol during the Group of 8 economic meeting this month. The alcohol ban was ordered after the arrest on Monday of a drunken Marine who the police said entered a private home and molested a 14-year-old girl who was sleeping there. The Marines will also be required to be in uniform at all times during the July 20-24 meeting, which President Clinton is to attend. Calvin Sims (NYT)
 
PAKISTAN: OUSTED LEADER'S ALLIES HELD
The police arrested dozens of supporters of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif in Punjab province in an effort to prevent his wife, Kulsoom Nawaz, from leading a procession from Lahore to Peshawar. Punjab officials said that large political rallies are outlawed, but Ms. Nawaz insisted that her march was to support victims of drought. Mr. Sharif was overthrown in an October coup and is serving a life prison sentence. P. J. Anthony (NYT)
 
SOUTH KOREA: MISSILE PROGRAM ON AGENDA
The assistant secretary of state for nonproliferation, Robert Einhorn, will visit South Korea next week to discuss Seoul's attempt to build longer-range missiles, officials said. The United States and South Korea have held a series of talks over the last two years about Seoul's wish to increase the range of its missiles, now set at 112 miles under a 1979 agreement. Samuel Len (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: STUDENT MEMORIAL
Students said they would hand out flowers in Tehran's streets and light candles today to commemorate a raid on a Tehran University dormitory a year ago in which one student was killed and scores were injured. The pre-dawn raid by hard-line security forces and vigilantes, which came hours after students rallied against the banning of a liberal newspaper, set off six days of nationwide protests by tens of thousands of students -- the worst unrest in Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
ERITREA: U.N. TEAM ARRIVES
A United Nations team making preparations for the deployment of peacekeepers to monitor the cease-fire between Ethiopia and Eritrea arrived in the Eritrean capital, Asmara. The team is scheduled to spend four days in Eritrea before returning to Ethiopia, a government spokesman said. Under the terms of the truce signed by Eritrea and Ethiopia on June 18, an unspecified number of peacekeepers are to be deployed in a security zone along the Eritrean side of the border, which is about 620 miles long. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PARTY POLICY;
Draft of Democratic Platform Is Echo of Gore's Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 7

 BODY:
The Democrats released a draft of their party platform today that strongly articulates the centrist "new Democratic" views of Vice President Al Gore, but also offers concessions to liberals on several major issues, including trade, the death penalty and gay rights.
In many ways, the 41-page document tries to straddle the same ideological divide that faces Mr. Gore in his quest for the presidency. Even as he tries to reach out to moderate and independent voters this fall, Mr. Gore will need to energize core Democratic voters, who tend to be more liberal. 
 On many major issues, the platform stakes out the centrist views first championed by President Clinton in 1992. It calls for fiscal discipline and paying off the national debt by 2012. It proposes modest tax cuts. It advocates more accountability for schools and teachers. It views global trade as crucial to economic prosperity. It endorses tougher penalties, including the death penalty, for violent criminals.
But on many of those issues, the draft platform -- which will be completed at a meeting in Cleveland later this month -- also includes provisions intended to mitigate the concerns of liberals.
For example, on trade, potentially the most divisive issue for the party, the 2000 platform includes significantly stronger language than the 1996 platform about protecting workers and the environment against the potential downsides of globalization.
"Al Gore will insist on and use the authority to enforce worker rights, human rights and environmental protections" in trade accords, it says. "We should use trade to lift up standards around the world, not drag down standards here at home."
In another tradeoff with labor, the document supports giving the president broad powers to negotiate trade agreements, a policy known as fast track that is strongly opposed by unions. But it also endorses legislation prohibiting the permanent replacement of workers on strike.
In another section, the platform asserts that more police officers and tougher penalties, including capital punishment, have helped reduce crime. But it will also include language advocating that people facing the death sentence have access to DNA testing and adequate counsel.
The crime-fighting section includes another plank sought by minorities: the condemnation of racial profiling by police officers.
In a section with the centrist-sounding title "Valuing our families," the platform will say that the party "supports the full inclusion of gay and lesbian families in the life of a nation." The provision is intended to suggest that the party supports civil unions for gay couples, though perhaps not religious ones.
Where the platform adopts Republican-sounding ideas, it usually criticizes the Republican version of those ideas. On tax cuts, for instance, the platform advocates reductions for "working parents." But it harshly attacks Gov. George W. Bush's proposed across-the-board tax cut with populist language.
"It would let the richest 1 percent of Americans afford a new sports car and middle class Americans afford a warm soda," the platform says.
The draft also echoes Mr. Gore's attacks on Mr. Bush's proposal to let taxpayers invest part of their Social Security payroll taxes in the stock market.
"Taken together, George W. Bush's $2 trillion tax cut, his campaign-season spending proposals, his support for privatizing Social Security add up to an assault on the surplus, causing Americans to have to choose between drastic cuts in education and health care or a return to the days of deficit spending," the draft reads.
Not surprisingly, the platform highlights Mr. Gore's core campaign proposals to preserve Social Security, expand health care, help the elderly buy prescription drugs, overhaul the campaign finance system and strengthen gun regulations.
And it devotes it largest section to Mr. Gore's education proposals.
On foreign policy, the platform calls for increasing military pay, enacting the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and creating a limited national missile defense system capable of defending against attacks from North Korea or the Middle East.
In its language as well as its policies, the document echoes Mr. Gore's stump speeches. It is divided into three major sections -- prosperity, progress and peace -- which were the themes of a recent campaign swing by the vice president. It paraphrases the title of Mr. Gore's book on the environment, saying, "The Earth truly is in the balance."
And it closes with a pet Gore slogan: "Now, we say to America, 'You ain't seen nothing yet.' "

HEADLINE: World Bank Rejects China's Proposal to Resettle Farmers

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Under heavy pressure from the United States, the World Bank's board overruled the bank leadership today and denied financing for a sensitive Chinese antipoverty proposal that set off a North-South struggle over aid.
The $160 million plan, part of which would have resettled 58,000 mostly ethnic Chinese farmers in an area that nomadic Tibetan herdsman once dominated, divided leading borrowers from rich nations, including the United States. Rarely has any World Bank project aroused as much internal dissent and outside protest. 
 China withdrew the project from consideration this morning, when the board made it clear that it would not agree to finance the project and would reconsider the plan only after a lengthy and potentially intrusive study on its environmental and social effects.
The Chinese delegate to the bank, Zhu Xian, attributed the defeat to "enormous political pressures" brought to bear by wealthy nations and pledged that China would use its own money to finance the proposal.
Numerous outside groups campaigned to stop support for the project. Demonstrators gathered outside the bank headquarters here and cheered the decision.
Advocates for Tibet and human rights groups have argued that resettling the farmers in Qinghai Province would reinforce Chinese claims to historically Tibetan lands.
For the 181 member nations of the bank, the struggle was over controlling the tens of billions of dollars that the bank lends to developing nations each year. Led by China, the bank's No. 1 borrower and a nation that has often successfully defended its interests in international organizations like the United Nations, developing nations pushed the board to finance the project and leave its execution in the hands of bank managers, people involved in the debate said.
But the United States and leading industrial nations argued that the bank management had ignored its internal procedures when approving the project. The United States signaled that it believed that the board had to take a more active role in reviewing lending programs.
"We and numerous other shareholders were not prepared to support this project, because we did not believe that it was in compliance with the bank's own policies," a senior Treasury Department official said. "The bank needs to prepare specific proposals to give the shareholders a greater sense of confidence that management has the internal capacity to apply its established internal policies."
An inspection panel commissioned by the board of the bank reported last month that the bank had violated its guidelines when it approved the proposal. Bank officials acknowledged errors, but dismissed the report as an attempt by some board members to exert more control over day-to-day affairs.
People involved in the discussion said that the United States and Japan wanted to kill the project outright and that Britain, Germany and other European nations were prepared to consider the case again after the bank had studied its effects more thoroughly.
But China objected strenuously to to a fresh review. Mr. Zhu said some nations were using the cover of internal guidelines as a way to inject political control over lending. "Compliance policies have been interpreted by some to an extreme and used for political purposes," Mr. Zhu said.
China's decision to withdraw the project is a setback for the bank president, James D. Wolfensohn. He had urged the board to approve the proposal. Mr. Wolfensohn, recently reappointed with President Clinton's support, favored the plan despite United States opposition.
The bank thinks of China as one of its most successful customers. It has loaned China $4 billion for 31 antipoverty projects and helped 200 million Chinese climb out of poverty in the last 20 years, bank officials say.
But the Qinghai project, which is most likely to be the last one eligible for the bank's most-subsidized loan program because average per capita income in China has risen so high, became the most sensitive.
Supporters of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet who was born in eastern Qinghai, have argued that the bank would have contributed to increasing Chinese domination in the Tibetan region by helping to move mostly Han Chinese and some Hui Muslim farmers into a largely unsettled area of Qinghai. Some Tibetans claim that area as part of their homeland.
The resettlement part of the project had been scheduled to cost $40 million.
"It's like moving people from Denver to a native American reservation in Colorado," said John Ackerly, president of the International Campaign for Tibet, which has fought the project. "This is an area where Tibetans have lived for generations."
The bank said those arguments were unjustified. The project would have paid to move farmers who live in arid eastern Qinghai to irrigated lands farther west in the same province. The bank also said Qinghai, part of China before Beijing invaded Tibet in 1951, was already predominantly Han, the dominant Chinese ethnic group.
Nations that opposed the proposal said they did so more because of how the bank had handled it rather than the project itself. Though the board gave initial approval to the plan last year, it ordered an inspection panel to address concerns that the bank had not sufficiently explored all aspects.
The panel's report said the bank had originally classified the project as needing a relatively low level of review when it should have required the highest level. The report added that the bank had failed to explore alternatives and it strongly implied that China had intimidated bank managers to expedite the approval.
The United States and Japan argued that the panel's conclusion should be enough to end discussion of the plan. But several other wealthy nations thought that it still made sense for the bank to be involved, especially because China intended to pursue the project on its own.
Britain issued a statement today calling the outcome a Pyrrhic victory for opponents. "World Bank involvement," the statement said, "would have ensured that high social and environmental standards were adhered to."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Sister Cities of the World Find a Common Cause;
Duluth Finds a Key To the Global Economy And Cultural Ties, Too

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: DULUTH, Minn.

 BODY:
On the street here these days you hear French, Swedish, Russian, Japanese and at least half a dozen other foreign tongues. It is not tourists who give the city this cosmopolitan air, but business executives slinging around expressions like informationsteknologi (Swedish for information technology) and keizai kaihatsu (Japanese for economic development).
Not too bad for a city that 80 years ago, under the alias Zenith, was branded as hopelessly small-minded and provincial by Sinclair Lewis in his novel "Babbitt." 
 Duluth is still no New York or Los Angeles, of course. Or even a place like Rochester, Minn., home of the Mayo Clinic. But it has focused more on the wider world not just because of its shipping trade through the Great Lakes but also because of its sister-city program -- the nonprofit city-to-city network inspired by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's suggestion in 1956 that citizen diplomacy might reduce the chance of future world conflict.
The program, which really took off around the country in the 1970's and 80's, began largely with international cultural exchanges, and support for health and education. Now, the emphasis is changing to a more bottom-line approach.
"There is a new interest in business and economic development," said Lewis F. Harwood, a spokesman for Sister Cities International, the United States service association based in Washington that administers the program.
"You could see it last April at an international conference in Merida, Mexico, where representatives from about 20 American cities came looking for international business links and trade opportunities with other municipalities throughout the Americas," Mr. Harwood said. "We think they were quite successful at making these connections."
Economic development has long been pursued at the national level by the Commerce Department, Mr. Harwood acknowledged. And states and large municipalities, which can afford offices of economic development and send trade missions around the world, have long been doing business internationally. Now, however, more and more cities are reaching out internationally through city-to-city relationships. "It's definitely a trend," Mr. Harwood said.
To be sure, some people think the program is a waste of time and money. In the early 1990's, for example, an editorial writer in Duluth wondered aloud what the city's mayor was doing in Japan on what he called a sister city "junket" when he ought to be at home in Minnesota minding the store. But despite such sniping, this city and many others are hoping to use the program more actively to pursue development projects in a globalizing economy.
And in the case of Duluth that switch in emphasis to international business seems to have been, at least in part, a recognition of problems in the local economy. Between 1980 and 1990, for example, the Duluth-Superior, Wis., region lost more than 26,000 people, adding to the incentive of local officials to take advantage of every program they could.
By the end of 1999, about 1,280 American cities were engaged in the sister city program, some more widely than others. Seattle, for example, has 20 sister cities around the world, from Christchurch, New Zealand, to Haiphong, Vietnam. New York City has six, including Madrid and Cairo.
Duluth now has four: Thunder Bay, Ontario; Ohara, Japan; Petrozavodsk, Russia; and Vaxjo, Sweden. These partnerships have generated more than $10 million in direct revenue for the city over the last few years, according to Duluth's mayor, Gary L. Doty.
More important, programs that started out as cultural ties have become in many cases profit-centered enterprises. The Duluth-Vaxjo link, for example, resulted in an ambitious project that its investors, who anted up $24 million, hope will make Duluth a major port city for information technology as it has long been for timber, grain and iron ore.
In 1995, Mayor Doty led a delegation to Vaxjo seeking to expand cultural exchanges based on the Swedish heritage of a large segment of the city's population. But it was something they stumbled on in the nearby town of Ronneby that provided the big inspiration. For a decade, the city of Ronneby had been host to a technology campus that brought together under one roof about 100 high-technology businesses, branches of academic institutions, professors working as research and development consultants, and students taking classes and serving internships. Such interactions at the campus, Soft Center Ronneby, provide, among other things, a sorely needed supply of well-trained information-technology workers.
"This is what we should be doing," Mayor Doty exclaimed.
Michael J. McNamara, who had joined the delegation as a representative of the Duluth Chamber of Commerce, got the message, too. "It's a school-to-work model for the information-technology industry," he said.
In short order, a four-story technology campus rose in downtown Duluth, financed by city, state and private money. It is one of a growing number of such centers throughout the world based on the Ronneby model.
Christened Soft Center Duluth, the enterprise held an open house for prospective tenants last month. Visitors came from England, Scotland, France, Norway, West Africa, South Africa, Canada and many parts of the United States. The building is now 30 percent occupied, by tenants including academic institutions, high-technology concerns and a big-name investment bank.
"The center is attracting the kind of tenants they want at a somewhat slower rate than anticipated," said Kjell Knudsen, dean of the School of Business and Economics at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, who once served as an unpaid board member of the Soft Center. "But the prospect is that it will succeed."
Among those working at the video terminals in the new building recently was Joe Allert, 19, a sophomore majoring in business at the Soft Center branch of the University of Minnesota-Duluth.
"I came here because I like the idea of having educational institutions in the same building as employers and even Salomon Smith Barney and other business," he said.
Not all of Duluth's sister-city partnerships are focused on hard-headed business projects. The relationship with Petrozavodsk is, thus far, purely philanthropic, recently involving an effort to raise funds for clothing and supplies for children in orphanages. And the link with Thunder Bay, only a few hours away by car, is largely cultural. But another tie that may result in a business deal is Duluth's relationship with Ohara, which set the stage for all four of Duluth's sister-city partnerships. This tie began during the United States occupation of Japan.
One night, a gang of sailors from the heavy cruiser Duluth returned from shore leave with a 750-pound, medieval temple gong in tow. The bronze gong, covered with ancient inscriptions and fanciful dragons, is recognized in Japan as a national treasure.
The captain considered the gong a legitimate war trophy and arranged to have it delivered to the ship's namesake: the city of Duluth. For the next decade, the gong was on display first in City Hall and then in Duluth's Enger Park.
In 1951, a visiting Japanese college professor happened to see the gong. He explained to Duluth's mayor how important it was to Japan, and asked to have it returned.
A lengthy correspondence followed, and eventually the gong was sent back to Ohara -- a fishing village 90 miles southeast of Tokyo from which it had been taken. In gratitude, the Japanese delivered a full-scale replica of the gong for display in Enger Park.
In 1990, Duluth and Ohara became sister cities. And last month, a group of 15 visiting Japanese dignitaries and several dozen Duluthians held a ceremony in Enger Park to rededicate the replica as a symbol of peace and mutual understanding.
A soprano sang the Japanese national anthem and then the American. Next, Mayor Doty and Soichiro Oya, a petroleum entrepreneur who led the Japanese sister-city delegation, jointly clanged the gong with a huge striker in the name of everlasting peace.
After the ceremony, the conversation turned to golf.
While golf is an expensive sport in Japan, where the links are crowded and reservations hard to come by, Duluth, by contrast, is a golfer's paradise, ranked by Golf Digest as the best of America's 309 small cities for access to good, affordable links.
So why not market golfing vacations in Duluth for Japanese tourists? Carl Seehus, Duluth's director of parks and recreation and a former director of the city's sister-city program, was talking up the idea. And Mr. Oya, an avid golfer, agreed.
"The last decade was for cultural exchanges," Mr. Oya added. "The next decade will be for business."

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Dear Ralph:

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
Nader for president! You say you are serious this time, running as the candidate of the Green Party, and you deride those who say you should get out of Al Gore's way. Fair enough. Third parties are an honorable, if frustrating, American tradition.
What is puzzling to some of your old admirers is what you stand for. You say the two major parties are practically Tweedledum and Tweedledee -- there are "few major differences" between them. Sure, they are both awash in campaign money that keeps them close to business. But no major differences? Are you serious? 
 Take one of your concerns, the environment. When Newt Gingrich & Co. took control of the House, Republicans tried to gut the country's environmental protection laws. They were stopped by President Clinton's skillful use of the veto and veto threats. A Republican from Texas, where environmental regulation is in the hands of the polluters, is not likely to be that kind of president.
Or take law. You and I first met in law school. You have used the legal process well, and I believe you must still have a deep concern for law and the courts.
The prospective Republican candidate has spoken admiringly of the judicial record of Justice Clarence Thomas. The Democrat would almost certainly make appointments to the Supreme Court on the model of President Clinton's moderate-liberal choices, Justices Ruth Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer. No major difference?
It is surprising that you pay little or no attention to one area where there is in fact little difference between President Clinton and the Republican Congress -- and the records of both are abysmal. That is civil liberties.
Federal habeas corpus, a fundamental safeguard of freedom, was ravaged by legislation signed without objection by President Clinton. The Republican Congress cut off funds for a handful of resource centers that provided lawyers for prisoners on death row, many of whom had been represented by incompetent counsel.
The Counter-Terrorism Act, drafted by the Clinton administration, imported into our law the loathsome practice of trials on secret evidence. The Immigration Act of 1996 compelled the deportation of people who had committed trivial crimes years before the act was passed.
By attacking those affronts to due process and American decency, a third-party candidate could have a real impact. He could shake the major parties' indifference and touch the country's conscience. Don't you care?
What you mainly seem to care about these days is free trade. You are against it -- or say you want it with so many ifs and buts that it amounts to the same thing. You and your organization, Public Citizen, led the way to the Seattle protests against the World Trade Organization.
You talk about the importance of seeing that other countries have laws like ours to protect fair labor standards, the consumer, pure food and the environment. Those are fine ideals. But the effect of insisting that other countries meet our standards before we trade with them would be, as you must know, devastating.
What South Africans need is jobs; about a third of them are unemployed. The same is true in most of the developing world. Yes, we should worry about underpaid child workers in Asia producing goods for the American market. But efforts that focus attention on such cruelties have been quite effective. To use, instead, the blunderbuss of stopping or handicapping trade would make life harsher for all.
Free trade benefits Americans enormously, too. Your great early achievement was to bring General Motors to heel. But what really forced reform on G.M., and gave us all better cars, was competition from Japanese and other imports.
Your protectionist stance has put you in bed with some of the most reactionary forces in this country. You are a twin of Pat Buchanan on the issue. The New Republic reported that Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch got money from Roger Milliken, the far-right South Carolina textile magnate who has bankrolled the conservative cause from Barry Goldwater on.
Protectionism would destroy our prosperity and make the world's poor even more miserable. It is a strange platform for the Ralph Nader who says he speaks for the weak and the neglected. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Interview With Bushes

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview today with former President George Bush and his wife, Barbara, about the presidential campaign of their son Gov. George W. Bush of Texas:
 
 Q. Are you confident your son will win?
 
 GEORGE BUSH. I think he'll win. Again, it's mind-boggling for me, a former president, to think our son will be president. I think a lot of it is that after this primary, where he took such a huge pounding, the press had a massive love affair with John McCain -- nobody can question that, that's just objective, even from a nonobjective guy -- but after that, there was a distorted view of George, I think, and now . . . people are beginning to see what his heartbeat is, what he's really like, that he's a decent person, that he likes people, has done a good job in his state. I don't think in the fall that the press is going to have the same love affair with Gore that they had with John McCain. 

 Q. Why?
 
 MR. BUSH. Well, I think they don't like him so much.
 
 Q. For a good reason?
 
 MR. BUSH. Oh, I don't know about that. I'm going to leave it to George's campaign to define Al Gore. He can identify with people, and I think that's coming through. And also, they're going to want change. And I believe there is a Clinton fatigue. And all of these things will inure to George's benefit just as Gore will be trying to have this good economy inure to his . . .
 
 Q. Why do you think there's Clinton fatigue?
 
 BARBARA BUSH. We took a vow. Can't break it. Never to speak badly about your, your ----
 
 MR. BUSH. We don't get into that because he beat me and then it looks like a poor sport, but I did speak out once in the depths of the Monica Lewinsky thing and said this is disgraceful. But I think it's more than that very unhappy time period of impeachment. I think it's change. I think I was the victim of people wanting change: "Eight years of Reagan, four years of Bush, we want a change." And all the things that I felt strongly about never materialized as issues. And I think the same thing is true now. I think people kind of like change, like the idea of change from time to time. I think that works for George's benefit. I don't think Gore can present himself as a candidate of change. . . .

 Q. Does your son know as much about foreign affairs as you did when you were elected?
 
 MR. BUSH. No. But he knows every bit as much about it as Bill Clinton did.
 
 Q. As much as Gore?
 
 MR. BUSH. Gore's had eight years of experience there. But the way I should be judged . . . is by the kind of people I had around me. Because I didn't know all this stuff. You know, how much reduction you can do on atomic weapons. But Brent Snowcroft did. I didn't know how Gorbachev was going to react when the Iraqis invaded Kuwait, but Jimmy Baker was over there the next day, with Shevardnadze and Gorbachev, and figured it out. I didn't know how the military would work, but we had Colin Powell and Norm Schwarzkopf. We had confidence in generals and officers who were right when all the critics were wrong. So how do you know? You get good people. George knows enough to do that . . .
 
 Q. If you were campaigning against your son, wouldn't you be calling his tax cut too large?
 
 MR. BUSH. You won't believe this. I literally don't go into the analysis of these issues. If you asked me, life or death, "You've got to tell me how big the tax cut is that George is proposing," I couldn't tell you. I don't give a damn. Because I'm out of it. I'm out of it. And I don't do television and I don't do interviews because the minute I said I would differ with Jeb or with George, you would have an obligation to rush down there and say, "Your nutty father doesn't agree with you, what do you think?"

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1072 words

HEADLINE: Payrolls Grew Modestly as Jobless Rate Slipped to 4%

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
After a disastrous drop in jobs in May, American companies added modestly to their payrolls in June, creating 206,000 new jobs, the Labor Department reported yesterday, reinforcing the impression that the economy is slowing.
Job creation in the private sector has now fallen from an average of 244,000 a month in the first quarter to only 110,000 a month from April through June. But if companies are reluctant to hire, they are still hiring in sufficient numbers to keep the unemployment rate at only 4 percent last month, down from 4.1 percent in May -- the lowest levels since the late 1960's. 
 "Economic growth is slowing, but gently, so far," said James Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Manhattan Bank.
The coming and going of thousands of census takers skewed the overall job numbers in both May and June. The total number of jobs created in June -- covering government employees as well as the private sector -- was only 11,000. That was mainly because 190,000 census takers, having finished their work, left the Census Bureau's payroll.
In May, the hiring of 356,000 census takers swelled the total job count to 171,000. Without them, private-sector employment fell by 165,000, the largest drop in eight years and the first of any size since the economy began to soar in the mid-1990's. The May loss had been estimated as 116,000 but was revised yesterday to 165,000.
"You still have about 428,000 temporary census takers out there, and they will come off the payroll, probably in July and August," said Thomas Nardone, chief of the division that prepares the employment data at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The Clinton administration acknowledged that the new job report added to the evidence that the economy is slowing. "We do see signs of moderation," Labor Secretary Alexis Herman said, "but the economy is still steady and stable and strong."
Stock prices soared yesterday in response to the new evidence of slowing, the expectation being that the Federal Reserve will be less likely to raise interest rates at its next policy meeting, on Aug. 22. Rising rates encourage investors to switch their money out of stocks and into interest-bearing investments.
"Another weak month would kill an August rate hike," Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist for High Frequency Economics, advised his clients yesterday, referring to the June job report.
But some Wall Street economists argue that although job creation may be slowing, inflation remains an issue, even in a weakening economy, and the Fed will have to deal with it. Labor shortages and competition for workers, this argument goes, must eventually force up wages and then prices, although that has not happened yet to a significant degree.
"The market is discounting any further Fed rate increases, which I think is a mistake," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist of Deutsche Bank North America. Mortgage rates and other consumer rates, he argued, are not yet high enough to dampen demand sufficiently to discourage price increases.
Others pointed to wages. Average hourly earnings for production workers, representing about 75 percent of the 131.6 million people in the work force, rose by 5 cents in June, to $13.71, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The increase in May was only 2 cents.
When viewed over 12 months, the rate of increase is a mild 3.6 percent. But since January the average hourly pay for production workers turns out to have risen at an accelerated 4 percent annual rate.
"The hourly wage increase was not comforting at all," said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors Inc. But the National Association of Manufacturers, a trade group, saw the glass as half full. It noted that recent improvements in productivity had more than paid for the hourly wage increase. The productivity growth rate measures an average worker's output during each hour on the job. The higher the output, the more revenue the worker brings in for his employer to pay for wage increases without raising prices.
"The wage path implies an underlying rate of inflation of only about 1 percent a year," Jerry Jasinowski, president of the manufacturers' group, said in a statement. The manufacturers have been arguing against any further rate increases by the Fed, insisting that more will slow the economy too much.
The Fed has raised rates six times since June 1999, for a total of 1.75 percentage points, and the effect on demand helps to explain why the economy has begun to slow down, economists say. Another reason cited is gasoline price increases, which divert family income from other spending. Still another is heavy buying of homes, cars, appliances, furniture -- to the point that demand is sated.
The stock market wealth effect no longer has its old kick, others argue. With stock prices going sideways in recent months, or falling in the high-technology sector, consumers no longer feel as confident about their wealth and limit their spending. And a strong dollar is restricting exports, particularly manufactured exports.
Most job growth in June was in the service sector, particularly business services, which added 54,000 jobs, and in retailing, which added 49,000 jobs, mostly at restaurants. Consultants led the growth in business services, with healthy increases also in temporary help, health services, engineering and hotels.
Employment in the financial sector seemed to show the effects of the slowing economy and higher rates. Jobs in this sector fell by 6,000 last month and 20,000 so far this year, with cutbacks in commercial and mortgage banking, insurance and real estate.
Construction employment, which has fluctuated sharply with the weather, grew by 3,000 jobs in June, raising the average monthly gain to 20,000 this year, down from 25,000 a month for 1999.
Still, the June figures gave evidence of the tight labor market. The unemployment rate for women who support families fell in June, as it did for teenagers and people with a high school education or less. The number of people holding part-time jobs because they could not get full-time work also fell.
Among blacks and Hispanic people, however, the unemployment rate, which jumped in May, did not fall back in June. And the percentage of people who quit a job confident that they can get another in a strong economy fell by 1.1 points in June, to 12.1 percent, its lowest level in months.
