HEADLINE: A Place of Their Own, With a Difference

BYLINE: By NANCY DONIGER

 BODY:
JOSEPHINE BOJNOWSKI, 83, surveys her small but cheerful apartment at Lockwood Lodge, an assisted living center associated with Ashlar of Newtown, and smiles at the place she has called home for the past year.
Ms. Bojnowski, a former teacher and reading supervisor for the Newington school system, lived alone in a single-family house after her husband died but she could no longer manage after breaking her leg. "There were too many stairs," she said. "I needed a place that served food and provided assistance." 
 Ms. Bojnowski reflects a growing number of elderly Americans who need help with some of the activities of daily living but otherwise want to retain their independence.
Assisted living is the fastest growing residential alternative for elderly people with incomes high enough to support the monthly fees, averaging $2,500 or more, since Medicare does not cover assisted-living expenses.
Assisted living is defined as a living arrangement in which residents buy or rent their own apartment, where they live independently with medical and housekeeping assistance. They receive three meals a day in a common dining room and share many common areas with other residents. There also is a nurse on call 24 hours a day.
The adoption of assisted living regulations by the Connecticut Legislature in November 1994 paved the way for growth, according to industry officials. Since the regulations were adopted, 70 assisted-living service centers have been licensed in the state.
Colonel John Kulp, 86, who retired from the United States Army, chose Lockwood Lodge because of its attractive ambience, services and proximity to his daughter in Redding.
"It's bigger than Thoreau's cabin at Walden Pond," he said about his one-bedroom apartment. "I would rather be climbing the Alps, or out running around, but I decided to move here when I began to have trouble with my vision. I need someone to look out for me as I get more absent-minded."
With the explosion of new centers, many still under construction, have come vacancies, particularly at some of the older complexes and at those with studio apartments. No longer is a waiting list the rule at most centers. This is due in part to the newness of the industry in Connecticut and a lack of awareness about it by the consumer, industry officials said.
But Chris Carter, the executive director of the Connecticut Assisted Living Association, disputes the notion that assisted-living centers in the state are overbuilt. CALA was founded in June 1995 and offers education, training and information to raise the level of awareness about assisted living, in addition to fostering ethical standards and serving as a legislative ally.
"Connecticut has 175,000 residents over the age of 75," he said. "It's our belief that 50,000 of these individuals need assistance with daily living, of which 20,000 have an annual income of more than $25,000, making them eligible for assisted living.
"Connecticut has 70 assisted living sites with a total of 4,000 units," he continued. "The market is not overbuilt. With education, all the units will find themselves in demand."
The Greens at Canondale in Wilton opened two years ago and has full occupancy. Its monthly fees range from $3,750 to $5,850. A certain number of units are designated for people with lower incomes.
"We have residents who have been here since we opened," said Sandra Sajec, executive director at the Greens. "This is their home. We haven't lost too many."
By and large, residents must foot the bill for assisted living without Medicare reimbursement. But long-term care insurance is a growing commodity, offered by private insurers such as General Electric, John Hancock and Travelers. Some companies are even offering long-term care insurance for their employees' parents, according to Tim Hodges, vice president of marketing for Kensington Green of Southbury.
Kensington Green is a 120-unit facility that will emphasize a healthy life style, focusing on diet, exercise and social relationships. It will have 24 separate apartments for people living with Alzheimer's disease. The facility is scheduled to open in March 2001.
"We did a market feasibility study to find out the demand and determined it was there," Mr. Hodges said.
The average age of assisted living residents is 84-85, and their average stay is two years, according to Mr. Carter. He said residents either die or require greater care at a nursing home.
Ginny Carroll, the Lockwood Lodge marketing director, said there is an industry-wide problem of people waiting until they are physically incapacitated before looking into assisted living, which is geared to people who enjoy relatively good health.
"I'm trying to get people to think about assisted living before a crisis occurs," said Tony Copeland, a spokesman for the AARP, "so they can take the time they need to find a facility, research it and make sure it meets their needs."
Ms. Carroll also mentioned an unanticipated phenomenon.
"We're finding the demand to be different than we expected," she said. "Through our studies, we expected more people to want studio apartments, due to the economics. We're finding people don't want to give up their space. They want to bring their memories. One-bedroom apartments are much more popular than studios."
Mark Ryan, secretary of the state for the Office of Policy and Management, said the state has been studying assisted living with interest, in an effort to deal with an aging population whose ranks are expected to surge over the next 30 years with the graying of the baby boomers.
According to Mr. Ryan, Connecticut has one of the highest percentages of elderly residents in the nation.
The statistics are dramatic, with 34 million Americans 65 or older, up from 20 million in 1970, and the numbers are expected to swell to 70 million by 2030, according to AARP statistics.
The number of elderly residents in Connecticut is proportionately higher. Nationwide, the percentage of people 65 or over is 12 percent, compared with 14.3 percent in Connecticut, according to 1990 state and federal census reports. By 2030, 20 percent of the national population will be over 65 and Mr. Ryan said Connecticut's population is expected to be elderly about 10 years sooner.
"We're making major investments in assisted living," Mr. Ryan said. "We believe there is a good chunk of people in nursing homes who are poor but could manage well with assisted living, while improving their independence, respect and dignity."
The Office of Policy and Management and other state agencies are planning a pilot program with 300 assisted-living beds in five or six urban and lower-middle-class suburban communities for people living on Medicaid. A bill is pending in the state legislature that would allow assisted living to be layered into existing congregate care housing for the elderly, based on the belief it will provide a less costly and more desirable alternative to nursing homes for low-income elderly residents, according to Mr. Ryan. If the bill passes, some or all of the costs could be covered by Medicare.
Martha Meng, a lawyer with Murtha, Cullina LLP of Hartford and New Haven, was part of a working group convened in 1991 by the Department of Health to write regulations for assisted living. The group completed the task in November 1994.
"The assisted-living services agency is the licensed entity and must provide services within a managed residential agency that is registered with the state but is not itself licensed," she said. "The managed residential agency is the platform, or physical plant for the services that must be provided to qualify as assisted living."
Services include three meals a day, housekeeping, laundry, transportation, access to health care, 24-hour security and staff availability, an emergency call system, medication management, social and recreational activities; and assistance, as needed, with eating, bathing, dressing, and mobility.
Assisted living is as popular with baby boom children as it is with their older parents.
Diane Mauriello of Newtown and her husband have school-age children living at home and they also have primary responsibility for their aging parents. Ms. Mauriello's father-in-law had a stroke last year and had to move to a nursing home in Southbury. Her mother-in-law, Cara Mauriello, 82, is frail, but not incapacitated. Although she does not need a nursing home, she can no longer live alone.
"She was depressed and was not eating," Ms. Mauriello said of her mother-in-law. "She didn't like living alone and needed companionship."
Since moving to Lockwood Lodge, she has blossomed, Ms. Mauriello said. "She looks good, is well cared for 24 hours a day and never lonely. My husband and I were able to go on a cruise and leave her. We wouldn't have been able to do that before."
Darlene O'Connor, director of integrated care for the Connecticut Department of Social Services, offered the following advice for anyone considering assisted living for themselves or a loved one: "Make sure you know what you are purchasing now and down the road, when you need more support. What conditions can the facility handle? What happens when your assets are gone?"
To learn more about assisted living, visit CALA's Web site at
Ctassistedliving.com or the AARP's site at www.aarp.org.

HEADLINE: IN THE GARDEN;
Some Lessons of Old From Williamsburg

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
I WENT to Colonial Williamsburg not long ago. It was Garden Week in Virginia, and, like thousands of my fellow enthusiasts, I was eager to see some of the extraordinary private gardens that were open for the festivities. I also wanted to find out what a 21st-century Northeastern gardener can learn from gardens that have been recreated over the past 60 years to resemble those that existed in 18th-century Virginia.
I am not the only one with such interests. Historic gardens are very hot right now. Expensive subdivisions seem to be full of people willing to spend vast sums of money to adorn the grounds of their new McMansions with everything from Victorian bedding-out schemes to French parterres. 
 The McMansionites are clearly the spiritual descendants of the colonial governor, Alexander Spotswood, who was convinced that he could create a fashionable watering hole within the confines of a colonial backwater by installing an ornamental water feature at the rear of the governor's mansion. The governor's canal and fishpond have been recreated, and are sited conveniently near another of his innovations, a boxwood maze. He would undoubtedly be gratified to learn that water features and mazes have become fashionable again.
But pleasure gardens were not the only gardens flourishing within the colonial capital. Neatly planted symmetrical kitchen gardens, containing combinations of edible plants, herbs, ornamentals and even fruit trees, existed near the homes of working class, professional and wealthy residents. According to Kent Brinkley, director of horticulture for the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, it is these gardens that have the most relevance for today's gardeners.
"Most of the gardens at Colonial Williamsburg are comparable in size to today's home lots," he said. "This helps modern gardeners relate to them in a more intimate way." Large estate gardens may be inspiring, added Mr. Brinkley, but it is easier to translate ideas when they are presented on a residential scale.
Williamsburg's gardens were also full of old-fashioned plant varieties that are identical or at least similar to varieties that were cultivated during the 18th century. Contemporary gardeners are becoming interested in older varieties, and a look at Williamsburg's plant lists can serve as a jumping-off point for selection of specific cultivars for a period bed or garden area. In an era when even the most devoted amateur gardeners are pressed for time, the tough plants favored by colonists merit attention. One example of such toughness, Mr. Brinkley said, is the roses grown in some of colonial gardens. The plants may not have the largest blossoms, but they are very hardy.
Perhaps the most important lesson that I learned from Williamsburg is also the least tangible. Over the course of the past 15 years, changes in scholarship and developments in landscape archaeology have led Mr. Brinkley and other horticulturists to reexamine the way colonial gardens have been portrayed. The gardens that were reconstructed in the 1930's and 40's when Colonial Williamsburg was a new venture, were Colonial Revival rather than true colonial gardens. The difference between the two is sometimes subtle, according to Mr. Brinkley, but in general the Colonial Revival gardens in the historic area, while presenting an elegant period feel, did not reflect the economic and social status of the colonial-era owners of specific properties. Now, that has become an integral part of garden restoration. "The use of finely crafted pickets instead of plain boards for fences says something about the status of the owner of a garden," Mr. Brinkley said. Personal wealth might also have led a colonial homeowner to install brick walks between garden beds, as opposed to dirt paths covered with a less costly material.
This emphasis on class distinctions does not please everybody, but it made me feel closer to the original gardeners, many of whom were also busy working people, with gardens that were not necessarily tidy.
The other lesson that I learned from Mr. Brinkley and the gardens of Williamsburg is that in historic garden recreation, as in any kind of gardening, there is no such thing as being finished. Mr. Brinkley's cited the example of the Taliafero (pronounced toliver) Apple, a variety discovered by the father-in-law of a prominent Williamsburg resident George Wythe and cultivated by Thomas Jefferson. The apple has disappeared from cultivation, but Mr. Brinkley hopes that somewhere, on an abandoned farmstead, a Taliafero apple tree clings to life. If such a tree exists, he looks forward to providing a safe haven for it in Williamsburg, and eventually, returning both the tree and its fruit to commerce.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Odetta, Still Singing the Blues

BYLINE: By E. KYLE MINOR

 BODY:
WHEN Odetta, the unofficial queen of American folk music, last released a blues album 38 years ago folk purists wagged their admonishing fingers at her for betraying them.
"Blues Everywhere I Go," her latest blues album, proves once again that Odetta's talent transcends any one style. 
 "Back then there were people who wanted to make sure that the music stayed where it was," said the 70-year-old singer, who performs an outdoors blues concert from 4 to 6 p.m. on Saturday at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. "But I'm not a purist in any way, shape or form."
Odetta may be a folk icon, but her music includes the blues, jazz, spirituals, Appalachian songs and English folk songs. "Blues Everywhere I Go," her 27th solo album, pays homage to the great blueswomen of the 20's and 30's: Bessie Smith, Ma Rainey, Victoria Spivey, Sippie Wallace and Memphis Minnie. "T.B. Blues," "Unemployment Blues," "Rich Man's Blues," "WPA Blues," and "Please Send Me Someone To Love," a duet with Dr. John, are among the recording's dozen songs.
"One of the many reasons I wanted to do the blues album is that I get pretty fed up with stereotyping of our black community as being represented by prurient sex or 'I'm gonna shoot you or I'm gonna cut you'," she said in a phone conversation from her home in New York. "There was blues in the 20's and 30's that dealt with society's foot stepping on our throats."
That oppression, Odetta continued, included sending black soldiers to Europe during World War I and II and their returning to segregation and unemployment.
This kind of social protest has long been evident in Odetta's vast song repertory. The seeds of social conscience were planted during her childhood in Los Angeles. "They didn't have signs for black and whites, but you knew where you could and couldn't go," she said. "There were no signs, but there was attitude."
Odetta left home at 18 to perform in the chorus of a national tour of "Finian's Rainbow," a musical, appropriately enough, about prejudice. She then settled in San Francisco where she learned to play the guitar and began performing in the folk clubs. She worked across town from a young, aspiring performer named Maya Angelou. "I was playing the Tin Angel and Maya was at the Purple Onion," said Odetta, who has remained friends with the poet. "She's done pretty good since then."
So has Odetta. Her reputation is that of a singer of uncompromising integrity as a result of performances at the Newport Festival, at Carnegie Hall and for President John F. Kennedy on the nationally televised program, "Dinner With the President." She marched with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Selma and she sang at the 1963 March on Washington. Odetta was also an influence on Joan Baez, Bob Dylan and Janis Joplin and younger singer-songwriters including Tracy Chapman.
Odetta still acts when afforded the opportunity ("I'm a big ham," she said with a laugh).
Her film credits include Tony Richardson's "Sanctuary" (1960) with Yves Montand and Lee Remick. And on television she appeared with Cicely Tyson in "The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman." She has also appeared with the Stratford Shakespeare Company in Ontario and at the Neptune Theater in Halifax.
Odetta's folk identity, however, remains. Since the social injustices that primed her singing career 50 years ago show no signs of relenting, she still has plenty to sing about.
"The song is the result of something," she said. "I'm infuriated. Does it take 41 bullets to kill someone? I'm infuriated that a cop has a license to kill an innocent person and that a jury lets him get away with it."
The worst thing that could happen to Odetta's career, it would seem, would be to have a perfect world. "Then I'd have nothing to sing about," she laughed.
That wouldn't be so perfect.
Odetta performs out of doors on Saturday from 4 to 6 p.m. at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main Street, Ridgefield. Tickets are $15 and $20. The number to call for ticket information is (203) 438-4519.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneur From India Learns to Lobby

SERIES: A Diverse Island

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY

DATELINE: PORT WASHINGTON

 BODY:
KEEPING a low profile comes naturally to Ananta P. Mukherjee, the owner of Colonial Wines and Liquors on Main Street, which he bought in 1997. Both by temperament and by life experience, Mr. Mukherjee, who is known as Tony, has relied more on hard work than on stirring the pot.
But all that changed when Mr. Mukherjee, who is 57 and a native of Calcutta, recently petitioned the Chamber of Commerce and the Port Washington Police Department to correct a situation that he says is hurting his business: a forbidding No Parking sign in front of his store. 
 The parking ban, he says, hampers the drivers who deliver his stock 10 times a week. Customers are sometimes unable to pick up large orders without getting tickets.
Many neighboring storekeepers have the same complaint, but none have been as determined as Mr. Mukherjee to change the status quo.
Unlike many immigrants, who may come from societies where aggressive action is frowned upon, or who may avoid public discourse because they are embarrassed by their imperfect English, Mr. Mukherjee -- perhaps emboldened by the maelstrom of political activity characteristic of Long Island -- comes to his current mission from a background of trailblazing action.
Mr. Mukherjee first demonstrated a flair for independence when he graduated from high school and left his parents and seven siblings in Calcutta to pursue a degree in mechanical engineering in Manchester, England.
Although his family was accomplished -- two brothers are lawyers and another a plastic surgeon, his four sisters graduated from college and his father and paternal grandfather were renowned lawyers -- he thought a degree from an English school "would help me fulfill my childhood dream of going abroad and pursuing my ambitions."
After paying his own way through school and graduating, he looked for jobs in England, but a petroleum crisis and widespread job layoffs made prospects there grim. He sought the help of the United Nations, which referred him to the International Committee for European Migration to Latin America. Within months, he was working for General Motors in Sao Paolo, Brazil.
He and his wife, Shiuli, who is also from Calcutta, had three children, but when their eldest, a boy, was on the threshold of college, Mr. Mukherjee decided that colleges in Brazil were not for his children, and he sent his son to Texas A&M University.
"I wanted my children to have the kind of opportunities to prosper that are only offered by the American dream," he said. "I knew that they would grow in America's increasingly diverse society and that being U.S. citizens, along with their ability to speak different languages, would open many doors to them in this global world." The Mukherjee children speak English, Spanish, Portuguese and Bengali.
Mr. Mukherjee's aspirations derive in large part from early experiences. Born in 1943, during one of India's worst famines, he remembers vividly the tales his family told of the conflict between Britain and Japan, and of having to flee Japanese bombing raids in Calcutta to a village in what is now Bangladesh.
"My father always believed in the concept of simple living and high thinking," he said. "And my wife and I also believe that it is better to live modestly and put a greater emphasis on education and the preservation of our cultural heritage."
After their son began studying in Texas, the Mukherjees moved to New York, living first in Huntington, then in Texas, and finally moving to Port Washington. Mr. Mukherjee had done well in Brazil, but "I spent a lot of my savings trying to make a life here," he said. "It wasn't easy, but I never experienced any discrimination, thank God."
"I went to the library every day," he said, "looking in the newspapers for jobs. I calculated my family's needs, but I was already in my 50's and it was difficult. I saw that jobs like working in a newsstand or gas station or repairing cars wouldn't earn me enough money to educate my children. When I saw an ad for a liquor store that I could afford, I bought it."
His travels in Brazil and Europe for General Motors had given him the opportunity to visit several wine regions. "I've always been interested in wines," he said, adding that he drinks two glasses of wine each night (and runs four miles every day), "so learning about other kinds of liquors was interesting to me too."
The Mukherjees, who are Hindu, have permanent resident status. After five years' residence in the United States, they will be eligible to apply for citizenship.
Learning about parking bans has also been instructive. When the response to his complaints to the Chamber of Commerce and the police department proved less than encouraging, Mr. Mukherjee wrote a letter to his community newspaper, suggesting that the shopkeepers "work out a series of compromises" with officials.
When the letter initially yielded no response other than encouraging words from neighbors, he circulated a petition that he plans to present to May Newburger, the Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead.
Mr. Mukherjee has rallied like-minded neighboring storekeepers, including Linda Yau, the owner of the Lucky Star Chinese takeout restaurant, and Kenny Louie, the owner of Hime, a Japanese restaurant, who said: "There's no reason trucks can't park in front for 5 or 10 minutes. It makes sense."
The police chief, William J. Kilfoil, while acknowledging "there's definitely a problem," explained that when people park in the heavily trafficked area in front of Mr. Mukherjee's store, "traffic backs up eastbound and parking there creates a dangerous situation for motorists and pedestrians, the worse stop on Main Street."
"We do the best we can, but there's no easy solution," added Chief Kilfoil, who once walked patrol on Main Street. "Maybe this can be worked out with the town, but sometimes delivery people just have to use hand trucks like they do in the City. If someone's parking there, we'll tell them to move. But if they don't, it's a $25 ticket."
Mr. Mukherjee's efforts may soon pay off. In the words of Warren Schein, the president of the Chamber of Commerce for nine years, "We have to help each other so the community is a better place to live."
To that end Mr. Schein, who is also the deputy commissioner of parks and recreation for the Town of North Hempstead, which runs the Port Washington Parking District, said he had proposed a "red meter zone" to allow commercial vehicles to park for deliveries from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.
"I've seen this in Great Neck and Glen Cove and the Hamptons, and it works," Mr. Schein said. "This would make it easier for storekeepers to do business, for shoppers to avoid double-parking and having to drive around double-parked trucks, and for truck drivers who won't have to hunt for spots."
The plan is subject to town board approval, "but I'm sure it will be approved," Mr. Schein said.
In the meantime Mr. Mukherjee continues to collect signatures on his petition and to deliver to customers who tell him they do not have the time or patience to find a parking spot near his store. And he and his wife continue to work hard to support their children.
Their elder son, Shoummo, a graduate of Hofstra University, now works in the financial department of Citibank. Their daughter, Shilpi, studies computer graphics at SUNY Stony Brook. Their younger son, Sergio, a recent graduate of Schreiber High School in Port Washington, will attend Cornell University in the fall.
As for his foray into community politics, Mr. Mukherjee said: "Apathy is the great enemy of our society. I believe in the American way of life, being thankful for every freedom, and also having the right and the privilege of trying to redress a grievance."
 
A Diverse Island
Articles in this series are looking beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native-born Long Islanders. Future articles will examine immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric. Previous articles examined the lives and aspirations of Muslims on the Island, a Korean entrepreneur and her American-raised son, and a Colombian landscaping entrepreneur.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 7; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 630 words

HEADLINE: Island Awash With Film Festivals

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to films and film festivals, can there be too much of a good thing?
Starting Friday, when the Long Island International Film Expo 2000 opens in Malverne, and continuing with the 2000 Stony Brook Festival, then ending with the Huntington International Film Festival, more than 50 feature films will be screened over 17 days. That's after the Long Island Film Festival showed 20 features at three sites in Suffolk in May, and before the Hamptons International makes its splash in October. 
 In its third year under the umbrella of the Long Island Film and TV Foundation, the Nassau-based International Film Expo is meant to bring industry to the area. In that goal it is similiar to the Long Island Film Festival, which began 17 years ago as an Island-wide effort, but currently grows out of the Suffolk County's Office of Economic Development.
"We want to keep our local filmmakers here and attract others from all over the world and convince them to make their films on the Island," said Debra Markowitz, director of cinema-TV promotion for the Nassau County Department of Commerce and Industry. "It brings jobs and money here."
"Jingle Hell," a first-time feature produced and co-written by Carter Ann McGowan of Garden City and directed by Will Tully of Hampton Bays, spent about $150,000 on the Island, shooting in Quogue, Smithtown, St. James, Mattituck and Hampton Bays. The comedy, about a family reunion, had its premiere at the Long Island Film Festival and will be screened in Malverne and Stony Brook.
The Hamptons event was created in part to provide off-season business in the resort area.
"As your festival grows, and along with it your level of notoriety, you attract more established filmmakers and more people from out of town who stay at local hotels and eat at local restaurants," said Alan Inkles, director of the Stony Brook event, which began five years ago as a way of keeping the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University productive in the summer. Mr. Inkles emphasizes independent films, with the goal of eventually joining the ranks of major festivals like the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, and the Toronto International Festival.
Mr. Inkles believes he is approaching that level. Three established distributors have given him films that will make their New York premieres in Stony Brook before starting commercial runs. They are "Thomas and the Magic Railroad," a live action-animated family film with Alec Baldwin and Peter Fonda; "Steal This Movie," based on the life of Abbie Hoffman, with Vincent D'Onofio and Janeane Garofolo, and "Mr. Rice's Secret," a Canadian coming-of-age drama with David Bowie.
The Cinema Arts Center's fourth annual Huntington International Film Festival is intended to address a problem for foreign films.
"With this international globalization of filmmaking -- a few big companies controlling the production and distribution in the whole industry -- we're seeing the death of national cinema all over the world," said Charlotte Skye, co-founder and co-director of the center.
"Those of us who grew up on Fellini and Bergman couldn't do that anymore," added Vic Skolnick, her co-founder and co-director. "Only the foreign films that look like potential big box office hits are distributed now and most of them are dubbed."
The Long Island International Film Expo 2000 will be held Friday through July 20 at the Malverne Cinema 4 on Hempstead Avenue. For a schedule: (516) 561-3168.
The 2000 Stony Brook Festival is from July 19 to 29 at the Staller Center on the Stony brook campus of the State University. (631) 632-2787.
The Huntington International Film Festival is from July 28 through 30 at the Cinema Arts Center on Park Avenue. (631) 423-3456. 
http://www.nytimes.com
